headline: Big Advance? No, Thanks, He'll Publish It Himself
abstract: Article on Benjamin R Kaplan, 23, whose self-published book, How to Go to College Almost for Free: The Secrets of Winning Scholarship Money, has sold 25,000 copies since February and who is starting 25-city book tour; increase in number of self-published books discussed; photo (M)

headline: American PC Sales Slow Sharply as Prices Rise

headline: Deutsche Telekom Deal: Did Barriers Fall in Europe, Just to Rise in the U.S.?
abstract: Congressional moves to block acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless Corp by Deutsche Telekom, which is owned by German government, could invite retaliation against American communications companies active in Grmany and elsewhere in Europe, and might also run afoul of US commitments to World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Killings Drive Indonesians Into Risky Boats and Dangerous Seas
abstract: Fighting in Maluku islands, Indonesia, between Muslims and Christians spurs many islanders to flee, driving them into risky boats and dangerous seas; nearly 500 people are feared dead following sinking of their battered ferry; passengers were desperately fleeing Moslem gangs that were killing people, apparently in revenge for what they describe as wave of killings by Christians in December; photo; map (L)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: INTERNETPUBLIC MEETINGS ABOUT INTERNET The Internet Policy Institute, a Washington-based independent research organization, plans to hold eight "town hall" meetings to gather grass-roots information on Internet policies and will present its findings to the next president after the November elections. The meetings are being held jointly with eight universities across the country to get "outside the Beltway" views on the Internet, said James L. Barksdale, former president and chief executive of Netscape Communications and chairman of the institute, which is nonpartisan.  Leslie Wayne (NYT)

headline: Co-Founders of Africana.com Sell Venture to Time Warner
abstract: Henry Louis Gates Jr and Kwame Anthony Appiah, Harvard University professors, sell Africana.com, Web site dedicated to black history and culture, to Time Warner Inc; Gates says deal will help keep Web site alive; photo (M)

headline: Retailers Post Weak August, Hoping It's Not Holiday Omen
abstract: Goldman Sachs retail composite index shows retail sales for August in stores open at least a year rose just 3 percent, lower than analysts expected and weakest August results in three years; results for specific major retailers noted; graph; chart (M)

headline: WorldCom and Sprint End Their $115 Billion Merger
abstract: Worldcom Inc and Sprint Corp officially abandon their $115 million merger, bowing to pressure from regulators in US and Europe that creation of such large telecommunications company would stifle competition (M)

headline: At Mideast Summit, The Mood Improves
abstract: At Camp David, the Israeli peace delegation's mood grew more hopeful, and officials outside the negotiations said Prime Minister Ehud Barak believed the chances for success have improved.    President Clinton also sounded upbeat, and rearranged his trip to Japan to return earlier tomorrow and resume his mediation.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper rises on signs of strengthening demand; prices of other commodities listed; graph (S)

headline: Tokyo Politician's Earthquake Drill Is a Military Moment
abstract: Shintaro Ishihara, right-wing governor of Tokyo prefecture, transforms annual earthquake readiness drill into one of largest military exercises most Japanese have seen since end of World War II; sight of more than 7,000 uniformed soldiers in streets of central Tokyo revives discussions of a militarist past that is fast fading from living memory; photo (M)

headline: Oversight Failure Blamed In Financier's Fraud Case
abstract: Tennessee investigators say Martin R Frankel, who prosecutors contend masterminded elaborate insurance fraud from his estate in Greenwich, Conn, might have been shut down as early as decade ago if Tennessee regulators had done their jobs properly; state's comptroller of treasury found that there was 'gross breakdown' in regulation of Franklin American Life Insurance, company that was Frankel's main insurance entity (M)

headline: Whose Intellectual Property Is It, Anyway? The Open Source War
abstract: Essay by Peter Wayner on desire for control of intellectual property inspired in part by software industry; proposal from World Intellectual Property Orgn, arm of United Nations, would allow big corporations to protect facts in their databases; although this may protect big databases, it would also constrain little ones; facts would go from being things owned by everyone to things that can be herded and owned by single person or company; drawing (M)

headline: Record Auto Profits Bolster Hyundai, and Embolden Creditors
abstract: Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, reported record profits in automotive subsidiary Hyundai Motors for first six months of year; earnings surged to 310.4 billion won, or $278 million, from 110.2 billion won in year-earlier period (M)

headline: Tracking the Tour de France on the Web

headline: A Bevy of Experts With Soapboxes, and Sites to Fill
abstract: International Business Machines Corp is embarked on five-year, $100 million program to build the world's most powerful supercomputer, named Blue Gene, whose mission will be to simulate the folding of proteins, an enourmous task that could yield new understanding of Alzheimer's or mad cow disease and aid in drug design; machine will have a 'processor in memory,' or PIM, design, meaning that memory will be on the same chip as the processor; IBM says computer will be 'self-healing,' capable or running when processors fail; drawing (M)

headline: ARAFAT WILL MEET WITH BARAK IN U.S. FOR PEACE EFFORT
abstract: Pres Clinton says Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat will meet at Camp David on July 11 for summit aimed at helping them frame peace agreement they hope to reach by September; says both leaders will face 'most profound questions,' and that success is not guaranteed; Barak says meeting will be 'important moment' in history of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations; says he will seek separation from Palestinians and establishment of good-neighborliness with them; senior Palestinian negotiator Abu Ala accuses Clinton of bending to Israeli pressure; says he doubts summit will achieve any of its aims; Palestinians make clear that divisions between both sides are so great that more discussions are needed at lower level before convening leaders; photo (M)

headline: S.& L. Profits Fell 5 Percent in 2nd Quarter
abstract: Office of Trift Supervision says savings and loan associations earned $2 billion for second quarter, down 5 percent from $2.1 billion a year earlier; says number of problem institutions was unchanged at 14 (S)

headline: INVESTMENT IN CHINA
abstract: Foreign investment in China falls nearly 8 percent, to $22.79 billion, in first eight months of year compared with same period a year earlier (S)

headline: AVIS PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO $100 MILLION OF STOCK
abstract: Avis Group Holdings Inc plans to buy back as much as $100 million in common stock in effort to improve share price (S)

headline: TRADE FIGHT OVER RUM TRADEMARK
abstract: Dispute between European Union and US regarding use of Havana Club trademark for rum will probably be mediated in World Trade Organization (S)

headline: Indonesian Is Under Fire For Comments About Timor
abstract: Indonesia's new defense minister, Mohammad Mahfud, has raised widespread concerns in Indonesia and abroad with his stand that people of East Timor want to return to Indonesian rule; he cites United Nations failure to establish government there, interview; holds foreign nations who were behind independence movement create violent situations to bar return to Indonesia; foreign officials say remarks reflect his dearth of diplomatic experience and Indonesia's deep sense of resentment over secession (M)

abstract: Toyota Motor Corp says General Motors was premature in announcing that it will use GM's OnStar communications system in its vehicles (S)

abstract: Stocks and bonds rally in Brazil on news that Moody's Investors Service is contemplating upgrade of country's debt rating; Moody's says economic recovery has allowed Brazil to shrink its budget deficit, reducing chances of debt default (S)

headline: Australians Pushing Away From the Table
abstract: Article on how Australian executives are giving up the once traditional long lunch, succumbing to capitalist credo that productivity and profit-making constitute higher calling than leisurely midday meal; photo (M)

abstract: Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc acquires Cambridge Discovery Chemistry of Britain for about $53 million (S)

headline: Swiss Voters Reject Limit On Number of Foreigners

abstract: IBM, major sponsor, rents cruise liner, docked next to Sydney's landmark Opera House, and will fly about 2,000 employees and clients to Australia for Olympic games (S)

abstract: Article describes history of antibiotic drug Trovan, developed, manufactured and merketed by Pfizer; only after more than a million prescriptions for it had been written did it become clear that it causes liver damage in some patients (M)

headline: ADATOM ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS AND CHANGES
abstract: Adatom.com, electronic commerce business, will cut its 55-person work force by 45 percent and reduce spending as part of a restructuring effort aimed at focusing on partnerships in China (S)

headline: A Seven-Year Lesson in Investing: Expect the Unexpected, and More

headline: B.A.T. PROFITS RISE
abstract: British American Tobacco PLC reports first-half pretax profits rose 6 percent, to $1.04 billion, as its global sales increased 23 percent, to 396 billion cigarettes (S)

headline: Israeli Hopes Rise at Talks as Clinton and Barak See Better Chance of Success
abstract: Pres Clinton and Prime Min Ehud Barak express optimism that Israeli-Palestinian peace talks at Camp David will be successful, but a senior Palestinian official, Abu Mazen, reports no lifted spirits among Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: All 118 on Sub Probably Dead, Russians Assert
abstract: Vice Adm Mikhail Motsak of Russian Navy says all 118 members of crew of wrecked submarine Kursk are now probably dead; says that in frantic initial hours, survivors trapped in sunken vessel had signaled their comrades on surface to send down air because their sealed compartments were filling with water; say some men may have tried what would have been suicidal exit through rear hatch, causing one of last dry compartments to flood; says most of sailors died in first minutes after still-unexplained explosion sent Kursk crashing to seabed; Norwegian divers with video equipment begin descent to assess damage to Kursk; Motsak, in statement broadcast on state television, says navy is investigating three possible causes of blast: collision with another vessel or World War II mine, or some unknown internal accident that set off explosion; photos; map (M)

headline: Bloomberg, Internet Wire Hit by Emulex Suit
abstract: Bloomberg, Internet Wire Hit by Emulex Suit

headline: BREWER REJECTS TAKEOVER
abstract: British brewer Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries rejects takeover offer by Botts & Co (S)

headline: TENNECO JOINS EFFORT TO CREATE AN AUTO-PARTS WEB SITE
abstract: Tenneco Automotive joins other makers of auto parts, Dana Corp, Delphi Automotive Systems, TRW Inc, Timken Co, Valeo SA and Robert Bosch GmbH, to form Internet site that would cut costs in replacement-parts business (S)

headline: Stalinesque Lines, But a Silky Sound; Man, That's One Ugly Microphone
abstract: Oktava, small, Soviet-era factory, in Tula, Russia, manufactures bad-looking, good-sounding microphones; many musical professionals deeply appreciate these ugly devices; largest market for these microphones is young musicians starting home recording studios; photo (M)

abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair is expected to meet with Nissan Motor Co of Japan executives to discuss company's future investment in Britain; Nissan is worried that pound's strength makes British exports too expensive and could jeopardize plans to build new Micra subcompact (S)

headline: Patents; A Web site for cargo rates lays claim to a business method, entering a gray area of the law.
abstract: Neil Barni and Daniel Miller patent a method of pooling the prices that various freight carriers charge for land, sea and air cargo shipments, posting them on a central Web site and allowing customers to browse and comparison-shop for their shipping needs; patent also allows shippers and customers to negotiate rates and routes and to hold interactive auctions to set shipping rates (M)

headline: Plotting the Next Chapter of Storytelling on the Web
abstract: SO far, much of the entertainment action on the Web has come from the dozens and dozens of dot-com start-ups that have struggled to attract audiences by transmitting short pieces of video and animation -- minifilms, cartoons, soap opera installments, sitcoms -- that usually last no longer than a few minutes. It has been a hard slog. Some big names in Hollywood were recruited to create these new entertainments for various sites, and while most of the productions have been quite raw and awkward to view on a computer, a few have been extraordinarily clever.    Now, however, the thinking seems to be shifting. There is a growing suspicion that streaming vignettes, no matter how clever, are unlikely to ever draw a mass audience away from its television sets. If all the Web is doing is creating jerky, inferior versions of the stories that make up movies and TV shows, why should people pay attention?

headline: Swiss Physicists Face Decision In Race for Atomic Particle
abstract: Swiss physicists at CERN nuclear laboratory in Geneva are in quandary over whether to proceed with building a $4 billion particle accelerator or to continue experiments with current equipment in search for Higgs boson, particle that may be source of all mass in universe; say upgraded machine at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory near Chicago may be powerful enough to make discovery first, after beginning operations in spring 2001 (M)

abstract: Intel plans to introduce simple digital camera that will sell for $149.95; Intel Pocket PC Camera allows consumers to take Internet-ready photos and record short video clips at or away from personal computer; photo (S)

headline: Protests Distract Global Finance Meeting
abstract: Masked protesters hurl cobblestones and attack police with homemade gasoline bombs in unsuccessful bid to shut down joint World Bank-International Monetary Fund meeting, Prague; riot police escort government ministers into special subway cars to whisk them from meetings at end of session, restoring normal access by evening; police and many protesters say squadrons of European anarchists and communists provoked violence; many of financial leaders pledge to rededicate selves to fighting poverty; World Bank president James D Wolfensohn cites need to make globalization instrument of opportunity and inclusion, not fear; police prepared for siege, with 11,000 officers outnumbering demonstrators; photos (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Internet companies learn how to personalize service.

headline: As Statehood Deadline Passes, Gazans Riot Over Lesser Issues

headline: Rather Be in Philadelphia? G.O.P. Convention's Online
abstract: Internet is a new presence at this year's Republican National Convention, and it is blurring barriers between those who are at convention and those who are not; Webmasters say Internet has ability to encourage grass-roots political involvemnt and can challenge ability of parties and pundits to set political agenda; Web surfers are able to pull up candidates' speeches, videos of proceedings and party position papers, share political opinions, participate in opinion polls, and scan and zoom in on convention floor via 360-degree cameras; photo (M)

headline: Barak Asked Clinton To Raise Embassy Issue
abstract: Clinton administration officials say Pres Clinton, in raising prospect of moving American Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, responded to unusual request made by Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak as he left failed Camp David peace talks; national security adviser Samuel R Berger says Clinton decided to use interview on Israeli television to help Barak shore up his political position in Israel; Barak reportedly also asked number of congressmen to reintroduce resolution on moving embassy (M)

abstract: Chase Manhattan chairman William B Harrison says fewer than 3,000 jobs worldwide will be lost because of its $33 billion purchase of J P Morgan & Co; Harrison and Morgan chief executive Douglas Warner 3d say overlap between two bank is minimal (S)

abstract: Article on lack of air traffic to and from mid-sized American cities, which is hampering local industrial growth; photo (M)

headline: Most Recent Killing May Push Germans to Act on Hate Crime
abstract: Anti-immigrant incidents, ranging from verbal abuse to killings, have become part of fabric of life of eastern Germany, notably in Dessau region, which was once center of flowering of German culture; between slaying of Angolan Amadeu Antonio in 1990 and recent murder of Mozambican Alberto Adriano in June, racist murder rate has been running at two per year by most cautious government estimates, but human rights groups put figure at more than 10; fundamental causes seem rooted in western takeover of East Germany, dismantling of its society and industry and odd effect on ravaged landscape of immigrant asylum ploicy whose logic has become impenetrable; map; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Some online sellers are hiring prominent auditors to verify their privacy policies and increase trust.
abstract: Some online sellers, responding to consumer doubts that sellers will keep their data private, are hiring leading auditors to verify privacy policies; moves are putting pressure on other e-commerce companies to follow suit, no matter how costly such audits might be; Expedia.com hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to visit its offices and probe how it handles customer data; photo (M)

headline: Goldman Said to Be in Talks To Acquire Spear, Leeds
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group is reportedly in serious talks to acquire Spear, Leeds & Kellogg (M)

headline: WINE SALES SITES TO MERGE
abstract: Internet wine retailers Wine.com and WineShopper.com to merge; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Sun to Introduce Two Computers Today
abstract: Sun Microsystems plans to introduce two computers that are first of new generation of systems intended to raise performance of high end of Sun's product line; computers--desktop work station and workgroup servicer--are priced to start at $10,000 (S)

headline: Business Links On Web Raise Antitrust Issues
abstract: Companies in practically every industry rush to join business-to-business exchanges on Internet, raising new concerns about antitrust questions among regulators; exchanges, known as B2B Web sites, create a place for companies in same industry to buy and sell goods, potentially saving millions of dollars in back-office costs by setting up national marketplace online; but sites, which can compile huge amounts of sensitive data and are often jointly owned by corporate rivals, also create new opportunities for collusion and price-fixing; regulators and executives agree that stakes are enormous, with B2B sites already accounting for about $150 billion in annual sales, significantly more than consumer retail sites (M)

headline: PANTRY AGREES TO PURCHASE 26 FAST LANE STORES
abstract: Pantry Inc agrees to expand its convenience store outlets by purchasing 26 Fast Lane stores from R R Morrison & Son Inc (S)

headline: Tyranny of Design
abstract: Albert Z K Sanders letter on Aug 3 article on Web page designe
