abstract: Owens Corning will consolidate its advertising account by naming Doner to handle duties ranging from advertising to media services to interactive assignments; billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Slide on Worries About Computer Shipments  Stocks dropped, pushing the Nasdaq composite index below the 4,000 level as a report that growth in personal computer shipments slowed in the second quarter led to a slide in shares of computer makers.    The Nasdaq composite index fell 112.88 points, or 2.8 percent, to 3,981.57. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 48.44 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,685.12. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index sagged 15.90 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,464.29. [Page C12.]

headline: BRAZILIAN UNEMPLOYMENT DROPS
abstract: Brazil's unemployment rates falls in June to 7.4 percent from 7.8 percent in May (S)

headline: Ex-I.R.S. Lawyer Faces Tax-Evasion Charge in Stock Case
abstract: Max C Tanner, former Internal Revenue Service lawyer, and four other men are indicted on charges of tax evasion and other crimes stemming from what prosecutors describe as stock swindle in which profits of Maid Aide Inc were funneled through offshore accounts; indictment contends that in September 1996 Tanner began scheme to defraud investors by manipulating price of shares; prosecutors say Tanner paid kickback of 5 percent of his profit to securities broker Kevin J Ruggiero; also indicted on conpiracy charges are stock promoters Dennis D Evans, Kenneth W Kurtz and Mark A Taylor (M)

headline: WEBVAN FOUNDER STEPS ASIDE
abstract: Webvan Group names its chief executive, George Shaheen, as chairman to replace its founder, Louis Borders, who will remain a director (S)

headline: GRIDLOCK IN THE SKIES: A special report.; Crisis for Air Traffic System: More Passengers, More Delays
abstract: Second consecutive summer of chronic flight delays and cancellations ends with no relief in sight despite expenditures of billions of dollars, and repeated warnings over past decade that air traffic system is approaching gridlock; most experts predict delays, which have risen nearly 50 percent in last five years, will become worse, not better; Federal Aviation Administration, which runs air traffic system, predicts that by 2010 number of airline passengers will rise by 59 percent, to one billion; 70 percent of increase is expected to occur at country's 28 largest airports; current crisis is result of airline deregulation, one of government's most successful economic initiatives, and one of its longest and most expensive blunders, namely, ill-fated attempts to develop new air traffic control system; airlines blame FAA, attributing delays and cancellations to antiquated air traffic control system that cost more than $5 billion in 1999 alone; FAA blames airlines for knowingly scheduling more takeoffs and landings at major airports than system can handle; both criticize Congress for not appropriating enough money to fix system, and localities for preventing building of new runways at congested airports; photo; diagrams; charts (L)

headline: Privacy Plan Likely to Kick Off Debate
abstract: The goal of the plan announced by President Clinton's chief of staff, John Podesta, sounded admirable: to overhaul the nation's privacy laws, harmonizing a patchwork of inconsistent rules and extending to e-mail and mobile phone messages the same strict safeguards against government snooping that now apply to telephone calls.

headline: Economic Scene; Don't underestimate the government's role in building the economy.
abstract: Jeff Madrick's 'Economic Scene' column says oversimplified fear of 'big government' has been damaging and does not accurately reflect American history; contends government has done many things well, and beyond historical evidence, there is also strong statistical support for idea that government investment has produced substantial returns; cites provocative model of public investment developed by Ishaq Nadiri, New York University economist, and his colleagues; graph (M)

headline: A Forum for Media Feedback and Back Talk
abstract: Jim Romenesko's MediaNews.org is a Web site where journalists can argue, announce their new jobs, toast their friends and denounce their enemies; Eugene Kennedy gets a lot of supportive comment for an article of his on the site that contends that Mike Barnicle, who lost his job as columnist at Boston Globe in 1998, was victim of shifting standards and deeply mixed messages from the Globe's editor, Matthew V Storin; photos (M)

headline: Leery of the Web, Olympic Officials Set Limits on News
abstract: Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, becomes benchmark in struggle between those who hold intellectual property rights in sporting events and those seeking to cover sports, especially for ever-expanding universe of news outlets on Internet; Olympic committee is controlling where and how images and accounts of games reach public out of concern that power of Internet could eventually undermine economic foundation of modern Olympic movement; actions echo developments in other areas of sports, as both amateur and professional teams and leagues aggressively invoke property rights to control how and by whom events are covered (M)

headline: ALBANIA JOINS TRADE GROUP
abstract: Albania becomes 138th member of World Trade Organization, eight years after applying to join; photo (S)

headline: CNN Is Seeking A New Strategy; U.S. Operations Chief Quits As Management Is Revamped
abstract: Departure of Richard N Kaplan as president of CNN's US operations and revamping of its entire executive structure reflect network's failure to maintain ratings in face of increasing competition in cable news and the absence of the kinds of stories that have made CNN the network to turn to in times of crisis; CNN is expected to shift from the sophisticated, expensive and highly produced programming that Kaplan had hoped would lift ratings and toward a rougher, newsier feel and stories with a broader audience appeal; photos; graphs of ratings of CNN, CNBC, MSNBC and Fox News (M)

headline: Move by Gerber Scientific
abstract: Gerber Scientific Inc is considering options for its Coburn optical business, including possible sale (S)

headline: Arguing Against Net Trespass
abstract: Concerned that a recent federal court ruling dangerously extends the ancient law of trespass to cyberspace, 28 leading Internet legal scholars are arguing in an appellate court that the decision "threatens the very foundations of the Internet."

headline: After a Hedge Fund's Fall, Is Wall Street the Wiser?
abstract: Article assesses whether Wall Street has learned lessons from its extraordinary investment of $3.65 billion in Long-Term Capital Management, obscure hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn, to save it from imminent collapse; photo (M)

headline: THE BOSS; It Takes a Solid Foundation
abstract: The Boss column profiles Ida L Castro, chairwoman of Equal Employment Opportunity Commission; Castro comments; photo (M)

headline: AT&T LATIN UNIT POSTPONES SHARE SALE
abstract: AT&T Latin America Corp, citing low stock prices, postpones planned issuance of 35 million common shares just weeks after company merged with FirstCom Corp, broadband communications group that operates in Chile, Peru and Colombia; company will instead rely on $200 million finance package from parent company, AT&T Corp, and long-term financing from vendors like Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks to finance its expansion (S)

headline: NEW FUNDS FOR MILLENNIUM DOME
abstract: Operators of Britain's Millennium Dome, threatened once again with bankruptcy, win fresh injection of $74 million from National Lottery; dome has so far cost about $957 million in public financing but has failed to attract enough visitors to cover costs; its was sold in July for $157 million to consortium led by Nomura International of Japan, which takes over at end of year with plans to change attraction into theme park (S)

headline: Excite At Home Will Merge Global Assets
abstract: Excite At Home will merge its international assets with European rival, Chello Broadband NV, to create largest high-speed Internet service provider outside US; Excite will invest 400 million euros ($374 million) in new company, called Excite Chello; AT&T now controls 56 percent of Excite (S)

headline: Many big brand names steer clear of the 'Dr. Laura' show.
abstract: Premiere episode of Dr Laura Schlessinger syndicated television series suffers from summer's worth of protests by gay and lesbian activists; well-known advertisers mostly shun the show; photo (M)

headline: Lawmakers Ask for Delay In Review of Nasdaq Rule
abstract: Congressmen ask Securities and Exchange Commission to extend period for comment on plan intended to give investors more information about Nasdaq stocks and trades at best available prices (M)

headline: FUNGUS CONSIDERED AS A TOOL TO KILL COCA IN COLOMBIA
abstract: Colombia, under pressure from US, reluctantly agrees to take first step toward developing powerful biological herbicide against its coca and heroin-poppy fields; US has been quietly debating for years ways of conducting field tests of such a herbicide, developed from fungus that occurs naturally in many types of cocoa and other plants; Colombian officials say they are completing proposal to UN that will include testing for presence of fungus, Fusarium oxysporum, in coca, raw material of cocaine; government is suporting project as Pres Clinton is about to sign bill providing $1.3 billion in aid to Colombia to fight drug traffickers and insurgents who protect their trade (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; For a Prize That's Olympian, China Jumps the Gun
abstract: Beijing, China, is preparing for Summer Olympics of 2008, to which capital desperately wants to play host, even though International Olympic Committee will not select venue for another year; Chinese suffered huge loss of face in 1993 after Sydney, Australia, was selected by slimmest of margins for 2000 Summer Games; photo (M)

headline: Colombia Pledges to Investigate Killing of 6 Children by Troops
abstract: Colombian government promises full-scale investigation of army attack on elementary school hiking trip that left six children dead; top commanders of army initially blamed guerrillas for deaths, but various witnesses have come forward to say there were no rebels near shootings; episode comes at particularly embarrassing moment for Pres Andres Pastrana, who is preparing for Pres Clinton's six-hour visit on Aug 30 and for Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright to certify whether Colombia has met human rights conditions and is eligible to receive military component of new $1.3 billion aid program (M)

headline: Investing; Peer-Group Pressure Hurts a Ford Offspring
abstract: Shares of Associates First Capital Corp have fallen nearly 50 percent since company was spun off from Ford Motor Co two years ago, even though it has posted 19 percent or better earnings growth for each of last five years; stock has been hurt by tumult in financial-services sector and concern that Federal Reserve may tighten monetary policy too much and tip economy into recession; photo, graph (M)

headline: Major Central Banks Step In to Shore Up the Ailing Euro
abstract: PRAGUE, Sept. 22 — Shaken by the relentless decline of Europe's single currency, the euro, the European, American and Japanese central banks launched a surprise rescue attempt today to fight what they called a threat to the world economy by purchasing billions of euros on the global foreign exchange market.

headline: American Topics
abstract: In 1985, Thomas Turnipseed began cultivating loblolly pines on a corner of his 500-acre (200-hectare) soybean farm outside Montgomery, Alabama. Now, logging is his sole cash crop. Nor is he alone. Small rural loggers like Mr. Turnipseed and big commercial loggers like Georgia Pacific have been thriving in Alabama.

headline: British Wireless Venture Is in Talks to Sell a Stake
abstract: TIW UMTS, British wireless telephone venture backed by Hutchison Whampoa and Telesystem International Wireless, looks to sell about one third of itself to NTT DoCoMo and Royal KPN; TIW UMTS hopes to receive as much as $2 billion from sale (M)

headline: DRIP's Aren't Sexy, and That's Their Charm
abstract: Article assesses value of dividend reinvestment plans as means to build stakes in market heavyweights that may be about to rebound; chart (M)

headline: Clinton Hurries To Returnto Camp David
abstract: Pres Clinton leaves economic summit meeting in Okinawa early to rejoin Mideast peace talks at Camp David between Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; photo of signed fax sent by leaders in meeting in Okinawa to Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright, encouraging her efforts at Camp David talks (M)

headline: PACIFIC GULF PROPERTIES TO SELL 1,139 OF ITS UNITS
abstract: Pacific Gulf Properties Inc sells 1,139 units at seven of its traditional multifamily properties to three unrelated buyers for $61.2 million in cash and repayment of approximately $11.3 million of debt; deal also involves assumption of about $20.4 million of debt (S)

headline: A Speedy Internet Path Is Slow as an Investment
abstract: Investor enthusiam cools for publicly traded companies that provide digital subscriber line services to residential and small-business users (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ELECTRONIC ARTS CORP., Redwood City, Calif., which makes software for interactive games, said it planned to split its stock two shares for one. The split will double the number of shares to 142 million while halving the value of each share. The new shares will be issued on Sept. 8 to shareholders of record as of Aug. 25. The shares traded at $91.875, apiece, up $2.3175.    CITIGROUP INC., New York, the financial services giant, said it agreed to purchase privately held AST StockPlan Inc., a stock benefit plan services provider that specializes in technology companies. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The deal is expected to close by the end of the month.

headline: HEARTLAND ADVISORS URGES DONNELLY TO CONSIDER SALE
abstract: Heartland Advisors, which has 27 percent stake in Donnelly Corp, urges company to consider sale of company or other action to increase its stock price (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of August 18 Business Day article on new technologies in orthodontics

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MERCATOR SOFTWARE INC., Wilton, Conn., the maker of software that links incompatible computers, said it had agreed to market products and build software with Tibco Software Inc., Palo Alto, Calif. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: A Rights Advocate Who's Also Britain's First Lady
abstract: Cherie Booth, wife of British Prime Min Tony Blair, joins panel of lawyers from Britain and United States in discussing revolution taking place in English courts as Britain prepares to incorporate European convention on human rights into British law; Booth is first prime minister's spouse to discuss anything of substance publicly; Booth is taking leading role in what, for Britain, is controversial cause: human rights law in increasingly Europeanized England; forum, in Manhattan, is sponsored by New York University; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: DEALS

headline: VNU, A PUBLISHER, AGREES TO BUY A TRADE SHOW OPERATOR
abstract: VNU NV acquires Miller Freeman USA, second-largest trade show operator in US, for $650 million in cash and stock; seller is United News and Media (S)

headline: FRENCH UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLS
abstract: France's jobless rate falls to 9.6 percent in August from 9.7 percent in July; number of job seekers falls 4,000, to 2.527 million; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises after OPEC says drop in an index price means producers no longer need to raise output; in New York, crude oil for August delivery rises $1.11, or 3.6 percent, to $31.94 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.50   9.50   7.75       Discount rate   6.00   6.00   4.50       Federal funds   6.56   6.65   5.03       3-month T-bills   6.07   6.10   4.76       6-month T-bills   6.03   6.07   4.92       10-yr. T-infl.   3.97   3.99   4.04       10-yr. T-note   5.68   5.72   5.88       30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.66   6.01       Telephone bd.   7.98   7.98   7.84       Municipal bds.   5.73   5.72   5.79        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: A Costly Lesson About Best-Laid Plans
abstract: Los Angeles Community Development Bank, a Clinton Administration pet project that was supposed to create inner-city jobs by lending to local companies not served by commercial banks, has turned into a disaster for which no one wants to take responsibility (M)

headline: An Online Magician Who Has a Sense of Drama
abstract: Richard Robinson runs several Web sites devoted to magic, and on them he stresses the importance of showmanship and drama; photos (M)

headline: On the Avenue, Off the Avenue: Saks Is Getting an Annulment
abstract: Saks Inc, previously called Proffitt's, announces that less than two years after it acquired Saks Fifth Avenue and renamed itself, its board approves plan to split again into two separate public companies; spun-off entity will be called Saks Fifth Avenue Enterprises Inc and will include luxury-oriented stores of Saks Fifth Avenue; the Saks Direct, which includes catalog and Internet operations; and Saks Off Fifth, its upscale outlet business; Saks Inc will retain rest of department store business--including such regional stores as Proffitt's, McRae's and Parisan--and will eventually be renamed; shareholders are expected to receive one share of Saks Fifth Avenue Enterprises common stock for every three shares of Saks Inc stock that they own; Philip Miller will continue as chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue; Christina Johnson will remain president and chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue stores division; department store group will search for new chief executive; Saks Inc chairman R Brad Martin comments; photo (M)

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 6 Others On Busy Street in Sri Lanka
abstract: Tamil rebel suicide bomber kills self and six others, Colombo, Sri Lanka, in apparent effort to disrupt election campaigning; photo (M)

headline: ICG CHIEF STEPS ASIDE
abstract: ICG Communications Inc chairman and chief executive, Carl Vogel, and board members Gary Howard and Thomas Hicks resign one day after warning of lower sales (S)

headline: German Suitor Said to Show A New Interest In Qwest Deal
abstract: Deutsche Telekom reportedly makes informal overtures about reigniting merger talks with Qwest Communications International; moves comes as Deutsche Telekom is simultaneously conducting intensive negotiations with VoiceStream Wireless Corp; deal with both would enable Deutsche to achieve goal of becoming significant player in American telephone market, controlling both nationwide wireless and fixed-line networks; photo (M)

headline: PROFIT RISES AT BRITISH BANK
abstract: HSBC Holdings PLC reports pretax profit rose 28 percent, Jan-June, to $5.2 billion (S)

headline: I'll Take the Red One: Do Computers Now Sell Like Cars?
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on apparent slowdown in computer industry and its impact on US economy; says slower growth for computers does not spell doom for economy, or companies involved, but it does call into question high multiples that computer stocks have come to enjoy; graph (M)

headline: Nasdaq Open Short Sales Up
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose 4.5 percent in most recent month; charts (S)

headline: Tale of Bad Timing at AMF: Silk Stockings and Bowling Shows
abstract: AMF Bowling has racked up losses and its stock price has sunk since Goldman, Sachs led buyout in 1996; directors reportedly weigh range of revamping options, including prepackaged bankruptcy; company has been hurt by drop in popularity of league bowling, lifeblood of bowling business; graph (M)

headline: Is It Bold and New, Or Just Tried and True?; Chrysler Plays It Safe in Minivan Redesign
abstract: Chrysler has cultivated reputation for daring, innovative designs, but was sufficiently alarmed by public's hostile reaction to Ford's radical restyling of Taurus sedan and wagon to rethink its own redesign of its minivan line; ultimately, Chrysler chose to play it safe by making only minor changes in new minivans that go on sale in August; marketing experts note many companies are reluctant these days to tamper with proven success; photos graphs (L)

headline: Hey, Walkman: Time to Face the Music on a Chip
abstract: Handheld MP3 players, less than two years after their introduction, are being promoted as challenge to cassette and CD players as standard for listening to music on the go; so far, appeal of MP3 players is based on small size, virtually skipless playback and ability of user to create own roster of songs; designers are working to improve quality of sound and storage capacity, but they have a long way to go; for now, players still depend almost exclusively on personal computers as way to download digital music, which makes audience smaller than that for other formats; legal issues abound in the downloading of music, but industry is working to develop better ways to offer music online that also protects copyright; several new MP3 models discussed; photos (M)

headline: Q & A / Peter Gottfried, secretary for integration : Hungary Vows to Meet EU Criteria by 2003
abstract: Hungary is one of six countries expected to be in the "first wave" of European Union expansion. For many, its strong economy makes it the front-runner: Gross domestic product is expected to grow 5.5 percent or 6 percent this year, inflationary and budgetary pressures are under control, and privatization and restructuring are almost complete.

headline: Wife Visits American Held by Moscow
abstract: Cheri Pope and Repr John E Peterson visit Pope's husband, Edmond, who has been in jail in Russia for five months on espionage charges; asks Russia to allow Western doctors to examine Pope, who has bone cancer; Pres Clinton and other US officials continue to pressure Russia to free Pope, who was arrested for supposedly trying to buy classified plans for Russian torpedo system (M)

headline: Many Holes Weaken Safety Net For Victims of Failed Brokerages
abstract: Securities Investor Protection Corp provides safety net for investors that is full of holes; corporation, industry-financed but not government-backed, is chartered to protect each investor with securities held at member brokerage firm for up to $500,000, with claims for cash limited to $100,000 per customer; convincing it to pay can be extremely difficult, since it requires investors to run gantlet of legal technicalities that would challenge even those knowledgable about securities law; securities lawyers say situation arises because trustees overseeing cases are chosen by, and paid by, corporation, compared to independent trustees who are appointed by courts to handle corporate bankruptcy cases, and are working for people owed money; trustees working for Investor Protection Corp, many from coterie of lawyers who have made lucrative speciality of such cases, have received far more representing corporation than corporation has paid to investors; critics say trustees wanting repeat business from corporation have incentive to minimize payouts to investors; system's shortcomings are evidence in case of Kevin Heebner, who battled corporation to recover part of $100,000 investment; photos; charts (L)

headline: Multimedia Search Engine Retrieves Private Files
abstract: Multimedia Search Engine Retrieves Private Files

headline: Belfast Journal; Murals of 'Troubles' Draw Passions, and Tourists
abstract: Tourism is surging in Belfast, Northern Ireland, since peace agreement was reached; people are visiting city's most forbidding neighborhoods to see provocative murals by loyalists and Republicans; map; photos (M)

headline: Global Meeting Planned for Better Public Toilets
abstract: SINGAPORE, Sept. 17 — Relief may finally be on the way for one of life's most common minor horrors: the public restroom.

headline: China's Censor Is Customer No. 1
abstract: In China's march from centrally planned economy to market economy, officials have promoted advertising as accelerator of economic development and welcomed it as way to supplant government subsidies for many television stations and periodicals; on the other hand, government has also criticized advertising as conduit for both fraud and unwelcome foreign ideas; Louis Wong, president of Megacom Advertising in Beijing, accepts Chinese advertising rules, but finds them annoying; photos (M)

headline: Heinz Shares Fall On Profit Warning
abstract: H J Heinz Co says second-quarter profit will be lower than analysts expect; company's shares fall nearly 5 percent; for first quarter, ended Aug 2, profit rose to $237.7 million from $223.8 million in year-earlier quarter; sales fell 1.3 percent, to $2.15 billion (S)

headline: Defending Napster To the Editor:
abstract: Thomas Wolfe letter on Aug 31 article holds both sides in debate over Napster neglect benefits of innovation and progress likely to sprout if Napster were left alone; drawing

headline: COSINE I.P.O. TAKES OFF
abstract: Shares of CoSine Communications almost triple after company raises $230 million in its initial public offering (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: AVADO BRANDS, Madison, Ga., named Ronald N. Magruder chief executive at its Hops Restaurant Bar Brewery brand, succeeding Tom Schelldorf, who left.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar rises against the yen on speculation that coming reports will provide further evidence of growth without fanning inflation; table (S)

headline: McKesson HBOC Files Suit Against Rival
abstract: McKesson HBOC Inc, largest US drug wholesaler and leading health care software designer, sues rival W3Health Corp, and 12 former McKesson HBOC employees, accusing them of stealing software trade secrets; W3Health denies allegations, saying that McKesson is bullying rival that has created superior product and is trying to discourage McKesson workers from leaving for better jobs (S)

headline: Booting Up Overseas?Look Before You Plug
abstract: Booting Up Overseas? Look Before You Plug

headline: CYTEC TO SELL PAPER CHEMICAL DIVISION TO BAYER AND CIBA
abstract: Cytec Industries plans to shed paper chemical operations through two sales to Bayer AG and Ciba Specialty Chemicals AG, totaling about $115 million; Bayer of Germany will pay about $90 million for parts of business, while Ciba of Switzerland will pay about 38 million Swiss francs, or $23 million, for the rest (S)

headline: HYUNDAI LOSS WIDENS
abstract: Hyundai Electronics Industries, world's No 2 maker of memory chips, sees first-half, 2000, losses triple to $335 million (S)

headline: Giving Online Audiences News They Want
abstract: New Web sites offer users television-style news reports in digestible bits that can be pieced together into personalized newscasts; are based on assumptions that consumers want information and entertainment on demand and that high-speed Internet connections, offered by broadband services, can finally give it to them; Yahoo, Zatso.com and Jagfn.com offer services, but the most ambitious is FeedRoom, which Jonathan Klein is setting up with $35 million in venture capital; photo (M)

headline: Decorating On Deadline
abstract: Responsible Party column profiles Paul Romer, producer of CBS's new television program Big Brother; Romer is called on to decorate 66 rooms for film sets in 11 countries in less than two weeks; photo (M)

headline: ICANN CLOSES MEMBER DRIVE
abstract: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers says 158,000 Internet users signed up during its first at-large membership registration period; program is intended to give Internet users a voice in Icann's policy making structure for administering Internet's domain name and numbering systems; photo (S)

headline: Both Stocks Jump as Software Merger Is Announced
abstract: Share prices of Phone.com and Software.com, two relatively small, money-losing software companies, jump following announcement of merger; investors add $2.6 billion to their combined market values (M)

headline: Wavering Senators Feeling Pressure on China Trade Bill
abstract: Corporate leaders and several of Pres Clinton's cabinet officers intensify pressure on wavering senators to reject amendment that could jeopardize passage of China trade bill; Sens Fred Thompson and Robert Torricelli want to impose sanctions on Chinese companies if they are caught exporting nuclear, chemical or biological weapons or long-range missiles (S)

headline: Verizon Wireless Offers Free Phones
abstract: Verizon Wireless will give customers who choose two-year contracts for digital cellular service new phones at no cost when they renew their service agreements; program, called New Every Two, is intended to retain customers for longer periods while letting them keep up with new technology; users spending $35 or more a month on wireless service are eligible (S)

headline: Cellular Phones to Carry Radiation Level Label
abstract: Largest manufacturers of cellular telephones, in effort to ease concern over possible health risks from mobile phones, are planning to disclose on their packages radiation levels emitted from devices they sell; under proposal submitted by Cellular Telephone Industry Association, cell phone manufacturers will begin on Aug 1 to seek trade group's certification (S)

headline: A Casbah for Clothes Is Bustling in California.
abstract: Joel Kotkin column on retail apparel corridor in Los Angeles, Santee Alley; 80-block jumble of pre-war commercial buildings houses 5,000 companies employing 50,000 people and taking in $8 billion annually in retail and wholesale business; photos (M)

headline: Video Dresses Up E-Mail Ads
abstract: Video e-mail, which is relatively new, is being embraced as way for advertisers, organizations or entertainers to tell story and give consumers access to extra features that all-text e-mail cannot provide; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia's Quirky Leader Apologizes and Pledges Order
abstract: Indonesia's Pres Abdurrahman Wahid apologizes in state of the union speech for falling short of expectations as country struggles to build working democracy and says he will name executive minister to bring order to his flailing administration; says he will concentrate more on foreign affairs in future and create sort of prime ministerial post to handle day-to-day domestic administration; admired for his integrity, democratic ideals and intellect, he has drawn constant criticism for disorganized and impulsive leadership style (M)

headline: MASCOTECH TO BE SOLD TO HEARTLAND INDUSTRIAL PARTNERS
abstract: MasoTech Inc, metal products maker, will be acquired by Heartland Industrial Partners LP for up to $803 million in stock (S)

headline: Verizon Awards Work To Burrell Agency
abstract: Verizon Communications. formerly Bell Atlantic, names Burrell Communications Group to handle its brand introduction drive (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CREATIVE HOST SERVICES INC., San Diego, a provider of in-flight catering and food, news and other airport concessions, said it planned to buy closely held GladCo Enterprises, gaining 20 food concessions at Pittsburgh International Airport and three other airports in the eastern United States.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: British pound falls to seven-year low against $US; graph (S)

headline: APPROVAL FOR MOTOROLA EXPANSION
abstract: China's government approves $1.9 billion investment plan by Motorola Inc to expand its semiconductor-making operations in Tianjin (S)

headline: NIPPON TO RAISE FUNDS
abstract: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp plans to sell as much as $3.5 billion in stock to finance recent purchase of Internet company in US (S)

headline: AT&T Quarterly Profit Surpasses Forecasts
abstract: AT&T Corp reports second-quarter earnings that modestly exceed analysts' expectations; but revenue growth continues to slow amid deepening erosion in core consumer long-distance business; earnings are $1.75 billion, up from $1.59 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue is $16.22 billion, up from $15.75 billion a year ago; photo (M)

headline: From Europe, Creative Taxation; Hungry for Revenue and Seeing Web Sales as a Banquet
abstract: European officials are pushing to adopt narrow but potentially far-reaching proposal to ensure that digital products bought in Europe over Internet do not escape value-added tax; legislation proposed in June by European Commission defines digital products like software and video programming downloaded by computer as services rather than goods; sales; while sales of digital products from outside Europe are only small fraction of that amount, policymakers are fretting over possible lost revenue; European governments depend on value-added tax for roughly 40 percent of their total revenue, while state sales taxes in US make up only about 25 percent of total state tax revenue; map; graphs; photo of European Commission internal market commissioner, Frits Bolkestein, who is pushing proposal to prevent 15 nations in European Union from downloading software on US Web sites, tax-free (M)

headline: Singling Out Sierra Leone, U.N. Council Sets Gem Ban
abstract: UN Security Council votes to impose worldwide ban on purchase of rough diamonds from Sierra Leone until its government can establish system to certify origin of stones being exported, and begins to assert its authority over diamond fields which are under control of rebels who smuggle stones through Liberia to international markets; sales of diamonds provide money to finance conflict; resolution, sponsored by Britain, is experimental and is aimed at getting at roots of war (M)

headline: Personal Business: Diary; Study Finds Gender Gap In Workplace Discipline
abstract: Women are significantly less effective than men in doling out discipline to subordinates at work, according to a new study.     The study, ''Gender and Discipline in the Workplace: Wait Till Your Father Gets Home,'' will be presented tomorrow at the Academy of Management meeting in Toronto. It was based on interviews with 163 employees  68 women and 95 men who had been disciplined by supervisors in all types of job settings.

headline: Clearing the Decks for a Trade Pact's Riches
abstract: New trade pact between US and Vietnam rescinds US embargo that blocked trade for 19 years; lower American tariffs on Vietnamese goods will increase demand for them and, consequently, production; article focuses on impact of new paradigm on Vietnam's fishing and shipbuilding industries and on Anthony D Salzman, American expatriate who imports Caterpillar industrial engines into Vietnam; photos; charts; graphs (M)

headline: Amendment Killed, Way Is Cleared for China Trade Bill
abstract: Senate clears last major hurdle to passing trade bill with China, handing Pres Clinton one of his top remaining foreign policy goals; amendment to impose sanctions on Chinese companies that export sophisticated weapons to hostile nations is rejected, 65 to 32, on bipartisan vote; vote virtually assures that Senate will join House in ending annual Congressional review of China's trade status (M)

headline: Who Cares, as Long as It's Natural?
abstract: Daniel Akst column questions Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Co's 'natural' cigarettes and other pretend 'natural' products (M)

headline: Student Admits Hacking U.S. Government Computers
abstract: Student Admits Hacking U.S. Government Computers

headline: TRACK-SHARING PACT
abstract: Rivals Canadian Pacific Railway and Canadian National Railway agree to share some track in US and Canada (S)

headline: Investing; A Buyer's Market in Cars and Car Stocks
abstract: Investment community remains extremely uninterested in stocks of automobile manufacturers; despite their high sales and profits, car stocks languish; photo; graphs (M)

headline: WEBMD TO CUT JOBS IN REVAMPING
abstract: WebMD Corp, Internet company that links insurers, doctors and patients, will cut 1,100 jobs as it eliminates overlap from acquisitions; job cuts will be completed by end of year; Garden.com Inc, which sells gardening products on Internet, will lay off 93 workers, or 30 percent of its full-time staff; graph (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for ELIZABETH WARREN; Bankruptcy Borne of Misfortune, Not Excess
abstract: Excerpts from conversation with Elizabeth Warren, co-author of new book The Fragile Middle Class, about bankruptcy filings and finances of middle-class America; photo (M)

headline: Web Surfing, at the Sound of Your Own Voice
abstract: AS manufacturers of wireless phones, handheld computers and other Internet gadgets scramble to make Web information accessible without the need to boot up a computer, some companies have a different plan. They are adapting the Web to the one device that virtually everyone has: the telephone.

headline: Old Ties to Serbia Still Bind Many in Montenegro
abstract: Montenegrans are divided over moves toward independence by Pres Milo Djukanovic, who broke with Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic in 1997 and is now regarded by many as traitor to centuries of Montenegrin-Serbian brotherhood; photo; map (M)

headline: Buddhists Seek Asylum for Leader in India
abstract: Representatives of Kagyu school, one of four main branches of Tibetan Buddhism, petition India to grant asylum and freedom of movement to Karmapa, Ugyen Trinley Dorje, their 15-year-old leader, who remains under virtual house arrest at Indian monastery eight months after fleeing Tibet in Jan; demand he be allowed to take charge of school's Rumtek monastery; Dalai Lama, leader of another Buddhist school, backs stand (M)

headline: Microsoft Loses Key Strategist To Retirement
abstract: Paul Maritz's unexpected retirement costs Microsoft Corp key strategist; photo (M)

headline: State Dept. Unfreezes Hundreds of Promotions After Delay for Security Review
abstract: State Department says continuing security crackdown led to freezing of promotions for over 200 senior officials, pending review of their security records by Foreign Service director general Marc Grossman; unfreezes promotions of 200 midlevel officials after weeklong delay; says under 10 of senior officials were barred from promotions after review; some in department complain of poisonous atmosphere created, in part, by security officials; resent Sec Madeleine K Albright's plan to promote senior security official David G Carpenter to under secretary, title never before held by security worker (M)

headline: Serbs´ Leader Plans a Kosovo Visit Soon
abstract: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 31 (AP) — Despite a United Nations indictment against him, President Slobodan Milosevic plans to visit Kosovo, the province he ceded to foreign control last year after air attacks by NATO, a top aide said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Assembly Line to Be Added At Daimler Plant in Alabama  DaimlerChrysler plans to announce today that it will nearly double production in Alabama, adding another assembly line close to the site where it already builds Mercedes M-Class sport utility vehicles, auto industry officials and consultants said over the weekend.    Auto industry consultants and auto parts suppliers said that the company would make a so-called crossover vehicle that would combine the features of a minivan and the M-Class sport utility vehicle. [Page C2.]

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    UKRAINE: PUTIN DEATH PLOT FOILED -- Tipped off by unidentified foreign intelligence services, Ukrainian agents foiled a bid to assassinate President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Yalta last month, the head of Ukraine's security service said. At the time the security chief, Leonid Derkach, said four Chechens had been held, along with several Middle East residents. Russia has long asserted that Chechen rebels are supported by Middle East militants.   Michael Wines    RUSSIA: THE KURSK'S FUTURE -- The minister for atomic energy, Yevgeny Adamov, said it might be safer to leave the submarine Kursk in the Barents Sea rather than risk a nuclear accident by raising it. ''From the point of view of the nuclear reactors, and the nuclear situation, there is no need to raise the submarine,'' he said. Environmental groups have warned of the risk of leaking radiation in adjacent fishing grounds. An aide to Mr. Adamov said he was concerned that cutting holes to retrieve crew remains could further weaken the vessel and make its raising more dangerous.   Patrick E. Tyler

headline: Israel's Leader Faces Turmoil on All Sides
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak's political problems deepen as his right-wing opponents vow new efforts to bring down his government; Likud Party leader Ariel Sharon calls for new elections; warns his coalition will call Parliament, set to begin three-month vacation, back into session if Barak tries to 'sneak' through Palestinian peace accord; bars division of Jerusalem; Moshe Katsav, first Likud candidate ever elected president, is sworn in amid turmoil and consternation within remnants of Barak's battered coalition; photo (M)

headline: Swedish Bid for London Stock Exchange Is Expected
abstract: OM Gruppen, which runs the Stockholm stock exchange, is expected to make a formal offer for the London Stock Exchange, which has rejected an informal 800-million-pound ($1.18 billion) proposal; offer, which could include a hostile bid, would come just weeks before a shareholder vote on proposed merger between London and Frankfurt stock exchanges, which, along with an alliance with Nasdaq stock market, would create a pan-European powerhouse with 24-hour global market; Swedish overture also revives interest in Euronext, a combination of Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris exchanges (M)

headline: What's in a Name
abstract: To the Editor:    The article on finding the right screen name reminded me that sometimes the choice pays off in unexpected ways. I picked ''wyvern'' for several reasons: I liked how it looked and what it meant (a two-legged dragon with wings and a barbed tail), it was so obscure that nobody else was likely to have it, and it was my favorite Scrabble word when I was growing up.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Malone in Talks to Increase Stake in News Corporation  John C. Malone and Rupert Murdoch are considering a deal that would increase the size of their investments in each other's companies, according to people close to the talks.

headline: New Programs Remove Unwanted Internet Files
abstract: New category of software is emerging to help clean up hard drives; iClean by Aladdin Systems promises to seek out and delete unnecessary browser cache files safely and to wipe out Internet history and cookie files for privacy-conscious Web surfers (S)

headline: Chinese Farmers Rebel Against Bureaucracy
abstract: August protest by over 10,000 angry farmers in Yuandu against high taxes and administrative fees has spurred thousands more angry farmers to rampage through neighboring towns in impoverished region of China's Jiangxi Province; such disturbances are increasingly common across China, where up to 900 million still depend on land for their livelihood and Communist Party bosses are seen by peasants as oppressors; government hopes to stop scattered unrest by raising farm incomes, cutting local bureaucracies and reforming tax system; basic cause of problem is that farmers have no political power, with local party officials still appointed from above; map; photo (M)

headline: Review Under Way For Phone Venture
abstract: BellSouth in Atlanta and SBC Communications in San Antonio, have begun a review for a joint venture of the merged North American wireless operations of the two companies, a deal which is still under regulatory review.    Larry Solomon, a spokesman for SBC, confirmed a report of the review that appeared in Advertising Age this week.

headline: AOL Agrees to Make Service Accessible to the Blind
abstract: AOL Agrees to Make Service Accessible to the Blind

headline: Effort Ends on Taittinger Control of Group
abstract: PARIS, Sept. 20 — A pact involving Asher B. Edelman, the American corporate raider, that aimed to crack the Taittinger family's hold on the French luxury group Société du Louvre has dissolved, leaving Mr. Edelman with a smaller stake.

headline: Press Role for a Media-Shy Mogul
abstract: Acquisition of Santa Barbara News-Press from New York Times Co by Wendy P McCaw, one of wealthiest, if not best known, women in US, has been billed as victory of community spirit over homogenizing influence of a distant corporate overseer, but McCaw insists she does not invest in assets for purely sentimental or other nonbusiness reasons; McCaw is estimated to be worth $1.5 billion; she paid about $100 million for News-Press; photo (M)

headline: Italy Journal; On a '44 Battlefield, a Salute for a Black Hero
abstract: Black American veterans who fought in Italy in World War II return to village of Sommocolonia to honor their comrade, Lt John Fox, who was killed in battle on Dec 26, 1944; Fox, who ordered his own men to fire on his position to stem enemy attack, was awarded Medal of Honor more than 50 years later; anguish that black veterans relive is echoed among Italian war survivors who welcome their return; just as black comrades and their relatives cannot shed their bitterness over United States' long refusal to recognize combat records of black servicemen fully, many Italian veterans cannot forgive their own countrymen who fought against them more than 50 years ago; photos; map (L)

headline: Major Gauges Rise in Sluggish Trading Before Holiday
abstract: Stocks rise broadly in sluggish pre-holiday trading; Dow Jones industrial average gains 112.78 to 10,560.67; Nasdaq composite edges up 25.82, to 3,991.93; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 14.72, to 1,469.32; chart (M)

headline: Go.Com Says Losses Grew in 3rd Quarter
abstract: Go.com Inc, Internet unit of the Walt Disney Company, reports fiscal third quarter loss of $272 million, compared with loss of $251.1 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Passage of Cellular Phone Tax May Solve E-Commerce Riddle
abstract: Congress approves legislation specifying that each cell phone will have 'primary service area' for purpose of state and local taxes; users pay between $4 billion and $7 billion annually in state and local cell phone user taxes, and sorting out those taxes has been costly for companies; legislation may help solve issue of how and where to tax goods and services sold over the Internet (M)

headline: DAEWOO AUDIT DEEPENS
abstract: South Korean government extends audit of conglomerate Daewoo Group after auditors found fresh evidence of further false accounting (S)

headline: The Telecommunications Circle of Life
abstract: Even professional investors are having trouble keeping track of merger deals among telecommunications companies, and its is becoming hard to find companies that are not involved in the speculation one way or the other, as predator or prey; drawing, graph (M)

headline: Schedule for Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      AdStar.com, Marina del Rey, Calif., an initial public offering of a million units, each representing three common shares and two redeemable warrants. Paulson Investment.

headline: Advertising as Farce Alongside the Tour de France
abstract: 40 European companies and hundreds of workers are part of enormous advertising convoy that precedes Tour de France as world's greatest bicycle race takes three weeks to circumnavigate more than 2,200 miles of France as well as parts of Switzerland and Germany; companies such as Michelin and Credit Lyonnaise hawk their goods and services along route; photo (M)

headline: A New Nuclear Reactor Sheds Only Some Light on Brazil
abstract: Brazil's second nuclear reactor, Angra II, comes online with generating capacity of 1,300 megawatts; reactor is part of plan for meeting country's desperate need for new sources of electricity, but offers only a fraction of estimated 26,000 megawatts that will be needed in next five years; officials are trying to provide enough power by importing from Argentina and Paraguay, as plan to build 49 thermoelectric plants runs into delays and hydroelectric facilities are threatened by drought; photo (M)

headline: Goldman Sachs to Allow Big Sale of Shares by Ex-Partners
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group says it will let its former partners sell as many as 18 million shares of stock in offering that could be bigger than firm's $3.66 billion initial public offering last year; firm will not get any of proceeds; shares being offered for sale are owned by two big institutions and people who were partners in firm when it went public or who already had retired as partners; only about 17 percent of Goldman's shares are owned by outsiders; other 83 percent are held by firm's current and former employees, Hawaiian trust called Kamehameha Activities Association and Sumitomo Bank of Japan (M)

headline: The Bike Computer: A ‘Black Box’ for the Bicycle
abstract: The Bike Computer: A ‘Black Box’ for the Bicycle

headline: Microsoft Files Brief Asking Supreme Court to Send Antitrust Case to Appeals Court
abstract: Microsoft Corp files legal brief with Supreme Court arguing that government's antitrust case is unsuitable for direct appeal to the court because it is complex and because Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson made serious and substantive procedural errors at trial; says appeal should go first to federal appeals court in Washington, which ruled in favor of company in related case; company's argument rests heavily on scathing attack on work of Judge Jackson, questioning his impartiality and even-handedness of his decision in general (M)

headline: Terrorism Suspect Waives Extradition Hearing
abstract: Mokhtar Haouari, Algerian, waives his right to extradition hearing in Canada and will be turned over to US to face charges of helping Ahmed Ressam, who was arrested in December in Washington State after crossing Canadian border carrying explosives and bomb-making equipment (M)

headline: Report Says Global Accounting Firm Overlooks Factory Abuses
abstract: Prof Dara O'Rourke, who has inspected more than 100 Asian factories for World Bank and various United Nations organizations, contends that world's largest factory-monitoring firm, PricewaterhouseCoopers, does shoddy job and overlooks many safety and wage violations; his report is rare inside look at auditing firms that inspect overseas factories to see whether they are sweatshops; report says PricewaterhouseCoopers has pro-management bias, did not uncover use of carcinogenic chemicals and failed to recognize that some employees are forced to work 80-hour weeks; Pricewaterhouse officials defend their monitoring but acknowledge their inspectors occasionally miss things that expert on industrial hygiene, like O'Rourke, would uncover (M)

headline: 2 French Journalists Tell of Escape From Jolo Rebels
abstract: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines—  After 10 weeks of captivity in the mosquito-invested hills of a remote southern Philippine island, freedom for two French journalists came during a moment of confusion.

headline: Manufacturing Growth Rate Is the Slowest in 17 Months
abstract: June manufacturing expansion is slowest in 17 months, as manufactuters begin to feel effects of six interest-rate increases during past year; graph (M)

headline: BID FOR NORWEGIAN COMPANY
abstract: Kvaerner makes $506 million offer for Norwegian oil-services company Aker Maritime to build its oil and gas business abroad; graph (S)

headline: Agency Cleared For Oversight Of Net Names
abstract: General Accounting Office concludes that Clinton administration acted within the law when it delegated control of the Internet address system to a private group, the nonprofit Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann; says Commerce Department also had legal authority to enter into agreements with Icann and allow it to collect fees to recover its costs; Afternic.com, which auctions previously registered domain names, drops what is believed to be the first lawsuit against Icann (S)

headline: Shorter Term For President? The French Say Ho-Hum
abstract: French Prime Min Lionel Jospin moves to whip up enthusiasm for September 24 referendum on whether to cut president's term from seven to five years; argues that shorter term would likely eliminate France's awkward periods of cohabitation, where president and prime minister belong to different parties, as has happened three times in past 15 years; says five-year term would keep president on his toes, but acknowledges vast majority of French citizens are unlikely to go to polls (M)

headline: A Bottleneck Between the Digital Player and the Ear: The PC
abstract: New generation of music management software simplifies downloading and transfer of music to personal digital audio players; some products described (M)

headline: DEBT RELIEF FOR TAIWAN DEVELOPER
abstract: Ever Fortune Group, Taiwan property developer that has run short of cash, reaches agreement with creditors to extend payments and reduce interest on $836 million worth of debt (S)

headline: Dictionary Publishers Going Digital
abstract: Digital dictionary efforts are being advanced by Houghton Mifflin (American Heritage), Merriam-Webster, Oxford University Press (Oxford English Dictionary) and Microsoft (Encarta); Houghton Mifflin hopes to sell electronic versions of fourth edition of American Heritage dictionary for inclusion in other companies' software, Web sites and digital publications; some philologists worry that new pressures of the online market may end up favoring well-connected or well-positioned dictionaries like Encarta over more authoritative lexicons; effort to build common digital archive of American usage samples has yet to win help from many of nation's big publishers, who would stand to lose the advantage of their own proprietary archives; lexicographers are coming to see World Wide Web as a gold mine for linguistic research (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Profits May Not Be Enough to Offset Fed's Drag
abstract: Outlook for second-quarter earnings is best it has been in years, but a look back at 1994 shows that even great earnings news may not lift stock prices much if Federal Reserve is intent on raising interest rates to slow overheating economy (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Flight attendant and author of 'Around the World in a Bad Mood' likes corporate fliers best.
abstract: Article on Rene Foss, flight attendant for Northwest Airlines for 16 years and author of musical revue Around the World in a Bad Mood, comments on how she likes corporate fliers the best (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Holocaust Group to Step Up Pressure on Austria for Reparations
abstract: Claims Conference, international organization that seeks compensation for Holocaust survivors, votes at New York City meeting to pressure Austria to admit complicity during Nazi regime and improve reparations to Jews (M)

headline: Rome Journal; Italy's Fascist Buildings in Style, and for Sale
abstract: Italians are coming to appreciate architecture of Fascist era, which they have long ignored or despised, and interest has been brought to a head by controversy over proposed government sale of Foro Italico, sprawling 1930's sports complex in Rome; architecture was Mussolini's favorite mode of propaganda; foreigners have long vaunted the ingenuity and daring of Fascist architects, who sought to blend the classicism of ancient Rome with 20th-century functionalism and rationalism; right-wing groups oppose sale of Foro Italico; photo (M)

headline: P.& G. Reports Earnings in Line With Lowered Forecasts
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co, troubled by rising costs, management turmoil and credibility problems on Wall Street, reports fourth-quarter results that are in line with lowered forecasts; company also advised that earnings growth in first half of its new fiscal year would be sluggish; reports fourth-quarter earnings of $516 million, compared with year-earlier $414 million; excluding an after-tax reorganization charge of $261 million, company earned $777 million, down 3 percent from year-earlier $799 million (M)

headline: A Shoe That Will Give Runners And Walkers Instant Feedback
abstract: Reebok is working a new kind of sneaker, due for introduction in July 2001, that it says will accurately tell wearers not only how far they have run or walked, but also at what pace and how many calories they expended along the way; its underlying technology was developed FitSense of Newton, Mass; photos (M)

headline: CARREFOUR'S PROFIT UP
abstract: Carrefour SA reports first-half profit from operations rose 11 percent, to 302 million euros ($270 million), from 273 million euros in 1999 period; net income rose to 277 million euros, from 266 million euros; photo (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence -- July  Existing-Home Sales -- June

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A top accounting executive asks the S.E.C. to amend a new proposal on auditor independence.
abstract: Phil Laskaway, chairman of Ernst & Young, major accounting firm that has been supporting Securities and Exchange Commission effort to tighten rules on auditor independence, says that SEC's rule proposal goes too far and would create too much uncertainty about what activities are permitted (Market Place column) (M)

headline: AIR CANADA WILL TRIM 2,000 JOBS
abstract: Air Canada will eliminate about 2,000 jobs after completing its acquisition of Canadian Airlines; says there will be no involuntary layoffs (S)

headline: Charges From Spinoff Will Give Ford a Loss
abstract: Ford Motor Co will take $3.3 billion in charges for costs of spinning off its Visteon Corp parts unit and reorganizing its European business, resulting in its first quarterly loss since end of 1992 (S)

headline: British Panel Supports Cloning of Human Cells for Research
abstract: LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) — A panel of experts has urged the government to allow the cloning of human embryonic stem cells for scientific study of transplants. The government accepted the recommendation today and said it would submit legislation to adopt it.

headline: ANALOG DEVICES IS BUYING BCO OF NORTHERN IRELAND
abstract: Analog Devices Inc, maker of high-speed communications chips, will acquire BCO Technologies, electronics-components maker based in Northern Ireland, for about $150 million in cash (S)

headline: CIBA CHEMICALS' PROFIT IS UP
abstract: Ciba Specialty Chemicals' net income climbed to 215 million Swiss francs ($125 million) in first half of year from 73 million francs a year earlier; Ciba says second-half growth will slow compared with levels for first six months (S)

headline: Harman in Stock Buyback
abstract: Harman International Industries will buy back up to two million of its shares in the next year; move would be worth $130 million at current market prices (S)

headline: The Nerd as Stereotype
abstract: Dan Bloch letter questions whether women in computer science are concerned that they will become antisocial nerds or concerned that they will meet men who are antisocial nerds (July 27 article)

headline: Executives Promoted At New York Times
abstract: New York Times promotes Rhonda Novick to vice president, consumer marketing; Roland Caputo is named to newly created position of vice president for business development; Rick Ueland is promoted to president of City and Suburban Delivery Systems Inc, which has primary responsibilty for wholesale delivery of newspaper in New York region, succeeding Caputo; will also retain title of executive director of newspaper's circulation operations (S)

headline: An Old-Fashioned Idea
abstract: Incoming: An Old-Fas

headline: Bridgestone Alters Reimbursement Limit
abstract: Bridgestone Corp is dropping restrictions governing when consumers can be reimbursed for cost of replacing 6.5 million Firestone brand tires that are being recalled amid US safety investigation; Bridgestone had initially said it would repay consumers for replacement tires that were bought between Jan 1 and Aug 8 at company-owned or authorized retailers; company limited reimbursement on competitors' tires that were bought as replacements at other stores between Aug 9 and Aug 16 (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    THE HAGUE: SREBRENICA TESTIMONY -- A former Bosnian Serb general, Radislav Krstic, on trial before the United Nations war crimes tribunal, accused his former commander in chief, Ratko Mladic, left, of personally overseeing the massacre of thousands of Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995. The videotaped testimony was the first time the tribunal had heard evidence directly placing Mr. Mladic, who is still at large, in charge of the forces that carried out the killings.   (Reuters)

headline: EARTHLINK LOSS NARROWS
abstract: Earthlink reports smaller-than-expected net loss for second quarter, as revenue rose by more than 40 percent; loss was $35.2 million compared with $50.9 million a year ago (S)

headline: Article 2000092091063364141 -- No Title
abstract: EDUCATION COLUMN

headline: COMPAQ FINED FOR OVERCHARGES
abstract: Justice Department says Compaq Computer has agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle claims tht Digital Equipment, which it acquired in 1998, overcharged government for installing computer equipment; Digital admitted in 1995 that it submitted inflated labor costs to Defense Department for work done in Orlando, Fla, and in Frankfurt (S)

headline: FORD SAID TO PLAN IMPROVED MILEAGE IN SPORT UTILITIES
abstract: Ford Motor Co plans to increase average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent, or roughly five miles a gallon, over next five years; increase would be first major change in fuel economy of any passenger vehicle class in almost 20 years; Ford, at least at first, does not plan to pass extra cost of producing more fuel-efficient vehicles directly to customers, expecting increased sales to offset lower profits (M)

headline: Ex-Regulator Sentenced in Telemarket Fraud
abstract: Judge Joseph DiCierico sentences John A Field 3d, former US attorney and commodities regulator, to 24 months in prison for becoming co-conspirator with operators of fraudulent telemarketing scams involving securities and commodities (M)

headline: TOMKINS PUTS ITS SMITH & WESSON UNIT UP FOR SALE
abstract: Tomkins PLC will put its Smith & Wesson Corp unit, biggest US handgun maker, up for sale (S)

headline: MPOWER SHARES FALL 28% ON REDUCED FINANCIAL OUTLOOK
abstract: Mpower Communications shares fall 28 percent following firm's forecast of lower cash flow and sales (S)

headline: Ericsson Shares Drop 12% On Slow Cell Phone Sales
abstract: Healthy increase in second-quarter earnings fails to stop investors from hammering shares of Swedish cell phone maker Ericsson; shares fall $2.75, to $19.8125 (M)

headline: Andersen Split Into Two Firms By Arbitrator
abstract: International arbitrator severs Andersen Consulting from parent Arthur Andersen, tax and auditimg firm; Andersen Consulting must relinquish name and pay Arthur Andersen $1 billion; decision ends acrimonious three-year battle, and is seen as major victory for consultants whose unit has been split off without having to pay any of $14.6 billion in damages sought by Arthur Andersen; partnership has operated under umbrella company Andersen Worldwide since 1989, but companies had little to do with each other; traumatic rift stems from fact that Andersen Consulting became more profitable than parent during past decade and chafed over sharing of profits; chief executive Joe W Forehand and other officials laud ruling; Arthur Andersen chief executive Jim Wadia says he is satisfied with ruling; announces resignation; says he was appointed three years ago largely to oversee dispute, and that his job is done; ruling by arbitrator Guillermo Gamba discussed; photo; charts (M)

headline: U.S. Rights Report Faults China For Harassing Religious Groups
abstract: US State Department report accuses Chinese government of harassing religious groups; holds that there is marked deterioration in religious freedom; cites new state law granting state and local officials broad authority to suppress 14 minority religions, including Falun Gong Movement (S)

headline: RISE IN IRISH INFLATION
abstract: Annual inflation rate for Irish economy rose to 5.5 percent for year ended June 30, increase of 0.3 percent from May; photo of Prime Min Bertie Ahern (S)

headline: THE INNOCENTS/A Special Report; Jailed Unjustly, Peruvians Try to Rebuild Shattered Lives
abstract: Outside his powder-blue shack, Antonio Alejo waits quietly for customers in need of an oil change or a brake job. He smiles faintly as his youngest child plays with his two stepchildren, running around some burning trash on the sand dune that is his front yard. With business slow, he tends a few geraniums and sunflowers and occasionally fixes a bowl of rice.    Mr. Alejo is slowly picking up the shards of his life.

headline: NAPSTER FILES ARGUMENTS
abstract: Napster makes its final written presentation to US Appeal Court, seeking to overturn lower court decision in July that threatens to shut down company by blocking major-label songs from being traded on Napster service (S)

headline: With Clinton Due, Holbrooke Defends U.N.
abstract: With President Clinton preparing to visit New York this week for a meeting of world leaders at the United Nations, the American ambassador, Richard C. Holbrooke, said on Saturday that the United States must focus more on its ties with the organization, which he called "indispensable" to American foreign policy.

headline: STUDY SAID TO FIND U.S. MISSILE SHIELD MIGHT INCITE CHINA
abstract: Highly classified intelligence report reportedly warns that deploying American national missile defense could spur China to expand its nuclear arsenal tenfold and lead Russia to place multiple warheads on ballistic missiles; says Chinese expansion would prompt buildups by India and Pakistan; report underscores warnings by opponents that Clinton administration's proposal for limited defense system could lead to new arms race with Russia and, to lesser extent, in Asia; also underscores emerging threat to United States from missile proliferation (M)

headline: Palestinian, Israeli Forces Exchange Fire on Third Day of Clashes
abstract: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- Israeli troops and Palestinian police exchanged fire in a third day of clashes on Saturday, further damaging chances of securing an Arab-Israeli peace deal. About 200 Palestinians were wounded in the violence sweeping the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the death toll rose to at least seven from violence earlier this week. It started after right-wing Israeli politician Ariel Sharon -- a figure of hatred for Palestinians -- visited a site in Jerusalem's Old City on Thursday that is sacred to both Jews and Muslims. Witnesses said Palestinian police and Israeli soldiers opened fire during clashes near a Jewish settlement in Gaza on Saturday, and medical sources said more than 70 Palestinians had been injured in the violence there. Israeli security forces also opened fire in the West Bank city of Nablus when hundreds of Palestinians marched towards an army checkpoint. Witnesses reported three people hurt. Thousands of demonstrators gathered in the divided West Bank city of Hebron. Some threw stones and others hurled petrol bombs at Israeli soldiers and at least 60 people were injured. In Jerusalem, Israeli police said Palestinians threw stones at cars and buses and, as a security precaution, police evacuated worshippers from the Western Wall of the Old City where Jews were reciting prayers on the Jewish New Year. Dozens of other people were reported injured in isolated clashes across the West Bank. The Israeli army said it had used live ammunition in Gaza to target people ``endangering soldiers,'' as well as rubber-coated metal bullets and teargas there and elsewhere. ``PROVOCATIVE'' VISIT BY SHARON BLAMED Palestinian leaders had called a one-day general strike in memory of Palestinians killed on Friday during clashes at the Jerusalem holy site known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as al-Harim al-Sharif. They blamed the violence on the Israeli authorities' show of force and the ``provocative'' visit by Sharon to the Old City. A total of at least 400 Israelis and Palestinians, and several tourists, have been reported injured so far. The explosion of Arab-Israeli violence soured not only Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak's Barak's New Year, or Rosh Hashanah, weekend but also his push for lasting peace with the Palestinians. In New York, U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan telephoned Barak as well as Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Friday. ``He expressed his concern over the recent violence in Jerusalem and urged the leaders to do everything they can to reduce tensions, restore security and continue to work towards a peaceful settlement of the remaining issues that divide them,'' U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said. Arafat arrived in Cairo to discuss the violence with Egypt's Hosni Mubarak, a close ally of Washington and president of one of the only two Arab states to have made peace with Israel. Egyptian radio reported Mubarak had issued a statement blaming ``provocative Israeli actions'' for Friday's clashes in Jerusalem, the main stumbling block in the peace process. ``A statement issued by the Egyptian Presidency noted that, at a time when the peace-loving forces were looking forward to a breakthrough in the Palestinian-Israeli negotiations, they were taken aback by the bloody incidents that too place yesterday (Friday),'' the radio said. SAUDIS BLAME ISRAEL Palestinian Minister Nabil Shaath said he was due to leave on Sunday to meet foreign ministers of Luxembourg, France, Britain, Ireland and Belgium and top European Union officials at Arafat's request to brief them on the bloodshed. Saudi Arabia, another staunch ally of the United States and supporter of Washington's role as Middle East peace broker, put the blame for the violence squarely on Israel. ``Saudi Arabia condemns the brutal assaults inflicted on Palestinian citizens in Jerusalem by Israeli occupation forces,'' the Saudi Press Agency quoted an official statement as saying on Friday night. Saudi Arabia is the birthplace of Islam and home to the world's two main Muslim shrines. Gulf media railed against the ``horrific massacre'' of Palestinians in Jerusalem and one newspaper in Qatar said the killings showed Israel was still the Arabs' foe. ``The events prove that Israel was neither a neighbour nor a peace partner. It is no more than an enemy,'' Al-Sharq's editorial said. In south Lebanon on Saturday, thousands of Palestinian refugees demonstrated against the killings. They marched through Ain el-Hilweh, the biggest refugee camp in Lebanon, chanting anti-Israeli slogans and burning an effigy of Sharon. ``Sharon, we will never forget your massacres in Sabra and Shatila. The Aqsa Mosque (in Jerusalem) is Arab and will remain Arab,'' read one banner. In 1983 an Israeli inquiry found Sharon indirectly responsible for the killing of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in Beirut. He was defence minister at the time, during an Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Russia called on Palestinians and Israelis to stop further bloodshed from derailing the peace talks. ``Moscow is extremely alarmed,'' a Russian Foreign Ministry statement said on Saturday. ``These tragic events are the consequences of provocative acts in the area of Muslim holy sites on September 28,'' it said in apparent criticism of Sharon's visit to the Temple Mount.

headline: Bypassing College
abstract: Lee Goeller letter on Sept 7 article about young people who are forgoing college to start technology jobs

headline: What's More Exciting: Rockets or Revenue?
abstract: Executives at other networks score NBC deal to give producer Mark Burnett share of advertising revenue of his new show, Destination Mir, in which endurance contest winner will get trip to Russia's Mir space station; Burnett defends deal, noting that he pitches his shows to advertisers himself and that advertisers can associate themselves directly with shows; photo (M)

headline: Schein Subpoenaed by States on Pricing
abstract: Schein Pharmaceutical Inc, generic drug maker, is subpoenaed by New York, Florida, Nevada and other states seeking information on its drug-pricing practices (S)

headline: NEXT LEVEL STOCK LOSES HALF ITS VALUE ON ANALYST REPORT
abstract: Shares of Next Level Communications lose more than half their value after Lehman Brothers says Qwest Communications International may reduce purchases from company, phone-equipment maker (S)

headline: New Software Being Offered By Microsoft to Catch AOL
abstract: Microsoft is preparing new marketing push for its Internet service, MSN, including mass-distributed software offering free hours for signing up, promotional deals with Radio Shack and Best Buy, broadband service and special software designed to make it easier to use Microsoft sites like MoneyCentral, Encarta and HomeAdviser; has had trouble gaining ground against America Online (S)

headline: Philips to Release DVD Recorder in 2001
abstract: Philips to Release DVD Recorder in 2001

headline: China Arrests Owner of Internet Cafe
abstract: Jiang Shihua, owner of an Internet cafe in Nanchong, China, is arrested and charged with subversion for posting articles critical of Communist Party, the latest sign of the government's campaign to tame the explosion of electronic information (S)

headline: Red Dot, Meet Green: If It's Tuesday, Network!: New York; A Little Optimism At the Fashion Show
abstract: First Tuesday gathering of venture capitalists and new-economy entrepreneurs at Ohm discotheque in New York draws 600 people from list of 1,400 who wanted to attend, but technology stock meltdown in April has made investors more selective in picking ventures to back (M)

headline: DDB Reorganizes Interactive Agencies
abstract: DDB Worldwide in New York is merging its worldwide interactive agencies into one unit, Tribal DDB Worldwide (S)

headline: Fallon Minneapolis Chosen by Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup chooses Fallon Minneapolis as agency of record to handle the Citibank consumer business in US (S)

headline: Out-of-This-World Philanthropy
abstract: Paul G Allen and Nathan Myhrvold donate $12.5 million to SETI Institute to fund search for intelligent life beyond Earth (S)

headline: Clinton Nudges Arafat
abstract: Pres Clinton urges Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to take step forward in Mideast peace talks ahead of Sept 13 deadline, television interview; confirms Jerusalem issue blocked accord at Camp David talks; sees accord possible (M)

headline: With Project Expanding Net's Reach, There Are No Strangers in Paradise
abstract: Schools and libraries on American Samoa become less remote from the rest of the world thanks to E-rate, government program that provides computers and Internet access to all public and private schools and libraries; E-rate is now a success, but it was nearly defeated by Republican lawmakers, who called it the 'Gore tax' because Vice Pres Al Gore championed program, which imposes a fee on long-distance telephone companies; photos (M)

headline: Nortel Agrees to Buy Alteon For $7.8 Billion in Stock
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp agrees to acquire Alteon WebSystems Inc for $7.8 billion in stock (M)

headline: As Japan Deregulates, Quality-of-Life Laments; Mom and Pop Do Battle With Discounters
abstract: Growth of discount stores and other shopping options in Japan threatens local mom-and-pop shops, which have traditionally been the backbone of Japanese neighborhood, and they have become a rallying point for forces opposed to deregulation; local shops are a drag on Japanese productivity, accounting for 55 percent of retail employment, while entire retail industry accounts for 12 percent of total employment and 5 percent of total gross domestic product; neighborhood groups are banding together to fight incursions by big store chains, and large retailers must now get permission from local committee to open stores; photos; graph (M)

headline: Down From Summit, Into Vale of Uncertainty
abstract: Analysis of outlook for Mideast peace in light of failure of Israelis and Palestinians to come to terms at Camp David summit; notes Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak's sober assessment of talks conflicts with stand by Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat that talks paved way for peace agreement by Yasir Arafat's Sept 13 deadline for declaring Palestinian state unilaterally; photos (M)

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE SAYS IT WILL MEET PROFIT FORECASTS
abstract: Procter & Gamble, expects to meet profit estimates for its fiscal first and second quarter, sending its shares up 8.3 percent; plans to cut costs, raise prices on some products and revive some brands (S)

headline: COURIER WILL BUY DOVER PUBLICATIONS FOR $39 MILLION
abstract: Courier Corp agrees to buy Dover Publications for $39 million, adding special-interest books to its list of titles as it seeks buyers on the Internet (S)

headline: Vote at Dime Is Said to Favor North Fork
abstract: Dime Bancorp says its shareholders voted against management's five board nominees, leaving North Fork Bancorp free to pursue its $1.85 billion hostile bid for company (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: E7TH.COM, New York, named Jay M. Margolis chairman and chief executive, succeeding Todd Ricci, who remains with the company as chief strategic officer. Mr. Margolis had been chief executive at Esprit de Corp.

headline: TERAYON AGREES TO BUY MAINSAIL FOR $163 MILLION

headline: Blair Aims Big Surplus At Crime and Health Issues
abstract: LONDON—  Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer on Tuesday announced a major increase in public spending over the coming three years, saying the Labour government was determined to use its big budget surplus to finance improvements in health care, education, transportation and crime-fighting.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: NEW LAWS AID MILOSEVIC  Yugoslavia's federal Parliament approved new election laws that provide President Slobodan Milosevic with the legal framework to stay in power. The laws define new election procedures under which a president is elected by a majority in a popular vote, regardless of turnout, in a country where the opposition may boycott the polls. They also allow the president a second four-year term. Mr. Milosevic, who was elected in 1997 after serving two terms as president of Serbia, is widely expected to run.   (AP)

headline: Senate Votes to Ease Computer Exports
