headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    SPAIN: JUDGE INDICTS ARGENTINE -- Judge Baltasar Garzon indicted a former Argentine military officer on charges of genocide, torture and terrorism, acts he said were committed under Argentina's military government two decades ago. Judge Garzon, who led a drive to extradite the former Chilean dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, on human rights charges, acted after hearing testimony from Argentines in Europe who said they were tortured by the officer, Ricardo Miguel Cavallo, pictured here. Mr. Cavallo is in Mexico awaiting possible extradition to Spain.   Benjamin Jones (NYT)

headline: Ivax Says Bristol-Myers Deal Aims to Delay a Generic Drug

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow and S.& P. 500 Gain, But Nasdaq Slumps 2.2%  Stocks were mixed as investors switched out of technology companies on fears that their earnings growth might slow and moved into more traditional and cheaper sectors, like consumer products.    The Dow Jones industrial average gained 84.97 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,606.95, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.27 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,438.10. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 81.47 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,685.52. [Page C9.]

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    VATICAN: CATHOLICISM'S ROLE -- The Vatican issued a strong statement seeking to affirm and ''clarify'' Roman Catholic teaching on the uniqueness of Christianity and the Catholic Church. The document, written by the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, says that salvation is available only through Jesus Christ and that Christ's church ''continues to exist fully only in the Catholic Church.'' It also says Christ's church is ''present and operative'' in other churches provided that they share a Catholic understanding of the Eucharist and preserve an ecclesial structure in which bishops trace their authority to the Apostles.   Gustav Niebuhr    BRITAIN: TWINS CASE DELAYED -- Citing the complexities of the case, the Court of Appeal said it would be next week before it could decide whether a High Court judge was correct in giving doctors permission to proceed with an operation separating joined twins that would sacrifice the life of one to save the other. The parents, identified only as Catholics from a ''remote'' European community, said their faith compels them to let nature take its course even if it means the death of their children, born last month.   Warren Hoge

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: INTERIOR MINISTER SET TO QUIT -- The prickly and outspoken interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, will resign today, French news organizations reported, quoting government officials claiming to be privy to a conversation between the minister and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. Mr. Chevenement, who has resigned from two previous governments on matters of principle, publicly disagreed with Mr. Jospin's plan to grant greater autonomy to Corsica.   Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)    SWITZERLAND: NESTLE PAYING HOLOCAUST FUNDS -- Nestle will contribute $14.6 million to the $1.25 billion settlement between Swiss banks and Jewish groups to settle claims over Holocaust-era victims' accounts. The Swiss-based food giant said it is making the payment because it is ''either certain or it may be assumed'' that some of its companies in countries under Nazi control had probably used slave labor. Contributions will also be made to similar funds in Germany and Austria, it said.   Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

[Page A1.]    Books Ordered by Chapter or Verse  This fall, hundreds of books like travel guides will be sold on the Internet in parts -- chapters, maps and even paragraphs -- that can be mixed and matched a la carte by readers. headline: Untangling The Wireless Web; Cellular Internet Is a Format War For the Carriers
abstract: Back in Reykjavik, Skuli Mogensen saw the wireless Internet craze that was sweeping his native Iceland and had an inspiration: why not try to export the revolution by taking his company's software for mobile wireless devices to the United States?    So he has been preparing his company, OZ.com, to be a trans-Atlantic wireless contender. ''I had no doubt this thing will explode in America,'' said Mr. Mogensen, 31, who incorporated OZ in San Francisco. ''The U.S. market has relatively high usage of the Internet, PC's, cable modems, Palm devices and cell phones, so why shouldn't the wireless Internet be used to unite all of these things?''

headline: AOL-Time Warner Rivals Preparing for Interactive TV Fight

headline: At Least 55 Dead as Greek Ferry Sinks in Aegean
abstract: PAROS, Greece -- A Greek ferry struck a patch of rocks in the Aegean Sea and sank, killing at least 55 of the more than 500 people aboard who panicked and started jumping overboard, rescue officials said. ``We're finding bodies all the time. There are 55 dead and about that number of people missing,'' rescue force chief Andreas Kois said Wednesday. Many of the dead were young children, who were not required to be counted on the passenger list. A port official also suffered a heart attack and died after hearing news of the sinking, the coast guard said. Justice Minister Michalis Stathopoulos said the accident was caused by ``criminal negligence,'' and prosecutors ordered the arrest of the ship's captain and four crew members. Coast Guard chief Andreas Sirigos said the 34-year-old ferry boat hit a large rocky outcrop late Tuesday in rough seas about two miles off the popular resort island of Paros. A crew member interviewed by telephone said there was an orderly evacuation. But passengers reported a strong collision and then panic. ``The ship fell apart as it sank. There were people hanging from the railings. Children were crying and old people were screaming,'' Zoe Kolida told private Mega television. ``I jumped in and looked back after about 50 meters and the ship was gone.'' ``I thought of the Titanic,'' another survivor, engineer Stamatis Delavinias, told Mega. ``The boat sank in about half an hour. There were old women and others who were afraid to jump in the sea.'' Dozens of fishing boats, other vessels and British Navy helicopters rushed to the scene and helped in the rescue. The ferry's owner said there were 447 tickets sold and 63 crew members aboard, but the exact number of passengers was not known as some may have purchased their tickets onboard and children under the age of 5 are not required to have tickets. Some reports said at least 20 people from another ship owned by the same company may have boarded the ferry. The head of the Paros Health Center, Dimitris Stavrakis, said ``there a number of young children among the dead.'' A British Navy helicopter in rescue operations touched down at Paros airport and was seen unloading four bodies, including that of an infant. Some survivors taken to other locations, including the nearby island of Antiparos, also said they had not been registered by rescue authorities. It was not known how many foreigners were aboard, but they reportedly included passengers from Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Norway, and the United States. Coast guard officials were baffled as to why the 345-foot, 4,407-ton Express Samina hit the Portes islet, a large rocky outcrop which is marked on maritime charts and has a navigation light. ``You have to be blind not to see it,'' Sirigos said. ``It is inexplicable how the ship collided with a well-known rock that carries a light visible from a distance of seven miles.'' The accident was even more surprising for a vessel such as the Express Samina, one of more than a dozen ferries that daily sail to Paros and other resorts. The ship's captain Vassilis Yannakis, his lieutenant, Anastasios Psychoyos, and three crew members were arrested. A supreme court prosecutor also summoned two senior officials from the ferry's operator, Minoan Flying Dolphins, to give testimony. The captain of another ferry, Theoharis Tsoukalas, said he made the same run almost every day and could not remember ``any other ship ever hitting there.'' Greek and British warships on maneuvers in the area scoured the area as life rafts and vests washed ashore. Rescue efforts were hampered by a fresh gale with winds blowing up to 46 mph. British helicopters rescued at least 12 people, including two Britons, clinging to rocks in the swelling seas and took them aboard the HMS Invincible for treatment. They were suffering from cold, shock and minor cuts and bruises. Sirigos said 443 people from the ship had been accounted for at the island's health center. He appealed for any survivors staying at hotels or private homes to register at the health center. The ferry makes regularly scheduled runs from the Athens port of Piraeus to the island of Samos with a final stop at the tiny Lipsi islands near the Turkish coast. It was about to make a stop on Paros, 100 miles southeast of Athens, when it hit the reef. Sirigos said the coast guard was also investigating why it took the crew nearly 20 minutes to inform the coast guard that the ship was sinking.

headline: Personal Business: Money & Medicin; Breaking the Code of Lab Bills
abstract: It is a familiar sequence of events to anyone who has spent much time in a doctor's office. You have blood taken, you call for the results, you get on with your life and then weeks, months or even years later, you receive a bill from the laboratory or an explanation-of-benefits letter from your insurance company.     These missives can be maddening, and not only because they arrive so long after the fact. There is usually no way for a layman to discern the test in question or which doctor ordered it; all you see are a few numerical codes. Unless you own the handbook that explains what ''82947'' stands for, you're at least one phone call away from an explanation.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST

The bid signals his return to the acquisition trail after two years of accounting problems that grew out of his biggest merger, with CUC International. Mr. Silverman offered about $740 million, or $29 a share, but investors bid up the shares of Avis $5, to $30.50. [Page C2.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: No Lasting Problems Seen For Mitsubishi in Japan  Despite the public humiliation that it had concealed customer complaints about defects for more than two decades, Mitsubishi Motors, Japan's fourth-largest carmaker, is not likely to suffer a significant loss in sales or damage to its brand image in Japan, analysts say.    For one, analysts said, both Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru, and Daihatu Motors were forced to recall cars in the late 1990's, with little effect on sales. And despite the deception in Mitsubishi's case, there was no evidence that the defects had caused any fatal or otherwise serious accidents, further limiting potential public reaction to the recall of 620,000 cars and trucks. [Page C2.]

headline: Congressional Report Says Corruption Is Stifling Bosnia
abstract: General Accounting Office says that pervasive crime and corruption are blocking success of Dayton peace accord in Bosnia and that Clinton administration should consider suspending its extensive aid until local authorities show a determination to fight such abuses; says corruption could interfere with eventual withdrawal of United States and other NATO troops (M)

headline: Technology Briefs
abstract: Technology Briefs

headline: Main Gauges Advance Smartly as Inflation Fears Ebb
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 112.09 points, or 1 percent, to 11,215.10; Nasdaq composite index is up 102.54 points, or 2.5 percent, to 4,206.35; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advances 15.09 points, or 1 percent, to 1,517.68; graph; chart (M)

headline: ADVANCE IN SUPERCONDUCTING
abstract: American Superconductor Corp and Rockwell Automation, division of Rockwell International, says it has passed milestone in government-sponsored research to develop high-temperature superconducting motors by successfully operating world's first 1,000-horsepower unit using such technology; harnessing superconductivity, rare phenomenon in which electrical current flows without resistance, could save billions of dollars annually in energy costs for utilities and users of large motors (S)

headline: Article 2000091791477972252 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: At the G.O.P. Convention, Carmakers Toot Horns ...
abstract: General Motors and DaimlerChrysler use Republican National Convention as marketing opportunity (S)

headline: SIEMENS WILL PURCHASE ACUSON FOR $700 MILLION
abstract: Siemens AG acquires Acuson Corp, maker of ultrasound radiology devices, for about $700 million (S)

headline: Local Scandals Govern Hong Kong Vote
abstract: Most Hong Kong voters see legislative elections as chance to register dissatisfaction with local establishment, not to stand up to China; focus has shifted from debates about freedom and law to local scandals and economic problems (M)

headline: So What About Mount McKinley?
abstract: McDonald's forces McWellness, three-year-old Swiss company that provides online health assistance to business travelers, to change its name; co-founders Barbara Staehelin and Catharina Maulbecker say they named company McWellness because they had been working at consulting firm McKinsey; their firm is now GetWellness; drawing (M)

headline: Yes, the Euro Will Rebound. Someday.
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column analyses past, present and future of the euro; graph (M)

headline: Salomon to Buy U.S. Treasury Interest
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney offers to buy $94.5 billion worth of interest portion of Treasury securities, known as strips, from institutional and retail owners (S)

headline: UMPQUA PLANS TO ACQUIRE VRB BANCORP FOR $51.5 MILLION
abstract: Umpqua Holdings Corp acquires VRB Bancorp for $51.5 million (S)

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK TO ACQUIRE CUSTODIAL ACCOUNTS
abstract: Bank of New York Co agrees to acquire $9 billion in custodial accounts that are administered by Bank of America Private Bank in Los Angeles, unit of Bank of America Corp; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Watch Your Back, Harry Potter; A Wizardly Comuter Game, Diablo II, Is a Hot Seller
abstract: Diablo II, Dungeons and Dragons-like computer game for older teenagers and adults from Blizzard Entertainment, sells more than million copies worldwide and is within striking distance of popular Harry Potter books in terms of revenue; is on track to be one of top selling computer games but has won little attention in media; unlike Potter books, which have won praise for drawing videogame-crazed and television-besotted children back to reading, Diablo II has drawn condemnation for ensnaring players in morbid world view and gluing them antisocially to computer screen; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Computer Science Brain Drain
abstract: Weeks before the beginning of the upcoming fall semester, Benjamin Kuipers, chairman of the University of Texas at Austin Computer Science Department, was scrambling to find two professors to teach core courses. The alternative was to cancel classes students needed to meet graduation requirements.

headline: Hostile Suitor to Make Case In London Exchange Takeover
abstract: OM Gruppen is expected to show documents to shareholders to support its hostile bid for London Stock Exchange and explain why its plan would make more sense than friendly merger with Frankfurt stock exchange; publication of documents should set off new round of dealing in increasingly bitter batttle for London exchange (M)

headline: Group Objects to F.B.I. Release of Carnivore Information
abstract: August 18, 2000

headline: People
abstract: Jimmy Siegel is promoted to executive vice president and executive creative director at New York office of BBDO Worldwide; Howard Karel is named worldwide account director on Johnson & Johnson account at New York office of DDB Worldwide; succeeds Ned Russell, who resigned; Nick Bishop, executive vice president and managing director at McCann-Erickson/A&L, is named to new post of vice president for consumer connections at marketing division of Coca-Cola Co; Jeff Einstein is named to new position of director for interactive for North America at Rapp Digital Communications; Blake E Foehlich is named vice president and director for interactive at Rapp Digital; Robert Cunningham is named president at ePartners (M)

headline: Arboreal Scandal in Israel: Not All of the Trees Planted There Stay Planted
abstract: Israeli tabloid causes stir with article suggesting that workers uproot saplings planted by tourists in Jerusalem to make way for next day's busload of tree-planting tourists; Jewish National Fund, sponsoring agency, suspends some workers and sets up public committee headed by former judge to probe charges; map; photo (M)

headline: Mexico's Ousted Party Tries to Regroup After Stunning Defeat
abstract: Elder statesmen of Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party agree on formula aimed at maintaining internal discipline as party's long monopoly over Mexican power and wealth draws to a close; 21 state governors, after meeting with Pres Ernesto Zedillo, announce that they have convinced party's top leader, Dulce Maria Sauri, to remain in her post for a few months while party decides how to choose her replacement (M)

headline: Mystery Factor Is Pondered At AIDS Talk: Circumcision
abstract: Scientists at 13th international conference on AIDS, Durban, South Africa, explore puzzling but potentially important finding that circumcised men are much less likely to become infected than those uncircumcised; have come to suspect that circumcision is important factor in vast differences among African countries in rates of infection with HIV; compelling evidence from epidemiologic studies has led them to debate whether to promote large-scale circumcision programs as means stop epidemic; photos (M)

headline: I.B.M. EXPANDING VENTURE WITH RETEK
abstract: Shares of Retek, maker of software for retail sales industry, surge after IBM says it will take undisclosed equity stake in company (S)

headline: Washington Takes a Blast From Its Envoy At the U.N.
abstract: UN Amb Richard C Holbrooke, taking aim at both Congress and Clinton administration, says American reluctance to sufficiently pay for UN peacekeeping could cost US much more in emergency relief and direct involvement of US forces in future crises (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE  NORTHERN IRELAND: NO OBJECTIONS TO A PARADE Residents of the main Catholic neighborhood of Londonderry have dropped objections to a parade by 30,000 Protestants through the city on Saturday after rare direct talks between the rival communities produced agreements on limiting routes and reducing the police presence. Under an agreement hailed as a model for settling disputes during the so-called summer marching season, the Bogside Residents Association will not protest the annual parade by the Apprentice Boys organization celebrating the relief of the city in 1689 from the siege by the forces of the Catholic King James II.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

abstract: When the public schools in Exeter, N.H., gave Internet access to students in 1998, they chose not to use filtering or blocking software on classroom terminals, opting instead for a less restrictive combination of supervision and spot-checks.

abstract: Vodafone AirTouch is talking to Wind SpA about buying Infostrada, Italian fixed-phone company that Vodafone inherited as part of its purchase of Mannesmann of Germany; Wind's bid of 11.5 billion euros, or about $9.7 billion, exceeds 9 billion euro offer from Albacom, business phone consortium that is 23 percent owned by British Telecommunications (S)

headline: Annan Tells General Assembly to End Barriers
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan opens UN General Assembly with tough message charging that Assembly itself is more often than not the wall where innovative ideas crash; demands action on reorganizing and strengthening peacekeeping and enlarging Security Council to increase diversity and voice of developing world; his photo (S)

headline: Iran Assembly Pushes on Women's Rights
abstract: Iran's reformist Parliament shows its determination to forge ahead with social change and grant women additional rights by raising marriage age, changing law allowing fathers to marry off daughters as young as 9; will probably raise age to 15 or 16, although many reformers favor 18 (M)

headline: Give and Take on Napster
abstract: Yang Suh letter defends Napster software for sharing music files (June 29 article)

headline: New Economy; Latin America is a difficult -- but attractive -- region for e-marketplaces that are trying to enlist small businesses.
abstract: Operators of e-marketplaces, Internet portals through which companies do business with one another, are counting on power of Internet to break down traditional information and trade barriers that confine most small companies in Latin America to doing business within 30 miles of home; are still struggling to work out kinks that have so far impeded Latin America's small businesses from reaping benefits of Internet-based trade as they race to stake claim in market; drawing (M)

headline: Verizon Strike Settled in Full After Accord On Overtime
abstract: Vero

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    CHINA: EDITOR DETAINED  The Beijing police formally detained Bei Ling, the American-based editor of an independent literary journal. The move gives the authorities 30 days to investigate Mr. Bei. It is not yet clear why he was picked up, though the police have also seized several hundred copies of his journal, which carries a photo of the exiled dissident Wang Dan and a poem by a dissident literary critic, Liu Xiaobo.    Craig S. Smith (NYT)

headline: Mexico Imprisons Two Generals, Longtime Suspects in Drug Cases
abstract: Mexican prosecutors say that Gens Francisco Quiroz Hermosillo and Mario Arturo Acosta Chaparro have been arrested by military on charges of collaborating with Juarez drug cartel (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bank One Loss Fails to Scare Investors Away
abstract: Loss of more than $1 billion in second quarter is not enough to scare investors away from Bank One Corp stock; chief executive James L Dimon announces $1.91 billion restructuring charge that wipes out company's quarterly profit and leaves it with loss of $1.27 billion; bank also slashes its dividend in half; stock rises $2.625, or 8.8 percent, to $32.625, on trading volume of more than 12 million shares; several analysts express confidence in Dimon's ability to turn around troubled bank (Market Place column) (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; E-retailers turn to the printed page to put their wares before consumers.
abstract: Some online retailers, including RedEnvelope.com, eHats, Food.com and eZiba.com, mail out print catalogs to help sell their products, saving money and reaching Americans who are not connected to Internet; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls after OPEC tells its members to be prepared to increase output by 500,000 barrels a day to curb high prices; graph; chart (S)

headline: Competing Alliances Set In Electronic Book Field
abstract: Microsoft and Adobe Systems announce rival alliances that step up competition to develop standard format for electronic publishing; Amazon.com will open electronic book store on Microsoft Web site that will distribute free copies of Microsoft's Reader software; Adobe is buying Glassbook, smaller maker of software for reading on screen (S)

Study Says That Napster Increases Music Sales

abstract: Citigroup and America Online are teaming up to offer payment and other financial services on the Internet; financial terms undisclosed (S)

abstract: Diversity and G.E.

headline: Camp David Terms Roil West Bank Settlers
abstract: Many Jewish settlers on West Bank are roiled by outcome of Camp David summit, even though talks faltered; approximately 40,000 settlers, especially those around hot spots of Hebron and vicinity, will be left under Palestinian rule in any peace agreement; many must choose either to remain or accept whatever compensation is offered to return inside sovereign borders of Israel; feel government, which once regarded them as pioneers, is now rejecting them as liabilities; maps; photos (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of September 17 Grass-Roots business column on economic effects of reduced air service to Reno, Nev, which misstated surname of International Game Technology chief executive Tom Baker (not Butler) (S)

headline: Airbus Industrie Is Considering A Very Big Bet; Group Thinks Behemoth Jet Will Take on the Boeing 747
abstract: European Airbus Industrie group is close to introducing gigantic double-decker jumbo jet, known for now as A3XX, for use on long-distance routes like those between Asia and Europe or US; jet, with capacity of 555 to 800 passengers, would carry at least 140 passengers more than largest Boeing 747; its development cost would exceed $10 billion; Boeing remains skeptical, saying there is very limited market for such a plane; charts; photo (M)

headline: FOUNDRY SLUMPS ON SALES NEWS
abstract: Foundry Networks' shares drop $26, to $98.125, after company reports second-quarter sales that rose at slower pace than those of rivals; Foundry says sales rose 27 percent, to $88.8 million, from $70 million in first quarter; graph (S)

abstract: Shares of Stamps.com surges 33 percent after Intuit says it will add online postage provider to 2001 versions of its Quicken home and business financial software products; graph (S)

headline: AXA RESULTS DISAPPOINT
abstract: AXA SA's shares fall sharply after it reports 3.3 percent first-half rise in net income, lower than many analysts expected; net profit rose to 1.21 billion euros, or $1 billion, but property and casualty insurance income dropped 14 percent; graph (S)

headline: Violence by a Muslim Sect Stuns Malaysia
abstract: Malaysians are stunned by violence of Islamic sect members who looted two army camps in northern state of Perak, made off with armaments, seized four hostages and tortured and killed two of them before surrendering to security forces after jungle siege; Malaysia, with its large Chinese and Indian minorities, is model of multiethnic harmony; now there is fear that Muslim insurgencies in neighboring counties will spread to Malaysia; maps (M)

headline: New Initiative Aims to Make Devices Work Together Seamlessly : Fine-Tuning the Wireless Net
abstract: PARIS—  The standards are set, the licenses are being awarded, the smart handsets are on their way.

headline: PACCAR IS EXPECTED TO LAY OFF UP TO 500 IN OHIO
abstract: Paccar, world's second-largest truck maker, may lay off as many as 500 workers at plant in Chillicothe, Ohio (S)

headline: Bill Sends a Kind of Hush Over Bond Funds
abstract: Pending legislation to change the way government-sponsored agencies such as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are regulated could have profound effects on government bond funds; more than one-fifth of all assets held in such funds are Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac debt, which have come to be regarded as near-perfect equivalent to ultrasafe Treasury bonds (M)

headline: A CHINESE PLEDGE ON STOCK SALES
abstract: Finance Min Xiang Haicheng of China says government is committed to sell much of its stake in companies listed on the country's two stock exchanges to raise money to finance social security (S)

headline: WILMAR INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE HARDWARE DISTRIBUTOR
abstract: Wilmar Industries pays about $214 million for Barnett Inc, hardware products distributor and marketer (S)

headline: Compressed Data; I.B.M. Ads Give Starring Role To Its Unix Computer Servers
abstract: International Business Machines launches ad campaign for its Unix server that proclaims its superiority to those made by Sun Microsystems; photo (M)

headline: Iran's Well-Covered Women Remodel a Part That Shows
abstract: Comment on women in Tehran, Iran, who are getting a nose job, which is being viewed as a cool thing to do, in light of law in Iran that requires women to cover their hair and to conceal shape of their bodies in loose clothing; Iranian-women wear their post-surgical bandages like badges of honor, or at least indicators of a certain degree of wealth; getting a nose job is now seen fashionable, and facelifts are expected to follow; photos (L)

headline: KOREAN BANK WORKERS IN TALKS
abstract: South Korea's top economic officials reach modest breakthrough with bank union representatives, by getting labor officials to join working-level to discuss specific issues; Korea Financial Industrial Union has threatened to strike if government continues with its industry revamping, beginning witgh placement of weaker banks under financial holding company (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO SELL MASONITE SUBSIDIARY
abstract: International Paper Co is in talks to sell its Masonite Corp unit to Premdor Inc (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FLOWSERVE CORP., Irving, Tex., a chemical plant equipment company, agreed to sell a pump plant in Tulsa, Okla., in an attempt to win approval from the Justice Department for its proposed $775 million purchase of Ingersoll-Dresser Pumps, a unit of the Ingersoll-Rand Co., Woodcliff Lake, N.J.    MYND, Blythewood, S.C., a software company formerly known as Policy Management Systems, said it would not be receiving a bid from a second suitor, smoothing the path for the $16-a-share offer by the Computer Sciences Corp., El Segundo, Calif.

headline: Big Board Sues Web Impersonators of Chief
abstract: New York Stock Exchange files suit against ten unidentified persons on charges of impersonating its chairman and chief executive, Richard A Grasso, on popular Internet message board, Ragingbull.com (S)

headline: VERIZON WORKERS FORM PICKET LINES AS TALKS CONTINUE
abstract: Thousands of telecommunications workers form picket lines at Verizon's facilities along East coast as negotiators press efforts to end strike by 86,000 members of Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers; strike has disrupted operator-assisted services, repairs and installations for 25 million residential customers from Maine to Virginia; job action, over issues including outsourcing of work and unionization of workers in wireless industry, may help define role of organized labor in some of most rapidly growing high-tech industries; company has limited its impact by deploying about 30,000 managers to cover tasks normally performed by striking employees; photo; charts; maps (M)

headline: New Economy; AOL's rivals want to see its instant messaging system open up before a merger makes the company any bigger.
abstract: America Online's rivals are pressing to force company to open system that effectively bars users of their instant messaging services from exchanging messages with AOL's users in real time; Microsoft Corp is among dozen or so smaller players in market that decry what they call AOL's market-dominating behavior; Federal Communications Commission weighs issue as it reviews AOL's proposed merger with Time Warner; drawing (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of August 1 article about role played by Congressional candidates at Republican National Convention

headline: In Azerbaijan's New World, An Old Fox Clings to Power
abstract: Pres Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijian is presented with new challenge as Russia seeks to recapture lost influence in former Soviet republics; Aliyev, wily veteran of Soviet politics and of KGB, says closer cooperation is useful, but Russia must view Azerbaijan as equal, not as client state; Aliyev has been credited with bringing measure of economic stablity to his country, particularly by forging joint ventures with Western oil companies to exploit Caspian Sea oil and gas reserves; critics complain that little of promised oil wealth has trickled down to general population, and some accuse him of stifling political dissent by keeping opposition parties weak and substituting his strong personality for lasting institutional change; Aliyev scoffs at criticism; says he will run for re-election in 2003, rejecting concerns about his age, 77, and quadruple bypass surgery last year; photo; map (M)

headline: Germany Set To Overhaul Its Program On Pensions
abstract: FRANKFURT—  The German government will unveil a long-awaited overhaul of the state-run retirement system Tuesday in the latest reform of its once-sacrosanct welfare state.

headline: Fewer Inflation Alarms in New Fed Survey
abstract: Latest regional economic survey by Federal Reserve says economy has slowed, dampening demand and keeping consumer prices in check (S)

headline: 'Big Brother' Proves Another Big Hit for CBS
abstract: TV program Big Brother proves to be another ratings hit for CBS, pulling in 22.5 million viewers in its first broadcast July 5; show does reveal some signs that it may not have kind of phenomenal appeal, at least initially, that the other summer hits have demonstrated; photo (M)

headline: Somalis Get Leader; Now They Need a Nation
abstract: Abdikassin Salad Hassan, Somalia's first president in nearly decade, arrives in Mogadishu, escorted by 1,000 heavily armed militiamen; gets joyous welcome from Somalis packing soccer stadium, hopeful of end to civil war; flees stadium after nearly being crushed by well-wishers; warlords who had threatened to block new government take no action, with some of their followers bucking them to greet Salad; photo (M)

headline: Millions Phoning Online, Finding Price Is Right Even if Quality Isn't
abstract: Millions of people have begun to slash cost of their long-distance telephone calls by plugging into fast-growing trend for Internet-based voice communication; nearly two dozen companies have begun offering long-distance calls over Web--free or substantially cheaper than otherwise available; sound quality still has a way to go, but much of growing interest in so-called Internet telephony has to do with its relative simplicity; most users need only Internet hookup, headphones and microphone; roughly 15 million people in US use voice communication over Internet, compared with 5 million a year ago; combined revenue of Web talk providers is seen growing at compound annual rate of 200 percent a year over next several years, to $16.5 billion by 2004 from $208 million in 2000; Peter Boghossian, philosophy professor, comments on cutting his long-distance bill by making calls over Internet; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chronic Flight Delays Tied to Deregulation  Most experts now believe that delays in the nation's air traffic system, which have risen nearly 50 percent in the last five years, will get worse, not better. The Federal Aviation Administration, which runs the air traffic system, predicts that by 2010 the number of airline passengers will rise 59 percent, to 1 billion. About 70 percent of that increase will occur at the country's 28 largest airports.    The story of how the nation's air travel system reached its current crisis can be traced back to one of the Government's most successful economic initiatives -- airline deregulation -- and to one of its longest and most expensive bureaucratic blunders: the F.A.A.'s ill-fated attempts to develop a new air traffic control system. [Page A1.]

headline: NORWEGIAN PHONE STAKE SOLD
abstract: Tele Danmark and its main shareholder, SBC Communications, agrees to sell their joint 40 percent stake in NetCom of Norway to its Swedish rival, Telia, ending two-month deadlock; SBC, which owns 42 percent of Tele Danmark, will report pretax gain of about $500 million in third quarter from sale, while Tele Danmark will make gain of 1.7 billion Danish kroner ($206 million) (S)

headline: A Safe Player in the Market Embraces Risk to Save a Life
abstract: Carnegie Hero Fund Commission honors market analyst and financial adviser James Stack among 22 Carnegie Heroes; Stack, who is known for his conservative approach to investment risk, risked his life to save Randall Bruckner from drowning in Whitefish Lake, Mont, on April 11 (M)

headline: Management From the Sandbox
abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder On the Job column offers funny comments from children about their parents' jobs; drawings (M)

headline: Online Mediation
abstract: University of Massachusetts Center for Information Technology and Dispute Resolution director and SquareTrade.com consultant Ethan Katsh letter on August 20 article describes dispute resolution services provided by SquareTrade.com (S)

headline: Netpliance Is Betting That Less Will Be More
abstract: Netpliance announces upgrading of its i-Opener Internet appliance in preparation for a big retail push for the holiday season; photo (S)

headline: Good Screen Names Are Hard to Find And Getting Harder
abstract: Good screen names for e-mail addresses are getting harder to find, particularly at big Internet access providers, where so many names have already been claimed; e-mail services often suggest adding number to name already claimed; photos (M)

headline: Rockport is trying to change its stodgy image with a redesign of its shoes and a new campaign.
abstract: Stuart Elliott's Advertising column on new advertising campaign by AG Worldwide for Rockport Co, which is embarking on redesign of its footwear to make them seem less stodgy; photo (M)

headline: Infonet Said to Be in Talks About a Dutch Acquisition
abstract: Infonet, data communications company, has exploratory talks about buying Equant, Dutch telecommunications company (S)

headline: PRIVATE SECTOR; Gray Flannel Suit at the Dot-Com
abstract: Charles M Peck, the new chief executive of Theglobe.com, is an old-school executive who seems an odd fit at the formerly highflying Internet company; Peck has indicated he plans to expand and diversify company, not reinvent it; photo (M)

headline: Newsprint Operation Sold
abstract: Media General Inc sells its newsprint operation to Enron Corp for $72 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: HEATING OIL SOARS. Heating oil futures soar; graphs; other commodities results (S)

headline: Media, New and Old
abstract: Jane Pollak letter on Sept 21 article on wireless e-mail device

headline: TWO TOP EXECUTIVES QUIT DRKOOP.COM
abstract: Drkoop.com warns that its second-quarter losses will be more than Wall Street expects; chief operating officer Dennis Upah and chief financial officer Susan Georgen-Saad resign (S)

headline: Picket Lines Swell and Telephone Disruptions Spread in Strike
abstract: Strike by more than 86,000 workers of Verizon Communications intensifies as problems with local consumer telephone service begin to spread and picket lines swell in a 13-state region stretching from Maine to Virginia; chances of a quick resolution appear to grow more distant as negotiators hit a snag on several issues; business customers appear to be relatively unaffected by the strike, but residential service in scattered areas is knocked out by incidents of vandalism; photo (M)

headline: REMEC OFFERS $428 MILLION FOR ALLGON
abstract: Remec Inc offers to buy Allgon AB, Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, for 15.75 million of its shares in deal worth about $428.2 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: POTLATCH CORP., Spokane, Wash., a producer of paper and lumber, said it would shut a plywood plant in Jaype, Idaho, and dismiss 215 workers because of falling plywood prices.    CONAGRA INC., Omaha, completed its acquisition of International Home Foods, the maker of Chef Boyardee pasta and other products.

headline: New China Flights Put Old Foes at Odds; New York, Chicago and 3 Airlines Lobby Hard for Lucrative Market
abstract: New York City and Chicago are lobbying hard over which city will become take-off point for lucrative set of new flights to China scheduled to begin next April; in New York's corner is Delta Air Lines, which wants to fly to Beijing from John F Kennedy International Airport; American Airlines wants to fly from O'Hare International Airport in Chicago to Shanghai; bickering between Delta and American may help open door to another well-connected contender: United Parcel Service, since bilateral aviation agreement with China forces Transportation Department officials to choose between passenger and cargo carriers, rather than allocating routes to each separately; graph; photos (M)

headline: First Central Lab for Linux Research Planned
abstract: Intel, IBM, Hewlett-Packard and several other computer companies will jointly create and finance a laboratory for developing and testing advances in Linux operating system; laboratory, Open Source Development Lab, will be in Portland, Ore, and have several satellite offices around the country to support it; will be designed in particular to create Linux-based versions of the so-called enterprise software, which is used on superpowerful servers that automate corporate financial and human resource and customer service backbones; Linux has not made sinificant inroads in that area despite strong growth over all in operating system's market share (M)

headline: STANDARD CHARTERED ACQUISITION
abstract: Standard Chartered PLC will pay $1.32 billion in cash to buy Chase Manhattan Corp's Hong Kong credit card and retail banking division; acquisition will make Standard Chartered biggest credit card provider in Hong Hong with one-quarter of market; will finance acquisition by issuing 50 million new shares at 915 pence and by selling British subsidiary to Lloyds/TBS for 627 million pounds (S)

headline: STAKE SOLD IN SOUTH KOREAN BANK
abstract: Consortium led by Carlyle Group and J P Morgan has become largest shareholder in South Korea's KorAm Bank after acquiring 40 percent stake for 455.9 billion won ($412.6 million) (S)

headline: Wealthy Nations Plan a Doubling of Debt Relief
abstract: Financial leaders of rich nations plan to announce at annual meeting of international lending agencies high-profile drive to double to 20 number of poor nations granted debt relief by year's end; will reportedly ease conditions usually imposed on nations seeking relief; seek to defuse complaints of antiglobalism protesters that poorest nations have become increasingly indebted to rich at time of unprecedented prosperity; tables of nation's now getting debt relief and of likely new recipients (M)

headline: SINGAPORE LAND COMPANY DEAL
abstract: Singapore government-owned Pidemco Land Ltd and DBS Land Ltd agrees to merge through share swap to form largest listed property company in Southeast Asia, with total assets of 18 billion Singapore dollars ($10.34 billion); DBS Land will become unit of Pidemco Land after the merger (S)

headline: NOKIA FORESEES SLOWDOWN
abstract: Finnish mobile phone maker Nokia expects its third-quarter earnings per share to be below level in second quarter; reports second-quarter earnings were 951 million euros, or $887 million, up from 581 million euros a year earlier; graph (S)

headline: The Law's Spirit, Over Its Letter
abstract: Article profiles attorney David T Link, who designed ethical curriculum for faith-based law school of St Thomas University in Minneapolis; photo (M)

headline: Poland Spy Inquiry Said to Be a Failed Political Tactic
abstract: Many Poles and Western diplomats believe that Marian Krzaklewski, Solidarity's current leader and presidential hopeful, was behind charges that Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski and former Pres Lech Walesa spied for Communist secret police; special court has cleared both men, and Kwasniewski, now that he has been cleared, is almost guaranteed re-election; photos (M)

headline: EMI Says It and Time Warner Make Deal Concessions
abstract: Time Warner and EMI Group, in an attempt to keep European regulators from blocking $20 billion merger, propose what they call 'substantial' concessions that might include selling some of their record labels; deal still faces skepticism of European antitrust officials, who have threatened to block it if companies do not make big concessions (M)

headline: Suburban Genetics: Scientists Searching For a Perfect Lawn
abstract: Scott's Company, world's largest maker of lawn and turf products, is developing varieties of grass genetically altered to withstand applications of most potent weedkiller and remain healthy and green; is also developing varieties that grow at slower pace, reducing need for lawn mower, and strains that could be drought-resistant or bred to flourish in winter; other possible varieties described; products are not expected to reach market for at least three years; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; The air-traffic system approached gridlock over the weekend, with delays of up to eight hours.
abstract: Air Traffic system in United States approached gridlock over weekend, with delays of up to eight hours; only travelers who checked Federal Aviation Administration web site knew about severe problems at 40 airports; passengers at airports complain they were given virtually no information by airlines about delays (M)

headline: A Magazine Seeks Management Potential
abstract: Giveaway magazine aimed at MBA students, MBA Jungle, is formed by Ridgewood Capital and Korn/Ferry International to aid employers anxious for access to latest crop of MBA candidates (S)

headline: South Korea Opens the Gates to Pop Culture From Japan
abstract: SEOUL—  Like the Japanese youths in Tokyo's Harajuku or Roppongi districts, young South Koreans dye their hair bright blond, wear enormous platform heels, read Japanese comic books and listen to the hard-driving sounds of Japanese rock and rap bands.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RADIO ONE INC., Lanham, Md., the largest United States broadcaster serving black audiences, said it had completed its acquisition of 12 radio stations from Clear Channel Communications Inc., San Antonio, and AMFM Inc., Dallas, for about $1.3 billion. Including the acquisitions, Radio One owns 51 stations.

headline: A Tax Bite With Gaps In Turkey
abstract: Flourishing cash economy and other schemes to conceal income by business owners and self-employed people in Turkey is challenging country's efforts to control inflation and pay civil servants decent wage to complete its transformation from developing to developed nation; corporations pay about 40 percent in income tax and individual rates go as high as 55 percent; Ministry of Finance estimates that in recent years 5 percent to 10 percent of taxes go unpaid, but most experts view figures as conservative; under prodding from International Monetary Fund as condition for $3.9 billion loan, government has been working on new reforms; results of new rules, adopted in 1968 to increase compliance by basing taxes on declared earnings rather former assessment of standard of living were widely ridiculed (M)

headline: SBC TO SELL WIRELESS UNITS IN LOUISIANA TO ALLTEL
abstract: SBC Communications will sell some wireless assets in Louisiana to Alltel Corp for about $400 million to clear way for joint venture with BellSouth (S)

headline: Few Would Pay More for Irradiated Meat
abstract: WASHINGTON, Sept.5 -- Half of American consumers surveyed were willing to buy meat and poultry treated with irradiation to kill foodborne diseases, but only one- fourth were willing to pay extra for the products, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: Arnold Selected By Monster.com
abstract: Monster.com, job-search Web site operated by TMP Worldwide, ends two-year relationship with advertising agency Mullen in Wenham, Mass; billings estimated at $75 million to $90 million; account is in review (S)

headline: Modis Discovers a Way to Keep Its Owners in the Dark
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on how Modis Professional Services managed to keep from shareholders the figures for its accounts receivables, measure of how much customers owe but have not yet paid; notes that its chief executive, Derek E Dewan, and its chief financial officer, Michael D Abney, are both accountants, former managing partners of Coopers & Lybrand; says Modis treats its information technology division, its largest segment, as a discontinued operation because business is being spun off to shareholders; says fact that revenues at information technology division fell 14 percent is not good news; says fact that Dewan bought stock at $10.25 a share in April, or 25 percent more than current price, is encouraging; graph (M)

headline: Fuad Serag Eddin, 89, a Figure In Egyptian Politics for 50 Years
abstract: Fuad Serag Eddin, Egyptian politician, dies at age 89; photo (M)

headline: Evildoer, Kidnapper, Tamils' Hero, Rolled Into One
abstract: Veerappan, legendary bandit who kidnapped matinee idol Rajkumar, has defied expectations by not demanding huge ransom or amnesty for his crimes, but rather a list of demands for ethnic Tamils and the poor in South Indian states of Tamil Nadu and Karnataka; government has fulfilled several demands, and official emissary R R Gopal, a magazine editor, is venturing back to undisclosed jungle location to continue negotiations; looming question is what Veerappan will do with Rajkumar, who in taped statements has expressed great sympathy for his captor; there is risk of violence should he be harmed, and kidnapping has already provoked days of violent demonstrations in Bangalore, capital of Karantaka; map; photo (M)

headline: Give and Take on Napster
abstract: Gene Santagada letter says June 29 article on Napster failed to mention that real-time computer-to-computer file exchanges have been popular for years among users of Internet Relay Chat

abstract: Excerpts from communique issued by French government about crash of Air France Concorde, translated by The New York Times (M)

headline: 2 Executives Are Named To Head 20th Century Fox
abstract: News Corp names Jim Gianopulos and Tom Rothman as co-chairman of company's 20th Century Fox unit; photo (M)

headline: Cooking Up Humor
abstract: Naomi Siegel letter comments on the Krispy Kreme Web site (Sept 7 article)

headline: How do you sell a skimpy mink bikini? Call Frankie Avalon.
abstract: American Legend, maker of finest mink coat available, has begun print advertising campaign aimed at young women; campaign was created by Laspata/DeCaro with billings estimated at $2 million; photo (M)

headline: IRELAND CAPS LIQUOR PRICES
abstract: Irish government, worried about inflation, freezes liquor and some soft-drink prices in pubs, hotels and restaurants for six months (S)

headline: Stellar Second-Quarter Profit Expected From Nortel
abstract: Stellar Second-Quarter Profit Expected From Nortel

headline: Is It Back to School, Or to the Loan Officer?
abstract: Average family will spend $5,423 to prepare for new school year; this applies to students on all educational levels, from elementary school through college (S)

headline: Justice Dept. Clears SBC and BellSouth Venture
abstract: SBC Communications Inc and BellSouth Corp win Justice Department approval to create nation's second-largest mobile-phone company after agreeing to sell overlapping properties in 16 markets with 20 million people; those markets include Los Angeles, New Orleans and Indianapolis (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: GEMPLUS, Gemenos, France, named Antonio M. Perez president and chief executive. He comes from Hewlett-Packard, where he held the titles of corporate executive vice president, president for the consumer business and digital media solutions, and head of corporate marketing.     GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Stamford, named Joe Parsons, who led e-business at GE Capital, the finance unit of General Electric, to head its private investment unit, GE Equity. He succeeds Michael Pralle, who was named to lead GE Capital Real Estate, a GE Capital division. Mr. Parsons is succeeded by Mike Stout, who also remains chief investment officer at GE Capital's global consumer finance business.

headline: Blemished Goods For Bargain Hunters
abstract: Online Shopper column on Web sites that have replaced outlet stores as primary source for manufacturers' seconds at bargain prices; variety of sites can be accessed using 'blemished' as search term; tips for ordering noted; drawing (M)

headline: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?
abstract: Linda Kundell letter responds to Fred Brock's July 2 Seniority column on advertising industry's targeting of young consumers, despite growing wealth and numbers of older consumers; finds editorial style and content of Modern Maturity magazine irrelevant, preferring Fast Company magazine (M)

headline: Questioning the Labor Shortage
abstract: To alleviate apparent shortages of computer programmers, President Clinton and Congress have agreed to raise a quota on H-1B's, the temporary visas for skilled foreigners. The annual limit will go to 200,000 next year, up from 65,000 only three years ago.

headline: Random House To Establish Exclusively Digital Unit
abstract: Random House, largest United States trade publisher, plans to create new purely digital imprint; AtRandom will publish about 20 books that will be sold online as electronic books or in single copies printed on demand, but not be shipped to bookstores; all of biggest New York publishing houses are moving quickly to prepare for possibility that digital books will soon take off, seeking digital rights to new and previously published books; are beginning to set rules of digital publishing, from authors' royalties to prices consumers will pay (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Big Web Portals Lose Influence to Sites With Games
abstract: Subtle shift is taking place in balance of power between retailers and major Web portals they have relied on to send them business; Nielsen/Net Ratings finds that portals are losing their dominant position as source of traffic for e-commerce companies and that new category of sites is gaining influence in referral arena: sweepstakes and lottery sites; graph (S)

headline: Oregon to Put $1 Billion in Buyout Fund
abstract: Oregon Public Employees' Retirement System votes to invest $1 billion in new buyout fund from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, biggest commitment ever to private-equity pool; Kohlberg Kravis is aiming to amass as much as $10 billion for what would be world's biggest buyout fund (S)

headline: W.H.O. Says Files Show Tobacco Companies Fought Antimsoking Efforts
abstract: World Health Organization report says tobacco industry documents show industry took part for years in sweeping campaign to influence and undermine WHO's anti-smoking efforts worldwide; holds industry used network of front groups and groups with industry ties to thwart WHO; says industry consultants got posts at WHO-affiliated groups and that new rules are probably needed to require agency employees, consultants and advisers to disclose industry ties; report sheds new light on role played by Philip Morris chairman Geoffrey Bible, then head of company's international tobacco division, in 1988 in devising ways to undercut WHO; company says it has changed policies (M)

headline: Sun-Drenched Okinawa Is an Uneasy Place to Meet
abstract: Okinawa, Japan's choice as site of economic summit meeting, is backwater province plagued by tragic past and lacking infrastructure to handle major international gathering; Japanese and American officials fret about potential for mishap and mayhem, given Okinawans' anger at large US military presence; recent arrest of US marine accused of molesting schoolgirl heightens outrage among islanders who have vowed to disrupt summit meeting; about 27,000 people form human chain around Kadena Air Base; photo; map; Pres Clinton is first US president to visit Okinawa since it reverted back to Japan in 1972 (M)

headline: The Estate Tax's Pulse
abstract: Uncertainty over future of estate tax leaves confusion among wealthy attempting to shield their estates from taxation (M)

headline: FORD SAYS 78% OF DEALERS ARE BACKING ONLINE VENTURE
abstract: Ford Motor Co says 78 percent of its eligible member dealers have agreed to participate in FordDirect.com, which will sell cars and trucks on Internet at prices dealers pay; first online site is expected to be running in California in October (S)

headline: URUGUAY BREWER FOR SALE
abstract: Brazil's Cia de Bebidas das Americas, world's number 3 brewer, and France's Groupe Danone say they might buy Uruguay's number 2 brewer, Compania Salus (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPENO RELIEF IN IRISH INFLATION The inflation rate in Ireland remained at 6.2 percent in August, the highest in the European Union, according to figures released by the Central Statistics Office. The government said the rate would moderate by the end of the year, but Irish economists predicted that the worldwide increase in oil prices would push inflation up to 7 percent within the next few months. In response to the figures, three of Ireland's largest trade unions called for a renegotiation of the national wage agreement put in place when inflation ran at 2.5 percent.

headline: CHESAPEAKE ENERGY IN DEAL TO BUY GOTHIC ENERGY
abstract: Chesapeake Energy Corp, natural gas exploration company, will buy rival Gothic Energy Corp for $28 million in stock and will assume $316 million in debt (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Jury in Florida Awards $144.8 Billion to Smokers  A jury in Florida ordered the tobacco industry to pay $144.8 billion in punitive damages to 500,000 smokers in the largest damage award in United States history.

headline: Home Depot Ousts Operations President
abstract: Shawn McGhee is ousted as president of Office Depot Inc's North American operations; company names Bruce Nelson chief executive, replacing David Fuente; is looking for chief financial officer to replace Barry Goldstein, who is retiring; Robert Keller, former executive vice president, is named to new position of president of Business Services Group (S)

headline: Where G.E. Falls Short: Diversity at the Top
abstract: Article, assessing top executives at General Electric in light of impending resignation of chief executive John Welch and other recent changes, holds company's weakness is that it is run by white men; photos (M)

headline: Wobulenzi Journal; Young Man Decides to Wive It Wealthily in Uganda
abstract: Ahamadah Ntale has a vision for a new compact between men and women in Uganda, starting with him. A few weeks ago, he walked into the local office of one of Uganda's national newspapers and left the reporter with a story that ran with this headline: ''Man hunts old woman to marry.''    He is 25, a scooter taxi driver. He said he wanted a woman between 35 and 45, loving and free of AIDS. Most important, she would have to defy Uganda's tradition of men paying a dowry for their brides. The bride-to-be must cough it up to HIS parents.

headline: Local Issues Prolong Phone Strike in 6 States
abstract: Two days after more than 50,000 employees in Verizon Communications end 15-day strike in New York and New England, representatives for thousands of their colleagues continue to haggle with company over details of contract proposal, prolonging walkout in six Eastern states; overtime issue remains open in mid-Atlantic region (M)

headline: ASSEMBLY IN GAZA DEFERS DECLARING PALESTINIAN STATE
abstract: Palestinian leadership assembly bows to international pressure, postponing declaration of statehood and recommitting to Middle East peace effort despite deeply deadlocked negotiations; casts decision as forward-thinking rather than as defensive step; adjourns for up to two months, entrusting statehood aspirations to Yasir Arafat and senior advisers; Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak welcomes delay, but says he has no illusions about securing final peace agreement (M)

headline: Priceline Shares Fall on Word Sales Won't Meet Forecasts
abstract: Shares in online retailer Priceline.com fall more than 40 percent after company says its sales in third quarter will be as much as 11 percent below analysts' forecasts; company attributes shortfall to slow sales of airline tickets, it signature product, which still account for 87 percent of its sales (M)

headline: Intervention Means Winners and Losers
abstract: Central bank intervention in currency markets creates winners and losers in international finance and commerce; their manuevers to buoy sinking euro, down 13.7 percent against dollar this year so far, would benefit American exporters whose profits have suffered markedly because of euro's weakness; but foreign travelers' costs would rise (M)

headline: Investing; The Pocketbook Issues In the Future of Coach
abstract: Parent corporation of Coach Inc, Sara Lee Corp, might renege on its announced spin-off and public offering of Coach; selling its subsidiary privately could yield greater profit (M)

headline: Judge Rejects One Argument In Biotechnology Patent Suit
abstract: Judge overseeing patent infringement lawsuit by Amgen Inc against Transkaryotic Therapies eliminates one of Transkaryotic's defense arguments, weakening their position (M)

headline: People
abstract: Peter Bemis, president and creative director at Frankfurt Balkind West, Los Angeles, is named to additional new posts of partner and chief executive; Ann Pichette is named to new post of executive vice president and managing director for Sprint consumer long-distance account at Draft Worldwide; Jim Elms is named to new post of media director for Nike account at Wieden & Kennedy (S)

headline: French Concords Ordered to Remain Grounded

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    UKRAINE: ECOLOGICAL DISASTER -- With hundreds of villagers in south-central Ukraine complaining of skin rashes and other symptoms of environmental poisoning, President Leonid Kuchma, left, declared the region about 320 miles south of Kiev an ecological disaster zone. Some officials said the outbreak was caused by chemical spills from a Soviet-era missile base, but others said high concentrations of nitrites in drinking water and foodstuffs indicated high fertilizer concentrations may have contaminated water supplies.    Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

headline: Korean Defense Chiefs Meet
abstract: CHEJU, South Korea, Sept. 25 — In the most important meeting between the two countries since their historic June summit, defense ministers from North and South Korea met here today to discuss ways of lowering tensions across the world's most heavily armed border.

abstract: Goldman Sachs Group confirms plan to acquire Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, biggest trading firm on floors of nation's stock and options exchanges, for as much as $7.4 billion; will play $4.4 billion in stock and $2.1 billion in cash; Goldman expects to complete deal by end of year; photo (M)

abstract: France's Remy Cointreau SA acquires Bols Royal Distilleries for $461 million; graph (S)

abstract: Survey of 897 consumers whose household income is in top 25 percent nationally finds that 92 percent have home computers and 75 percent have Internet access, but only 3 percent have used Internet for any financial purpose and only 12 percent have made investment or bought a financial product online (M)

abstract: Profile of Ozires Silva, new president of Brazil's largest airline, Varig; Silva, former top executive of Embraer aircraft maker, comments on problems that he says confronts Varig; photo (M)

abstract: Zoesis Studios is starting Web site for interactive cartoon characters imbued with behavior that mimics human emotion; eventually hopes to create new medium of interactive entertainment parallel to television; drawing (M)

abstract: British and German regulators say London and Frankfurt stock exchanges have not yet devised adequate rules to guarantee financial transparency of what would be Europe's dominant transnational stock market after merger (M)

headline: To the Summit, Step by Step: Why Clinton Took the Risk
abstract: Events leading up to Pres Clinton's decision to broker talks between Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat at Camp David began with failure of Clinton's meeting with late Syrian leader Hafez al-Assad in Geneva in Mar; Geneva meeting made it clear that Israeli-Syrian peace effort was leading nowhere and focused attention on Arafat (M)

headline: Putin Is Acclaimed On Pyongyang Visit : After Decades of Sullen Isolation, North Korea Emerges as a Key Player
abstract: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, gave President Vladimir Putin of Russia the kind of rousing welcome on Wednesday that he had accorded to only one other visitor: President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea.

headline: Indonesia May Ask Help To Pacify The Malukus
abstract: Pres Abdurrahman Wahid says he might seek international assistance to halt 18 months of sectarian violence in Indonesia's eastern Maluku Islands, where rogue army units have taken sides in growing clashes between Christians and Muslims (S)

headline: A Message to Web Designers: If It Ain't Broke, Don't Fix It
abstract: Web users are becoming increasingly impatient with constant face lifts of their favorite sites or with sites that are difficult to navigate; designers note importance of reliability, speed, customization, and anonymity to increasingly sophisticated clients; biggest complaint about Web design is information overload, usually when companies have concentrated too much on design and content and not enough on how information is structured; revamping of sites can cause customer revolts, as evidenced by recent barrage of criticism that forced Salon.com to undo many of changes it made to its site; photos (M)

headline: Two Drugmakers Report Strong Earnings
abstract: Merck & Co and Pfizer Inc post strong gains in second-quarter earnings; net income at Merck increased 16 percent, to $1.72 billion compared with $1.48 billion in year-earlier period; sales rose 18 percent, to $9.54 billion from $8 billion; Pfizer says profit rose 21 percent, to $1.44 billion compared with $1.19 billion a year ago; sales rose 14 percent, to $7 billion from $6.5 billion (M)

abstract: July 27, 2000              Go to article

headline: Microsoft Asks Case Be Denied Fast Track
abstract: Microsoft Corp makes final plea to Supreme Court to send its antitrust case to federal appeals court for 'onerous task' of reviewing record instead of hearing appeal directly; Justice Department has urged court to hear appeal directly (M)

headline: Unstuffing Those Stuffy Staff Meetings
abstract: Dot.com executives throughout the country are shunning traditional corporate meeting spaces for more unorthodox sites, ranging from rooftops to parks, from pet shops to church choir lofts; believe introverted technology workers open up more readily in such settings than in a boardroom; photo (M)

headline: Auto Industry May Ease Safety-Ratings Stance
abstract: High number of sport utility vehicles that have rolled over because of defective Firestone tires has splintered auto industry's once-monolithic resistance to federal ratings of new models' tendency to roll over, increasing odds that such ratings will be imposed; regulators have been studying rollovers for 27 years, but industry lobbyists have appealed to members of Congress from auto-producing states to block periodic efforts to adopt rules that would address the problem; rollovers kill 9,500 of 41,000 Americans who die each years in crashes (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: US Treasury prices fall in thin trading; chart (S)

abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  None

headline: Israel´s Leader Faces Turmoil on All Side
abstract: JERUSALEM, Aug. 1 — Prime Minister Ehud Barak's political problems deepened today as his right-wing opponents, sensing blood with their stunning defeat of Shimon Peres, his presidential candidate, vowed new efforts to bring down his government.

headline: Netanyahu, In Atlanta, Is All Smiles
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu was among a crowd of oblivious techies here today, trying his best to pitch the merits of an Israeli telecommunications company while being repeatedly interrupted by calls on his cellular telephone.    ''Sorry, story's breaking,'' he said with a satisfied grin. ''It's a nice story to break.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: AT&T Considers Spinoff Of Long-Distance Business  AT&T is considering spinning off its long-distance telephone operation, the largest in the nation, as a separately traded tracking stock, people close to the company said this week.     One reason AT&T may want to issue a new stock to track the long-distance unit is that its shares have languished recently. AT&T hit a new 52-week low during trading yesterday and closed at $31.8125, down 31.25 cents. Management is eager to bolster the stock price and believes that issuing a tracking stock might accomplish that if the shrinking consumer long-distance unit was separate. [Page C14.]    E-Signature Bill Is Signed Into Law  President Clinton signed legislation giving legal weight to electronic signatures. At a ceremony in Philadelphia, the president used both the traditional felt-tip pen signature and the more high-technology method of inserting a signature card into a computer. [C3.]    Oracle's President Steps Down  Oracle, the world's second-largest software publisher, said that Raymond Lane, its president and chief opperating officer, had abruptly resigned. Mr. Lane, at Oracle for eight years, had held the post of president since 1996. [C3]    Doctors Seek Antitrust Exemption  Elated with a victory in the House, doctors opened a campaign to persuade the Senate to give them an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues. But the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said he would stand in their way. [A1.]    Personal Spending and Income Rise  Consumer spending rose by 0.2 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported, matching expectations. Americans' incomes, which include wages, interest and government benefits, rose 0.4 percent in May, slightly more than expected. [C3.]    2nd-Quarter Slump for Underwriters  The amount raised in the United States by investment banks in stock and bond offerings -- $451 billion -- was down 24 percent from the second quarter of 1999. Fees for underwriting new issues sank about 20 percent from $3.29 billion in the period a year earlier. [C14.]    $765 Million Investment in Italtel  Cisco Systems and the private investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice agreed to acquire 80 percent of Telecom Italia's computer network equipment unit, Italtel, for $765 million. The two investors hope that by forging an alliance with Cisco and by making the company independent from its Italian parent, it will become more competitive. The investors said they hope to sell shares of the new company to the public soon. [C4.]    Russia Exerts Control Over Gazprom  Russia's government strengthened its influence over Gazprom, the natural gas giant. Shareholders voted in a new board, tipping the balance to favor the government, which controls 38.4 percent of the company. The vote greatly reduced the influence of Gazprom's chief executive, Rem Vyakhirev, who had wielded tremendous power. [C2.]    Japan Rescues a Department Store  Japan's Financial Reconstruction Commission, the agency charged with overseeing reform in the banking system, said the government would spend 97 billion yen, or $924 million, of taxpayer money to help rescue Sogo, a highly indebted department store. [C2.]    U.S. Markets to Close Early  The stock market and other financial markets in the United States will close at 1 p.m. Monday and be closed on Tuesday in observance of the Fourth of July. Most overseas markets, however, will be open both days. United States markets will reopen on Wednesday.

headline: INTERWOVEN TO PURCHASE NEONYOYO FOR $70 MILLION
abstract: Internet software developer Interwoven Inc acquires Neonyoyo, developer of wireless technology, for $70 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Link Between Tires and Crashes Went Undetected in Federal Data
abstract: Statistics from widely used Transportation Department database, analyzed by The New York Times, show that fatal crashes involving Ford Explorers were almost three times as likely to be tire-related as fatal crashes involving other sport utility vehicles; Ford, Firestone and federal safety regulators say they never detected pattern; photo; graphs; tire flaw is now blamed for 88 deaths in rollovers; Firestone documents obtained by Congress show that contrary to testimony, executives knew in last February about rising warranty costs for tires recalled in August; Ford president, Jacques Nasser, told House hearing that despite recalls overseas, company's data did not show problem in US (M)

headline: JAPANESE INSURANCE ALLIANCE

headline: U.S., Fearing Swine Fever in Britain, Bans Imports

The key to the newest version is that it will be Internet-based, meaning employees and customers can use the program with a Web browser instead of tapping into an internal software program.    The stakes are high for PeopleSoft. Its software release is months behind those of its competitors, Oracle and SAP. Plus, PeopleSoft is coming off a disappointing year of flat revenue and a falling stock price. [Page C2.]

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: INTERNET FLAT-RATE PLAN HALTED The AltaVista Internet company has scrapped what would have been a breakthrough plan to offer flat-rate Internet service in Britain, asserting that it had run into roadblocks. In contrast to the United States, where AltaVista is based and where flat-fee and no-fee Internet access have encouraged use, Web users in Britain pay by the minute. New regulations forced British Telecommunications to offer Internet service providers like AltaVista wholesale unmetered service, which the companies can resell to consumers at a flat rate. AltaVista had signed up 270,000 subscribers.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

If an agreement is reached, it would be the symbolic end of the swachbuckling style of deal-making celebrated in the 1980's, which has been replaced by a blander type of investment banking. Market Place.
