headline: 20 Killed in Latest West Timor Attack
abstract: ATAMBUA, Indonesia, Sept. 8 -- The United Nations said 20 people were killed in fresh fighting in Indonesian West Timor on Friday, two days after the murder of three U.N. aid workers. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) agency in the East Timor capital, Dili, said the latest clashes occurred at the refugee camp of Betun, which had been taken over by pro-Jakarta East Timorese militias the previous night. ``The 20 casualties reported have been killed...we have no information so far about the wounded. We don't know whether they are Indonesian citizens or East Timorese," UNHCR operations manager for East Timor Bernard Kerblat told reporters. Betun is a stronghold for the militias which razed East Timor after it voted in August, 1999, to end Indonesia's military rule and who fear returning to their homeland, now under U.N. rule. The camp is just south of the West Timor border town of Atambua, where militias butchered three foreign UNHCR workers on Wednesday and mutilated their bodies. FUNERAL MAY HAVE BEEN TRIGGER About 1,000 people attended the funeral in Betun of a militia leader whose murder earlier this week is believed to have triggered Wednesday's violence. ``The funeral was quite tense because the mob, mostly in trucks and motorcycles, roamed the town first, forcing shops to close and residents to stay inside," an army intelligence officer said in Atambua. But he denied there had been any clashes. Kerblat said no aid workers were among the latest victims but gave no further information. The United Nations pulled more than 240 workers and dependents out of West Timor after Wednesday's slayings. Indonesia's cabinet spent most of the day on the issue but came up with nothing new to appease international anger over the militias and the murders. ``Indonesia will take wise, fair and realistic steps to seek a permanent solution," top security minister Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono said afterwards, adding investigations were continuing. President Abdurrahman Wahid did not attend the meeting. He is in New York for a special U.N. summit, where he faced angry world leaders over Wednesday's murders in Atambua. The killings overshadowed the start of the U.N. summit in New York, where a minute's silence was held for the three men from the U.S. commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Croatia and Ethiopia. At least six West Timorese residents also died in Wednesday's bloodshed and scores of houses were torched. REFUGEES ON THEIR OWN Atambua, about 2,000 km (1,200) miles east of Jakarta, was tense and deserted on Friday with almost no traffic and most residents shut up in their houses, fearing further trouble. The handful of people on the streets were too afraid to speak to visiting journalists, who were also turned away by hotels afraid their presence would bring trouble from the militias. The U.N. withdrawal leaves more than 120,000 East Timorese living in refugee camps in West Timor without any outside help. They were among more than 300,000 people the militias forced across the border from their homes in East Timor in a rampage that followed the territory's independence vote. Indonesian newspapers on Friday condemned the brutality as a national disgrace. The Jakarta Post demanded the military disband the militias it created in a failed bid to swing last year's East Timor vote. ``The Indonesian military, being the chief sponsor of the militias must be made to rein in its proxy soldiers, disarm them and arrest their leaders who have perpetrated the campaign of terror," it said in an editorial. And it urged the government to bring the army officers and militias behind last year's bloodshed to trial. ``Surely the government must now realise the shame and disgrace which the Atambua killings have brought on the entire nation is simply too high a price to pay to shield the dozens of murderous generals, colonels, lieutenants and militia leaders from having to appear in court," it said. U.S. President Bill Clinton, in New York for the U.N. summit, raised the killings at a Security Council debate on peacekeeping. ``I ask the Indonesian authorities to bring those responsible to justice, to disarm and disband the militias and to take all necessary steps to ensure the safety of those continuing to work on humanitarian goals there," Clinton said. Authorities have arrested 15 people over Wednesday's murders. Provincial military chief Colonel Jurefar told Reuters a company of reinforcements -- about 90 men -- had arrived in West Timor and the rest of the battalion was due later on Friday. ``They will establish order there with the police," he said. ``They will confiscate weapons."

headline: Generic-Drug Maker Agrees to Settlement In Price-Fixing Case
abstract: Generic drugmaker Mylan Laboratories tentatively agrees to pay $147 million to settle accusations that it improperly cornered market on raw materials for two widely prescribed drugs and then raised price of those drugs, in some instances more than 3,000 percent; if approved, settlement would be largest ever reached by Federal Trade Commission in an anticompetition case and would settle lawsuits filed by the commission, 33 states and variety of other drug purchasers, from large health maintenance organizations to groups of patients; would also break new legal ground by using most of money to reimburse consumers; settlement is also seen as important step in efforts by government to control rapidly rising medical costs; case concerns antianxiety drugs lorazepam, generic version of Ativan, and clorazepate, generic version of Traxene (M)

headline: CYBERONICS BOARD REJECTS OFFER FROM MEDTRONIC
abstract: Board of Cyberonics, maker of devices that treat epilepsy, rejects $480 million buyout offer from Medtronic, pacemaker manufacturer (S)

headline: The Right Strategy for Fox; Conservative Cable Channel Gains in Ratings War
abstract: Fox News Channel, cable television network created by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp to counter what Murdoch called CNN's liberal bias, is growing in ratings, household distribution and revenue; network's fight for acceptance as mainstream news source may be hindered by its perceived right-wing bias; graphs of market share; photo (M)

headline: NESTLE'S PROFIT SOARS
abstract: Nestle SA posts better-than-expected earnings for first half of year; net profit rose 35 percent, to 2.8 billion Swiss francs, or $1.61 billion, from 2.08 billion francs in year-earlier period (S)

headline: New Realism Wins the Day as Senate Passes Trade Bill
abstract: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 — The Senate's overwhelming vote today to give permanent trade benefits to China ended a clash between America's global economic interests and the notion that the United States could use the annual threat of trade sanctions to change Beijing's behavior.

headline: Financial Times Objects To Portrayal of Reporter

headline: MERCK WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR OSTEOPOROSIS DRUG
abstract: Merck & Co's bone-building osteoporosis drug Fosamax is approved by Food and Drug Administration for use in men; drug is expected to generate more than $1 billion in sales this year (S)

headline: CEPHALON SHARES DROP AS DRUG FAILS TEST
abstract: Cephalon shares drop sharply after company reports its narcolepsy drug, Provigil, does not improve symptoms of patients with attention deficit disorder (S)

headline: MARCONI IN DEAL FOR MARIPOSA

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    CZECH REPUBLIC: JEWISH CEMETERY -- The government has been sued in the European Court of Human Rights in a dispute over how to preserve a 13th-century Jewish burial ground on the Prague site where an insurance company is building its headquarters. The suit was brought by the Committee for the Preservation of Jewish Cemeteries despite a March agreement between the government and local Jews on encasing the cemetery in concrete, and building above and below it.   Steven Erlanger (NYT)

headline: Putting Photos of Wares Onto eBay Auction Site
abstract: Q.  I am a computer novice and would like to sell items on the eBay auction site. How do I add pictures of the items I wish to sell?    A.  To display pictures of your wares on the eBay site, you must have electronic copies of the photographs. Using a digital camera to take the photographs makes it relatively simple to upload the files to your computer and will save some steps.

headline: Do Students Need a Computer Time Out? Teachers Question Technology Report
abstract: Saying new technology can make more students eager to learn, elementary school teachers using the new tools in the classroom are questioning a recent study that calls for young children to take a "time-out" from computers.

headline: Glasses That Light Up the Day May Also Lighten Gloomy Spirits

headline: Everybody Has an Opinion, If Not a $15 Million Bonus

headline: Speaking English Is My Business

headline: Converging Forces Have Kept Junk Bonds in a Slump

Terms were not disclosed.    CALPINE CORP.,  San Jose, Calif., a power-plant developer with projects in 27 states and Canada, plans to build and operate a $430 million natural gas-fired 770-megawatt power plant in Haywood County, Tenn.

headline: Priceline.com Is Selling a $190 Million Stake to Two Investors
abstract: In a deal as complex as his patented method of selling airplane tickets, Jay S. Walker, the founder of Priceline.com , agreed yesterday to sell $190 million of his shares to Paul G. Allen's Vulcan Ventures and John C. Malone's Liberty Media Group .

headline: Gulf Grows Over the Use of Islamic Law in Nigeria

headline: Fujimori Takes Oath as Protests Blanket Area in Smoke

headline: Deutsche Telekom Stands To Gain a U.S. Foothold

headline: Who pays attention to television and radio commercials? Whispercode is watching.
abstract: Prestesting Co has devloped new system called Whispercode that measures exactly who is in a room or automobile at precise moment a television or radio commercial is broadcast (M)

headline: Ford Says Firestone Was Aware of Flaw In Its Tires by 1997
abstract: Ford Motor Co releases documents showing that in 1997 Bridgestone/Firestone began receiving numerous complaints of injuries and property damage involving certain Firestone tires that were not recalled until recently; discloses that some of recalled tires have rates of injury 100 times greater than for those not recalled; says many of claims were sent to Bridgestone by vehicle owners from 1997 to 1999 but that Ford was never informed; says it only learned of high rate of claims week ago, when it performed its own computer analysis of Bridgestone's data; Bridgestone reportedly resisted Ford's disclosure of information; Ford's new automobiles, particularly sport utility vehicles, are equipped with two-thirds of recalled tires (M)

headline: An industry group revamps its awards in an effort to improve the way women are portrayed.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: LAWMAKER TO QUIT -- Mo Mowlam, the former Northern Ireland secretary whose popularity among the Labor Party faithful and with the public has regularly exceeded that of Prime Minister Tony Blair, said she would not run for re-election to Parliament in the vote expected later this year. Reported to be unhappy at being replaced in the Ulster job in 1999 and given a marginal cabinet position, she said, ''I have several years of my working life left and want to do something different before I finally retire.''   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Defense Came in Several Packages, All Flawed
abstract: Dream of defense against ballistic missiles goes back to Eisenhower era, but it was in Persian Gulf War--first antimissile war--that support grew for kind of system that Clinton Administration was considering; diagram; photo (M)

abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc, second-largest maker of contact lenses, is in discussions to buy unidentified ophthalmic pharmaceuticals company outside US (S)

headline: G.M. Revamps Incentive Plan Even After Profits Rise

headline: INFORMIX WARNS ON PROFITS AND SHARES TUMBLE
abstract: Shares of Informix plunge deeply following software maker's announcement that second-quarter earnings would be below expectations (S)

headline: Times Is Sued By N.B.A. Over Sale of Photos

headline: As Hot Economy Pushes Up Overtime, Fatigue Becomes a Labor Issue
abstract: Problem of physical exhaustion on job is growing as tightest labor market in nearly 50 years leads to rise in overtime; backlash is growing around nation, in courts, state legislatures and labor negotiations, over expanding workweek; Maine, spurred by worker death, recently became first state to limit mandatory overtime; photo (M)

headline: Japan, Feasting on Whale, Sniffs At ´Culinary Imperialism´ of U.S.
abstract: TOKYO, Aug. 9 — To understand why Japan expanded its whale hunt ing activities last month, despite in ternational opposition, come to din ner at Taruichi, a festive whale-meat restaurant in Tokyo's trendy Shin juku district.

headline: Pentagon Security Gate Misfires, Injuring German
abstract: Germany's defense minister Rudolf Scharping is injured and briefly hospitalized after retractable steel security barrier springs up beneath motorcade on arrival at honors ceremony at Pentagon; German Embassy attache and American security aide are also injured; other similar incidents recalled (S)

headline: Trying Out a Different Set of Wheels
abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on rollators, push cart that helps people walk easily under their own power; notes rollators are popular in Europe but rarely seen in US; US importer Nick Thompson comments; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS

headline: Congress Appears Ready to Tackle Vehicle Rollover Problem
abstract: US Congress appears ready to tackle vehicle rollover problem in wake of 103 deaths attributed to defective Firestone tires, most of which occurred in Ford Explorers that flipped when their tires failed; automakers have blocked federal action on problem for 27 years; Sen Richard Shelby, chairman of Approppriations Subcommittee on Transportation, drops his objections to plan put forward by regulators last May to begin providing customers with information this winter on stability of many 2001 models; regulators have chosen to rate all family vehicles, giving them one to five stars, with highest ratings going to vehicles, like cars, that are very wide in proportion to height of their center of gravity; method does not take into account new electronic suspension systems that can improve stability; National Academy of Sciences will conduct nine-month study on ways to improve rating methods, and regulators will be required to reconsider their method based on academy's recommendations; graph (M)

headline: Proposed Transfer For Gas Line Stake
abstract: DTE Energy Co and MCN Energy Group propose transferring interest in natural gas line in Detroit to Unicom Corp to resolve concerns raised by Federal Trade Commission over DTE's purchase of MCN (S)

headline: Virtual Reality Comes Back In New Guise: Collaboration
abstract: Biggest names in industry and many start-up companies use Siggraph convention in New Orleans to unveil latest products for high-technology tasks like computer animation, data compression, virtual reality and three-dimensional imaging and prototypes from emerging technologies; many technologies seem to be pushing hard to expand beyond current boundaries; photos (M)

abstract: Reliance Group Holdings Inc, which is teetering on edge bankruptcy, cedes control of its finances to Pennsylvania Insurance Department (S)

abstract: Anchor Gaming will buy about 4.6 million of its shares from its chairman, Stanley Fulton, and members of his family; deal is valued at $306 million (S)

ATLANTIC COAST HOLDINGS INC., -- Dulles, Va., a regional airline, announced a firm agreement to buy three Canadair regional jets from Bombardier Inc. for about $66 million and a conditional offer for 27 more.

headline: As Profits Soar, Corporate America Takes On More Debt
abstract: Floyd Norris column on growing debt of corporate America; notes that corporate debt equals 46 percent of gross domestic product, up from 38 percent five years ago; says as evidence mounts that economy is slowing, credit markets are becoming tighter, junk bond market is becoming reluctant to finance many companies and banks are growing more cautious; graph (M)

headline: Gundersen Acquires British Company
abstract: Gundersen Partners LLC, which specializes in executive searches for marketing, advertising and communications companies, has acquired Bucher/Rugman in London, which has similar specialties; financial terms undisclosed (Advertising column) (S)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: The Opposite of Amazon.com; Small Stores Plug Chinks in the Mortar With the Web
abstract: National Trust for Historic Preservation survey of more than 1,500 businesses in 16 downtwon commercial districts nationwide indicates that the Internet can spur sales in storefront retail businesses; finds that small retailers seem to do best in virtual world by focusing on unusual products or aiming to give excellent, personalized customer service; shows that some 16.4 percent of Main Street businesses polled are already using Internet to sell things; finds merchants that sell online have experienced 12.8 percent increase in overall sales; Mary DeFore who runs small boutique with her husband, James, in Thomasville, Ga, and Fred Wilber, who owns small music store in Vermont, comment on success of their Web sites; graph; photos (M)

headline: BRITISH CONTROL OF GERMAN COMPANY
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC confirms it will take control of Viag Interkom, German telephone company, by doubling its ownership stake to 90 percent in deeal worth $6.73 billion in cash; seller is E.On AG, German energy concern; British Telecom chief executive Peter Bonfield comments; photo (S)

headline: Some Say Morgan Lost Independence by Trying to Be True to Founder´s Goals
abstract: Nearly a century ago, the House of Morgan and its founder, J. Pierpont Morgan, preserved the American financial system in the midst of a widespread panic.

headline: In Effort to Save Lives, South Africa Creates an Anti-AIDS Campaign That Minces No Words
abstract: South Africa launches advertising campaign laced with hard-hitting, erotic phrases to encourage young people to talk freely about sex and risks of teenage pregnancy, AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases; down-to-earth campaign is aimed at reducing by one-half rate of infection from HIV in five years; 4.2 million infected people in South Africa represent largest such group in world (M)

abstract: Links to voter registration Web sites are appearing on sites of candidates, political parties and other groups in current election year (S)

abstract: Diageo PLC of Britain reportedly holds preliminary talks with Bacardi Ltd and several others about forming a joint venture to make bid valued at more than $7 billion for spirits business of Seagram Company (S)

abstract: IBM acquires Aragon Consulting Group for undisclosed terms to add marketing research services for its Internet clients (S)

headline: Whoever Wins, Vote in Mexico Will Be Fateful
abstract: Mexicans prepare to vote in presidential that will usher in period of uncertainty whether or not PRI maintains long grip on power; opposition candidate Vicente Fox Quesada has pledged to rule with caution, but victory would shatter elite; new win by PRI would outrage many in educated and middle classes; profiles of candidates (M)

headline: BARNESANDNOBLE.COM BUYING FATBRAIN
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com will buy Fatbrain.com for $64 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: CENDANT EXPECTS EARNINGS TO BE IN LINE WITH ESTIMATES
abstract: Cendant Corp expects third-quarter earnings to be in line with analysts' estimates (S)

headline: South Koreans Impatient For Return of Prisoners
abstract: SEOUL—  After Amnesty International reported in 1994 that a former South Korean schoolteacher named Ko Sang Moon was a prisoner in a North Korean concentration camp, Mr. Ko appeared on North Korean television saying he was married and doing fine. His wife in South Korea committed suicide.

headline: For Mac Users, Help From an Unlikely Quarter
abstract: MacIntosh users may have easier time in a Windows world now that Microsoft has spun off a unit to create Mac software from ground up, instead of merely recycling old Windows code into Mac versions of its programs (State of the Art column) (M)

headline: T-Online CEO Keuntje Resigns for Personal Reasons
abstract: T-Online CEO Keuntje Resigns for Personal Reasons

headline: E-Commerce Report; Advertisers are turning to specialists to handle their e-mail marketing campaigns.
abstract: FloNetwork and other companies arise to help e-mail marketers handle the challenges they face, which range from privacy issues, like getting permission to send e-mail to customers, to technical hurdles in composing, sending and tracking large volumes of mail; complexity of delivering customized messages is one of main reasons marketers choose to work with a technology company specializing in e-mail services; photo (M)

headline: Little Action Expected From Report on Auto Fuel Use
abstract: Government report reaches few conclusions about effects of tightening federal fuel-economy regulations for automobiles, making it virtually certain that regulations will not be changed by Congress before end of 2000; Sen John McCain, who is chairman of Commerce Committee, ordered report from General Accounting Office last spring, when high gasoline prices were prompting outrage among motorists (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: List of key rates on government bond issues

headline: Online Shopping Boosting Traditional Retailers When Store Sales Lag
abstract: August 23, 2000

headline: U.S. to Withhold Money for Haiti's Presidential Election
abstract: US will withhold observers and financial aid for Haiti's presidential elections in November because of government's unwillingness to recalculate results of recent legislative elections that gave overwhelming and disputed majority to party of former Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide; will also scrutinize all other development aid to ensure that it does not go directly to government, but through private nongovernmental organizations; will review hundreds of millions of dollars in loans pending before international financial institutions (M)

headline: High Court Says Appeals Court Should Review Microsoft Case
abstract: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Supreme Court handed a victory to the Microsoft Corporation today when it summarily rejected the government's plea to immediately hear the appeal of its landmark antitrust case and instead returned the proceeding to an intermediate appeals court, in effect prolonging the legal battle by at least a year.

headline: DEUTSCHE POSTE TO OPEN NETWORK
abstract: European postal regulators order Deutsche Poste, Europe's largest mail company, to immediately open part of its delivery network to United Parcel Inc; order means Deutsche Poste must now forward many United Parcel packages to their final address at discount; ruling is setback for Deutsche Poste, which has purchased controlling stake in DHL International (S)

headline: Daimler Seeks More Control Of Mitsubishi
abstract: DaimlerChrysler, which has based its hopes for Asian expansion on partnership with Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, is demanding more control in the wake of a scandal over defective cars that has engulfed Mitsubishi; Daimler executives say they want more control over Mitsubishi, in which Daimler has been planning to pay $2 billion for 34 percent stake; but they refuse to say what form that control might take; Japanese television reports Daimler executives are demanding that their stake be increased at no extra cost to 40 percent; police again raid Mitsubishi offices in search of documents that might provide basis for charges of criminal cover-up; photo (M)

headline: Hilton's Earnings Climb 14%
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp reports second-quarter net of $88 million, compared with $77 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: POSTAL STAKE FOR SALE
abstract: Germany plans to sell about 25 percent of Deutsche Post, which has set provisional date of Nov 6 for its initial public offering (S)

headline: Modest Job Growth Helps Major Market Indexes Rise
abstract: Report of slowed job growth helps markets end higher; Nasdaq Composite up 27.48 at 3787.36; DJIA up 61.17 to 10,767.75; S&P 500 up 10.37 to 1462.93; yield on 30-year bond falls to 5.71 percent; graph (M)

headline: F.C.C. Promises Close Scrutiny Of German Bids
abstract: Federal Communications Commission chairman, William E Kennard, says that because Deutsche Telekom is controlled by German government, any offers it makes to buy American telephone company will face heavy regulatory scrutiny; says important national security and competition questions would require close examination; Deutsche Telekom has made offer to acquire US-based VoiceStream Wireless Corp for about $53 billion; photo (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: Beyond the Glass Ceiling; Women's M.B.A. Program Is Redefining Its Mission
abstract: Graduate School of Management at Simmons College in Boston, which was established as an all-woman program in 1974 in order to ensure students a classroom environment free from male dominance, now sees its goal as grooming women for advanced leadership roles as chief executives; new focus means not teaching women how to mimic men, or even women, but to be individuals with their own leadership qualities; Simmons program is still the only all-woman business management program, and its enrollment is growing even while other business schools, now far more hospitable to women, struggle for applicants; photo; graph (M)

headline: GENZYME TO PURCHASE GELTEX PHARMACEUTICALS
abstract: Genzyme Corp acquires GelTex Pharmaceuticals for $1 billion in cash and stock (S)

headline: As Price of Progress, Turkish Villages Are Flooded
abstract: Villages along Euphrates and Tigris rivers in southern Turkey that were inhabited since beginning of civilization are being flooded into watery oblivion by vast dam system, and way of life is being erased for tens of thousands of people who live in places of great archaeological value and those in historically insignificant hamlets, like village of Samsat; destruction is price of progress as Turkish government is in final years of its largest public works project to improve economy of impoverished region; photos; maps (M)

headline: Print Magazines Introduce Embedded Web Links
abstract: Print Magazines Introduce Embedded Web Links

headline: MERRILL SHUTTING SHOPPING SITES
abstract: Merrill Lynch is pulling plug on two Web sites designed to help its brokerage customers make consumer purchases, Shopmerrill.com and Merrillauctions.com (S)

headline: Mexican Murder Suspect Is Sought by U.S.
abstract: US seeks extradition from Mexico of Agustin Vasquez Mendoza, who is suspected of the 1994 murder of Richard Fass, an American anti-drug agent (S)

headline: Nasdaq Amends Proposal For a New Trading System
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market officials revise plan for more centralized system for executing stock trades in response to criticism that original plan would treat some investors' orders unfairly; under new plan, an attempt to mollify operators of electronic communication networks, known as ECN's, Nasdaq will no longer post prices on its system based on inclusion of ECN access fees; new plan will allow users to choose which market participants want to deal with (M)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS HUGHES WINS SATELLITE WORK New ICO , the satellite communications company soon to merge into Craig O. McCaw's ambitious Teledesic satellite venture, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Hughes Space and Communications Company on plans for Hughes to produce 14 satellites. The agreement includes 3 new satellites and modifications to 11 spacecraft that Hughes had in production when ICO Global Communications, New ICO's predecessor, filed for bankruptcy just over a year ago. Mr. McCaw led a group that brought the company out of bankruptcy for $1.2 billion and forged plans for a satellite system capable of offering a range of data and Internet services in addition to the voice traffic ICO Global had envisioned. The network is now scheduled to begin operations in 2003. Hughes said the satellite design was one of the most complex ever undertaken. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

headline: Music for Nothing
abstract: Mike Stoller letter says it is not fair that he and other songwriters and the musicians who perform their music are deprived of royalties due on recordings that are downloaded with with the aid of Napster (June 29 article)

headline: Radio Interference
abstract: G Chris Boynton letter on July 20 article on electronic fences for dogs

headline: TOYOTA EXPECTS STRONGER RESULTS
abstract: Strong foreign sales cause Toyota to expect to report higher earnings than it had anticipated; profit forecast is raised by 43 percent (S)

headline: Trading Opens in Vietnam; Officials Limit Stock Prices
abstract: Socialist Republic of Vietnam opens first-ever stock market; session lasts two hours, offers two stocks and total value traded was almost $5000; fledgling market is cramped by scarcity of sellers and government-imposed ceiling on permissible bids; implicit is government's acknowledgement of right of private ownership and of its transfer; photo (M)

headline: On a New Map, the Income Gap Grows
abstract: Analysis of Internal Revenue Service figures shows that average after-tax income of richest 1 percent of Americans soared, albeit unsteadily, by 89 percent between 1986 and 1997, to $517,713, while bottom 90 percent rose scant 1.6 percent, or $364, to $23,8008; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: SHAS CHIEF'S SENTENCE UPHELD -- The Supreme Court denied a request for a new hearing on a three-year jail term for fraud, bribery and breach of trust imposed on Aryeh Deri, former leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. It ordered Mr. Deri to begin his sentence on Sept. 3. Mr. Deri, a charismatic former interior minister of Moroccan descent who built Shas into a powerful legislative bloc, was convicted of taking bribes at the Interior Ministry.   John F. Burns (NYT)

headline: N.T.T. RETREATS ON CONNECTION FEES
abstract: Shares of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's former telephone monopoly, climbed 6.4 percent after the company indicated it would bow to pressure to lower fees it charges other carriers to hook into its local network at a faster pace. N.T.T. also sharply increased its earnings forecasts to 172 billion yen from 99 billion yen because of growing dial-up Internet use by consumers.   Stephanie Strom (NYT)

headline: A Top Earner for Cambodia / 'You Haven't Seen Anything Yet' : Angkor Wat:After the War, Here Come the Tourists
abstract: BANTEAY SREI, Cambodia—  Seated in the shade of giant trees that tower above the exquisite temple of Banteay Srei, six amputees, all victims of the war, invasion and civil conflict that wracked Cambodia for decades, played haunting folk tunes on traditional instruments.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: OFFER TO VOTERS  The European Union, in a policy coordinated with the United States, offered to lift sanctions on Serbia and provide aid if a candidate opposing President Slobodan Milosevic wins elections scheduled for Sunday and is allowed to take office. In a ''message to the Serbian people'' issued in Brussels, the Europeans urged Serbs to use their vote against Mr. Milosevic. On Saturday American officials made a similar offer. Steven Erlanger (NYT)    MONTENEGRO: MILOSEVIC AWAITED  President Slobodan Milosevic is expected to make a campaign visit to northern Montenegro tomorrow, said the Yugoslav prime minister, Momir Bulatovic. Mr. Bulatovic, left, heads the pro-Milosevic opposition party in Montenegro, whose government is urging its people to boycott the vote on Sunday and is edging toward independence from Serbia.    Steven Erlanger (NYT)

headline: The Very Model Of Conciliation
abstract: New mediation program at US Postal Service has reversed growing number of complaints lodged by employees against management; lawyers at Postal Service, as part of settlement of class-action lawsuit in 1994, created program called Redress to settle disputes using neutral outside mediators, and tested it in few cities before rolling it out nationally in 1997; in first 22 months of full operation, from September 1998 through June 2000, 17,645 informal disputes were mediated under program, and of those, 80 percent were resolved; former Postal Service lawyers Cynthia J Hallberlin and Mary S Elcano, now with private law firm Brown & Wood, have set up service to resolve job disputes at other coporations that is based on process in place at post office; drawing; graph; photo (M)

headline: Cooper Tire May Become Focus of a Safety Investigation
abstract: Natioanl Highway Traffic Safety Administration is considering opening investigation of Cooper Tire and Rubber Co; agency head Dr Sue Bailey says her office has recently become aware of lawsuits asserting that dozens of deaths and serious injuries had been caused by premature tread separations on tires made by Cooper; review of accident reports and court records by The New York Times shows that early tread separation in Cooper tires has been named as cause of accidents that led to at least 35 deaths over last six years; Copper denies company's tires are defective or unusually prone to deadly separations (M)

headline: U.S. to Move Against Japan Over Whales
abstract: White House plans to declare that Japan has violated international whaling rules by expanding whale hunt this year, and will start process that could lead to economic sanctions against Japanese imports within two months; Japan claims that Bryde's and sperm whales are being harpooned in North Pacific for scientific research, but whale meat remains delicacy in Japan (S)

headline: Report Questions a Number in Microsoft Trial
abstract: Richard B McKenzie of University of California at Irvine contends that there are probably fewer than 10,000 Windows programs in use today and that most users probably have no more than a handful on their computers; Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's antitrust ruling against Microsoft Corp was based on trial testimony that there were 70,000 programs written to run solely on Windows operating system; that figure was not contested by lawyers for Microsoft, and indeed its marketing and advertising materials in 1997 claimed that as many as 100,000 programs existed for Windows operating system (M)

headline: ABITIBI-CONSOLIDATED PLANS CUTS AT NEWSPRINT PLANTS
abstract: Newsprint maker Abitibi-Consolidated will close US mill and slow down Canadian plant; goal is improvement of profits (S)

headline: Fashion Marketers Plan Changes
abstract: Bali Co, parent of Sara Lee Corp, names Shahid & Co to handle advertising for its Bali, Barelythere and Wonderbra apparel brands; billings estimated at $10 million; account had been handled by TBWA/Chiat/Day; L'Oreal names LaMicela New York as third ad agency of record for its consumer products division; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: UTILITY SAYS PROFITS WILL BEAT ESTIMATES IN 3RD QUARTER
abstract: Reliant Energy Inc expects its third-quarter profit to exceed analysts' estimates, buoyed by wholesale power sales in California region and its utility in Houston (S)

headline: Blair's Disenchanted Kingdom: Strike Takes a Toll
abstract: News analysis: protests over fuel prices which brought Britain to virtual standstill also claimed as victim Prime Min Tony Blair's eight-year-long lead in opinion polls that Labor Party has held over Conservatives (M)

headline: Excite@Home to Merge International Operations With Chello
FIVE QUESTIONS; Politics and Deutsche Telekom
abstract: Five Questions column offers excerpts of interview with Deutsche Telekom chairman Ron Sommer on company's expansion plans in US and elsewhere; photo (M)

headline: Summit Bancorp Said to Discuss Acquisition by FleetBoston
abstract: Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, is in talks to be acquired by FleetBoston Financial Corp; executives will not disclose terms of deal, but analysts estimate bank could be sold for $7 billion (M)

headline: Indonesians Ponder the Law, Their Hearts, Suharto's Fate
abstract: Indonesians are abuzz with anger and frustration over court ruling that former Pres Suharto is too ill to stand trial on charges of embezzling $590 million; streets of Jakarta are strangely quiet in wake of riots set off by decision; Pres Abdurrahman Wahid, on state visit to Brazil, calls verdict biased and says government plans appeal; photo (M)l

headline: V.I.P.'s Are Helped Through Kennedy by a V.B.P. (Very Busy Person)
abstract: Sgt Vito Asparro of Port Authority police, who is in charge of dignitary protection at Kennedy International Airport, is busy preparing for mass exodus of world leaders from United Nations Millennium Summit; photo (M)

headline: Beating the Market, Until the Expenses Pile Up
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column, based on studies by University of Maryland finance Prof Russ Wermers, concludes that while average stocks bought by fund manager outperform market, return declines when expenses are factored in; graph (M)

headline: 2 Views of Mideast Peace
abstract: News analysis: there is a go-for-broke quality to Israeli and United States approach to coming Camp David summit meeting, but for Palestinians there is at best an aspiration that three-way meeting will serve as stopgap to keep stalemated peace effort alive so that a partial deal can be achieved by September; Prime Min Ehud Barak will come to meeting as a weakened leader with goal of pushing peace effort to a conclusion before he loses his grip on power; similarly, Pres Clinton appears to have decided that he cannot make things worse by forcing the parties into an endgame; but Yasir Arafat, whose lifelong struggle rests on this effort, will approach summit far more skeptically and cautiously, taking part against counsel of his senior advisers, who think groundwork has not been laid for compromise on any major issues (M)

headline: Agencies Selected By Toysrus.com
abstract: Toysrus.com names Los Angeles office of D'Arcy Masius Benton and Bowles to handle its strategic and creative advertising account; billings estimated at $25 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: PEPSICO SAYS VICE CHAIRMAN WILL RETIRE IN EARLY 2001
abstract: Pepsico Inc announces retire of its vice chairman, Karl von der Heyden (S)

headline: Economy Grew At 5.6% Rate In 2nd Quarter
abstract: Commerce Depatment reports gross domestic product grew at 5.6 percent annual rate in second quarter compared with first-quarter pace of 4.8 percent; Labor Department reports initial jobless claims fell by 24,000 last week, to two-month low of 287,000; graph (M)

headline: Microsoft to Ask High Court Not to Hear Its Case Now
abstract: Microsoft to Ask High Court Not to Hear Its Case Now

headline: SONY PLANT PLANS
abstract: Sony Corp will spend 100 billion yen ($942 million) over next five years on a new plant in Japan to produce microchips used in mobile phones and digital cameras (S)

headline: 'Big Brother' Host Seeking Credibility
abstract: Julie Chen, CBS news reader who is a host on Big Brother, a show managed by CBS Entertainment, is reportedly rejecting lines from show's scriptwriters that she thinks would undermine under journalistic credibility; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Phone Strike Drags On As Contract Talks Continue  As Verizon Communications prepares to enter its fifth day of bargaining with its striking unions, the question arises: Has Verizon gotten more with this strike than it bargained for?    As the walkout by 86,000 workers of Verizon, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, has developed into one of the most unruly strikes in years, doubts are growing over the company's preparation for the contract talks and its handling of the strike. [Page C8.]

headline: Cohen Warns Indonesians To Disband Timor Militias
abstract: US Defense Sec William S Cohen warns Indonesia that troubled country will face severe diplomatic and economic reprisals if fails to disband militia groups accused of killings and of causing havoc in divided island of Timor; expresses grave disappointment in meetings with Pres Abdurrahman Wahid and other top officials that government has failed to disarm pro-Jakarta militia that is accused of killing three unarmed UN workers on September 6 in West Timor; photo (M)

headline: Plan for Swiss to Pay Nazi Victims
abstract: Court-appointed master submits complex plan for distributing $1.25 billion in settlement payments by Swiss banks to Holocaust victims; $800 million would be set aside for Holocaust survivors or heirs who can show they held accounts in Swiss banks during World War II era (S)

headline: Ameritrade Shares Driven Up By Talk of Possible Takeover
abstract: Ameritrade's stock is driven up by speculation that fifth-largest online brokerage firm will be acquired by American Express Co (M)

headline: People
abstract: Michael McKenna, executive vice president and chief operating officer at Marsteller Advertising, New York, is names president and chief executive...Robert Cosinuke is named president of Digitas, Boston...Robert M Copeland is named senior vice president at Young & Rubicam (S)

headline: Addenda
abstract: Two Executives Leaving Saatchi

headline: 2 Ex-Executives Are Indicted In Fraud Case
abstract: Albert J Bergonzi and Jay P Gilbertson, former co-presidents of HBO & Co, medical software company, are indicted on charges of of using sham deals and bad accounting to inflate company's revenue and earnings by hundreds of millions of dollar; HBO & Co was acquired by McKesson in January 1999 for $14 billion; when merged McKesson HBO announced that its auditors had discovered fraud in April 1999, it shares fell almost 50 percent in one day, leaving investors $9 billion poorer; McKesson HBO stock has yet to recover; lawyers for Bergonzi and Gilbertson deny criminal charges, as well as related civil complaint filed by Securities and Exchange Commission; Dominick A DeRosa, former HBO vice president, agrees to pay more than $411,000 to settle SEC complaint against him in the case; DeRosa is not charged in criminal case and is cooperating with prosecutors (M)

headline: Time Warner to Let Internet Provider Use Cable System
abstract: Time Warner Inc, seeking regulatory approval for its planned acquisition by America Online Inc, makes its first deal to give independent Internet service provider access to its cable system; reaches preliminary accord with Juno Online Services Inc to offer high-speed Internet service to cable customers; plans to renegotiate exclusive deal with Road Runner LLC, its joint venture with AT&T and only service provider currently available to its subscribers (M)

headline: Internet Companies Aren´t as Sexy to Landlords Anymore
abstract: Internet Companies Aren't as Sexy to Landlords Anymore

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: Technology Briefings

headline: Code Name: Mainstream; Can 'Open Source' Bridge the Software Gap?
abstract: President's Information Technology Advisory Committee will recommend bridging the looming software gap facing the nation by adopting the open-source model: distributing software free and openly publishing underlying source codes so that other programmers can study, share and modify the author's work; open-source advocates say aim is not to destroy profit motive of software industry, whose members jealously guard source codes as a company's private property, but rather to bring software development into the Internet era by sharing knowledge widely, allowing programmers to build on each other's work and accelerate the pace of software debugging and improvement; companies in the open-source economy would make money mainly by tailoring programs for customers, and with service and support; photos; graph (L)

headline: Georgia-Pacific to Acquire Fort James
abstract: Georgia-Pacific Group will acquire Fort James Corp for $7.5 billion in cash and stock, creating world's largest maker of tissue (M)

headline: A Victory of Sorts for Abortion Rights in a Mexican State
abstract: Mexican abortion rights groups celebrate victory against resurgent efforts by conservative politicians and church leaders seeking to chip away at already limited rights to abortion after Gov Ramon Martin Huerta sends backs to state Congress for further study bill passed by Legislature that would have made state only one in Mexico to extend ban on abortions to cases of rape; map; photo (M)

headline: Step Right Up and Buy a Megawatt!
abstract: Pacific Gas and Electric has started online program in California called E-Bid that pays some big electric customers to cut their consumption during peak periods; program detailed; graph (special section, E-Commerce) (M)

headline: Motorola Seeks Ideas For Global Strategy
abstract: Motorola is asking agencies that handle its advertising duties, McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Leo Burnett USA and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, with combined billings estimated at $150 million, for ideas that could be used for global brand strategy (S)

headline: Asian Giants May Struggle for Gold
abstract: TOKYO—  China has 1.2 billion people to choose from and Japan is the world's second richest country. With such manpower, money and history, you might expect the two nations to be gearing up for a flood of gold medals at the Olympics.

headline: Online Funds, Built To Order
abstract: Folio (fn), Internet-based start-up service which lets investors build and trade their own baskets of stocks for $29.95 monthly fee, serves those eager to manage their own investments; photos (M)

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Soliciting Billions for Fund
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co is returning to some of its oldest customers to start what may be the world's top buyout fund; partners, George Roberts and Michael Michelson, are to appear before executives of the Washington state pension fund to solicit $1.5 billion; pitch follows by a week decision by Oregon's pension system to allot $1 billion; Kohlberg Kravis is raising fund that could reach $10 billion, which would pass $6 billion fund being raised by Thomas H Lee & Co (S)

headline: PRATT & WHITNEY GETS $200 MILLION JET ENGINE ORDER
abstract: Pratt & Whitney unit of United Technologies Corp wins $200 million order from International Lease Finance Corp for jet engines for eight Airbus Industrie aircraft; value of deal could climb to $450 million if International Lease exercises options for 10 more Airbus A330 aircraft (S)

headline: Hutchison Buys 51% of Andala In Permit Quest
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa, holding company owned by Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, buys 51 percent of Andala, giving the Italian company money to bid for a mobile phone license; Hutchison will join with Tiscali, an Italian telecommunications and Internet company, in bid for one of five licenses Italy will sell this year; Tiscali's stake in Andala is cut to 25.5 percent from 58 percent (M)

headline: Eye of the Beholder
abstract: Nigel Pond letter on Peter H Lewis's Aug 24 article holds quality of recording made on DVD Video Recorder cannot be higher than that of tape it copies

headline: SEMPRA TO INCREASE STAKES IN THREE ARGENTINE UTILITIES
abstract: Sempra Energy, owner of big California natural gas utilities, acquires stakes in three Argentine utilities held by Dominion Resources Inc for $145 million; Sempra Energy will get 21.5 percent stakes in companies that serve 1.2 million customers in Argentina, raising its stakes to 43 percent; Sempra is also buying 25 percent of company with controlling interest in electricity supplier serving more than 400,000 customers in province of Buenos Aires (S)

headline: Program Raises the Specter Of Viruses Attacking P.D.A.'s
abstract: The first malicious program to attack a Palm organizer appeared on the Internet this week, causing no permanent damage but leading security experts to warn that more harmful incursions are probably around the corner.    The program, known as Liberty Crack, is a not a virus because it does not automatically replicate. For that reason, most experts believe that it is already nearly extinct.

headline: A 'Tough' Plane, Almost All the Time
abstract: Pilots who have flown Concorde, commenting on Air France crash, say plane is tough and robust, but impossible to control should it lose side-by-side pair of engines at low speed just after takeoff; insist Concorde's design would not have contributed to disaster (M)

headline: ANOTHER INFUSION FOR DOME
abstract: British authorities acknowledge that more public financing will be given in subsidies to keep Millennium Dome open until end of year; grant will total around $110 million (S)

headline: REPUBLIC GROUP SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING SALE OR MERGER
abstract: Republic Group, faced with declining profits because of lower prices and slowing sales of gypsum wallboard, hires J P Morgan Securities for advice on sale or merger of company (S)

headline: Online Firm to Give Jobs to Top Stock Pickers
abstract: August 18, 2000

headline: People
abstract: Walter Coyle is named senior vice president and media director at Pedone & Partners, New York (S)

headline: NET STRONG AT HOUSEHOLD GIANT
abstract: Reckitt Benckiser says net income for second quarter grew 15 perecent, to 71 million pounds, or $106.5 million; revenue rose 4 percent, to 807 million pounds, or $1.21 billion (S)

headline: Financial Issues Jump, but Others Are Mostly Lackluster
abstract: Dow Jones stock average rises 59.34 points, or 0.5 percent, to 11,139.15; Nasdaq composite index gains 5.06 points, or 0.1 percent, to 3,958.21; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 1.35, or 0.1 percent, to 1,498.13; graph; chart (M)

headline: CADBURY IN PEPSI DEAL
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes PLC of Britain will buy Pepsi Cola Bottlers Australia to increase its market share in carbonated soft drinks; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: New Economy; A military agency spends billions on seemingly fantastic projects to ensure U.S. battlefield supremacy.
abstract: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, agency that played key role in funding development of Internet, other technologies of today's information-driven economy, outlines current agenda for symposium of engineers and high-technology executives; projects, all aimed at preserving technological superiority of United States military, include extremes in miniaturization like molecule-size computers; agency is increasingly looking for ways to repackage civilian technology for military as cost-effective alternative to sponsoring novel projects; drawing (M)

headline: Chase Manhattan Said to Be in Talks to Acquire J.P. Morgan
abstract: Chase Manhattan is close to reaching a deal to acquire J.P. Morgan & Co. Inc., for $30 billion or more executives close to the deal said today. Details of the negotiations were not immediately available, although these executives said an announcement could come as early as Wednesday morning.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AFRICA PRIVATIZATION PLAN ADVANCES The South Africa Government presented its most comprehensive plan yet for the privatization of the largest state- owned companies, saying it would sell off stakes in the nation's power utility, rail system and port operator and offer shares in the telephone compa ny and national airline. While the strategy has been in the works for months and many major points have been discussed, the announcement signaled an effort to consolidate the plans and accelerate the process. Officials would not dis close the timetable for each of the entities, saying only that they hoped the process would be com pleted by 2004.   Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

headline: In Managed Personal Accounts, A Challenge to Traditional Funds
abstract: Assets in privately managed accounts, also known as 'wraps,' have swelled in last few years as bull market has helped double number of millionaire households since 1983, to five million; threshold for such accounts can be as low as $50,000, but private portfolio managers typically look for at least $100,000 in investable assets (M)

headline: Article 2000092792839216536 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Hewlett-Packard Is in Talks to Buy Consulting Unit
abstract: Hewlett-Packard and PricewaterhouseCoopers confirm they are discussing sale of PricewaterhouseCoopers management and information technology consulting practice to Hewlett-Packard, which is expected to pay $17 billion to $18 billion in cash and stock; Hewlett-Packard cautions that some terms of transaction have not been agreed upon and that significant issues remain to be resolved, leaving open possibility that deal might yet unravel (M)

headline: Study Finds That Most Austin High-Tech Workers Are From Texas
abstract: Study Finds That Most Austin High-Tech Workers Are From Texas

headline: Beleaguered Indonesian Unveils New Cabinet
abstract: Pres Abdurrahman Wahid unveils revamped cabinet in move to revitalize his faltering administration and tackle acute social and economic woes that are threatening to tear Indonesia apart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar reaches a six-year high against the British pound on speculation that interest rates in Britain may be near a peak (S)

headline: Price of Tyco Unit Surges at Offering
abstract: TyCom Ltd raises $2 billion in its initial public offering, about 50 percent more than expected; Tyco International Ltd, TyCom's parent, sells 61.1 million shares at $32 each (S)

headline: Egypt Says Democracy Backer Spied for U.S.
abstract: Egyptian state prosecutor today expands list of accusations against Saad Eddin Ibrahim, prominent democracy advocate detained since June 30 without being formally charged, to include espionage for US; Ibrahim and supporters believe imprisonment is meant to prevent him from monitoring parliamentary elections scheduled for November; Pres Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party holds 97 percent of seats in People's Assembly, but elections have usually drawn charges of voter fraud; Egyptian Constitutional Court has ruled that last three parliamentary elections were flawed (M)

headline: Russia Seeks Way to Secure Its Grip on Chechnya
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin makes surprise visit to Mozdok military base near Chechnya to review deteriorating security situation in breakaway republic; reportedly convened meeting of top aides to consider military and economic steps to secure Russia's hold on area (M)

headline: Investing; Look Who's Smiling in A Sideways Market Year
abstract: Article on rising fortunes of stock brokers despite fact that market has not moved much more than 4 pecent from its December 31 level; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: A Context for Spending
abstract: Nathan Dungan, vice president of stewardship and brand development at Lutheran Brotherhood, offers advice on how Americans can avoid becoming entangled in a 'web of hypnotic consumption' (S)

headline: LABEL OWNER SUES MP3.COM
abstract: Zomba Recording files lawsuit against MP3.com, accusing it of willful copyright infringement in relation to its MyMP3.com site; photo (S)

headline: Hope Erodes for Azerbaijan's Sea of Refugees
abstract: Approximately one million Azerbaijani refugees who fled Nagorno-Karabakh after outbreak of fighting in 1992 between Armenians and Azerbaijanis remain scattered throughout 40 or more camps in Azerbaijan, former Soviet republic whose promised oil riches have yet to materialize; they are insufficiently cared for by their government and on verge of abandonment by international aid organizations; Western diplomats and humanitarian workers say Azerbaijani government is using camps as political pawns in its efforts to negotiate return of Nagorno-Karabakh, which represents 20 percent of its former territory and is occupied by ethnic Aremenians; government reached cease-fire with Armenian forces but no peace agreement that would allow refugees to return home; photos; map (M)

headline: Bias Case Against Morgan Stanley Settled
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co ends most embarassing chapter in its history when employee Christian Curry agrees to drop discrimination lawsuit and firm drops its countersuit; Curry, who is black, posed nude for gay men's magazine, was subsequently dismissed from his job; Morgan Stanley will donate $1 million to National Urban League, money that it would have spent on legal defense; says Curry gets nothing (M)

headline: Europe Phone Auctions:Too High?
abstract: PARIS—  At a summit meeting in Lisbon this year, European Union governments laid out an ambitious plan to overtake the United States in the Internet age by building an economy based on high technology and communications.

headline: Strong Gains Return Nasdaq to Positive Ground for Year
abstract: Nasdaq composit indes gains 143.17 points, or 3.6 percent, to close at 4,099.59, best finish since start of slump April 10; Dow Jones industrial average gains 56.57 points to close at 10,783.76; graph (S)

headline: NISSAN SELLS DRIVE SHAFT MAKER
abstract: Nissan Motor Co will sell its driveshaft division to GKN Japan Ltd and concentrate on its core business (S)

headline: Moscow Arrests Suspects but Can´t Link Any to Fatal Bombing
abstract: MOSCOW, Aug. 9 — Russian law enforcement officials said today they had detained a number of suspects in their investigation into the terrorist bombing of an underground pedestrian walkway that killed 7 and wounded 97 on Tuesday evening. But they said that so far none could be directly linked to the bombing in the heart of the Russian capital.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Consumer Borrowing -- June    TUESDAY  U.S. Productivity -- 2nd. Qtr.

headline: Luxury Products Makers in Europe Reporting Rising Profits, Revenues
abstract: PARIS, Sept. 14 — As booming economies around the world fuel the consumption of luxury goods, some of Europe's largest luxury goods retailers are reporting strongly improved sales and profits in the first half of the year.

headline: MICROSOFT ADDING LONG-DISTANCE
abstract: Microsoft Corp plans to announce availability of technology that will allow consumers to make free long-distance phone calls in US and Canada using company's MSN instant messaging service on Internet; technology, which uses network belonging to Net2Phone, is expected to increase popularity of making phone calls over Web (S)

headline: Splendid Maya Palace Is Found Hidden in Jungle
abstract: Archaeologists uncover ruins of vast and splendid Mayan city in remote Guatemalan jungle; photo; map; diagram; eighth-century palace at Cancuen had 170 high-ceilinged rooms built around 11 courtyards; Dr Arthur A Demarest of Vanderbilt University says earlier expeditions underestimated grandeur of palace and city that was prosperous center of commerce and crafts on Pasion River; Dr David Freidel explains importance of site; expedition co-leader is Tomas Barrientos (M)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Loses Ruling
abstract: Toys 'R' Us, largest US toy retailer, loses appeals court bid to overturn Federal Trade Commission finding that it tried to use its market influence to keep top-selling toys away from rival discounters like Costco and BJ's Wholesale Club (S)

headline: Gtech's 2 Top Executives Resign Amid Controversy
abstract: William Y O'Connor resigns as Gtech Holdings Corp's chairman-chief executive, and Stephen P Nowick resigns as president-chief financial officer; departures are result of board's dissatisfaction with unexpected announcement that revenue will fall short of expectations; W Bruce Turner will step in as nonexecutive chairman (M)

headline: Three Neo-Nazis Are Convicted of Murder of African Immigrant
abstract: Judge Albrecht Hennig finds three young neo-Nazis guilty of murder in beating death of an African immigrant, Alberto Adriano, in Dessau, Germany; finds Adriano was killed because of his skin color; cites need to put end to long series of such attacks in former East Germany; sentences Enrico Hilprecht to life imprisonment; sentences two juveniles, Christian Richter and Frank Miethbauer, to nine years in detention; Chancellor Gerhard Schroder calls for mass movement against racism and urges police and courts to crack down on extremists (M)

headline: Corporate Debt Offerings Planned for the Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    America Online Latin America Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., an initial public offering of 25 million class A shares. Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: F.T.C. SUES WEB SITES OVER BILLING
abstract: Federal Trade Commission and New York State attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, sue owners and operators of network of sex-oriented Web sites, including www.playgirl.com and www.highsociety.com, asserting they illegally billed thousands of people for services that were advertised as free and that they charged many others who never visited Web sites at all; suit contends Crescent Publishing Group, along with 64 affiliated companies, routinely charged people who provide credit card information obstensibly required to verify they were over 18 before they could view sites (S)

headline: K2 Design branches out into the risky realm of wireless services with acquisition of SilverCube.
abstract: K2 Design, which handles Internet marketing for advertisers like Hewlett-Packard and IBM, will join with Uniwired Ventures I, a venture capital partnership, to indirectly acquire for $14.8 million a majority interest in SilverCube Inc; Silvercube is a wireless professional services company that specializes in strategy and content development for the new generation of cellular telephones, pagers, hand-held computers and other devices that deliver text in form of news headlines, e-mail and advertisements (Advertising column) (M)

headline: NEWS CORPORATION BUYBACK
abstract: News Corp may buy back as much as 6.5 percent of its preferred shares, move that would help company pay for expansion; graph (S)

headline: With AT&T at the Brink, Pressures Rise at the Top

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Saudi Pledge Drives Crude Down 5.6%
abstract: Price of crude oil for August delivery on New York Mercantile Exchange drops $1.83, or 5.6 percent, to $30.67 a barrel, after Saudi Arabia's statement that it is ready to pump 500,000 more barrels a day; some analysts contend that Saudi Arabia wants to push price of crude oil below $30 a barrel and will do what is necessary to accomplish that goal, no matter the OPEC politics; OPEC's president, Ali Rodriguez of Venezuela, says there will be no production increase until there is agreement among all group's members; says he has been assured that Saudi Arabia will not act alone; graph; photos (Market Place column) (M)

abstract: TEHRAN—  Iran's conservative leadership on Tuesday closed the country's last major progressive newspaper, just days after the supreme leader, Ayatollah Sayed Ali Khamenei, declared that the progressive press threatened the national interest.

abstract: Ashanti Goldfields says second-quarter pretax profit dropped 54 percent, to $7.9 million, hurt by decline in price of gold (S)

abstract: Gavin Casey, chief executive of London Stock Exchange, resigns in wake of exchange's failure to merge with Frankfurt Stock Exchange; photo (S)

abstract: Fred Brock (Seniority) column wonders why advertisers and television networks go to great lengths and pay more to reach younger audiences when demographic statistics indicate the growing segment of population over 50 possess half the nation's disposable income, and people over 65 have twice the discretionary income of people ages 25 to 34; drawing (M)

abstract: California Prune Board receives Food and Drug Administration approval to rename prunes 'pitted plums' in attempt to boost sales; photos (M)

abstract: Ford Motor Co, which expects to equip over million of its new cars and trucks for wireless services by end of 2002, plans joint venture with Qualcomm; new company is tentatively called Wingcast (S)

abstract: Intel Corp agrees to buy closely held Trillium Digital Systems Inc for about $300 million in cash and stock, giving the largest computer chip maker more software for building networking products (S)

headline: Telnet Still Available For Cruising the Web
abstract: Q.  What is Telnet and what can it do? I have Windows 98. Can I use Telnet?    A.  Although it is not used as much as it once was because of the Web, Telnet can still be a good way to connect to other computers from your own machine. It is a text-based system that dates to the 1970's, and some users who are used to point-and-click browsing may find Telnet a bit arcane. If one doesn't mind the old-fashioned interface of typed commands and numbered choices, however, it is a speedy way to connect to systems like online library catalogs and electronic bulletin boards.

headline: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?
abstract: Iris Kaufman letter responds to Fred Brock's July 2 Seniority column on advertising industry's targeting of young consumers, despite growing wealth and numbers of older consumers; finds advertisers are focusing on population that is forming brand loyalties and buying first homes (M)

headline: Web Services Offer Solutions to Bookmark Overload
abstract: Online services help organize bookmarked Web sites; photo (M)

headline: Producer Prices Fell in August And Retail Sales Slackened
abstract: Labor Department reports producer prices fell unexpectedly and Commerce Department says retail sales cooled in August, indicating that economy is unlikely to ignite inflation; prices paid to producers fell 0.2 percent, first drop since May; through August, overall Producer Price Index rose at 3.2 percent annual rate, compared with 2.8 percent pace for first eight months of 1999; core index increased at 1 percent annual rate, compared with no change in period a year earlier; retail sales rose 0.2 percent, compared with 0.9 percent increase in July; sales were 7 percent higher than those in month a year earlier; Labor Department says number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose 13,000 last week, to 324,000, highest in 20 months and suggesting slower growth is leading to more layoffs; graphs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ruling by Arbitrator Splits Arthur Andersen in Two  An international arbitrator ruled that the world's largest consulting firm could separate from the the world's largest accounting firm.    The ruling frees Andersen Consulting, with 65,000 employees, from its parent company, which now consists entirely of Arthur Andersen, a tax and auditing firm with 77,000 employees. In exchange, Andersen Consulting will have to give up its name and pay Arthur Andersen $1 billion. Analysts called the decision, coming at the end of a three-year battle, a major victory for the consultants. [Page A1.]    Bear Stearns Settles a Lawsuit  Bear Stearns, the sixth-biggest United States securities firm, paid $30 million to settle a lawsuit over its role as an adviser on an ill-fated takeover, said lawyers involved in the case. The case sent tremors through Wall Street two years ago when a federal jury in California found the firm was negligent in the way it advised its client, Daisy Systems, on a 1989 purchase of Cadnetix, and awarded $108 million in damages to shareholders. The judge later reduced the award to $36 million. [C2.]

headline: THAT OWNS HYATT HOTELS WILL BUY CHAIN OF INNS
abstract: Hyatt Corp's Pritzker family agrees to buy US Franchise Systems Inc, franchiser of Microtel Inns and Suites, for $99.8 million; deal negates June agreement for family to invest $75 million to gain controlling interest in US Franchise (S)

headline: Napster: Unplugged?
abstract: Michelle Leake letter disputes Matt Richtel's July 9 contention that societal forces push college students toward using Napster, which she sees as mere part of churn in business cycle/

headline: Stephen King Sows Dread in Publishers With His Latest E-Tale
abstract: Stephen King plans to become first major author to self-publish on Internet, offering his new book, The Plant, in electronic installments available for downloading from his Web site; says he hopes to spur online publishing; shocked major publishers into jump-starting their digital books when he got Simon & Schuster to publish his novella Riding the Bullet in electronic form in Mar; new launch spurs debate over whether Internet can liberate authors from dependence on publishers, or just make it easier for famous people to rally their fans; Simon & Schuster says it backs King effort; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline rises more than 4 percent after major refinery in New York region is shut down for unscheduled maintenance; gasoline for delivery in August rises 3.77 cents, to 95.03 cents a gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Sugar Talks Between Mexico and United States Break Down
abstract: Protracted dispute over sugar trade between Mexico and US escalates when Mexicans reject US proposal and requests special arbitration hearing under provision of North American Free Trade Agreement; American side calls Mexican request inappropriate; American Sugar Alliance, coalition of US sugar producers, says it is shocked and disappointed; Mexican officials argue that Nafta allows them to export up to 575,000 tons a year of their excess sugar to US beginning Oct 1; US maintains that Nafta allows for only 110,000 to 120,000 tons (S)

headline: Northern Ireland Paralyzed By Unionist Demonstrations
abstract: Demonstrations by Protestant Orange Order succeed in paralyzing Northern Ireland; Orange Order was angered at being barred from staging annual march through Catholic neighborhood in Portadown; its militants are vehemently opposed to new power-sharing Catholic-Protestant government; maps; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WorldCom in Talks to Buy Communications Concern  WorldCom is in advanced talks to acquire Intermedia Communications, a telecommunications operator in Tampa, Fla., for almost $3 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the negotiations said.    Intermedia has been an attractive takeover target because it has a 54 percent stake in Digex, which provides Web-hosting services for corporate sites. WorldCom entered negotiations with Intermedia after talks between Intermedia and Global Crossing broke down. A third suitor, Exodus Communications, offered to acquire Digex directly but was rebuffed by Intermedia. [Page C2.]

abstract: Appeals Court rules that pilots' union, Air Line Pilots Assn, and its leaders must pay $45.5 million in damages to American Airlines for ignoring judge's order to end 1999 work stoppage; ruling follows by one day union's rejection of contract extension (M)

headline: Leader Moves To Dominate Civic Groups In Venezuela

headline: U.S. Seeks China's Help in Slowing the Flood of Illegal Immigrants
abstract: Doris Meissner, head of Immigration and Naturalization Service, holds talks with officials in Beijing, hoping to get commitment for more help in stemming huge flow of illegal Chinese immigrants into United States; service estimates that tens of thousands of Chinese are smuggled in each year; Western governments say international criminal gangs are making huge profits in illegal human trade; Chinese officials say relatively liberal American political-asylum process encourages poor Chinese to try their luck at emigration; Meissner counters that only 13 percent of political asylum claims by Chinese are successful (M)

headline: NORTEL WINS CHINA AND TAIWAN DEALS
abstract: Nortel Networks of Canada wins two contracts worth $525 million to build wireless telephone systems in China and Taiwan; one contract, worth $250 million, is for 1,900 new base stations for cellular telephone and Internet transmission for Chunghwa Telecom in Taiwan; second $275 million, contract is with Zhejiang Unicom in China to install infrastructure and software for wireless Internet services (S)

headline: Young Techies Say No to College
abstract: While his fellow seniors at Tiffin Columbian High School spent last year preparing for college, John- Thomas Gaietto set his eyes on heading straight to the pros. Distracted in school, Mr. Gaietto focused his energy and extracurricular time honing his skills and nurturing his natural gift.

headline: Barak Seeks to Limit Use of Religious Privileges in Israel
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak, surprising even some of his closest political associates and enraging his ultra-Orthodox opponents, tells supporters he plans to push 'civil reform' through Parliament that among other things would strip Jewish religious establishment of many privileges and powers; unexpected announcement, coming at time when Barak faces fast-approaching deadline in talks with Palestinians and several political challenges at home, leaves much of country wondering about his motives; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: ECOMMERCE LABEL OWNER SUES MP3.COM Zomba Recording said it had filed a lawsuit against MP3.com , the online music distributor that only last week was found in violation of copyright law in a similar suit filed by the Universal Music Group . The lawsuit accuses MP3.com of willful copyright infringement in relation to its MyMP3.com site, a service that lets users listen to the company's CD collection over the Internet. Zomba's Jive label records some of the biggest pop acts today, including Britney Spears, above, the Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync. A sister company, Zomba Music Publishing, filed a separate suit on the same ground. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT) LIFETIME INVESTS IN WOMEN.COM In a deal that could lengthen the life span of the beleaguered Web site Women.com , the company announced yesterday a joint equity and promotions agreement with Lifetime Entertainment Services, a joint venture owned by Hearst and Walt Disney . Lifetime Entertainment Services said it would purchase a 4.6 percent equity position in Women.com, while Women.com will purchase $10 million in advertising on Lifetime Television over three years. Hearst now owns 46 percent of Women.com. Susan Stellin (NYT) BIOTECHNOLOGY ULCER DRUG WORKS IN TRIALS Human Genome Sciences said yesterday that its drug for wound healing had accelerated the repair of chronic venous ulcers in an early Phase 2 clinical trial. The drug, repifermin, is a natural human protein and is believed to be the first drug discovered using genomics that has shown effectiveness in a randomized clinical trial. In a test of 94 patients, 63 percent of patients who received the high dose and 71 percent who got the low dose achieved 75 percent wound closure after 12 weeks, compared with 45 percent of the patients who got a placebo. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

headline: Don't Like Today's Candidates? Step Back in Time
abstract: American Museum of Moving Image presents online compilation of television campaign ads for presidential elections since 1952; photo (S)

headline: An Epitaph For a Rule That Just Won't Die
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column comments on Federal Reserve chmn Alan Greenspan's forecast that Nairu theory that links unemployment and inflation will likely fail as a useful economic indicator in years ahead; contends pronouncement will make it harder for Fed to justify it next interest-rate increase; graph (M)

headline: Distance Learning Goes Niche
abstract: With the market for adult education growing at an explosive rate, colleges and universities are finding it necessary to develop finely-tuned programs that cater to identified niches.

headline: FURTHER QUERIES IN YAHOO CASE
abstract: French court continues investigating whether Yahoo! violated national law by allowing Nazi memorabilia to be sold on Web sites (S)

headline: Indonesia Is Pressed To End Terror By Militias
abstract: United Nations Security Council unanimously condemns murder of three UN refugee workers in West Timor; demands Indonesia act immediately to disarm and disband militias believed responsible for killings and to ensure safe return of as many as 100,000 refugees who fled attacks in East Timor; will send delegation to Indonesia and East Timor to help implement resolution; US Amb Richard C Holbrooke blames murders on elements within Indonesian military who could have been removed earlier; Security Council adopts resolution after getting message from Pres Abdurrahman Wahid deploring murders and pledging to punish killers (M)

headline: S.E.C. Files Fraud Complaint Against a Financier
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files fraud complaint against Martin R Frankel, who bilked insurance companies and investors out of at least $200 million; he fled to Germany, where he is jailed on other charges while extradition procedures continue; numerous co-conspirators face deep legal troubles (M)

headline: Boeing Backs Start-Up's Project : In-Flight Shower:Ultimate Perk?
abstract: FARNBOROUGH, England—  For globe-trotting executives who expect to be able to work and relax at 35,000 feet as easily as if they were on the ground, an in-flight shower may be the ultimate accessory.

headline: As Peace Mission Deteriorates, U.N. Sends an Envoy to Congo
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan sends Gen Abdulsalami Abubakar of Nigeria to Congo to salvage what is beginning to look like a doomed United Nations peacekeeping mission (M)

headline: Boeing Plan for St. Louis
abstract: Boeing Co will invest as much as $250 million in upgrades at its St Louis military-aircraft division and sell some other facilities to St Louis Airport Authority to cut costs (S)
