headline: ELECTION.COM TO RUN ICANN VOTING
abstract: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, nonprofit agency charged with administering Internet domain names and technical functions, says online balloting for its board members will be handled by Election.com; more than 76,000 Internet users worldwide have registered to participate in vote for five board members to be held from Oct 1 to Oct 10 (S)

headline: Nortel in Talks With Corning On Optics
abstract: Nortel Networks is discussing possible sale of its fiber optics components business to Corning Inc through 'reverse merger' that could effectively make Nortel parent of Corning; deal would value Nortel fiber optic unit at more than $100 billion, more than Corning's total stock market value, and would make Nortel majority shareholder of Corning (M)

headline: Peru Says Organizers of a Deadly Protest May Be Prosecuted
abstract: Peru Pres Alberto J Fujimori harshly attacks opponents, holding they spurred deadly rioting and plotted to set fire to Congress building in unsuccessful bid to block his inauguration to third term; Prime Min Federico Salas says protest organizers may be prosecuted; Alejandro Toledo, who ran against Fujimori but dropped out of race before May runoff, holds damage and deaths were caused by government intelligence agents who infiltrated crowds; Fujimori shuffles cabinet; names Carlos Bolona economy minister; photo (M)

headline: Gibraltar Acquires Milcor
abstract: Gibraltar Steel Corp, steel processor, acquires Milcor LP (S)

headline: Excerpts From Federal Reserve Chairman's Testimony
abstract: Excerpts from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's report on monetary policy to Senate Banking Committee

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    AUSTRIA: EUROPEAN PANEL PICKED -- The European Court of Human Rights appointed three men to a panel that will study Austria's human rights record and the political nature of Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom Party, a step that seems to be ending Austria's political isolation. They are diplomats from Finland and Spain and a professor from Germany. France then indicated it was inviting Austria's envoys to its Bastille Day celebrations, on Friday, and Belgium said it was making a similar invitation for its national day.   Victor Homola (NYT)    BRITAIN: SPEAKER TO QUIT -- Betty Boothroyd, the first woman to be Speaker of the House of Commons, whose cries of ''Order! Order!'' are familiar to television viewers in Britain and abroad, announced that she will retire this fall. Ms. Boothroyd, 70, a Labor Party lawmaker since 1973 and Speaker since 1992, said ''Be happy for me!'' in response to groans of disappointment. She received a round of applause, rarely heard in Parliament.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas falls after tropical storm in Gulf of Mexico misses offshore gas rigs; in New York, natural gas for September delivery falls 8.4 cents, or 1.9 percent, to $4.234 per million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Media Talk; UPN Will Become Paramount Network
abstract: Viacom's UPN television network will change name to Paramount Network to reflect sale by Chris-Craft Industries Inc of its 50 percent stake in network; drawing (M)

headline: Week's Auction Includes 52-Week Bill
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of 3-  and 6-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned tomorrow.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding 3-month bill was 6.10 percent; a 6-month bill was 6.06 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 5.88 percent.

headline: AMBANC HOLDING RAISES BID FOR COHOES TO $130 MILLION
abstract: Ambanc Holding Co raises its offer for Cohoes Bancorp to about $130 million and urges Cohoes shareholders to reject competing merger agreement with Hudson River Bancorp (S)

headline: Annual Awards For Family TV
abstract: Second annual Family Television Awards are presented by coalition of advertisers interested in stimulating production of prime-time television programs that appeal to broader multigenerational audiences (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    POLAND: WALESA CLEARED -- Lech Walesa, who fought Communist rule for two decades before its fall in 1989, was cleared of collaborating with the Communist-era secret police and will be allowed to run for the presidency, which he lost in 1995. He was forced to defend his reputation in a special screening court, which dismissed suggestions in old police files that he spied on fellow dissidents. Mr. Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, was scrutinized under a 1998 law that requires candidates to declare whether they cooperated with the Communist secret services. There is no penalty for admitting collaboration, but anyone found to have lied is banned from public office for 10 years.    (AP)

headline: Proxim to Split Its Stock
abstract: Wireless technology company Proxim Inc says it will split its stock 2 for 1 (S)

headline: Icahn's Move Forces G.M. To Consider Hughes Deal
abstract: Analysis of possible sale of Hughes Electronics by General Motors Corp in light of Carl C Icahn's decision last month to buy GM stock (M)

headline: Healtheon/WebMD Quarterly Loss Narrows, Beating Consensus
abstract: Healtheon/WebMD Quarterly Loss Narrows, Beating Consensus

headline: Something to Watch Over Me; A Chip on the Wrist Helps Parents Keep Tabs on Children at a Water Park (for Starters)
abstract: ParkWatch, an electronic locating system, allows parents to keep track of their children at Hyland Hills Water World in Denver; creators, ParkWatch and WhereNet, hope equipment, adapted from technology used o track parts in warehouses and factories, will catch on at other parks; technology raises ethical and security issues for some people; photos; drawings (M)

headline: BRAZIL WIRELESS AUCTION
abstract: Brazil plans to auction three new cellular licenses to offer personal communications services across the country; licenses are expected to bring in up to $5 billion in new investment from American and European cellular providers (S)

headline: G.M. Doubles Its Stake in Suzuki Motor to 20%
abstract: General Motors Corp doubles its stake in Suzuki Motor Corp to 20 percent and GM's chairman John F Snmith Jr joins Suzuki's board; photo (M)

headline: Canada Goes Aboard Ship To Retrieve Its Weapons
abstract: Canadian troops swing down from a helicopter to board American merchant ship Katie, which for almost three weeks has held three Canadian soldiers and 10 percent of Canada's armored might hostage on high seas over nonpayment of shipping bill; incident spotlighted logistical weakness of Canada's military; photo (M)

headline: Testimony Ends in U.S. Case Against Credit Card Giants
abstract: Two-month trial of government's landmark antitrust case against Visa and MasterCard ends with both sides expressing satisfaction with their arguments and independent observers reluctant to predict outcome, which could lead to restructuring of giant, highly profitable industry (M)

headline: Kodak Stock Falls 25% on Sudden Sales Drop and Profit Warning
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co, citing sudden sales decline in every one of its busiensses, warns investors that its third-quarter earnings will be as much as 25 cents a share below expectations and that if sales do not pick up, fourth-quarter earnings might disappoint as well; says third-quarter revenue will probably fall short of expectations by $200 million to $300 million; share price plunges 25 percent, to $44.19 (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Inventory-Sales Ratio -- June    TUESDAY  Industrial Production -- July  Capacity Utilization -- July

headline: Shares Fall on Worries That Earnings Will Begin to Fade
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 183.49 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,516.48; Nasdaq composite index falls 41.85 points, or 1 percent, to 3,987.72, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 22.05 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,452.42; US bond prices and yields are little changed; yield on Treasury's 10-year note slips to 6.02 percent, from 6.03 percent, as price rises 2/32, to 103 15/32; yield on 30-year bond is unchanged at 5.81 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Janus Fund Has Sales of $471 Million
abstract: Janus Capital Corp's newest fund, Orion, has $471 million in sales directly through Janus; shares in Orion will now be available through outside distributors (S)

headline: Clinton Tries to Ease Anger At U.S. Troops in Okinawa
abstract: Pres Clinton arrives in Okinawa for economic summit meeting and tries to ease anger of islanders fed up with heavy US military presence; speaks at seaside memorial to more than 200,000 Japanese, Americans and others who died in fierce battle in 1945; US has 37 military facilities, which Clinton notes are being consolidated (M)

headline: French Bishop, Disciplined Over 'Gay Pride' Issue, Still Speaks Out in Rome
abstract: Bishop Jacques Gaillot of France says Roman Catholic Church errs in its opposition to homosexuality; says church should not have second-class citizens; says he has been told by superiors that pope does not want him to take part in seminar on religion and homosexuality, one event in seven-day gay pride festival in Rome called World Pride Roma 2000; Vatican opposition has elevated gay event into tense political battleground; photo (M)

headline: Places to Close In on Ragweed, but From a Distance
abstract: Numerous Web sites permit the study of ragweed and its allergenic properties (M)

headline: DAIMLERCHRYSLER HYUNDAI STAKE
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG is given approval by Hyundai Motor Co of Korea to buy 9 percent of company, giving DaimlerChrysler place in Asia's truck market; DaimlerChrysler will pay 430.9 billion won ($389 million) for the stake and will set terms to buy additional 0.99 percent soon (S)

headline: LAPORTE TO SELL UNITS
abstract: Laporte PLC, British chemicals maker, will sell about 60 percent of its business to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co for $1.2 billion in cash; Laporte also says its chief executive, Jim Leng, will succeed George Duncan, who is retiring, as chairman (S)

headline: Defending Napster To the Editor:
abstract: Evan Kaiser letter on Aug 31 article holds music file-sharing technology will boost music industry; drawing

headline: Morgan Stanley Creates Fund Tied to Internet Index
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter is introducing investment fund that will track Morgan Stanley Internet index, whose 29 stocks are chosen by Mary Meeker and other analysts at Morgan Stanley; Morgan Internet index has fallen 48.4 percent since its introduction on March 24; Meeker declines to comment; graph (M)

headline: Ads on Cell Phones (And You Thought You Had Escaped)
abstract: Advertisers are beginning to tap into cellular telphones with text messages to reach customers in more direct and timely way; pitch can be aimed at certain people and particular locations, tracking user's position to within 100 feet; SkyGo Inc plans test to learn what consumers like and dislike in wireless advertising; Rep Rush Holt plans bill to protect consumers from wireless spam; photo (M)

headline: Albright to Try to Shed Light on Missing Argentine Children
abstract: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 — Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pledged today that she will work to declassify United States government documents that may shed light on the kidnappings of hundreds of children from dissidents captured by the Argentine military during the dictatorship that governed here from 1976 to 1983.

headline: ARMSTRONG, A TILE COMPANY, WILL LAY OFF 300 IN EUROPE
abstract: Armstrong Holdings will eliminate about 300 jobs, or 17 percent of company's European work force, as part of reorganization there; expects to record related after-tax charge of up to $31 million for third quarter (S)

headline: GUARDIAN LIFE PLANS TO TAKE OVER BERKSHIRE LIFE
abstract: Guardian Life Insurance Co of America plans to take over Berkshire Life Insurance Co; there will be no exchange of cash in merger, but Guardian will assume responsibility for Berkshire's operations; Joseph D Sargent, chief executive of Guardian, will serve as chief executive of combined company, which will operate under Guardian name (S)

headline: Concorde Crash Inquiry Looks at Runway Debris
abstract: Investigators looking into crash of Air Force Concorde find 16-inch strip of metal on the runway that did not belong to the plane and a large gash in a piece of tire debris; this raises possibility that a problem that had nothing to do with the plane's mechanics could have caused the crash (M)

headline: CANADIAN COMPANY MAKES PURCHASE
abstract: Bracknell Corp of Toronto agrees to buy Able Telecom Holding Corp for 199.5 million Canadian dollars, or $134.2 million, in stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: JUNIPER AIMING ANEW AT CISCO
abstract: Juniper Networks, leader in Internet switching technology, will offer new line of products, mainly routing switches that are smaller, less costly and more efficient than its previous models (S)

headline: Water, Water Everywhere, And That Means Funds, Too
abstract: Water Fund, mutual fund run by Avalon Trust Co, invests in water utilities and companies developing filtration technologies (S)

headline: South Korea and Union Agree To End Bank Workers' Strike
abstract: South Korean government and labor leaders agree to end strike by bank workers who walk off their jobs to protest mergers that could lead to thousands of layoffs; union called strike to protest legislation that would authorize creation of financial holding companies, which regulators have suggested may be first step in merging troubled banks; photo (M)a

headline: SWISSCOM PLANS TO REORGANIZE
abstract: Swisscom AG will reorganize its business around operational units to focus more on mobile communications and less on fixed-line operations; mobile operations will be placed in separate company, Mobile Com AG; Swisscom plans to sell its 50 percent stake in Tesion, fixed-line operator, to its partner Energie Baden-Wurttemberg AG (S)

headline: 2 at Top of Nordstrom Quit; Family Members Take Over
abstract: John Whitacre resigns as chairman and chief executive of Nordstrom Inc and Michael A Stein resigns as chief financial officer; two members of Nordstrom family, which controls roughly one-third of company's stock, are named to top executive positions; Blake Nordstrom is named president and Bruce Nordstrom will be chairman of board (M)

headline: British Telecom Expected to Raise Stake in German Concern
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC is expected to announce that it will take control of Viag Interkom, a German telephone company, by doubling its ownership stake to 90 percent in deal worth about 6 billion euros ($5.46 billion); move shows British Telecom's increasing desire to take controlling interests in its investments rather than minority positions; British Telecom currently holds 45 percent interest in Viag Interkom; British Telecom has agreed to buyout of Viag Interkom's other major shareholder, E.On AG, German energy concern, which also holds 45 percent stake in German telephone company; Telenor AS, Norwegian telephone company, owns remaining 10 percent (M)

headline: Tory Party Leader Issues A Euroskeptical Manifesto
abstract: Britain's Conservative leader William Hague sets out 100 policy proposals that party hopes will help it defeat Prime Min Tony Blair and his Labor government in coming national election; 32-page document, entitled Believing in Britain, stresses party's determination to hold off any consideration that country adopt euro as currency in common with continental nations; pledges legislation to halt relinquishing of British sovereignty to European superstate; photo (M)

headline: Negotiators in Telephone Strike Make Little Progress
abstract: Negotiators in Telephone Strike M7

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: NAIL BOMBER SENTENCED -- David Copeland, 24, a confessed fascist, was sentenced to six life terms after a London jury found him guilty of three murders in a series of bombings aimed at the city's gay and nonwhite populations. The three deaths resulted from a nail bomb that devastated a Soho gay bar and injured 139 people. The jury rejected his defense of diminished responsibility.     Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: BMW EARNINGS RISE 67%
abstract: BMW reports first-half profit rose 67 percent, to 319 million euros ($295 million), from 191 million euros in 1999 period; graph (S)

headline: Report Says U.S. and Others Allowed Rwanda Genocide
abstract: International panel assembled by Organization of African Unity says that while Rwanda's Hutu-led government was behind genocide of 1994, United States and other nations that failed to prevent or stop it should pay a significant level of reparations; others singled out for blame include France and Belgium, United Nations, and the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches (M)

headline: Guerrilla Attacks Raise Worries in Central Asia
abstract: Deadly clashes between guerrillas and armies of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan, former Soviet republics in Central Asia, deepens concerns that effort is under way to destabilize region; recent attacks described; Uzbek government accuses Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, which it says infiltrated region from Tajikistan and Afghanistan; Kazakh government asks for broad new powers to curb religious extremists; map (M)

headline: CHINA SIMPLIFIES STOCK TRADES
abstract: China plans to unify trading systems of its two stock exchanges giving investors ability to trade through single account on both exchanges, which are in Shenzhen and Shanghai (S)

headline: Mexico's Defeated Leadership Squabbles Over the Next Step
abstract: Battle erupts within Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party following its election defeat, with several rival leaders maneuvering for control during painful transition that party leaders say will test its powers of survival; near chaos grips party after leader, Dulce Maria Sauri, resigns with expectation that entire cabinet will leave with her (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: European Music Stars Fight to Block Internet Piracy

headline: DELCO REMY WILL ELIMINATE 860 JOBS AS IT REORGANIZES
abstract: Delco Remy International, auto-parts maker, plans to eliminate 860 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, and take $22 million charge in its fourth quarter to reorganize (S)

headline: SUSPICIONS RAISED IN HYUNDAI DEAL
abstract: Hyundai Group lowers Chung Ju Yung's stake in Hyundai Motor Co by 6.1 percent, but shares, worth $179 million, are sold to domestic investors, raising suspicions that deals were prearranged to maintain Chung's influence (S)

headline: Trading Exchange to Throw Light on Murky Oil Market
abstract: Trading Exchange to Throw Light on Murky Oil Market

headline: E.U. Antitrust Officials Have B2B Exchanges in Sights
abstract: E.U. Antitrust Officials Have B2B Exchanges in Sights

headline: KPN REPORTS FIRST LOSS
abstract: Royal KPN NV of Netherlands cuts its annual earnings forecast and reports a first-half loss of 19 million euros ($16.9 million), its first ever, which is due to expense of mobile phone licenses and customers recruitment (S)

headline: Applied Microsystems Says It Will Miss Estimates
abstract: July 8, 2000

headline: BRAZIL DECISION ON BENEFITS POSTPONED
abstract: Brazilian Supreme Court postpones widely anticipated decision that could force government to pay up to $30 billion in back benefits to contributors to national workers' fund; government has been accused of shortchinging contributors from 1987 to 1991, during period of financial crisis (S)

headline: IMAX EXPLORES SALE
abstract: Shares of Imax Corp rise 18 percent after Toronto company, which designs movie projection equipment, says Wall Street firms Wasserstein, Perella & Co and Goldman Sachs & Co have been hired to advise on sale or merger; Wasserstein, Perella owns 30 percent of stock and wants to recoup its investment (S)

headline: Swiss Bank Is Acquiring PaineWebber
abstract: UBS AG, giant Swiss bank, offers to pay $12 billion in cash and stock for Paine Webber Group, fourth-largest US brokerage firm; almost $1 billion of purchase price will go into bonus pool to retain crucial Paine Webber employees; among biggest beneficiaries of acquisition will be General Electric Co and Paine Webber chairman-chief executive Donald B Marron; GE, which sold defunct Kidder Peabody brokerage firm to Paine Webber, owns about 31.5 million shares, or 22 percent, of Paine Webber's stock; those shares will be worth about $2.3 billion (M)

headline: CONSECO SELLING BANK CARD UNIT FOR $400 MILLION
abstract: Conseco Inc sells bank card unit to Wells Fargo & Co for approximately $400 million (S)

headline: PALM FORMS INVESTMENT UNIT
abstract: Palm, maker of Palm Pilot line of hand-held computers, is forming new unit, Palm Ventures, with $50 million to help develop wireless content companies, mobile systems integrators and Palm accessory manufacturers that support Palm operating system (S)

headline: 15 Reported Killed by Bomb at Jakarta Stock Exchange
abstract: Car bomb explodes in parking garage of Indonesian Stock Exchange building in Jakarta, killing 15 people and wounding dozens in country's newest brush with violence; unexplained explosion is latest of series in recent weeks; it comes hours before high-profile corruption trial of former president, Suharto, is scheduled to resume; Suharto fails to appear, citing ill health; Pres Abdurrahman Wahid has accused Suharto-affiliated military and political extremists of planting bombs and inciting unrest across country to discredit him and destablize his democratically elected government; photo (M)

headline: SYMANTEC BUYS A RIVAL FOR $975 MILLION
abstract: Symantec, largest maker of computer security software for consumers, acquires Axent Technologies Inc for about $975 million in stock (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Consumer Borrowing -- May  Inventory-Sales Ratio -- May    TUESDAY  Consu -- Mer Price Index -- June

headline: Japanese Economy Expands For 2nd Consecutive Quarter
abstract: Japan's Economic Planning Agency says economy expanded 1 percent in April-June quarter, stronger-than-expected performance driven by higher government and consumer spending; result translates into annual growth rate of 4.2 percent; one of biggest surprises is 13.6 percent increase in government spending (M)

headline: Taiwan Chief Drops Plan For Meeting In California
abstract: Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, abruptly cancels informal reception with members of Congress after vigorous protests from China and expressions of concern by State Dept; reception had been organized by Rep Sam Gejdenson as chance for Chen to meet bipartisan group of lawmakers; Clinton administration officials say they do not favor Chen's meeting with lawmakers or other American officials in way that could be construed as official contacts; Gejdenson, a Democrat, issues curt statement about Chen being pressured by administration and State Dept to refrain from meeting members of Congress; cancellation appears to avoid potentially divisive diplomatic confrontation with China (M)

headline: U.S. Navy Is About to Retire One of Two Top Rescue Subs
abstract: US Navy is planning to retire one of its two best rescue submarines at end of August in cost-cutting move that could make it harder to save stricken American submarines; the minisubmarines are among vessels that US offered to send to try to save sailors trapped in Russian submarine Kursk; Navy plans to build new generation of rescue vehicles in next five years, but now there could be pressure to keep minisub in use until new equipment is ready (M)

headline: New York Investor and A.I.G. to Increase Stake in Hyundai
abstract: Group of Western investors, including Wilbur L Ross, a specialist in corporate rescues, and the American International Group, plan to increase their investment in three financial affiliates of the Hyundai Group to $1 billion so as to gain a firmer hold on Hyundai Securities, South Korea's largest brokerage house (M)

headline: Oil Prices Falling? Don't Count On It
abstract: Robert D Hershey Jr column interviews Charles T Maxwell, of Weeden & Company, regarding likely future moves in price of oil; photo (M)

headline: Article 2000092691731182817 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: A Global Warming Report Predicts Doom for Many Species
abstract: World Wide Fund for Nature (World Wildlife Fund) reports that global warming could wipe out many species of plants and animals by end of 21st century; predicts devastation for species from Arctic polar bears to New England sugar maples (S)

headline: Clinton Wades Into the Details of Mideast Negotiations
abstract: Pres Clinton plunges into nitty-gritty of issue-by-issue deliberations at Camp David summit between Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; Israeli and Palestinian officials say negotiators, under Clinton's direct supervision, are engaged in forging working agreement in effort to establish concrete points of accord and highlight gaps; photo (M)

headline: Master of Facts, Legal and Musical
abstract: Profile of H Rodgin Cohen, a leading banking lawyer who has been named chairman of New York law firm Sullivan & Cromwell; Cohen has been a sought-after counselor to chief executives of banking industry's largest institutions and acted as an adviser on 10 of 15 largest banking mergers in 1990's; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls after Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany says he welcomes currency's decline; graph; chart (S)

headline: ONLINE HOUSEHOLDS APPROACH 300 MILLION
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings global Internet trends service says more than 295 million people in 20 countries around the world have Internet access from a residential personal computer; in 14 European markets, estimated 82 million people have access to Internet from home personal computer; in four leading Asia-Pacific markets, estimated 37 million people have access (S)

headline: Those Banner Ads Keep On Waving, But They're Singing a Different Tune
abstract: WAY back when, say in 1995, they were still something of a curiosity. That was the year that Yahoo first decided to put advertising on its site, a time when the words ''advertising banners'' still conjured images of cloth signs trailing from airplanes on hot summer days.    But Internet banners -- advertisements appearing on Web pages, often randomly, and usually in rectangular boxes -- did not remain a rarity for long. Cheap to put on the Internet, easy to design, they soon were everywhere. And euphoric Web site owners and eager advertisers were convinced that they could do just about anything.

headline: Somalis Take Close Look At Election In the U.S.
abstract: Somalis, despite mixed feelings about Americans, have strong affection for former Pres George Bush and back his son, Gov George W Bush, in United States presidential race; hope Gov Bush will reverse Pres Clinton's policy against American military involvement, although he has not signaled any plan for re-engagement; are growing optimistic that peace talks now under way in Djibouti may lead to return of government, but say any new government would need some funding (M)

headline: CENTEX SAYS 2001 EARNINGS WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
abstract: Centex Corp, one of largest homebuilders in US, says it expects 2001 earnings per share might be 25 cents to 50 cents above current analysts' estimates (S)

headline: Punching Around-the-Clock Time Clocks
abstract: Growing use of electronic devices to track employee's whereabouts described; photos (S)

headline: COVER-UP HURTS MITSUBISHI STOCK
abstract: Shares of Mitsubishi Motors fall 2 percent after company acknowledges that it had systematically covered up customer complaints since 1977 and would widen recall; graph (S)

headline: Fury of a Volunteer Firefighter Scorned
abstract: Article profiles Michael Nicholson, who was disabled in 1972 when he was hit by car while on call as volunteer firefighter outside Rochester, NY, and who has led crusade to overhaul way workers' compensation treats volunteer firefighters; photo (M)

headline: Berlin to Give Brandenburg Gate a Scrub
abstract: BERLIN, Sept. 28 — Decades of grime will soon be stripped from the Brandenburg Gate, the first cleanup for Berlin's best-known emblem since before World War II.

headline: FREESERVE POSTS LOSS
abstract: Shares of Freeserve, leading provider of Internet access in Britain, fall 3 percent, to 235 pence, or about $3.31, after it says first-quarter losses nearly doubled to 15.5 million pounds, or about $19 million; revenue grew more than threefold, to 14.6 million pounds (S)

headline: Computers Need Space to Work
abstract: J D Biersdorfter answers a reader's question on what to do when there is not enough available space on a hard drive to permit the computer to run efficiently

headline: Treasury Sale Holds Up, Despite Shrinking Debt
abstract: Article surveys this week's sales of Treasury securities, then looks to period ahead (M)

headline: E*TRADE TO BUY ELECTRONIC INVESTING
abstract: E*Trade Group agrees to buy Electronic Investing Corp (S)

headline: Doubts That Suharto Will Ever Go to Court
abstract: Former Indonesian leader Suharto calls in sick on first day of his trial on corruption charges, raising new doubts that he will ever be tried; prosecutors vow to plow ahead with charges that Suharto siphoned about $590 million in state funds through charitable foundations he controlled (S)

headline: Olcott D. Smith, 93, Chairman Of Aetna and a Hartford Leader
abstract: Olcott Damon Smith, who as chairman of Aetna Life and Casualty led formation of its international and financial services divisions, dies at age 93 (M)

headline: AIRLINE IN IRELAND NAMES EXECUTIVE
abstract: Aer Lingus Group PLC appoints Michael Foley, president of Heineken USA Inc, as chief executive, succeeding Garry Cullen, who resigned in February (S)

headline: A U.S. 'Product' Certain to Sell in Mexico: Lobbying
abstract: Scores of United States lobbyists are preparing their pitches to represent government of Pres-elect Vicente Fox, who is likely to pick new lobbying team to press political agenda of Mexico's new governing party in Washington; Mexico has become one of most prized foreign government lobbying accounts (M)

headline: U.S. Asks Putin Not to Sell Iran A Laser System
abstract: US presses Russia not to proceed with plans to sell Iran laser technology that it says can be used to make fuel for nuclear weapons; issue was raised by Pres Clinton in two recent meetings with Pres Vladimir Putin, who reportedly gave assurances that Russia would work with Washington to resolve dispute; officials call Putin's response ambiguous; note Russian and American technical advisers disagree over whether equipment could help Iran in what Washington says is secret program to acquire nuclear weapons; expansion of Russian nuclear contacts with Tehran since 1995, when Russia completed nuclear power plant abandoned by Germans in 1979, discussed; American allegations that Russia is providing critical technology to Iran has roiled US-Russian relations for years (M)

headline: AT&T Shares Up on Speedy At Home Deal
abstract: AT&T's stock rises on news that company has incorporated ExciteAtHome into its operations more quickly than expected, suggesting a faster move to high-speed Internet services; Standard & Poor's puts company's debt on review for a possible downgrade, citing management miscues and costly acquisitions; AT&T Latin America merges with FirstCom, a South American telecommunications company, to form a specialized broadband communications provider (M)

headline: Shares Fall as Investors Worry About Earnings Reports
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 62.54 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,741.22; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 9.69 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,439.03; Dow Jones industrial average slips 39.22 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,808.15; graph; charts (M)

headline: How to Turn Innovation Into Everyone's Goal

headline: Deutsche Telekom's Sideshow; Selling Cable Units To Small Fry to Keep The Sharks at Bay?

headline: Yugoslav Opposition Declares Victory as Votes Still Counted
abstract: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Claiming victory in an election marked by fraud allegations, Slobodan Milosevic's opponents warned that the Yugoslav president may try to rig the vote in a desperate attempt to keep the power he has wielded for 13 years. ``This is the dawn of our freedom,'' law professor and opposition candidate Vojislav Kostunica said early Monday as Yugoslavians poured onto the streets of Belgrade and other cities. By midmorning Monday, election officials had still not released any official numbers from Sunday's elections, nor had they resumed work suspended the night of the vote. An estimated 74 percent of the country's 7.6 million voters cast ballots for president, parliament and local officials. However, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia party claimed its candidate, 56-year-old Kostunica, had won the presidency, saying its poll watchers reported that he had an absolute majority, defeating Milosevic and three other contenders. ``Votes can be rigged when there is a slim difference between two groups, but when the difference is this big there is no way anyone can falsify the results,'' said Vladan Batic of the opposition alliance. No one in Milosevic's Socialist Party was willing to go on the record, but a senior official requesting anonymity told The Associated Press that the party's ``top people were debating all night ... We don't exactly know what we'll do.'' If no candidate ends up with an absolute majority, a runoff will be held Oct. 8. However, Milosevic was showing no signs of conceding defeat, and Western governments held late night consultations to determine how to respond. The European Union on Monday issued a statement criticizing Milosevic for intimidating voters and manipulating the presidential ballot, declaring that any effort by the Yugoslav leader to declare victory would be ``fraudulent.'' In Vienna, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, the chairwoman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, said in a statement, ``All available information points to a clear lead by the Democratic Opposition of Serbia's Vojislav Kostunica in the first round.'' British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook on Monday said ``all the reliable evidence'' shows Milosevic had lost and urged the president to step aside. ``Be honest with your people, don't cheat them, get out of the way and let Serbia get out of the prison into which you have turned it,'' he told a Labor Party conference in London, referring to Yugoslavia's main province. Early in the vote-counting, White House spokeswoman Nanda Chitre said questions about irregularities brought into question ``the integrity of the whole process.'' Hours later, as reports came out that the opposition -- which the United States backs -- was in the lead, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher in Washington took a softer tone, warning simply that ``the world is watching.'' Believing that there can be no stability in the Balkans as long as Milosevic remains in power, the United States has invested millions in an attempt to organize the traditionally fractured Serbian opposition and defeat Milosevic. Milosevic spokesman Nikola Sainovic, however, claimed that with 20 percent of the votes counted, Milosevic was leading by 44 percent while Kostunica had 41 percent. Kostunica's group, an alliance of 18 parties, claimed returns from 51 percent of 10,000 polling stations showed him leading with 53 percent to 36 percent for Milosevic. The ultranationalist Serbian Radical Party, which ran its own unsuccessful presidential candidate, said Kostunica was leading Milosevic by 53.5 percent to 37.9 percent with 20 percent of the votes counted. Confident of victory by an opposition that seemed hopelessly fragmented only months ago, huge crowds streamed into the streets of downtown Belgrade late Sunday to await official results. Helmeted riot police carrying shields and armed with tear gas cordoned off the group but later withdrew as the mood became more festive than confrontational. Similar gatherings were reported in Nis, Novi Sad, Cacak and several other towns in Serbia. There were no immediate reports of clashes, and the crowds dispersed early Monday. Despite the public euphoria, opposition leaders said they were concerned that Milosevic would try to claim victory -- or ensure a place in the runoff. ``Milosevic has to seriously understand the judgment of history, and he shouldn't gamble any longer,'' said Kostunica's campaign manager, Zoran Djindjic. Montenegro, the smaller republic that along with Serbia forms present-day Yugoslavia, said it would hold an independence referendum if Milosevic wins. If he loses, the European Union has promised Yugoslavia massive aid. Kostunica had been leading in opinion polls -- despite a campaign marred by a crackdown against opposition supporters. The Center for Free Elections and Democracy, a private group including human rights workers, lawyers and other volunteers, reported a turnout of 74.6 percent in Serbia. In Montenegro -- where the pro-Western government boycotted the vote -- the turnout was 24 percent, the opposition said. The center also reported major voting irregularities, including officials kicking opposition representatives out of polling stations or not allowing them to inspect voters' lists, voting boxes and ballots. The government's electoral commission said the vote passed without irregularities, ``despite Western propaganda.''

REPORT DUE  A report commissioned by the European Union to help it decide whether to continue sanctions against Austria is to be presented today to the current holder of the rotating E.U. presidency, President Jacques Chirac of France. The sanctions were imposed in February after the far-right Freedom Party joined Austria's ruling coalition. The report was to evaluate the ''respect'' of the Austrian government for ''common European values'' as well as the evolution of the Freedom Party.    Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: Japan's Bank Drops Zero-Interest Policy
abstract: Japan's central bank raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, defying strong pressure from government officials to keep borrowing costs close to zero.    While the move had been widely expected, it nonetheless sent a powerful message about the central bank's view that the Japanese economy, the world's second largest, has achieved enough momentum to keep expanding. The move also represented an unparalleled display of independence by the central bank, which had been given more autonomy under a change in the law a few years ago but had never exercised it until now.

headline: ETA Claims Responsibility for Recent Attacks in Spain
abstract: MADRID, Sept. 22 -- The Basque separatist group ETA claimed responsibility on Friday for a series of recent attacks in Spain, including the killing of a politician late last month, a failed assassination attempt and five bombings. ETA, in a communique published in the radical separatist newspaper Gara, said it bombed a Basque discotheque earlier this month because it considered the nightclub a centre of drug trafficking. ETA accused police of turning a blind eye to the illegal drug trade that it said ``hurts Basque youth and goes against the process of liberating the Basque Country.'' The communique was released just a day after the killing of a town councillor in a Barcelona suburb, the latest attack blamed on the guerrillas. ETA did not immediately claim responsibility for Thursday's assassination -- it rarely does until weeks later. But with Friday's communique, ETA has now admitted to 12 of the 13 killings tied to ETA this year since it called off its 14-month-long ceasefire last December. The guerrillas have been blamed for about 800 deaths in their 32-year fight for an independent state in northern Spain and southern France.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: NO APPEAL OVER TWINS  The parents of 7-week-old twins joined at the pelvis have decided not to appeal a Court of Appeal decision giving doctors permission to separate the infants in an operation that will sacrifice the life of one to save the other. The couple, from the island of Gozo, near Malta, had argued that their Catholic faith compelled them to let nature take its course although it meant the probable death of both children. But their lawyer said that after two court decisions against them, ''they feel they have done the best they can for both daughters.''    Warren Hoge (NYT)    GERMANY: UNITED AGAINST NEO-NAZIS  Leaders of the main political parties united in calls to combat right-wing extremism, which has led to a wave of neo-Nazi violence against foreigners. The Bundestag president, Wolfgang Thierse, left, said such attacks were an assault on a democratic society's values, and should not be regarded just as an east German problem. A government working group is considering the possibility of banning the neo-Nazi National Democratic Party.   Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: The Mahogany King's Brief Reign; Business Interests Lurked Behind Fiji's Haphazard Coup
abstract: Business interests were behind failed coup in May against Mahendra Chaudhry government in Fiji; former government forest manager George Speight, who held Fijian cabinet hostage for two months, had sought to control country's timber operations; foiled coup led to disturbances in which headquarters of Fiji Hardwood were firebombed; Fiji police are investigating whether Marshall W Pettit, Seattle-area real-estate developer who aspired to transform way developing nations manage their forests, paid bribes to Speight; Pettit also plunged into Fijian politics to fight former government's opposition to his plan, though there is no evidence he backed coup; Speight is in prison, charged with treason; Pettit, who has given up all hope of reaching timber deal in Fiji, has filed half a dozen lawsuits in local courts against government to recover some of money he lost; maps; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ITALY: CARDINAL CALLED RACIST -- A leading cardinal has set off a political furor by suggesting that Italy favor Roman Catholic immigrants over Muslims to "preserve the identity of the nation." Many center-left government ministers condemned Cardinal Giacomo Biffi's pastoral letter to his Bologna archdiocese as dangerous and racist. But some center-right politicians agreed with his proposal and the opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi said the cardinal's ideas "were deemed worthy of attention."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Stage Late Rally As Concerns Ease on Rates  Stocks staged a late-day rally as Wall Street bet that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates steady next week after more than a year of tapping on the brakes to slow dynamic economic growth in the United States.   The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 148.34 points, or 1.4 percent, to 11,176.14, its highest finish since April 11. The Nasdaq composite index, weighted with technology shares, rose 60.22 points, or 1.6 percent, to 3,849.69, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 19.72 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,491.56. abstract: Alan Nevins, agent with Artists Management Group, places orders for at least 18,000 copies of a client's book, Rich DeVos's Hope From My Heart, at a handful of small bookstores whose sales are reflected in New York Times's best-seller list; list's editors say unusually large bulk orders like Nevins's are deemed suspect and are typically not counted; Nevins's activities seem likely to reinforce concerns among publishers and bookstores about efforts to influence various best-seller lists artificially; Nevins says manipulating best-seller list was not his intention; Ron Land, sales executive at book's publisher, Thomas Nelson Publishers, says getting book on best-seller list was motive for arranging sales at bookstores (M)

headline: Arranged Marriages, Minus the Parents
abstract: Many Indian- and Pakistani-Americans are eliminating their parents as marriage brokers by turning to Internet Websites like Internet Matrimonials, A1 Matrimonials, IndianMarriages and Suitable Match; find the impersonal, direct communication through such sites to be more efficient and more in keeping with contemporary attitudes; most still judge potential mates by the criteria their parents would apply: religion, caste, subcaste and graduate degrees; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of September 17 Market Watch column about Nasdaq proposal for new system of handling trades; American Century Investments' Nasdaq trades on electronic communications networks cost far less than those through Wall Street brokerage firms (S)

headline: BIOMETRICS SOFTWARE MAKERS TO MERGE
abstract: Communication Intelligence Corp signs letter of intent to acquire privately held PenOp Ltd for stock representing about 5 percent of Communication Intelligence equity (S)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: INTERNET

headline: Tape Details Kickbacks To an Aide Of Chirac
abstract: More details are made public from videotaped confession of Jean-Claude Mery, former aide to French Pres Jacques Chirac, who tells of collecting kickbacks from contractors working in Paris housing projects; Chirac is accused on tape of masterminding multimillion-dollar slush fund in 1980's, when he was mayor (M)

headline: More Technology
abstract: There are encouraging numbers for Gateway and Compaq, humbling ones for Apple and Drkoop.com. Details appear in the Technology Briefing column as Business Day expands its coverage of technology. Page C6.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against the euro after rport on consumer prices shows that core inflation remained in check; in New York, euro settles at 92.65 cents, down from 93.55 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: LITTON INDUSTRIES SAYS PROFIT WILL MISS FORECASTS
abstract: Litton Industries, which builds ships for the Navy, says profit in current quarter and rest of fiscal 2001 will be below forecasts because of cost overruns on warships and tankers; company's shares plunge 24 percent (S)

headline: Faulting India, Rebel Group In Kashmir Ends Its Cease-Fire
abstract: Syed Salahuddin, leader of Hizbul Mujahedeen, calls off militant group's cease-fire in Kashmir, charging India has not reciprocated peace effort, news conference, Islamabad, Pakistan; cites India's failure to let Pakistan join in any talks; photo (M)

headline: Home-Grown Innovation, Home-Grown Workers
abstract: Steve Lohr Economic view column on new growth theory by Stanford Business School economist Paul M Romer, which emphasizes economic role of innovation and failure of universities to supply enough graduates for high-tech jobs (M)

headline: Frustrated Customers
abstract: Malcolm Campbell letter on July 20 article on the poor quality of customer service in high-tech retailing

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro closes at 94.18 cents; other currency trading results; graph (S)

headline: NET2PHONE FORMS VENTURE WITH CISCO
abstract: Net2Phone is branching out beyond its core business of providing low-cost voice and data calls over Internet in forming software venture with Cisco Systems; new company, called Adir Technologies, will sell software to communications companies seeking to route calling traffic over Internet (S)

headline: Sony Says It Will Offer a Palm-Based P.D.A.
abstract: Sony Says It Will Offer a Palm-Based P.D.A.

headline: Libraries and Catalogs
abstract: Andrew H Braiterman letter comments on Aug 10 article on how Internet has affected students' research strategies

headline: Installing a Scanner With Windows 98
abstract: Q. How difficult would it be for a mere novice to add a photo scanner to a Windows 98 computer?    A. All things considered, it is probably not as hard to add a scanner to a Windows 98 system as it is with earlier versions of Windows. Windows 98 can even detect and install the needed driver software for several scanner models, including ones made by UMAX, Hewlett-Packard and Logitech. That is not to say that only scanners by these manufacturers will work with Windows 98; it just means that you may have to do a manual installation for the drivers from the floppy disks or CD-ROM that come with a new scanner.

headline: Those Raises, Adjusted for Oil Inflation, Are a Mirage
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on decline in wage increases this year despite continuing US economic boom; graph (M)

headline: Elections Near, Rivalries Split Opposition to Milosevic
abstract: Split in opposition to Pres Slobodan Milosevic puts at risk its main achievement so far: its control over Serbia's major cities, including radio and television stations; American officials press opposition politicians to settle their differences to present united slate of candidates for local elections Sept 24 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: 2 European Exchanges Eager to Join Nasdaq
abstract: London Stock Exchange and Frankfurt exchange, or Deutsche Borse, say real goal of merger is to explore complete partnership with Nasdaq, which is run by National Association of Securities Dealers (M)

headline: A 2nd Front In the Inquiry Into Firestone
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration opens second investigation into Firestone tires, this time involving Steeltex tires used on largest sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans; has received 169 complaints of problems with tires, involving 89 crashes, 12 injuries and 2 deaths; complaints cover many tires in Suburban sport utility vehicles and large vans made by General Motors Corp as well as Excursion sport utility vehicles and F250 and F350 pickup trucks made by Ford (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: C.I.A. Is Said to Find Iraq Gives Contracts to Nations That Want to End Economic Sanctions
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency says Iraq has consistently used United Nations' oil-for-food program to reward countries that call for ending economic sanctions against Iraq, and to punish those that oppose lifting embargo; Clinton administration officials say Pres Saddam Hussein gives bulk of contracts in program to China, France and Russia, vocal champions of lifting sanctions, and denies contracts to traditional suppliers who have not called for end to sanctions, including Japan and Germany (M)

headline: The Web Helps Military 'Brats' Find Long-Lost Friends
abstract: Military Brats Registry and other Web sites allow people who grew up in military families to find long-lost acquaintances from childhoods that had them moving frequently around the country and the world; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Home Heating Oil Prices Surge on Sudden Drop in Inventories
abstract: Surveys by American Petroleum Institute and US Energy Information Administration show sudden drop in crude oil inventories, sending home heating oil prices to their highest in a decade; on New York Mercantile Exchange, price of crude oil for October delivery jumped 80 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $32.02 a barrel, while price of heating oil for September delivery rises 5.26 cents, or 5.8 percent, to 95.61 cents a gallon; Clinton administration is again mentioning possibility of using oil from government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to help push prices lower; connections of Republican ticket of George W Bush and Dick Cheney to oil industry will sharpen focus on issue this fall, especially if it is cold; Clinton says he will discuss high oil prices this weekend when he meets with Nigeria's Pres Olusegun Obasanjo, member of OPEC (M)

headline: Retail Sales Up on Bargains Offered by Clothing Chains
abstract: Sales in stores open more than year rose 3.7 percent in July 2000 as clearance sales enticed shoppers and helped make room for fall fashions and back-to-school items (S)

headline: Goldman Sachs Appointment
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group names Michael Carr to head its investment banking business in Asia, excluding its Japanese unit (M)

headline: Persistent Protesters From Banned Sect Keep Beijing Police on Edge
abstract: Chinese police and Falun Gong followers play grim game in Beijing's Tiananmen Square as lean young cadets dash across vast open space to snatch down ocher banners briefly unfurled by middle-aged members of banned sect; protests, and arrests, increase with approach of first anniversary of government crackdown on spiritual movement (M)

headline: Sudden Bereavement for 'the Dinosaurs' and Their Offspring
abstract: Vote against Institutional Revolutionary Party is rejection of Mexico's oldest and wisest leaders, known universally in political circles as 'the dinosaurs'; dinosaurs and their offspring hole up in party's headquarters, listening to televised returns showing their party being crushed; photo (M)

headline: Those Were The Days All Right. But No More.
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column interviews Morgan Stanley Dean Witter chief US investment strategist Byron R Wien concerning stock-market downturn in first half of year and outlook for stocks in second half; notes Wien expects market volatility to remain high; photo (M)

headline: Russians Want Beauty With Scent of Home
abstract: Devaluation of ruble has made domestic Russian cosmetics manufacturers competitive with foreign firms; Russian Oleg Nasobin started Green Mama, his cosmetics brand, in 1996 in Czech Republic; now his products sell in 36 countries and are fifth-largest in Russian cosmetics industry; photo; graph (M)

headline: Investors Weed Out Thorns From Greenspan's Message
abstract: Investors focus on all positives in testimony of Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, before Senate Banking Committee and send stock and bond prices sharply higher and interests lower; Nasdaq composite index jumps 128.93 points, to 4,184.56, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 13.61 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,495.57; Dow Jones industrial average rises 147.79, to 10,843.87; yield on Treasury's 10-year note falls to 6 percent, from 6.15 percent, while price rises 1 3/32, to 103 19/32; yield on 30-year bond falls to 5.81 percent from 5.91 percent; graphs; chart on key US interest rates (M)

headline: SPAIN FACES LAWSUIT
abstract: European Commission says it will go to court to force Spain to give up powers over formerly state-owned companies like Telefonica SA, country's dominant phone company; Spanish government opposition to torpedo Telefonica's planned takeover of Dutch rival, Royal KPN, in May; Rodrigo Rato, Spanish finance minister, says government opposed Telefonica merger because Dutch state still controls stake in KPN; photo (S)

headline: Men's Health, Trying to Win Youth Back, Names Editor
abstract: David Zinczenko is named editor in chief of US edition of Men's Health magazine (M)

headline: Daily News Opens a New Front in the Tabloid War; Free Paper Raises Stakes in Battle With Post
abstract: The Daily News will offer new afternoon newspaper for free, called Express, heating up New York City's long-running tabloid war; New York Post responds by cutting its newsstand price to 25 cents from 50 cents within city limits; observers say intensity of current battle reflects willingness of combatants to incur short- or medium-term losses in pursuit of long-term dominance; high-profile introduction of Express generates guarded excitement among advertisers, who are worried about reader erosion; The News, which had circulation of more than million decade ago, now has circulation of 700,000; photo; map; chart (M)

headline: For War-Weary Angola, Animals Offer a Peaceable Kingdom
abstract: Arrival of wild animals donated by South Africa to inhabit Quicama National Park, Angola's first game reserve, offers needed distraction to war-weary nation; park's own animals were poached and killed after civil war began in 1975; foundation that manages park has built fence and hired guards to protect animals (M)

headline: The Graphics Card Game
abstract: Until recently, the only home computer users who cared about seeing high-quality images on their monitors were hard-core gamers. But in the last few years, that circle has expanded to include people who watch DVD movies on their computers or edit digital photographs or videos on the weekends. And yes, some of them may even be tempted to play the occasional game of Quake III.

headline: Why Did French Runner Run Away?
abstract: SYDNEY—  Under the gaze of 110,000 fans in the goldfish bowl of Olympic Stadium and a worldwide television audience of millions, Marie-Jose Perec, the French runner, was to begin her quest for a third consecutive gold medal in the 400 meters on Friday.

headline: German Faults 'Silence' About Attacks on Immigrants
abstract: Wave of anti-immigrant violence in Germany prompts Foreign Min Joschka Fischer to suggest that silent majority may be abetting crimes by not speaking out against them; statement is thinly veiled allusion to past Germany passivity before rise of rightist violence; recent bombing in Dusseldorf that wounded nine immigrants, and spate of other attacks discussed (M)

headline: Madison Square Garden Names Executive
abstract: Seth Abraham is named executive vice president and chief operating officer of Madison Square Garden (S)

headline: Manila's Talk Of the Town Isn't Talk at All
abstract: 'Texting' as in exchanging short typed messages over cell phone has become popular in Philippines and has spawned entire subculture, complete with its own vocabulary, etiquette and tactical uses; it has become particularly popular in Manila, in large part because text messaging is cheap while traditional telephone service is spotty and Internet access by computer is expensive; photos (M)

headline: Phone Strikers Threaten End Of Pact Talks
abstract: Union representatives for nearly two-thirds of striking Verizon Communications workers say they will break off negotiations if they do not reach agreement with company by midnight Aug 18 (M)

headline: Explorer Tires Had to Carry A Heavy Load
abstract: Firestone tires used on Ford Motor Co's Explorer have fairly low weight-carrying capacity for a vehicle that size, particularly at low inflation pressure recommended by Ford; officials at Bridgestone/Firestone have been saying since recall that 15-inch tires are losing their treads at high speeds partly because drivers are overloading their vehicles; table (M)

headline: CLINTON DEFENDS COLOMBIA OUTLAY
abstract: Pres Clinton, accompanied by Republican and Democratic lawmakers, visits Colombia to lend backing to nation's counternarcotics program; insists $1.3 billion in planned military aid is limited to drug fight, and will not involve United States in government's battle with rebels; says continuing aid will depend on government's breaking ties with paramilitary groups and adhering to strict human rights standards; rebels and protesters are active in advance of visit; Clinton tours port used by smugglers, with Pres Andres Pastrana acting as translator; photos; map (M)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO CUT 1,000 JOBS FOR COMING MOVE
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp, maker of invasive surgical devices, to cut 1,000 jobs and move 900 more to sites in Miami and Ireland (S)

headline: REED ELSEVIER PROFIT SLIPS
abstract: Reed Elsevier reports first-half pretax profits of $529 million; says it will meet full-year earnings forecasts (S)

headline: Colorfully Reinventing The Wheel
abstract: Responsible Party column profiles B F Goodrich marketing manager Rick Shafer, the executive behind company's colorful Scorcher T/A automobile tires; buyers can design tire tread striped in two colors chosen from palette of eight; photos (M)

headline: BARRICK BUYS NEIGHBOR
abstract: Barrick Gold Corp acquires exploration properties in Tanzania and Peru wi

headline: European Central Bank Moves to Prop Up Sliding Euro
abstract: FRANKFURT, Sept. 14 — The European Central Bank took a limited step today toward intervening in world markets on behalf of the downtrodden euro, using money from its foreign reserves to buy $2.5 billion worth of euros and briefly halting the currency's tailspin against the dollar.

headline: Conoco Bids to Develop Nigerian Oil Field
abstract: Conoco Inc and partners, Phillips Petroleum and USX-Marathon Group bid $164 million for right to jointly develop oil field off Nigeria's Coast (S)

headline: Blair Says Blame Is His for Party's Plummeting Ratings
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain takes personal blame for government actions that have sent Labor Party's poll ratings plummeting, party convention, Brighton; urges party to remain confident it will defeat Conservatives in elections expected in next year (M)

headline: In Japan: Outsourcing Without A Capital 'O'
abstract: Stephanie Strom Business World column notes Japanese companies have begun cautiously experimenting with practice of outsourcing, but often choose to forgo potential cost savings to be achieved by cutting staff; finds trend reflects stubborn resistance to business practices that sacrifice employee well-being for sake of efficiency; photo (M)

headline: Adding Program Icons To Windows 98 Taskbar
abstract: Adding Program Icons To Windows 98 Taskbar

headline: TOYOTA PLANTS SHUT
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp will temporarily close 13 auto assembly plants in central Japan because rain storms from typhoon disrupted delivery of auto parts (S)

headline: ROCK-TENN TO SHUT DOWN CARTON FACTORY IN WISCONSIN
abstract: Rock-Tenn, manufacturer of paper boxes, will close plant in Madison, Wis, and dismiss up to 200 employees (S)

headline: Online Problems Overseas
abstract: Irene Starr letter comments on July 20 article on using a computer overseas

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WESTERN GAS RESOURCES, Denver, which gathers and processes gas, sold a gas-gathering pipeline system in eastern Oklahoma's Arkoma Basin to an undisclosed buyer for $10.5 million.    STROUDS INC., City of Industry, Calif., a bed and bath linens retailer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after an internal reorganization failed to stem losses. Strouds officials said they would close nine stores.

headline: Titan Sues to Block Damaging Anonymous Web Postings
abstract: Titan Sues to Block Damaging Anonymous Web Postings

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; SATELLITE SWITCHED OFF
abstract: Solidaridad 1, Mexican telecommunications satellite, is switched off after Satmex, country's only satellite operating company, fails in repeated efforts to restart its central processor; $250 million satellite, built by the Hughes Space and Communications, broke down on Aug 27 (S)

headline: Nomura Abandons Financing Of Britain's Spendthrift Dome
abstract: British division of Nomura Securities Co of Japan drops $157 million bid to take over financially ailing Millennium Dome in Greenwich, Eng, at end of year, when New Millennium Experience Co's one-year contract to operate dome expires; photo (M)

headline: Dance With Aliens and Save the World
abstract: Charles Herold reviews Sega's Space Channel 5 game; photo (M)

headline: Tense Election in Lebanon Mired in Bitter Power Plays
abstract: Voting begins in Lebanon's two-stage parliamentary election, overshadowed by Syrian dominance and bitter struggle between current government and its critics; acrimonious campaigns in Mansuriya, Christian heartland of Mount Hermon between Michel Murr, Syrian supporter, and opposition slate headed by wealthy businessman and former ambassador Nassib Lahoud discussed; map (M)

headline: On the Next Vacation, Don't Forget the Laptop
abstract: Survey by Andersen Consulting shows over half workers questioned contacted their office while on their most recent weeklong vacation; finds only 10 perent resented intrusion; shows workers who did not maintain office contact returned to average 37 e-mail messages and 11 voicemail messages and spent about six hours answering them; graphs (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ARMSTRONG HOLDINGS, Lancaster, Pa., named Michael D. Lockhart chairman and chief executive. Mr. Lockhart was most recently chairman and chief executive at General Signal.    BUDGET GROUP, Lisle, Ill., named William S. Johnson chief financial officer, succeeding Neal Cohen, who resigned. Mr. Johnson had been president at the fabrics and fiber division of BP Amoco.

headline: Bankruptices Defy Growth In Furniture
abstract: Recent bankruptcies of furniture sellers Heilig-Meyers Co and Living.com Inc show furniture business is joining retail clothing business in much more competitive arena where poor execution can lead to financial disaster; despite two bankruptcies, sales in furniture industry have been growing at more than 5 percent a year since 1992 and stand at $61 billion; with consumer spending starting to ease, growth in furniture sales is expected to slow to 2 percent to 3 percent this year, but analysts contend bankruptcies speak more to heightened competition than to overall weakness in industry (M)

headline: Stocks Rally As Data Hints At Slower Pace
abstract: Nasdaq composite index jumps 62.63 points, or 1.6 percent, to 4,023.20; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 22.23 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,478.80; Dow Jones industrial average rises 154.51 points, or 1.5 percent, to 10, 635.98; Treasury securities prices rise; yield on 30-year bond falls to 5.87 percent; crude oil for Aug delivery rises 29 cents, to $30.28 a barrel; graphs of stock and crude oil prices; tables of stock prices and key interest rates (M)

headline: Sister Cities of the World Find a Common Cause; Duluth Finds a Key To the Global Economy And Cultural Ties, Too
abstract: Duluth, Minn, and other American cities are reaching out internationally through sister city ties to pursue development projects in globalizing economy; switch in stress from cultural exchanges to international business seems, in part, to stem from recognition of problems in local economy; Duluth now has sister cities in Canada, Japan, Russia and Sweden; Mayor Gary L Doty cites benefits of partnerships; graph; photos (M)

headline: E-Mail Fans Are Friendly Folks, A Sociology Study Indicates
abstract: Study finds that frequent Internet users have far more contact with friends and relatives than infrequent users have (S)

headline: ENRON VENTURE IN JAPAN
abstract: Enron Corp plans to build thermal power plant in Japan (S)

headline: STARMEDIA TO CUT 125 JOBS
abstract: StarMedia Network plans to cut 125 jobs, or 15 percent of its staff, and take one-time charge of $2 million to $4 million in third quarter (S)

headline: Correction: Business School Acceptance Rates''
abstract: A chart on June 18 with an article about changes at the Harvard Business School improperly compared one aspect of the school's admissions with a different apsect of admissions at the Stanford Business School. For Stanord, the chart showed the percentage of applicants who were accepted; for Harvard, it showed the percentage of applicants who were accepted and then actually enrolled. Here is a corrected version showing the acceptance rates for both schools.

headline: Volunteers in White Collars With Political Stripes
abstract: Volunteer services of white-collar workers have become highly prized by political campaigns; business professionals exhibit qualities that political candidate value most: nuts-and-bolts organizational skills, management savvy and address books crammed with contacts; Jose Forquet of Goldman Sachs, who is co-founder of database used by Republican Party, comments; photo (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Phone Surfing For a Few Yen; Japan Web Sites Navigate A Serene Revenue Stream
abstract: Some Japanese Internet sites charge users and collect through customers' cellular telephone bills; this new business model may be tried elsewhere; photos; graph (M)

headline: Nigerian Leader Seeks Peacemaking Role
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 4 — Fifteen months after restoring democracy to Africa's most populous nation for the second time in 20 years, President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria said today that he was ready to step into a larger role in mediating an end to his continent's debilitating wars, beginning with Congo.

headline: Treasury and Debt Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.96 percent and a six-month bill was 6.00 percent.

headline: FEWER BRITISH JOBLESS
abstract: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 25-year low of 3.6 percent in August from 3.7 percent in July as further 18,000 people found work; wage increases fell in three months through July to annualized 3.9 percent, down from 4.1 percent in previous quarter; graph (S)

headline: Two Firms Offer Compromise on S.E.C. Audit Rule
abstract: Ernst & Young and PricewaterhouseCoopers break rank with other accounting firms and offer compromise proposal to impose significant restrictions on consulting work that accountants can do for their audit clients; propsal does not go nearly as far as one that Securities and Exchange Commission has put forth, but it would represent victory for SEC chairman Arthur Levitt, who seems determined to enact new rules this year; compromise proposal would bar auditors from performing some--but not all--internal auditing functions for companies that they audit; it would also restrict how much work audit firms could do in developing management information systems for audit clients (M)

headline: Convalescing, Japan Debates A Rate Rise
abstract: Japan's central bank could decide later this month to raise interest rates from their near-zero level now that economy appears to be gaining momentum; such move would be first increase in Japanese rates in a decade; bank's closely watched quarterly survey of business sentiment shows that big Japanese manufacturers were more confident of their future business prospects in quarter ending on June 30 than they have been in three years (M)

headline: Looking at Change From Both Sides Now
abstract: Interview with Prof Gary Hamel regarding his specialty, instilling the capacity for innovation in employees; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS; Hospital Chain's Critics Call Recovery Incomplete
abstract: Jeffrey C Barbakow, head of hospital chain owner Tenet Healthcare Corp, believes that his skills have led to hospitals' improved performance for both shareholders and patients; but workers and patients remain unsatisfied; photos (M)

headline: VODAFONE STAKE FOR SALE
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa will sell part of its 3.4 percent stake in Vodafone Airtouch, which it acquired through sale of Orange PLC to Mannesmann of Germany and Vodafone's subsequent takeover of Mannesmann; will sell $2.5 billion three-year bond that will be convertible into Vodafone shares (S)

headline: Pension Fund Issues Scorecard
abstract: $172 billion California Public Employees' Retirement System says it earned 10.5 percent on its investments in year ended June 30; performance is third consecutive decline in returns for Calpers (S)

headline: Quarterly Profit Falls 14% at News Corporation
abstract: News Corp says after-tax profit for fourth quarter fell 14 percent; profit before extraordinary items was $184 million compared with $214 million in year-earlier period; revenue in quarter ended June 30 rose 18 percent, to $3.9 billion (S)

headline: SAUDI INVESTS $50 MILLION MORE IN PRICELINE
abstract: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will invest $50 million in Priceline.com; photo (S)

headline: Kmart to Cut Inventory, Jobs And 72 Stores
abstract: Kmart Corp will take pretax charge of $740 million for inventory clearance and store closings; says substantial investment in technology will be critical to future growth; warns that excluding this write-off, second-quarter earnings will miss expectations; plans to close 72 stores and eliminate 5,000 jobs (M)

headline: About the Tables
abstract: New York Times has revised its stock tables, listing prices in dollars and cents rather than in fractions (S)

headline: Faltering Euro Faces Test in Markets Today
abstract: European Central Bank will have toughness and credibility tested on first trading day for foreign exchange markets since sagging euro won pledges of support from the world's major central banks; regards successful intervention as crucial for its credibility and that of currency itself (S)

headline: SINGER REORGANIZES AND EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Singer Co completes reorganization and emerges from bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: KELLWOOD AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF WOMEN'S CLOTHING
abstract: Kellwood Co acquires Dorby Frocks Ltd, women's clothing maker (S)

headline: Color Choices for Headphones Make Them iMacs for the Ears
abstract: Sony offers lightweigh headphones for use with portable music devices that come with interchangeable shells in translucent colors; photo (S)

headline: Merger or Not, Executives At Sprint Can Still Cash Out
abstract: With merger between Sprint and Worldcom all but called off, question is whether Sprint executives are going to stay and, if so, for how long; when Sprint shareholders approved $115 billion deal in April, merger agreement specified that most of Sprint's stock options outstanding would become fully vested and exercisable; that means that Sprint executives who were given stock options as incentive to stay with company, can cash them in and leave; photo (M)

headline: A Hollow Lesson
abstract: Labor agreement between Verizon Communications and Communications Workers of America shoul have little effect on rest of industry; Verizon will continue to be penalized to tune of billions of dollars of market value for strength of its unions (M)

headline: Netscape to Remove Feature in SmartDownload
abstract: Netscape to Remove Feature in SmartDownload

headline: Arab-Israeli Talks Open at Camp David
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak, Yasir Arafat and Pres Clinton begin their summit meeting at Camp David in Maryland, and Clinton speaks in idealistic tones of securing a just and enduring end to Israeli-Palestinian conflict; Israeli officials say they will soon resolve their dispute with Clinton administration over contract to sell Phalcon advanced radar system to the Chinese; photos (M)

headline: MTV CUTTING ONLINE JOBS
abstract: Viacom will cut staff at MTVi Group, Internet division of MTV Networks, by 105 positions, or 25 percent; postpones plans for spinoff of year-old MTVi, whose 22 Web sites include MTV.com, VH1.com and Sonicnet.com (S)

headline: Police Arrest 25 in Connection With Indonesia Bombings
abstract: Indonesian police arrest 25 people in connection with recent series of bombings in Jakarta, including one that killed 15 people at stock exchange; say suspects admitted carrying out bombings and indicated next target was American Embassy (M)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: INTERNETDISPOSABLE CREDIT CARD NUMBERS American Express said that within a month it plans to begin offering a free service that will generate random numbers that can be used instead of account numbers for cardholders making online purchases. A cardholder would be able to obtain a "private payment number" that could be used at any site that accepts American Express cards. To save a few clicks, cardholders would be able to download software from the company's Web site that would automatically produce a payment number for purchases at selected e-tailers, a spokeswoman said.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture accompanying July 2 article about Gen Wesley K Clark; photo showed Gen Joseph W Raltson, not Clark (S)

headline: In Challenge, Iraqi Jet Flew Over Saudi Desert, U.S. Says
abstract: State Dept says Iraqi fighter jet flew into Saudi Arabian airspace last week in suspected attempt to provoke confrontation with United States on eve of United Nations summit meeting in New York; flight heightens what American officials describe as sense that Pres Saddam Hussein is determined to test American resolve; in United Nations, tensions over Iraq are running high as Baghdad continues to refuse to cooperate with new team of weapons inspectors or with other UN humanitarian efforts (M)

headline: KOREAN STEEL CONCERN
abstract: South Korean government attempts for third time to sell its stake in Pohang Iron & Steel Company (S)

headline: Article 2000072690077884688 -- No Title
abstract: In a legal document filed today, Microsoft said the complexity of its antitrust case made it completely unsuitable for direct appeal to the Supreme Court. The Microsoft argument rests heavily on a scathing attack on the handling of the case by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who heard the suit in federal district court.

headline: Hussein Aide Says Iraq Won't Cooperate With Arms Monitoring
abstract: Two-day meeting of international arms inspection experts convenes at United Nations to review new monitoring operations for Iraq, but Tariq Aziz, Iraq's deputy prime minister, denounces the inspection commission and vows again never to cooperate with it (M)

headline: Kozmo.com Delays IPO, Talks to Buy Urbanfetch.com Continue
abstract: Kozmo.com Delays IPO, Talks to Buy Urbanfetch.com Continue

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: U.S. ESPIONAGE INQUIRY  The European Parliament in Strasbourg has voted to form a committee to investigate allegations that Washington's vast surveillance system, called Echelon, is being used to conduct industrial espionage now that the cold war is over. The system, maintained by the United States and several allies including Britain, listens to and watches millions of telephone, fax and e-mail messages each day. The committee is expected to report back in about eight months.    Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: INSTINET OFFERING PLANNED
abstract: Reuters decides to sell shares in Instinet, its electronic trading platform, in initital public offering (S)

headline: MODEM MAKER'S LOSS WIDENS
abstract: Efficient Networks Inc says its loss widened to $49.6 million in quarter ended June 30, from $12.3 million a year earlier; sales surged to $101.9 million from $7.7 million (S)

headline: Key Rates

headline: America Online Registers Strong Profit for Quarter
abstract: America Online reports fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $338 million, up 115 percent from year earlier; company earned $1.2 billion on sales of $6.9 billion, marking first time Internet company has earned more than $1 billion in a year; subscription revenue increased by 26 percent, to $1.2 billion (M)

headline: Nortel to Buy Sonoma Systems
abstract: August 16, 2000

headline: For the Families, Anger Mixes With Mourning
abstract: Sadness and anger grip Murmansk, Russian port city dominated by naval bases, where few people now hold out any hope for lives of 118 men trapped aboard submarine Kursk; familes of seven of the sailors are en route to Murmansk from city of Kursk, for which submarine is named; map; photo (M)

headline: PANCANADIAN WILL ACQUIRE OIL AND GAS ASSETS
