abstract: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd will buy oil and natural gas businesses of Montana Power Company for $475 million (S)

headline: Software Tells Wireless E-Mail To Please Get to the Point
abstract: Software company AmikaNow offers Web-based service that it says will automatically extract only most important sentences from long E-mail messages before passing them on to a wireless device (S)

headline: Nordstrom Chicago Debut
abstract: Nordstrom Inc opens its first department store in Chicago (S)

headline: COX SAYS IT SOLD $412 MILLION IN SPRINT PCS STOCK
abstract: Cox Communications sold $412.6 million in Sprint PCS stock in June and July (S)

headline: Swiss Acquirer Has Had Plenty of Its Own Problems
abstract: Profile of UBS, huge Swiss bank that is acquiring PaineWebber Group; chairman Marcel Ospel aims to refocus bank on managing money for wealth individuals worldwide (M)

headline: A Symbol of France Crashes in Flames
abstract: Witnesses say Air France Concorde jet was on fire as it took off from airport near Paris; residents of nearby Gonesse, where plane crashed, are shocked and distressed; maps; drawings table of data on Concorde (M)

headline: ALLAIRE STOCK FALLS 40 PERCENT
abstract: Shares of Allaire, which makes software that lets companies tailor Web site content for electronic commerce, fall sharply after company says sales of its core product will fall far short of expectations; graph (S)

headline: Rome Journal; Love-In for 2 Million Youths, Heartily Blessed by the Pope
abstract: More than two million young people gather in Rome, Italy, for Mass celebrated by John Paul II and for overnight vigil, closing out six-day World Youth Festival timed to coincide with Roman Catholic Holy Year; youth gathering is largest ever held in West; festival, which drew hundreds of thousands to packed prayer services throughout city and to mass confessions, described; photos (M)

headline: Watching and Wondering
abstract: Maggie Stenz letter complains that too many articles in Circuits section are about products and not about the real issues surrounding technology, including moral and ethical ones

headline: Technology Cases Raise Issues of Competence
abstract: Are today's technology issues too complex for the typical judge to judge?

headline: Frierson Mee Opening Paris Office
abstract: Ad agency Frierson Mee & Kraft is opening office in Paris (S)

headline: Court Says Agents Went Too Far in Online Sting
abstract: July 7, 2000

headline: Discarded Hindu God Does Not Bless India's Water
abstract: Bombay's annual Ganesh Festival begins, 10-day celebration of Hindu god Ganesh--bestower of happiness and eliminator of sorrow; festival is as much partying as prayer; tens of thousands of brightly colored statues of long-trunked deity are carried through the streets, then put in honored places in private homes or elaborate outdoor shrines; environmentalists do not like the way event traditionally ends, with icons disposed of in ceremonial immersion, by leaving them to disintegrate in lakes, creeks and conveniently located Arabian Sea; environmentalists contend there are massive fish deaths from toxins in paint; photos (L)

headline: Study Claims Downloads Spur Offline Music Sales
abstract: Study by Jupiter Communications concludes that people who use Napster and other Web sites that allow sharing of songs as MP3 files are 45 percent more likely to be CD buyers than nonusers are; Jupiter also faults study by Recording Industry Association of America that shows CD sales in stores near colleges have dropped in areas with high levels of MP3 usage (M)

headline: Diamond Traders Act on Africa War Issue
abstract: World Diamond Council expects to set up computerized global registry before Christmas shopping season that will help curb sale of gems used to finance wars in Africa; House Ways and Means Committee has scheduled subcommittee hearing to consider its own steps against trade in so-called conflict diamonds (S)

headline: Automated Advice Sites Turning Up the Heat on Planners
abstract: MOST of his peers look at the Internet and see a threat to their livelihood, but Frank Armstrong sees a medium for spreading the gospel of financial discipline to those he could not reach otherwise.    When he is not managing the finances of his wealthy clients from his office in Miami, Mr. Armstrong is serving as the chief investment strategist for DirectAdvice, an Internet company that says it is a low-price substitute for financial planners like Mr. Armstrong. DirectAdvice is one of several electronic services that have sprung up over the last year, offering investors advice on what to do with their money for as little as $50 a year.

headline: Stonyfield Farm tries to change the world and sell some yogurt.
abstract: Stonyfield Farm Inc's new print ads for organic yogurt features celebrities who are advocates of environmental causes or other projects, using them as link between commendable causes and Stonyfield's goal to change the world; since company was started 17 years ago, its dual mission has been to sell organic yogurt, while at same time promoting social and environmental causes; photo (M)

headline: BET IS BUYING 360HIPHOP
abstract: BET.com, a Web adjunct to Black Entertainment Television cable network, will buy a key competitor, 360HIPHOP.com, which is geared to music trends and information; photo (S)

headline: Pinochet Ruled No Longer Immune From Prosecution
abstract: Chilean Supreme Court divests Gen Augusto Pinochet of his senatorial immunity, removing legal hurdle to charging former dictator with role in kidnapping, torture and murder of thousands of people during his 17-year rule; demonstrators hail decision, Santiago; decision, which also ratifies legal doctrine that anyone who disappeared during dictatorship and is still missing is victim of ongoing kidnapping not covered by amnesty, will likely lead to prosecution of dozens of other retired military and police officers; ruling provokes veiled sniping between Pres Ricardo Lagos, Socialist, and army commander Gen Ricardo Izurieta, who has tried to coexist with civilian presidents and keep right-wing elements at bay; Izurieta makes provocative visit to Pinochet's home to express army's support for him; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: Technology Briefings

headline: Chips Off the P.& G. Block; Can a Start-Up Clean Up With Cast-Off Brands?
abstract: Article describes Redox Brands Inc, business begun and run by former Proctor & Gamble employees Todd Wichmann and Richard Owen; firm specializes in buying once-famous laundry and cleaning products which giant companies are willing to discard, and then marketing these cast-off brands; photos; graph (M)

headline: Britain Winces Over Denmark's Rejection of the Euro
abstract: Danish voters' resounding rejection of single European currency threatens British Prime Min Tony Blair's plan for similar vote, cornerstone of his effort to persuade reluctant Britons to adopt euro; passions highlighted by Danish vote undermine his efforts to cast Britain's debate in mainly economic terms; skeptics in Britain hold Danes rejected euro as precursor of European superstate that would submerge their sovereignty (M)

headline: The Electronic Fence: Guarding the Dog
abstract: The Electronic Fence: Guarding the Dog

headline: FISHER SCIENTIFIC SHARES JUMP AS PURCHASE IS CALLED OFF
abstract: Shares of Fisher Scientific International Inc rise 44 percent on news that it has ended its plan to buy PSS World Medical Inc for $746.9 million (S)

headline: Students See Risk in Online College Applications
abstract: July 6, 2000

headline: Fast-Forwarding Those Campus Visits
abstract: Collegiate Choice offers videotapes of college campuses which allow prospective student applicants to preview campus atmospheres without traveling to visit; drawing (M)

headline: Tread Failures Lead to Recall Of 6.5 Million Firestone Tires
abstract: WASHINGTON Aug. 9 -- The company that makes Firestone tires said today that millions of tires it had produced since 1991 seemed unusually prone to flinging off their treads, sometimes with catastrophic results. Facing 50 lawsuits, 46 deaths, 80 injuries and a federal investigation, the company said it would provide free replacements for the 6.5 million tires still on the road.

headline: Russia Drops Criminal Inquiry Into Troublesome Press Tycoon
abstract: Russian prosecutors abruptly drop high-profile criminal inquiry into Valdimir Gusinsky, press tycoon whose Media-Most empire has been among government's sharpest critics; prosecutors offer no explanation for abandoning investigation, although as recently as three weeks ago they had insisted to Parliament that Gusinsky defrauded government of at least $10 million; it is notable that inquiry is halted just before meeting between many of Russia's wealthiest of most politically influential tycoons and Pres Vladimir V Putin, whose government has moved against several of them in tax evasion and criminal cases; photo (M)

headline: Siegelgale Selected By Marriott
abstract: Marriott International names Siegelgate to handle advertising for Marriott and Renaissance hotels (S)

headline: About the Tables
abstract: New York Times is revising its stock market tables, listing prices in dollar and cents rather than in fractions; change is being made as stock markets move toward quoting prices of stocks and options in decimals (S)

headline: Rooting for WordPerfect
abstract: Kevin Rothman letter on Joel Brinkley's Sept 21 article on word processing software notes Adobe Acrobat is application, not format

headline: UNION PLANTERS TO ACQUIRE JEFFERSON SAVINGS BANCORP
abstract: Union Planters Corp acquires Jefferson Savings Bancorp Inc for about $140 million in stock (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Drop in inventories causes crude oil to rise; chart of commodities prices (S)

headline: India Jolted as One Legend Abducts Another
abstract: Legendary Indian outlaw Veerappan, who has eluded for decade hundreds of policeman dedicated to hunting him down in vast jungles of South India, has abducted beloved movie star Rajkumar in what police call bold bid to win pardon; has kept silent about what he wants, letting drama build; is sought for killing dozens of his pursuers, as well as strangling newborn daughter to silence her telltale cries; protests by star's fans have brought Bangalore, cosmopolitan city, to halt; most people return to work and bus service is restored, but schools remain closed and tensions remain high; photos; map (M)

headline: Warm and Fuzzy I.S.P.'s
abstract: Letter from George Hunka on Aug 17 article on Internet Service Providers

headline: Role Playing Without Sacrificing Action
abstract: Peter Olafson reviews Blizzard Entertainment's video game Diablo II; photos (M)1

headline: CNH GLOBAL TO CLOSE PLANTS AND ELIMINATE 1,800 JOBS
abstract: CNH Global NV, world's second-largest maker of farm tractors and combines, will close or sell seven plants in US and Germany, eliminating 1,800 jobs, or about 4.7 percent of work force (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro drops against US dollar after surprise decline in German business confidence; in New York, euro settles at 89.79 cents, down from 90.15 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Its Own Stock Battered, Softbank Abandons Spinoff Plan
abstract: Softbank Corp, one of world's biggest investors in Internet start-up companies, whose own share price has fallen more than 70 percent this year, abandons plan to sell shares in five subsidiaries (M)

headline: CONSECO INTENDS TO RAISE $2 BILLION OVER NEXT YEAR
abstract: Conseco Inc expects to raise $2 billion over next 12 to 15 months from selling assets and overhauling its consumer-lending unit (S)

headline: Lizards Behind PC Glass (Whew!)
abstract: Discovery.com offers virtual exhibition on lizards developed with American Museum of Natural History; photo (S)

headline: AT&T WIRELESS AGREES TO BUY SBC INDIANAPOLIS UNIT
abstract: AT&T Wireless Group agrees to buy Indianapolis wireless system of SBC Communications Inc for about $530 million in cash; deal would add more than 113,000 subscribers (S)

headline: British Airways and KLM End Merger Talks
abstract: British Airways and KLM abaond their merger talks; numerous regulatory and operational hurdles, in the end, were too much for bargaining powers of two companies to overcome; talks and their collapse leave trail of uncertainty about future of consolidation in airline industry in Europe and US; photo (M)

headline: McDonald's Shifts To New Slogan
abstract: McDonald's Corp is switching its ad slogan for first time in three years; new slogan, 'We love to see you smile,' is being introduced in campaign centered on changes company is making to its food and restaurants; campaign was created by DDB Worldwide (Advertising column) (S)

headline: NOKIA IN PHILIPPINES DEAL
abstract: Finnish cellular phone company Nokia signs $300 million contract to supply Philippine cellular operator Smart Communications with equipment to expand Smart's digital network (S)

headline: CANADA TRADE SETBACKS
abstract: World Trade Organization deals Canada two losses, with ruling against country's handling of certain patents and another ruling in favor of France's ban of Canadian building-product exports containing asbestos; WTO upholds earlier ruling that Canadian law limiting some patent protection to 17 years, instead of 20, violated global trade rules; decision primarily affects pharmaceutical patents; in asbestos case, WTO publishes official ruling allowing France's ban on grounds it was justified by exceptions for protecting human health (S)

headline: Four A's Web Site Is Sabotaged
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies says its Web site was broken into and material was posted there in support of actors' strike against broadcast advertisers (S)

headline: Media Talk; Questionable Letter For a Liar's Memoir
abstract: Lauren Slater, author of Lying: A Metaphorical Memoir, sends letter to New York Times Book Review purporting to be from the philosophy professor who wrote book's introduction and who wanted to rebut assertion by Rebecca Mead, who reviewed book, that he did not exist; says that her editors knew professor was fiction and that letter was intended to be funny; photo (M)

headline: Wells Fargo in G.E. Deal
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co agrees to buy most of GE Capital Mortgage Services's mortgage business and to collect its loan payments, becoming biggest processor of mortgage bills in nation (S)

headline: MEDIA: Dreaming in Tighter Focus; DreamWorks Scales Back Its Once-Grand Vision
abstract: Dreamworks SKG, which planned works in wide range of entertainment media, finds true success only in movie making, with its films grossing on average 15 percent more per film than any other studio; ranks close second behind Walt Disney Co's Buena Vista so far this year in box office revenue, even though Buena Vista has released nearly twice as many movies; David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg comment on scaled back plans; graphs of box office receipts; photos (M)

headline: Toysmart.com In Settlement With F.T.C.
abstract: Federal Trade Commission announces settlement to permit defunct online toy merchant Toysmart.com to sell its customer database as part of its bankruptcy plan; objections continue from privacy advocates and attorneys general of 39 states (M)

headline: Despite Benefits, Democrats' Estate Tax Plan Gets Little Notice
abstract: Small-business owners and farmers whose Washington lobbyists ardently support Republican plan to repeal estate tax seem largely unaware that Pres Clinton, who intends veto, has said he would sign legislation that would exempt nearly all of them from estate tax starting next year; photo; Democratic version would allow business owners and farmers to leave $2 million to heirs without tax, but Republicans insist that total elimination is only effective reform; tax experts Sanford J Schlesinger and Neil Hart point out that Democrats are offering better deal of immediate relief, but lobbying groups have done little to inform members (M)

headline: Metropolitan Life Earnings Up 18% in Quarter
abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance reports second-quarter operating earnings rose 18 percent, to $374 million, compared with $317 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: KEY MISSILE PARTS ARE LEFT UNTESTED AS BOOSTER FAILS
abstract: Crucial test in Pentagon's complex, $60 billion antimissile defensive system fails after high-speed interceptor 'kill vehicle' designed to destroy dummy warhead fails to separate from booster rocket; failure will make it politically and diplomatically more difficult for Pres Clinton to move ahead with plan administration contends is crucial to defend against attack, but which opponents say is technically unsound, militarily unnecessary and waste of money; reinforces calls in Congress to leave decision to next president; failure was in well-developed technology, used successfully in rockets that have launched satellites and missiles for decades; photo (M)

headline: Baldissero Canavese Journal; New-Age Commune Is Into Crafts and Time Travel
abstract: Damanhur, commune nestled amid tiny rural villages in Baldissero Canavese, Italy, has melded its California-style New Age spirituality with Northern Italy's customs and mores; its 500 residents, when not experimenting with time travel and 'Selfic' healing, make luxury craft items for export and have built ornate underground temple; founder, Oberto Airaudi, comments; map; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: IRANIANS PROTEST  Thousands of Iranians in exile demonstrated in Berlin against the start of a three-day state visit by President Mohammad Khatami. The police arrested scattered protesters after detaining dozens of opponents of the Tehran government during overnight searches of local residences. Security is high during Mr. Khatami's visit, the first by an Iranian leader since the 1979 Islamic revolution. Critics had urged Germany to withdraw the invitation because of Iran's poor rights record.    Alan Maimon (NYT)    FRANCE: MORE MAD COW DISEASE  Officials have found another three cases of mad cow disease, bringing the total this year to 26. The new outbreaks virtually assure that authorities will discover far more cases this year than they did last year, when 31 cases were recorded. Officials had hoped to see the number of cases declining by now. A testing program that started last month is likely to increase the number of cases even further, officials have warned.    Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: Redefining a 208-Year-Old Bank
abstract: Profile of David A Spina, chief executive of State Street Corp who is trying to redefine bank's divisive image and expand company into new financial services; photo (M)

headline: CANADA WEIGHS SANCTIONS
abstract: World Trade Organization rules that Canada may impose up to $157 million in sanctions over six-year period against Brazil to punish country for illegally subsidizing jet airline industry (S)

headline: These Unlikely Neighbors Won't Have Much to Say
abstract: London representatives of three rival American buyout firms will all occupy same building in fashionable St James district: Texas Pacific Group, Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; secrecy will become more important to all three (S)

headline: No Need for Lifeline After Kathie Lee
abstract: Television executives expect Live with Regis & Kathie Lee television program, which will be renamed Live with Regis, to survive Kathie Lee Gifford's departure because of Philbin's popularity; Buena Vista Television, which syndicates program, plans to use guest co-hosts while seeking replacement; photo (M)

headline: Wireless: The Latest Fund Fad To Fly On
abstract: Mutual fund industry has always been given to fads, and latest is wireless technology; four wireless sector funds have opened this year, and another is set to join them; last year, it was Internet funds, which now number 20-30, up from three in 1998; 25 telecommunications funds are open to set to open, up from 10 in 1998; drawing, chart (M)

headline: European Aircraft Maker Prices Its Shares
abstract: European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Co prices its stock at 19 euros a share for institutional investors; this puts a value on the company in total of around 15 billion euros, or $14.2 billion, one-fifth lower than analysts expected (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Phone Workers Threaten A Strike Against Verizon  In what would be one of the biggest strikes in a decade, 85,000 telephone workers on the East Coast are threatening to walk out next weekend in a struggle that pits old-line labor against the New Economy.    The workers are facing off with Verizon Communications -- the name that Bell Atlantic adopted last month after acquiring GTE -- in large part because they fear the company's widespread use of lower paid, nonunion workers in its fastest growing businesses, most notably wireless phones, will endanger the wages and benefits of unionized workers. [Page A1.]

headline: Business Travel; Oh joyous day! Virgin Atlantic makes it possible for passengers to use cell phones on flights.
abstract: Virgin Atlantic Airways becomes first airline to allow passengers to receive calls via their mobile phone number while in flight, using new technology that routes incoming cellular calls to handsets at passengers' seats; system was developed by British Telecommunications (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Swiss to Vote On Plan to Set Limit on Influx Of Immigrants
abstract: Switzerland to vote on proposal to restrict foreigners to 18 percent of population, now 7.3 million; nation, with largest number of foreigners per capita in Europe, is caught up in anti-foreigner sentiment; government is lobbying strongly against quota (M)/

headline: Nortel Negotiates With JDS Uniphase on Fiber Optics Supply
abstract: Nortel Networks and JDS Uniphase are in talks on multiyear supply agreement that would ease Nortel's concerns about JDS's proposed acquisition of rival, SDL Inc; agreement would guarantee Nortel supply of fiber optic components from JDS Uniphase; Nortel expects its sales of fiber optic equipment to exceed $10 billion this year and needs to ensure that it has enough components to make those products and to increase production in the future (M)

headline: French Minister Quits Post Over Autonomy for Corsica
abstract: Jean-Pierre Chevenement, key figure in Prime Min Lionel Jospin's government, resigns as French interior minister to protest Jospin's plan to give Corsica limited autonomy as way to end decades of separatist violence; photo; map; Chevenement warns of similar demands from other regions (M)

headline: Art Auction Houses Agree to Pay $512 Million in Price-Fixing Case
abstract: Sotheby's and Christie's agree to pay $512 million to settle charges that they cheated buyers and sellers in price-fixing scheme dating back to 1992; reported civil settlement comes as Justice Department steps up three-year criminal probe on collusion that stifled competition; settlement is equivalent of 3-4 years of annual pretax profits, but trial judgment could have reached $1.3 billion; civil case arose from federal antitrust probe of years of secret meetings involving Christopher M Davidge of Christie's and Diana D Brooks of Sotheby's, as well as longtime Sotheby's chairman A Alfred Taubman (M)

headline: Mexican Opposition Identifies 3,300 in Bank Loan Scandal
abstract: Opposition lawmakers in Mexico disclose names of about 3,300 wealthy debtors linked to questionable bank loans that became part of huge government bailout; list of loans totaling $7.8 billion includes many top-echelon magnates who were close to government and fell into deep financial trouble after currency crash of 1995; one $422,000 loan went directly to governing Institutional Revolutionary Party; also included are loans to several prominent bankers who are known to be facing criminal prosecution for huge frauds; entire bank rescue so far has cost Mexican taxpayers $100 billion (M)

headline: Murdoch Reduces Stake in EchoStar
abstract: SEC filing shows Rupert Murdoch sold seven million EchoStar Communications Corp shares worth $343 million on Sept 6 (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: TERROR CHARGES FOR 4 WESTERNERS -- The Yugoslav Army says it will press terrorism charges against two Canadians and two Britons arrested in Montenegro last week. Britain has described its two citizens, Adrian Prangnell and John Yore, as policemen helping to train a new force in Kosovo. They were traveling with the Canadians, Shaun Going, who also worked in Kosovo, and his nephew Liam Hall. Like many Westerners visiting Montenegro, the four did not have Yugoslav visas. Dutch officials are also seeking access to four of their nationals arrested some three weeks ago in Serbia and accused of plotting to kidnap President Slobodan Milosevic.   (Reuters)    YUGOSLAVIA: NEW MILOSEVIC CHALLENGER -- Formalizing the breach in opposition ranks and dimming chances of voting out Mr. Milosevic, a coalition chose a new challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, left, to run against him. Most opposition parties endorsed Mr. Kostunica, a moderate nationalist. But the Serbian Renewal Movement, the single largest opposition party, chose another candidate, the Belgrade mayor, Vojislav Mihajlovic.   (AP)

headline: EARTHGRAINS STRIKE IN SOUTHERN STATES EXPANDS
abstract: Strike at Earthgrains Co plant in Fort Payne, Ala, spreads to five other bakeries where worker contracts have expired; workers are represented by Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers union (S)

headline: Oldest Son's Revels Embarrass Blair
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, who has made a point of keeping his four young children out of news, is embarrassed by front-page headlines reporting arrest of his 16-year-old son, Euan, for public drunkenness (S)

headline: Advertising Gains Lift Profit At Times Co. and Gannett
abstract: New York Times Co says net income increased 21.8 percent in second quarter; Gannett reports 13 percent increase in profit; Times Co posts net income of $101.7 million compared with $83.5 million a year earlier; revenue rose 13.6 percent, to $885.6 million from $779.4 million; advertising revenue increased 14.3 percent, to $564 million; revenue at New York Times Digital grew to $13.5 million from $5 million, while operating losses rose to $15.5 million from $4.6 million; Gannett reports net income of $265.8 million compared with profit of $234.8 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 16 percent, to $1.49 billion from $1.28 billion (M)

headline: SoBe beverages plans a strategy to sustain its heady growth.
abstract: Sobe, four-year-old maker of noncarbonated beverages, is off to successful start, and co-founder John Bello plans more advertising as industry leaders, like Coca-Cola Co, take aim at upstart; Sobe has plans to put at least $12 million into advertising and sports sponsorship this year and will introduce several products in coming months; it has also announced plans to sell two-third stake to investment firm J W Childs Associates, development that many believe will lead to initial public offering of company; SoBe's rival, Snapple Beverages, is planning to go public later this year in offering estimated at $115 million; Coca-Cola and PepsiCo say they plan to introduce products similar to those marketed by SoBe and Snapple; photo (M)

headline: Global Crossing-Exodus Deal Said to Collapse
abstract: Global Crossing and Exodus Communications fail to agree on price for Global Crossing's Web site-hosting unit, Global Center, and the deal collapses (M)

headline: QWEST MOVES TO OPEN SYSTEM
abstract: US West, part of Qwest Communications International Inc, announces series of complicated technical initiatives meant to help new local phone companies connect to its network; Quest says it will allow its competitors to put more of their equipment in Qwest's facilities and will withdraw 17 lawsuits it has filed against state regulators challenging their ability to force company to open its systems (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Sporting goods Web sites, last year's costly rage, are turned over to the professionals.
abstract: Article on services provided by sporting goods Web sites such as EFanShop.com, SameDay.com and MVP.com; says leading company providing sevices to sports-related sites is Global Sports Interactive, which created and runs online stores of Sports Authority and Group Rallye's Athlete's Foot, among other retailers; photo (M)

headline: In Testimony, Firestone Puts Onus on Ford
abstract: Firestone Tire begins unusually explicit attack on safety of Ford Explorers in testimony before House subcommittee as two companies criticize each other's products and executives from both companies try to explain internal documents that committee members found incriminating; Firestone says operating Ford Explorer with its tires inflated to pressure recommended by automaker, 26 pounds per square inch, provides smaller 'margin of safety' than exists for competing sport utility vehicles; Ford says that Firestone tires on 1996 Explorers were involved in fatal rollover accidents at rate 15 times of Goodyear tires on same vehicle; Ford vice president Helen O Petrauskas tells Repr Billy Tauzin, who is presiding at hearing, that 26 pounds per square inch her company recommends is not only optimum level for handling, ride comfort and tire endurance, but is also well within guidelines of Tire and Rim Association; Bridgestone/Firestone Inc executive vice president John Lampe says '26 is the minimum for a speed-rate tire'; photo (M)

headline: Murdoch Deal Could Revamp New York TV
abstract: Sale of TV stations owned by Chris-Craft Industries to News Corp, owner of Fox network, is expected to be announced formally this week; $3.5 billion sale of 10 stations would give News Corp leader Rupert Murdoch ownership of two powerful TV stations in several major cities, including New York and Los Angeles; would also give him extended control of dissemination of local news in New York, where he would own both Channel 5 and Channel 9 as well The New York Post newspaper; deal raises questions about how News Corp will handle Federal Communications Commission restrictions on cross-ownership of newspapers and TV stations in same city; also throws into question what may happen to UPN network, owned by Viacom, which also bid for the Chris-Craft stations; UPN is slated to become the Paramount Network in January; Murdoch photo (M)

headline: TELEPHONE AND DATA PLANS $230 MILLION STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Telephone & Data Systems says it will buy back up to two millions shares of common stock worth $230 million (S)

headline: A Glossy Fund Sets Its Debut
abstract: Time Warner's Fortune Group plans to launch two exchange-traded funds later this year, including Fortune-50 Index Tracking Stock, which will be based on Fortune magazine's new 'e-50' Internet index (M)

headline: Built-In Telnet
abstract: Robert Furtkamp letter on Aug 31 Q & A article on Telnet

headline: Mexico Is Ordered to Pay a U.S. Company $16.7 Million
abstract: International tribunal orders Mexican government to pay $16.7 million in compensatory damages to Metalclad Corp, American company whose multimillion-dollar hazardous waste treatment and disposal site was blocked on environmental ground by government of San Luis Potosi; under Chapter 11 of North American Free Trade Agreement, disputes of this type that cannot be settled through negotiations may be brought before tribunal, International Center for Investment Dispute Settlement, obscure arm of World Bank; Nafta critics say decision shows how treaty can be used to circumvent local laws; company defends its compliance with environmentl regulations and says damages do not reflect its losses (M)

headline: Nasdaq Rises Sharply With Rebound in Computer Stocks
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 139.12 points, or 3.7 percent, to 3,865.64; Dow Jones industrial average falls 19.23 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,789.29; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 15.39 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,459.90; graph; chart (M)

headline: Amazon.com Revises Privacy Policy on Consumer Concern
abstract: Amazon.com Revises Privacy Policy on Consumer Concern

headline: HONG KONG GREW 10.8% IN QUARTER
abstract: Hong Kong extends its recovery, reporting that economic output grew 10.8 percent in second quarter; government raises its forecast for full-year growth to 8.5 percent, from 6 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Sales at Cisco Systems Increase 61% in Quarter  Cisco Systems reported a 61 percent gain in sales for its fiscal fourth quarter, as the company continued to be the leading supplier of the necessary hardware for the Internet.     Excluding acquisition-related charges, Cisco's earnings exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates by a penny a share. [Page C6.]

headline: Intel Logs 80% Rise in Net and Big Revenue Growth
abstract: Intel Corp says it earned $3.14 billion in second quarter ended June 30, up almost 80 percent from $1.75 billion in year-earlier period; revenue rose 23 percent, to $8.30 billion, from just under $6.75 billion (M)

headline: Putin, Exerting His Authority, Meets With Russia's Tycoons
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin convenes meeting with Russian tycoons to impress on them that he is one who runs country; some business leaders say they told Putin they are prepared to forgo special treatment and abide by government rules--if Kremlin creates fairer business climate; say that in return, they won Putin's assurance that they could hold onto their wealth and that their purchases of state property during post-Soviet privatizations would not be overturned; it is not clear whether Putin is really prepared to challenge vested interests and clean up government (M)

headline: Famous Dinosaur Gets Her Own Web Pages
abstract: Sue, world's largest, best-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex, has her own Web pages, part of Web site of Field Museum in Chicago, where Sue makes her home; site described; photo (M)

headline: BREWER'S PROFIT FALLS
abstract: Tsingtao Brewery Co of China says its first-half profit fell 7 percent, to 46.7 million yuan ($5.6 million), although sales rose nearly 51 percent thanks to a gain in market share achieved through purchases of small breweries (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of September 17 article about effects of Firestone's tire recall on its competitors, which misstated name of Michelin North America marketing president Scott Clark (not Scott Blake) (S)

headline: Philippine Leader, Facing Bad Reviews, Is Ready for a Change in His Image
abstract: Philippine public is desperate for Pres Joseph Estrada to address faltering economy, corruption and cronyism that seem to be ascendant, and Muslim separatists and kidnappers who are getting out of hand; Estrada, his options narrowed, has unleashed his army in take-no-prisoners campaign against rebels on island of Mindanao; political commentators seem unimpressed; investors are concerned about old-style cronyism that surrounds Estrada's government; World Bank recently estimated that corruption was costing Philippines $46 million a year; Estrada, former B-movie actor, has lackadaisical approach to government and has become subject of jokes, gossip and coup rumors; photos; map (M)

headline: Judge Rules Against MP3 On CD Copying
abstract: Judge Jed S Rakoff rules that MP3.com willingly infringed copyrights of Universal Music Group and orders it to pay $25,000 for each of Universal compact discs included in its My.MP3.com service; service lets users listen to music from any computer connected to Internet after indicating that they possess CD or have purchased it through online vendor associated with company; total damages could reach as high as $250 million, depending on how many copyrights MP3.com is found to have infringed (M)

headline: High-Tech Executives Urge Action on World's Digital Divide
abstract: World Economic Forum task force of high-technology executives urges wealthiest nations to act to erase growing digital divide separating developed and developing worlds, news conference; gives Japanese Prime Min Yoshiro Mori series of proposals; Japanese executives say Mori will announce at summit meeting of leaders of seven industrial nations that Japan will commit $12 billion in loans and $3 billion in grants over five years to information-technology initiatives in developing world (M)

headline: Ford Chief Executive Declines to Testify in Congressional Inquiry on Bridgestone Tires
abstract: DETROIT, Aug. 29 — The Ford Motor Company said today that its chief executive and president, Jacques A. Nasser, had declined invitations to testify next week before Congressional committees investigating tire failures, mainly on Ford Explorers. This prompted criticism from one lawmaker who is leading inquiries into the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires.

headline: MP3.com Soars After Settlement With Sony
abstract: August 23, 2000

headline: Hewlett-Novadigm Pact
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co agrees to buy 5 percent stake in Novadigm Inc as part of agreement to sell Novadigm's Internet management software (S)

headline: On Hair-Trigger Wall Street, A Stock Plunges on Fake News
abstract: Stock of Emulex Corp, manufacturer of fiber optic communications equipment, plunged from $103 per share to $45 in 15 minutes on Nasdaq on false report that chief executive resigned and that company would restate earnings for last two years; trading was temporarily halted; free fall dragged down several stocks of companies in similar businesses as well as broader Nasdaq; stripped more than $2 billion from company's market valuation; stock recovered to close at 105.75; chart (M)

headline: MERGER SPECULATION QUASHED
abstract: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux SA of France and E.ON AG of Germany say they have no plans to merge, quashing speculation they would join forces to create one of world's largest utilities and paving way for alliances with other rivals (S)

headline: BEAR STEARNS LOSES FIGHT TO PREVENT CLASS-ACTION SUIT
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies and its former senior managing director, Richard Harriton, have lost bid to stop Federal Judge John Sprizzo from certifying a case against them as class action that was brought on behalf of investors who bought stock in companies through defunct brokerage firm A R Baron; Bear Stearns acted as Baron's clearing broker from July 1995 to June 1996, when Baron went out of business; suit asserts that Harriton and A R Baron artificially inflated price of 10 securities (S)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and the Treasury's quarterly refunding including five-  and 10-year notes and a 30-year bond. The refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of $10 billion of five-year notes, followed by $10 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $5 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 6.03 percent and on the six-month issue, 6.02 percent. In when-issued trading, the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.00 percent, the 10-year note at 5.78 percent and the 30-year bond at 5.76 percent.

headline: S.E.C. Suspends Car Parts Maker
abstract: Trading in Save the World Air is suspended by Securities and Exchange Commission for 10 days because of concerns about accuracy of company's claims for antipollution device; company contends its Zero Emission Fuel Saver improves fuel mileage while eliminating most of pollution generated by internal combustion engines (S)

headline: AFFILIATED COMPUTER SERVICES SELLING A.T.M. UNIT
abstract: Affiliated Computer Services Inc agrees to sell its ATM unit to Genpass Inc for about $180 million (S)

headline: Toys 'R' Us Profit Is Down By 75% in Second Quarter
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Inc says fiscal second-quarter profit fell 75 percent; net income in quarter ended July 29 fell to $3 million from $12 million a year earlier; sales dropped 9.5 percent, to $2 billion from $2.2 billion (M)

headline: U.N. READIES TEAM TO CHECK WEAPONS HELD BY THE IRAQIS
abstract: UN assembles new team of arms inspectors to reenter Iraq within weeks, raising prospect of another confrontation with Pres Saddam Hussein over weapons programs; move comes two years after Iraq halted cooperation with previous group of inspectors, provoking diplomatic crisis and ongoing American and British air strikes; government has warned it will not cooperate with UN's new weapons commission, which Security Council ordered nine months ago in hopes of resolving objections to previous commission by Iraq, Russia and France; new team, with members from 19 countries, will be more accountable to UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan; will be headed by Hans Blix; members will work directly for UN, not for own countries as before; photo (M)

headline: Olympians Hope High-Tech Gear Will Give Them an Edge : Can the Clothes Make a Difference?
abstract: PARIS—  The Olympics might have been born from a desire to revive the virtues of ancient Greece, but at the turn of the millennium, the Games have become a showcase for new — and not so new — technology.

headline: Article 2000091493568625401 -- No Title
abstract: The Ultimate Remote Means Never Having To Leave the Couch

headline: Red Dot, Meet Green: If It's Tuesday, Network!: Singapore; A Caution Signal In Venture Capital
abstract: Caution is the watchword at First Tuesday gathering of venture capitalists and new-economy entrepreneurs at Bar in Singapore, where consultants outnumber investors, and both outnumber entrepreneurs with viable ideas; only small minority of people in Southeast Asia regularly use Internet, and they are separated by geography, language, culture and regulatory barriers; photo (M)

headline: Coal Mine Blast Kills 118 in China
abstract: SHANGHAI, China -- A gas explosion in a coal mine in southern China killed 118 miners, a mine official said Thursday.

headline: Novell Reports 83% Decline in Earnings, but Still Beats Estimates
abstract: Novell Reports 83% Decline in Earnings, but Still Beats Estimates

headline: Inquiries Find Little Abuse By Tax Agents
abstract: Investigations by Internal Revenue Service and watchdog, Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration, find some of 830 complaints of IRS taxpayer harassment two years ago were bogus, made in effort to derail audits and tax collections; others were either without merit or involved misconduct that fell far short of Congressional definition of harassment; spokesman for Sen William V Roth Jr, who sponsored 1998 IRS Reform and Restructuring Act, says results show that IRS employees are adhering to the law (M)

headline: Legal Tug of War
abstract: Legal Tug of War

headline: DAEWOO CHARGES POSSIBLE
abstract: South Korea's Watchdog Financial Supervisory Commission says Kim Woo Choong, former chairman of Daewoo Group, and as many as 40 executives from conglomerate may face criminal charges for inflating asset values of several affiliates, which worsened assessment of business group's liabilities; Daewoo is being sold off in pieces to repay debts totaling $79 million; photo (S)

headline: VODAFONE SELLING MANNESMANN ASSET
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch to sell as much as 49.9 percent of Infostrada, Italian telephone company acquired through merger with Mannesmann (S)

headline: GOVERNMENT TO BUY DAEWOO BONDS
abstract: Korea Asset Management Corp, state-run agency in charge of cleaning up bad debts within nation's financial industry, will buy 18.5 trillion won ($16.6 billion) worth of unsecured Daewoo Group bonds from local investment trust companies; is paying 6.4 trillion won for bonds, or 35 percent of their fave value (S)

headline: AT HOME BUYS POGO ONLINE GAME SITE
abstract: At Home says it acquired Pogo.com in stock transaction estiamted at $125 million to $150 million (S)

headline: MusicBank Bets on Working With Recording Industry
abstract: August 11, 2000

headline: Taiwan's Leader Considers Purchase of Updated Jet Fighters
abstract: Pres Chen Shui-bian says Taiwan should begin considering new fighter aircraft purchases, warning that in five years China could threaten Taiwan's ability to control skies over Taiwan Strait, a key factor in repelling a mainland invasion; suggestion is seen by analysts as aimed at United States, most likey supplier of any advanced fighter jets (M)

headline: U.S. and Jordan Move to Cut Trade Barriers
abstract: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 — The United States and Jordan are close to reaching an agreement to cut trade barriers, the top American negotiator said today.

headline: Article 2000091893508967801 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Like It or Not, North Koreans Tour a Mall in Seoul
abstract: On their first full day in South Korea after half a century, 100 North Koreans — in two controlled groups of 50 — experienced the capitalistic excess of a giant shopping mall today.

headline: New Firm Would Be a Merger Player
abstract: Credit Suisse's acquisition of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette is expected to catapult the combined company into a serious force in business of mergers and acquisitions (S)

headline: Massacres in Kashmir May Be Effort to Sabotage Peace Initiative
abstract: Indian Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee blames Pakistan for massacres in Kashmir in which at least 93 people have been killed in six separate incidents; holds Pakistan has ordered other militant groups to step up attacks in response to bid by Hizbul Mujahedeen for cease-fire and talks; Pakistan and several of groups critical of peace effort deny any role in attacks (M)

headline: Radio Station Leaves Earth and Enters Cyberspace
abstract: Radio Station Leaves Earth and Enters Cyberspace

headline: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL IS SELLING CHEMICAL UNIT TO APOLLO
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group sells Resins and Versatics chemicals unit to Apollo Management for undisclosed sum; Marvin O Schlanger, former president and chief executive of Arco Chemical, will be chairman of new company (S)

headline: U.S. Supreme Court Decides Not to Hear Microsoft Case
abstract: The Supreme Court, granting a Microsoft request Tuesday, refused to hear the massive antitrust case that threatens to break the computer software giant in two. The justices said the case first should be heard by a federal appeals court.

headline: Mack-Cali Buys Buildings
abstract: Mack-Cali Realty buys six office buildings in New Jersey office complex for $153.8 million; Mack-Cali pays $85 million to buy four buildings that are part of Mack-Cali Business Campus and Morris County Financial Center in Parsippany; in second transaction, Mack-Cali pays $68.8 million to buy two other buildings that are also part of Parsippany complex; sellers unidentified (S)

headline: REDBACK NETWORKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ABATIS SYSTEMS
abstract: Redback Networks will acquire Abatis Systems Corp, Canadian Internet protocol services company, for about $676 million in stock (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Personal Online Advice on Selecting a College
abstract: Live, one-on-one college advisory services, which has been offered primarily offline, is now available at PureAdvice.com (S)

headline: Personal Business; How Best to Deduct the High Cost of Gasoline?
abstract: Recent rise in gasoline prices makes its worthwhile for taxpayers who deduct business mileage to consider relative advantages of taking standard rate allowed by IRS or calculating actual expense; standard-rate deduction requires only that taxpayer keep track of mileage, but same taxpayer may save more by taking trouble to calculate actual expense; photo (M)

headline: INFORMIX TO CUT WORK FORCE AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: Informix Corp, database-software maker, will dismiss about 430 employees and take third-quarter charge as part of reorganization; job cuts account for about 10 percent of work force (S)

headline: STRONG RESULTS AT DE BEERS
abstract: De Beers says earnings more than tripled in first half of year, to $877 million, on 44 percent surge in sales to record $3.4 billion; sales helped reduce company's stockpile of diamonds by nearly one-third this year, to $2.7 billion (S)

headline: PPG SAYS 3RD-QUARTER EARNINGS WILL MISS ESTIMATES
abstract: PPG Industries Inc expects third-quarter earnings to fall below Wall Street's estimates because of slowdown in automotive and construction markets (M)

headline: CHINA GROWTH SURPASSES 8%
abstract: China's economy grew at annual rate of 8.2 percent in first half of year compared with 7.1 percent growth in 1999; foreign investment fell 7.5 percent from year-earlier period; Government spending surged 12 percent in lastest six months (S)

headline: Mostly White Party Seeking Voters From A.N.C.
abstract: South Africa's mostly-white opposition Democratic Alliance is campaigning to woo black majority and dent overwhelming popularity and power of governing African National Congress; is emboldened by startling fractures within ANC's black base of support in advance of Nov local elections; polls suggest growing percentage of blacks are willing to consider alternatives to ANC as they focus less on politics of liberation and more on basic governance and high unemployment and crime rates; maps; photo (M)

headline: Chavez Says He Will Crush Political Foes In Venezuela
abstract: Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez says he will use troops to crush street protests and to oust William Davila, opposition party governor of Merida, who was leading in his re-election bid until 6,000 ballots cast for him were declared invalid and pro-Chavez candidate declared winner by small margin; Davila charges fraud; opposition candidates in five other states make similar charges (M)

headline: UNITED RENTALS IN TALKS TO BUY W. R. CARPENTER UNIT
abstract: United Rentals, largest US equipment-rental company, is in talks to buy Horizon High Reach and Equipment, supplier of forklifts and hydraulic lifts for construction industry, for $90 million (S)

headline: U.S. Urging Milosevic Opponents to Unite for September Vote
abstract: American officials are reportedly pressuring Montenegro Pres Milo Djukanovic and leader of Serbia's largest opposition party Vuk Draskovic, both opponents opponents of Pres Slobodan Milosevic, to participate in Yugoslav elections in September; believe united opposition in Serbia, together with voters in Montenegro, would have good chance of defeating Milosevic in presidential and parliamentary elections; Milosevic and allies have begun new wave of repression; have altered Constitution to create direct elections for his position, which he otherwise would have to relinquish in July 2001; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  American Sts Wtr Co  Highwoods Pptys Inc    TUESDAY  Cooper Inds Inc  Emerson Elec Co  Great Lakes REIT Inc  Hershey Foods Corp  Home Pptys NY Inc  Liberty Corp SC  Philadelphia Subn Corp  Regency Rlty Corp  St Paul Cos Inc

headline: UNILEVER-BESTFOODS DEAL APPROVED
abstract: European Commission approves $24.3 billion acquisition of US food company Bestfoods by Unilever PLC; under European Commission's condition for approval, Unilever must sell brands and businesses worth $440 million in annual sales (S)

headline: AD AGENCY DEAL IS APPROVED
abstract: European Union Commission clears purchase by British advertising concern WWP Group of US rival, Young & Rubicam, for $4.7 billion (S)

headline: Personal Business; The Workstation As Archaeological Dig
abstract: Corporate America may be moving toward the paperless office, but many employees are still caught up in the daily paper chase. Desks remain buried under mounds of files, books, newspapers and unopened mail. How does this cubicle chaos affect job performance, either yours or your employees'? And what mysteries have been solved when messy desks are finally cleared? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. E-mail: onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Teachers Question Critical Study of Classroom Computers
abstract: Elementary school teachers using technology in the field are questioning a recent study that calls for a "time-out" for computers in classrooms with young children, saying that the new technology make their students more eager to learn.

headline: BLUEFLY EXPANDS AOL AGREEMENT
abstract: Bluefly.com, an Internet apparel retailer, expands agreement with America Online (S)

headline: THE BOSS; If Only I Could Be Foreman
abstract: The Boss column profiles Fred Poses, chief executive of American Standard Co, air-conditioning, automotive and plumbing company; photo (M)

headline: China Agrees To Free Poet After Protests From Writers
abstract: Huang Beiling, Boston-based Chinese poet arrested in Beijing on August 11 in connection with literary journal he edits, will be released and deported to US; is Chinese citizen with permanent-residence status in US; arrest drew protests from literary figures worldwide, as well as from US Embassy in Beijing; police confiscated hundreds of copies of Journal, Tendency, which is published in US, but gve no reason why they detained him; China's State Council Information Office says he was jailed because of illegal business activity (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: OPEC Agrees to Increase Production of Oil by 3%  Faced with mounting international pressure to drive down stubbornly high oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to increase its crude production by 800,000 barrels a day.    Just days before the OPEC meeting, the price of crude oil reached its highest levels since the Persian Gulf war before receding somewhat on Friday. OPEC members said they hope the 3 precent increase from current production will gradually push oil prices below $30 a barrel. [International, Section A.]    Human Genome Acquires Principia  Human Genome Sciences, a company that is developing drugs based on discovery of genes, said that it had acquired the privately held Principia Pharmaceutical for about $120 million in stock. Principia is developing a technology that could enhance the effectiveness of human proteins used as drugs. [C18.]

headline: DEAL FOR THAMES WATER
abstract: German utility company RWE AG will buy Thames Water PLC of Britain for 6.7 billion pounds and assumed debt, about $9.4 billion; Thames Water's chief executive, Bill Alexander, will head new company; photo (S)

headline: RIVAL SEEKS TO RESTRAIN INTEL
abstract: Broadcom Corp files filing suit to block Intel Corp from selling products that Broadcom says are linked to theft of its trade secrets; Intel filed suit in August, charging Broadcom with infringing its patents on cable and high-speed networking products; graph (S)

headline: VIRGIN SEEKS AIR INDIA STAKE
abstract: Worlr

headline: U.S. and Russia Open a Nuclear Swords-to-Plowshares Project
abstract: American and Russian officials, including Energy Sec Bill Richardson, dedicate 10-acre industrial park on site of former nuclear-arms factory, Sarov, Russia; park is second step in joint project American experts hope will provide jobs for up to 4,000 Russian weapons scientists and workers; Richardson is on weeklong swing through Russia and other former Soviet states to promote programs to curb spread of nuclear materials and technology (M)

headline: Taiwan Airline to Invest in a China Eastern Unit
abstract: China Eastern Airlines receives preliminary approval to sell 25 percent stake in its China Cargo Airlines subsidiary to China Airlines of Taiwan, first step in what would be landmark cross-strait cooperation if Taiwan's government allows deal to go through (M)

headline: GRANADA BUYS BRITISH TV ASSETS
abstract: Granada Media PLC agrees to buy television assets of United News & Media PLC for $2.64 billion, beating Carlton Communications PLC's bid for British TV dominance (S)

headline: In the Oil-Rich Nigeria Delta, Deep Poverty and Grim Fires
abstract: Niger Delta is one of world's top oil producers but because of Nigeria's complicated ethnic politics, residents have remained stunningly and desperately poor and thousands have been victims of pipeline explosions; in last two years, more than 2000 villagers have died in explosions, mostly while trying to scavenge small quantities of oil to sell; what is more, these explosions are not merely accidental, but result from sabotage; organized rings of thieves, believed to be allied with corrupt officials, siphon off huge quantities of fuel with sophisticated equipment, leaving the leaks that eventually attract villagers; scene in town of Oviri-Court described; map; photos (M)

headline: S.A.A. REINTRODUCES NIGERIA-U.S. FLIGHTS
abstract: South African Airways begins regular service between Lagos, Nigeria, and New York, ending stretch of almost six and a half years without direct flights; SAA won right to operate route for troubled Nigerian Airways several months after American aviation authorities lifted ban on flights between US and Lagos (S)

headline: Women Welcomed Back to Career Path
abstract: Booming US economy is forcing employers to actively woo women who held jobs before resigning to raise families; are finding them rich new source of talent; photos (M)

headline: Western Business Tempers Its New Enthusiasm for North Korea
abstract: Foreign business optimism over thaw between North and South Korea has waned considerably in few weeks since their leaders met and symbolic truckload of Coca-Cola crossed into the North; precedent-setting discussions in north capital of Pyongyang between Pres Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and his Communist counterpart, Kim Jong Il, generated kind of euphoria, and talk was heard of opening of North Kore; major American and European businesses are again expressing deep caution; Coca-Cola Co is vague about what it envisions doing in North Korea (M)

headline: U.S. Urges OPEC to Increase Oil Production
abstract: Energy Sec Bill Richardson calls on OPEC oil-exporting nations to increase their production as price of crude oil reaches $34.90 a barrel in New York (M)

headline: CINAR SEEKS MORE TIME
abstract: Shareholders of animated filmmaker Cinar Corp, who have been unable to trade their shares for last five months, are warned by company that several more months might pass before revised financial statements are delivered to regulators; after accusations of tax fraud and disclosure that $122 million was missing, company was ordered to revise its accounts for last three fiscal years; most of lost money has been recovered (S)

headline: Clicking Outside the Box
abstract: Most of major cable and satellite television companies will begin to roll out interactive systems, at least in test markets, this year; experts expect tens of millions of households to have access to some sort of interactive television in next few years; what viewers want and what they will pay for detailed; drawing; photos (special section, E-Commerce) (M)

headline: Man Jailed in 1st U.S. Online Gambling Conviction
abstract: August 11, 2000

headline: Cornhuskers Go Online, Not on TV
abstract: College football game between University of Nebraska Cornhuskers and Spartans of San Jose State University will be first live Webcast of college football game (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: EVERAD, New York, named Angela Pumo chief executive. She was most recently executive vice president at CNX Media Networks.    INTERNATIONAL ASSETS HOLDING CORP. named William C. Dennis Jr. to the post of president and chief operating officer.

headline: North Korea Reported Open To Halting Missile Program
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin, in announcement intended to remove prime rationale for American missile defense plan, says North Korea will abandon its missile program if other nations will provide it with rockets to launch satellites into space; announcement comes during meeting, Pyongyang, with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il; visit, first by Russian president to North Korea, is part of his intensive round of Asian diplomacy aimed at mobilizing opposition to American anti-missile plan; United States expresses willingness to explore deal in which North Korean satellites would be launched from other nations; photo (M)

headline: FOREST OIL AGREES TO BUY FORCENERGY, A RIVAL
abstract: Forest Oil Corp acquires Forcenergy Inc for about $615 million in stock to add wells in Alaska and Gulf of Mexico (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LIBERTY CORP., Greenville, S.C., which owns Liberty Life Insurance and Cosmos Broadcasting, said it would buy up to three million more of its shares, in addition to the one million already authorized for repurchase.    DIMENSION DATA HOLDINGS LTD., Johannesburg, South Africa, which helps companies set up computer networks and electronic businesses, said it would acquire TimeBridge Technologies Inc., McLean, Va., a privately held computer services company, for $135 million.

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: Technology Briefs

headline: Units Reorganized At Grey Global
abstract: Grey Global Group chief executive, Jeff Alperin, is leaving advertising agency; units in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Latin America are being reorganized (M)

headline: VIVENDI REVENUE RISES
abstract: French conglomerate Vivendi reports revenue increased in first half, 2000, by nine 9 percent to $17.5 billion (S)

headline: LINUX FINDS A TINY HOME
abstract: IBM researchers develop a complete version of Linux operating system that runs on a prototype computer only 2.2 inches by 1.89 inches by 0.48 inch (S)

headline: DSL.NET SHARES NEARLY DOUBLE
abstract: Shares of DSL.net double after IBM agrees to sell DSL.net's high-speed Internet access to small-business customers; graph (S)

headline: Report Challenges the Policymaking Elite : French Diplomats Told To Go Back to School
abstract: PARIS—  France has decided to send its governing elite, including its redoubtable diplomats, back to school to learn how to cope with new challenges in a more competitive, globalized world.

headline: Top European Luxury Goods Retailers Report Strong Profit Gains
abstract: Some of Europe's biggest retailers of luxury goods are reporting strong gains in sales and profits; LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France says operating profit in first half of year rose 31 percent, to 762 million euros, or about $655 million, on 40 percent increase in sales, to 5.03 billion euros; Pinault-Printemps-Redoute of France says first-half operating profit rose 35 percent, to 791.1 million euros, on 8 percent increase in revenue, to 11.3 billion euros (M)

headline: NO EASING OF IRISH INFLATION
abstract: Annualized inflation rate in Ireland in July rose to 15-year high of 6.2 percent, up from 5.5 percent in June; government says it will consider taking further anti-inflation measures; graph (S)

headline: Hospital Chief To Lead Aetna Managed Care
abstract: Dr John W Rowe, chief executive of Mount Sinai NYU Medical Center and Health System, is named president and chief executive at Aetna US Healthcare; in Aetna, country's largest health insurer, Dr Rowe takes over company that is faced with difficult task of improving customer relations while raising prices of managed-care coverage (M)

headline: Russian Tycoon in New Role As Organizer of Opposition
abstract: Boris A Berezovsky, archetypal Russian tycoon, politician and former force within Kremlin itself, will quit his seat in Parliament and will try to form alliance of big business and regional politicians aimed at curbing Pres Vladimir Putin's growing power; says he is resigning because he does not wish to take part in dismantling of Russia and imposition of authoritarian rule; statement is bluntest attack by major figure on Putin, who remains popular and has taken dead aim at country's business oligarchy and its 89 regional governors in effort to reimpose Kremlin control over almost feral political structure; photo (M)

headline: No Optimism About Mideast Talks
abstract: Pres Clinton plans separate meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders in New York during trip for UN General Assembly's Millennium summit; resolving major issue of Jerusalem still appears beyond reach; none of participants in long-suffering negotiations believe things will advance much; photo (M)

headline: Pennsylvania Launches Competition for "Digital School District" Funding
abstract: In an effort to spur innovation, maximize buying power and concentrate technology resources, officials in Pennsylvania have launched a statewide competition to create two cutting-edge digital school districts.

headline: I.B.M. Establishes Family-Care Fund
abstract: IMB establishes $50-million fund to help employees with child and elder care (S)

headline: Chechen Rebels Kill 37 Russian Soldiers In Truck Bombings
abstract: Chechen suicide bombers set off series of blasts throughout breakaway republic, killing at least 37 Russian soldiers and wounding 74; five trucks laden with explosives blow up in towns and cities ostensibly under Russian control; carefully coordinated rebel attack occurs just a week after Russian military declared that war is all but won; as toll of dead and wounded mounts, Moscow vows to break back of rebel resistance; rebels respond by saying they plan still more bombings; rumors are rife that Grozny, Chechen capital, will be attacked next; photo; map (M)

headline: Cisco to Buy Netiverse for $210 Million in Stock
abstract: July 8, 2000

headline: Arranged Marriages, Minus the Parents For Some South Asians, Matrimonial Sites Both Honor and Subvert Tradition
abstract: HARSHA KUMAR, a 29-year-old technology officer for an e-commerce company in Westborough, Mass., wanted to find a wife. And Mr. Kumar, who was born in India and educated in the United States, wanted to begin his search in a way that blended both Old and New World sensibilities.

headline: A Place to Go When There´s a Whole Lotta Shakin´ Goin´ On
abstract: When an earthquake roused tens of thousands of Northern California residents from their sleep early in the morning on Sept. 3, hundreds of those rattled souls went straight to their computers and logged onto the Internet.

headline: INTEL SAYS INVESTIGATION DROPPED
abstract: Intel Corp is notified by the Federal Trade Commission that its investigation into company's business practices has been closed; probe began in Sept 1997 in response to complaints that Intel had used anticompetitive practices to cement its near monopoly in microprocessors for personal computers (S)

headline: Orthodontics Via Silicon Valley; A Start-Up Uses Computer Modeling And Venture Capital to Reach Patients
abstract: Sunnyvale, Calif-based Align Technology has developed clear-plastic alternative to braces aimed at appearance-conscious adults; Align co-founders Zia Chishti and Kelsey Wirth have drawn attention of many orthodontists with their claim that computers can be used to design and make customized series of plastic retainers for each patient that would gradually move their teeth as prescribed by the orthodonist; unlike braces advertised as invisible but held in place by wire, Align's product is transparent; patients can switch to next retainer in the series every two weeks instead of visiting orthontist; Align system, marketed under Invisalign brand, is already inspiring competitors; GAC International, leading supplier of braces and other orthodontic supplies, recently began offering all-plastic device designed by Dr Keith Hilliard, Florida orthodontist; photos (M)

headline: No Engine Parts Found on Concorde Flight Path
abstract: French investigators say they have found no engine parts in trail of debris shed by Air France Concorde on its brief flight before crashing near Paris area airport; French authorities continue to ground Air France's remaining five Concordes (S)

headline: Ideas & Trends; Cloak, Dagger, Echelon
abstract: Reasonable debate over Echelon surveillance cooperative is complicated by nonsensical exaggerations of its capabilities; Echelon cooperative operates network of ground stations that gather data from the dozen or so satellites that carry most of word's television, fax, Internet and voice traffic; high-capacity computers allow millions of signals an hour to be intercepted and scanned for key words; map, diagram (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: California Company Victim Of a Fake Press Release  A fake press release sent over financial news wires set off a 60 percent decline in the shares of Emulex, a California company that makes fiber optic communications equipment. The price recovered after the company disclosed the hoax and said its business was flourishing. Government and financial agencies are investigating the fake release.

headline: Layoffs May Be at a Record Low, Survey Finds
abstract: Biennial job displacement survey by Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that number of permanent layoffs declined over last three years amid longest US economic expansion on record and that rate may match lowest in 20-year history of survey; women were laid off virtually as often as men, closing wide gap that had existed for most of last 20 years, while layoff rate for blacks compared with whites rose significantly; layoff rate for Hispanics dropped sharply, falling below that of blacks and differences between whites and Hispanics also narrowed; 3.3 million workers on job for three years or more were laid off during three-year period ending in 1999, while 4.3 million workers on jobs for less than three years lost jobs (M)

headline: SINGAPORE TELECOM IN INDIA
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd will pay $400 million for a minority stake in India's largest privately owned telecommunications company, Bharti Group (S)

headline: W.T.O. Allows Canada Record Sanctions Against Brazil
abstract: World Trade Organization will allow Canadian government to impose more than $1 billion in trade sanctions over next five years on Brazilian goods to compensate for Brazil's illegal aircraft industry subsidies; size of sanctions are largest trade retaliation award in WTO's five-year history (M)

headline: In Sharp Debate on Freedoms, Top Hong Kong Educators Resign
abstract: Two top officials at Hong Kong University resign after investigation finds they pressed prominent pollster not to publish surveys critical of territory's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa; report also implicates Tung and his senior adviser, Andrew Lo; dispute injects combustible element into Hong Kong's legislative elections (M)

headline: Fujimori Asks Washington for Backing on Peru Transition
abstract: Peruvian Pres Alberto K Fujimori, visiting United States, tells Clinton administration officials that he wants to restore democratic institutions undermined during his decade in office and seeks backing needed to restore full democracy; State Sec Madeleine K Albright backs his call for new elections in which he will not be candidate and to abolish National Intelligence Service headed by his disgraced adviser, Vladimiro Montesinos; Organization of American States officials warn conditions in Peru remain unstable because of uncertainty about Montesinos and urge he be made to feel secure in Panama, which weighs his asylum bid; Cesar Gaviria, OAS secretary general, defends his efforts to find haven for Montesinos; photo (M)

headline: BRAZILIAN CAR SALES
abstract: Sales of cars and trucks in Brazil rise in August from a year earlier; sales of Brazilian-made and imported vehicles to dealers rise 15 percent, to highest level since March 1999, and production of cars, trucks and buses rises 27 percent, to highest level in more than two years (S)

headline: A Lawyer's Double-Barreled Week
abstract: Profile of Ralph C Ferrara, partner at law firm Debevoise & Plimpton, who handled defense in class-action suits against American General, accused of charging blacks higher insurance premiums than whites, and Waste Management, accused of misleading investors about project earnings; companies announced settlements a day apart in mid-June (M)

headline: DVD Players Hot in United States, Hard Sell Back Home in Japan
abstract: DVD Players Hot in United States, Hard Sell Back Home in Japan

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: United States and Vietnam In a Sweeping Trade Accord  The United States and Vietnam have completed a sweeping trade agreement that would allow unfettered commerce between the two nations for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War more than a quarter-century ago, people involved in the negotiations said.    A handful of large American companies have invested in Vietnam, and some analysts think they would immediately add thousands of jobs in Vietnam if American tariffs of Vietnamese-produced goods are substantially lowered. The agreement would also open Vietnam's market of 77 million people to a wide range of American companies. [Page A1.]

headline: Giving Chips a Lesson in Power Management
abstract: The trouble with microprocessors today, according to Dr. David Albonesi, a professor of electrical and computer engineering at the University of Rochester, is that they are just too powerful. Most of the programs they run tap only a fraction of a processor's capacity, yet the unused portion exacts a price, as every notebook computer owner who has raced against a fading battery knows. Powerful means power- hungry.

headline: FORMER KODAK EXECUTIVE NAMED PRESIDENT AT GOODYEAR
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber names Robert J Keegan, former Eastman Kodak executive, as its president and chief operating officer; will assume posts on Oct 1; chairman-chief executive Samir F Gibara will give up titles of president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: Patents; Trademarks gain attention as passports to the Internet and for a critical vote ahead in Congress.
abstract: Trademark experts and owners are pressing Congress to approve international trademark accord backed by Patent and Trademark Office and Clinton administration; are worrried that Congress does not grasp importance of brands; photo (M)

headline: It´s a Word World, Or Is It?
abstract: HOW do you compete in a business where the next-largest company holds a market share hovering just under 100 percent? That's the quandary WordPerfect faces.

headline: FILE-SHARING HERE TO STAY?
abstract: Forrester Research Inc reports that Napster and file-sharing services like it are here to stay; says consumers will use any means necessary to gain access to content like music (S)

headline: Rush-Hour Bomb Attack Kills 8 in Central Moscow
abstract: Bomb explodes in pedestrial underpass in central Moscow during rush hour, killing 8 people, wounding 11 and sending dozens more fleeing smoke and flames; Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov links bombing, on first anniversary of lastest Chechen uprising, to rebels; urges residents to redouble vigilance; no organization claims responsibility; Chechen Pres Aslan Maskhadov denies Chechen involvement; Pres Vladimir V Putin reportedly orders probe; second bomb is found in area; map; photo (M)

headline: Russia's Powerful Regional Chiefs Yield Meekly to Putin
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin easily wins showdown with nation's 89 czar-like regional governors; governors meekly accept Putin's bill to overhaul federal tax code, plan designed to break their control over tax receipts; vote to abolish their own seats in Parliament's upper house and replace 89 other members, whom they handpicked from provinicial legislatures, with full-time and somewhat more independent legislators; bill is compromise measure that holds out prospect of new constitutional convention to set government's final form (M)

headline: Aetna to Sell Its International and Financial Services Units
abstract: Aetna Inc agrees to sell its international and financial services units to ING Group for $5 billion in cash; Aetna will create new health care company that will keep name Aetna; ING will also assume $2.7 billion of Aetna's long-term debt; plans to operate its growing US financial business from its existing headquarters in Atlanta; agrees to maintain number of Aetna employees at close to current levels, with future reductions mainly from attrition as employees retire or leave (M)

headline: PayPal Praise and Problems
abstract: Richard Rand letter praises PayPal online payment system (June 29 article)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Intel Warns That Revenue Will Fall Short of Forecasts  Intel warned that its third-quarter revenue was likely to be below the company's previous expectations, primarily because of weaker demand for the company's microprocessing chips in Europe.

headline: Canada's Tamils Work for a Homeland From Afar
abstract: Tamils living in Canada rally behind Sri Lanka's secessionist Tamil guerrillas; fund-raising for Tigers is illegal in United States; but Canada has no such prohibition, and Canadian intelligence officials and Sri Lankan diplomats say it has become increasingly important source of support for Tigers, who are seeking to carve a Tamil homeland out of Sri Lanka; photo of Tamils demonstrating in Toronto; map (L)

headline: MVP.com Leaves Leagas Dealany
abstract: MVP.com, online sporting goods retailer founded by John Elway, Wayne Gretzky and Michael Jordan, and its agency, Leagas Delaney, have parted ways after nine months; spending for account was initially estimated at $50 million, but has recently been around $15 million (S)

headline: RCA to Offer E-Books, The Next Generation
abstract: RCA is releasing two new electronic readers, or e-books; RCA's eBooks can handle only electronic books and magazines produced in special format that is also controlled by Gemstar International, which has licensed technology to RCA's owner, Thomson Multimedia; photo (S)

headline: Vatican Looks to New Cardinals and Papabili
abstract: Top Roman Catholic officials at Vatican seem to be working behind closed doors during Holy Year to reorganize top echelons and prepare for future; reassignment of Bishop Giovanni Battista Re, Pope John Paul II's deputy secretary of state, as head of office that selects bishops signals effort; he succeeds Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves; Vatican is preoccupied with selection of up to 20 new cardinals, probably including Re, who could be both electors and potential papal candidates; photo (M)

headline: L'Unita, Leftist Italian Paper, Halts Publication
abstract: L'Unita, once most powerful leftist newspaper in Italy, publishes its last issue, a victim of fall of Berlin Wall and market forces; it was founded in 1924 as mouthpiece of Italian Communist Party; it went into receivership two weeks ago; in related symptom of decline of left's strength in Italy, Democrats of Left move out of their historic headquarters and move into less expensive offices (M)

headline: MEDIATION FOR CANADIAN PILOTS
abstract: Air Canada and union representing its 2,200 pilots agree to nonbinding mediation that could lead to new contract; also agree there will be no strike or lockout as long as talks continue (S)

headline: Kraft Recalls Taco Shells With Bioengineered Corn
