abstract: Kraft Foods announces nationwide recall of taco shells, confirms that they contain genetically engineered corn not approved for human consumption; product was sold under Taco Bell brand; Kraft Foods is subsidiary of Philip Morris Companies; no illnesses have been reported from eating the taco shells made with corn bioengineered for livestock feed; photo (M)

headline: DVD Toy For Rich Techies
abstract: Peter H Lewis State of the Art column appraises Panasonic's DMR-E10, first consumer DVD video recorder from Japan to reach American market; photo (M)

headline: Distance Learning Goes Niche
abstract: With the market for adult education growing at an explosive rate, colleges and universities are finding it necessary to develop finely-tuned programs that cater to identified niches.

headline: Killer Toys and Wonder Woman: When a Soft Sell Is a Big Deal
abstract: Center for Exhibition Industry Research says that in $84 billion-a-year commercial exhibition business, high technology ranks third among major industries that allocate large part of their marketing dollars to trade shows and conferences; at 18 percent, high technology trails health care at 21.3 percent and manufacturing at 18.6 percent; photos (special section, E-Commerce) (M)

headline: Seagram Group Said to Drop Plan to Bid For Liquor Unit
abstract: Consortium led by management team of Seagram Co's spirits and wine unit reportedly decides not to bid for business, which is being put up for sale by Vivendi SA (M)

headline: PROFIT UP AT TARGET OF CEMENT TAKEOVER
abstract: Blue Circle PLC reports 14 percent rise in profits for first half of year, to 125.8 million pounds, or about $179 million (S)

headline: EQUENOM TO START GENE STUDY
abstract: Sequenom Inc and University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center will undertake large study aimed at linking genetic variations to disease (S)

headline: South Africa Fears Past Still Breeds Racist Evils
abstract: South African blacks make their way from remote farms and rural villages to give government hearings around country their accounts of mistreatment in post-apartheid era; simmering racial anxieties flare in bitter exchanges between Pres Thabo Mbeki and white opposition leader Tony Leon, which come as South Africa prepares to hold national conference on racism (M)

headline: Putin Bends Clinton's Ear Hoping to Halt Missile Shield
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia meets with Pres Clinton during Group of 8 meeting in Okinawa to argue against American deployment of a national missile shield; Clinton makes clear that he has not made a decision, but intends to make a decision during course of summer (M)

headline: SYCAMORE NETWORKS SALES SOARS
abstract: Sycamore Networks reports fiscal fourth-quarter profit of $18.3 million, compared with year-earlier loss of $9.08 million; graph (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Giving consumers access to the data collected about them online.
abstract: BeFree and other online advertising companies are taking steps that will allow consumers to see data collected on their online shopping and buying and to opt out of such tracking; photo (M)

headline: IRISH NEWSPAPER DEAL APPROVED
abstract: Dublin-based Independent News and Media secures approval from Britain's trade secretary to proceed with its acquisition of The Belfast Telegraph from British-based Mirror Group for 300 million pounds ($448 million); Independent News, which is run by Anthony J F O'Reilly, owns 28.5 percent of newspaper market in Northern Ireland and controls most of national daily newspaper readership in Republic of Ireland; photo (S)

headline: INFINITY BROADCASTING TO BUY 2 MEMPHIS RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Infinity Broadcasting Corp buys Memphis radio stations WMC-AM and WMC-FM from Raycom Media for $75.5 million (S)

headline: RAMBUS JUMPS ON LICENSING DEAL
abstract: Shares of Rambus rise after memory chip designer reaches licensing agreement with NEC of Japan (S)

headline: U.S. Officials Are Arguing Over Papers On Chile Coup
abstract: Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright has pledged to push for 'fullest possible declassification' of files related to United States involvement in coup that toppled Chile's elected Socialist government and 17-year military dictatorship that followed; George Tenet, director of central intelligence, recently notified members of Congress that he would withhold unspecified number of documents about Chile because they would disclose too much about how CIA conducts its business; last and largest release of interagency files related to Chile is scheduled for Sept 14; last year Pres Clinton ordered national security agencies to review for declassification documents that shed light on human rights abuses and other acts of political violence in Chile between 1968 and 1990 (M)

headline: Breakthrough in Lasers, With Many Potential New Uses, Reported
abstract: Researchers at Bell Laboratories of Lucent Technologies have created first solid laser from organic materials that is electrically powered, breakthrough that they and other researchers predict will lead to wide range of new uses for laser light in communications and information storage; results, reported in journal Science, were achieved with thin disks of crystallized benzene-based material called tetracene; researchers say it should eventually be possible to manufacture such lasers in thin films that could be incorporated in plastic sheets, allowing them to be inexpensively produced in wide variety of flexible shapes (M)

headline: Market Place; A Murdoch spinoff of Fox shares has been better for some than others.
abstract: Geraldine Fabrikant column on lagging price of Fox Entertainment Group shares, which have risen only 20 percent since November 1998, when News Corp spun off 20 percent of the unit; graph (M)

headline: Airwave Auction Raises $320 Million
abstract: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 — The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had raised about $320 million from the auction of airwaves to 14 companies for mobile wireless data services, dispatch, mobile telephony and other services.

headline: MONY GROUP IS BUYING ADVEST GROUP FOR $275 MILLION
abstract: MONY Group agrees to acquire Advest Group, financial services provider, for about $275 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Madison Avenue cranks into high gear, with some major accounts shifting agencies.
abstract: Advertising column notes some major account shifts (M)

headline: U.S. Contract to British
abstract: BAE Systems Applied Technologies, unit of British military and aerospace company BAE Systems PLC, wins $454.4 million contract from Federal Aviation Adinistration (S)

headline: CORN GLUT WORRIES IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: Surge in South Africa's corn production this year could soften prices of corn and threaten survival of some of country's farms; nation is expected to reap 11.2 million tons this year, 42 percent increase over last year's 7.9 million tons and country's biggest harvest in six years (S)

headline: Advertising: Addenda
abstract: Sun Names 2 Agencies to Share Its Work

headline: Online stalwarts beef up privacy initiatives
abstract: Online Stalwarts Beef Up Privacy Initiatives

headline: ReplayTV Withdraws Public Offering
abstract: ReplayTV Withdraws Public Offering

headline: Motorola Net Raced Ahead On Strong Sales in Quarter
abstract: Motorola reports strong sales and profit growth for second quarter; revenue was $9.26 billion, up 22 percent from year-earlier quarter; profits were $515 million (S)

headline: Toy Site Sued Over Privacy Concerns
abstract: Toy Site Sued Over Privacy Concerns

headline: WHAT'S NEXT; Mega-network: Strength in Numbers
abstract: Researchers are developing entirely new kind of computer network to accommodate vast amount of data to be generated by next-generation particle accelerator set to go live in 2005 at European Organization of Nuclear Research (CERN); new GriPhyN network will also serve other scientific megaprojects and may transform Internet; will be first large-scale data grid, intelligent network that will deliver not just raw data, but also power to do challenging computations; project, led by Universities of Florida and Chicago, has just gotten $11.9 million National Science Foundation grant; will cost another $70 million to build; drawing (M)

headline: Juno Surges After Distribution Deal With I.B.M.
abstract: August 17, 2000

headline: Icann Votes To Add More Domain Names
abstract: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers votes to increase the number of suffixes at the end of every e-mail address and Web page; one of its working groups has already proposed domain names ranging from '.banc,' '.museum,' '.union,' '.travel,' to '.sex' (S)

headline: Israel Unrattled by Iraq, but U.S. Unit Alerted
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak displays no an

headline: MILITARY CONTRACT SECURED
abstract: Israeli Aircraft Industries, state-owned military contractor, wins $270 million contract to build spy satellite for Turkey based on its own Ofek reconnaissance (S)

headline: Conseco Chief Got Big Bonus For Signing On
abstract: Conseco Inc says it paid George C Wendt signing bonus of $45 million when he was hired in June as chairman and chief executive; Wendt was also given 3.2 million shares of stock, now worth $31.2 million, as well as options to buy 10 million more shares; photo (M)

headline: Some Air Bags In 2 Models Are Flawed, G.M. Reports
abstract: General Motors Corp says that driver-side air bags on 115 Oldsmobile and Buick cars have inflated spontaneously when car was started or during normal driving conditions and that 268,000 cars in the 1995 and 1996 model years are vulnerable to the problem; has not recalled vehicles because it does not have replacement parts; has received 60 reports of injuries, 'primarily abrasions and bruises' (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 31 article on Campbell Soup Co, which misspelled an analysts name

headline: STRIDE RITE WARNS THAT PROFITS WILL BE BELOW FORECASTS
abstract: Stride Rite Corp ill report profits below estimates for its most recent quarter, in part because of lower sales at department stores (S)

headline: TIME WARNER TO SELL MUSIC ONLINE
abstract: Warner Music division of Time Warner will sell digital music over the Web, becoming lastest major music labels to do so; Wal-Mart says it will sell music from its Web site next year (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy to Israel Relieved of Post Over Security Issues
abstract: Martin S Indyk, US ambassador to Israel and an architect of US Mideast policy, is temporarily relieved of post and has had security clearance lifted pending investigationg of whether he mishandled classified materials; State Department says there is no indication of espionage and no US intelligence was compromised; photo (S)

headline: Of Perks and (Tupperware) Parties
abstract: Abby Ellin Preludes column draws parallels between hot new-economy jobs and selling Tupperware, following visit to www.tupperware.com Web site; notes Tupperware maintains million-strong army of consultants worldwide, with 75,000 in US; illustration (M)

headline: A Wave of the Hand May Soon Make a Computer Jump to Obey
abstract: Article on experiments in US and abroad on computer systems that use tiny cameras, fast processors and smart software to identify and respond quickly and accurately to range of hand gestures natural to humans; photo (M)

headline: Article 2000092390912343983 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: J. G. DURAND INDUSTRIES TO BUY MIKASA FOR $280 MILLION
abstract: J G Durand Industries will acquire Mikasa, marketer of dishes, crystal and silverware, for $280 million in cash (S)

headline: New Pressures Alter Japanese Family's Geometry
abstract: Young married couples in Japan are adopting new hybrid living arrangements that are rapidly redefining family; respond to pressures as varied as falling birthrates, rapidly aging population, high housing prices and persistent economic uncertainty; some grooms, in arrangement rare just generation ago, are living with wife's family and assuming burden of in-laws' eventual care; practice varies from fading custom in which man sometimes joins wife's family and takes their name; experts say Japanese family is shifting from model once heavily centered on male-based succession and inheritance as parents of brides and grooms struggle for such vital benefits from children as care in old age and maintenance of family graves; map; photo (M)

headline: USFREIGHTWAYS UNIT TO ACQUIRE LOGISTICS COMPANY
abstract: USF Worldwide Logistics unit of the USFreightways Corp agrees to acquire Ultimex Global Logistics PLC, a British transportation and logistics company (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; If Register.com, the domain name company, has hit bottom, the only way to go is up, right?
abstract: Market Place column on Register.com, New York-based company which registers Internet domain names for companies and individuals; says some analysts now see good reasons to buy stock, though shares have tumbled from $116 to $6.75; photo (M)

headline: Bear Stearns Settles Case Accusing It of Bad Advice
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies pays $30 million to settle lawsuit over its role as adviser to Daisy Systems Corp in its ill-fated purchase of Cadnetix Inc in 1989; in 1998, a jury in California awarded $108 million in damages to shareholders of both companies, which are now defunct; a judge reduced that to $36 million (M)

headline: German Official Pessimistic About Far-Right Violence
abstract: Foreign Min Joschka Fischer is pessimistic about eradication of rightist violence in eastern Germany; says it will take more than generation to overcome wounds of area that remains in 'twilight zone' between democracy and authoritarian tradition; says anti-immigrant violence that is chief focus of German political debate in past month is not confined to eastern Germany (M)

headline: In a surprise, Kmart gives a $100 million account to the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day.
abstract: Kmart awards its $100 million advertising account to New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day; account has been handled by Campbell Mithun (M)

headline: FleetBoston to Invest in Low-Income Areas
abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp announces plans to invest $600 million over five years in low- and moderate-income community housing (M)

headline: Muscle Power
abstract: Richard A Lowenstein letter on Aug 3 article on human-generated power says article missed one of early human-power-to-stored-energy devices: the self-winding watch (S)

headline: Alan M. Fortunoff, Retailer's Chief, Dies at 67
abstract: Alan M Fortunoff, who transformed mom-and-pop store in Brooklyn selling pots and pans to Fifth Avenue retailer specializing in discounted jewelry and home furnishings, dies at age 67; photo (M)

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: August 10, 2000           Tony Cenicola for the New York Times    Go to article

headline: OIL COMPANY SOLD
abstract: Russia sells small oil company, Onako, for $1.1 billion, more than double its asking price, in first major privatization since President Vladimir V. Putin was elected; buyer is Evro-Tek, Russian energy concern that is subsidiary of Tyumen Oil (S)

headline: LAS VEGAS SELECTS BOMBARDIER
abstract: Bombardier Inc wins $200 million contract to design and build elevated monorail in Las Vegas, linking eight hotels and casinos along four-mile section of Las Vegas Boulevard; Bombardier will be paid additional $56 million to operate and maintain four driverless, nine-car trains on the line for five years after service begins in 2004 (S)

headline: Corning Reportedly Will Buy Fiber Optic Division of Pirelli
abstract: Corning Inc, leading supplier of glass fiber, agrees to acquire fiber-optic telecommunications business of Pirelli SpA for about $3 billion (S)

headline: Chechnya Is Quieter, but Still a Deadly Quagmire
abstract: Chechnya continues to present Russia's gravest security challenge, year after Russian troops poured into breakaway republic; war has not gone away, even though region is no longer scene of major artillery barrages and pitched battles between thousands of soldiers and rebels seeking independent republic; Russian casualties continue every week as fighting shifts from large-scale assaults to skirmishing and ambushes that have turned Chechnya into nasty quagmire for Pres Vladimir V Putin and top generals; although almost everyone seems to agree that Russian firepower alone cannot bring end to fighting and that political solution is necessary, resolution seems as distant as ever; Akhmad Kadyrov, Russian-appointed leader of Chechnya who has survived several assassination attempts, says Chechens must stop conflict themselves or war will continue for 10 or 20 years; photos; maps (M)

headline: A Threat By Austria On Sanctions
abstract: Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel of Austria says his country will block expansion of European Union until it lifts sanctions imposed last February to punish country for letting party of Jorg Haider into government; sanctions have had no serious economic effect on Austria, but they rankle with Austrians; approval of any of dozen countries seeking admission to European Union must be unanimous, so Austria could play spoiler if it does not get its way (M)

headline: Soros Concedes Goof in Book. Global Economy Didn't Collapse.
abstract: George Soros takes back grave global economic forecasts he made in 1998 book; photo (M)

headline: Arafat's Visit to Barak's Place Broke the Ice, Both Sides Say
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak and aide to Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat hail Arafat's visit for late-night supper at Barak's home, holding it provided fresh momentum to peace talks; Arafat aide says meeting was engineered by S Daniel Abraham, American businessman who backs peace efforts through Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation, which he co-founded (M)

headline: Wong Doody Chosen For Clif Bar Account
abstract: Clif Bar Inc, which sells energy bars and other food products, names Los Angeles office of Wong Doody to handle its advertising account; billings estimated at $8 million (S)

headline: Adventures in Beta Land; Aqua Everywhere: An Early Look at OS X
abstract: J D Biersdorfer and Don Donofrio article of their test of beta version of Mac OS X software (M)

headline: Jury in New York Orders Bosnian Serb to Pay Billions
abstract: Federal jury in Manhattan orders Radovan Karadzic, former Bosnian Serb wartime leader, to pay $4.5 billion in damages to victims of rape, torture and genocide; award is largest to come from series of similar lawsuits that have been filed in US courts in last 20 years (S)

headline: Moscow Journal; With Bunkers Manned, Vodka War Is in Stalemate
abstract: Article on Russian government's effort to reconsolidate control over lucrative vodka industry that has set off latest round of business battles; country is riveted on struggle for control of Krystall factory near Moscow that makes Stolichnaya brand and is one of its oldest vodka-producing plants; map; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VANADIUM INTERNATIONAL INC., Reno, Nev., a company that explores for precious metals, said it agreed to buy the closely held Reno-based Cleartron Corporation, which is building a wireless communications network that uses low bandwidth to monitor remote devices like gas meters. The price would be about $81.8 million in stock.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rise in Rates Is Not Stemming The Euro's Slide
abstract: Rise in interest rates fails to halt slide of euro, which loses another 2.3 percent of its value against US dollar, settling at 87.01 cents; European currency also hits record low against Japanese yen as it briefly trades below 92 yen; graph; chart (M)

headline: Week's Equity Offerings
abstract: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: HASBRO, Pawtucket, R.I., named Alfred Verrecchia, chief financial officer, to be president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Herbert Baum, who became chairman and chief executive at Dial Corp.    MALAN REALTY INVESTORS, Bingham Farms, Mich., named Michael Kaline, vice president, to the post of president. He succeeds Anthony Gramer, who left his post as president and chief executive in May.

headline: Zale Net Up 36% On Jewelry Sales
abstract: Zale Corp profits rise 36 percent in its most recent quarter, to $11.6 million (S)

headline: New York´s Chaos Inspires Web Art
abstract: July 6, 2000

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of August 31 article about aides to Pres Richard M Nixon who expressed skepticism about assertions in new book that president took antiseizure drug Dilantin

headline: Critic of Army Is Assassinated in Secessionist Region of Indonesia
abstract: Tengku Safwan Idris, Islamic university rector and leading candidate for governor of Aceh, Indonesia, is assassinated at his home, Banda Aceh; was outspoken critic of use of military force to settle secessionist issue in province; police are unsure who is behind killing; secessionist leader Ayah Muni blames military; Hutomo Mandela Putra (Tommy Suharto) meets voluntarily with police and denies involvement in series of Jakarta bombings; map (M)

headline: Razorfish Stock Falls After President Resigns
abstract: Razorfish Stock Falls After President Resigns

headline: Britons Running Out of Patience as Costly Gas Runs Out
abstract: More than 1,000 gasoline stations across Britain close after groups of protestors, furious at high fuel prices, blockade oil refineries cutting off fuel deliveries and sending consumers rushing to pumps in mad race to fill cars before fuel ran out; protests echo similar demonstrations in Belgium, where truck drivers paralyzed center of Brussels; irate mood sweeps across Europe; groups in Ireland, Italy, Netherlands and Germany mount or prepare to mount own actions, emboldened by success of recent protests in France; chart; photo (M)

Number of Car Dealers Online Rising
abstract: August 25, 2000

headline: 2 Big Shareholder-Relations Companies Merging
abstract: Georgeson Shareholder Communications, world's largest proxy solicitation company, will acquire Corporate Investor Communications, third largest firm in industry of shareholder communications; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: BBDO Resigns Netpliance Account
abstract: BBDO Worldwide resigns advertising account of Netpliance after only five months, citing significant cutback in ad spending; Netpliance sells I-Opener, Internet appliance offering e-mail without computer (S)

headline: G.M. Vows Gain On Gas Mileage
abstract: General Motors challenged Ford to a battle over which company can deliver bigger improvements in fuel economy, particularly for sport utility vehicles.    Ford said last week that it would improve the gas mileage of its sport utility vehicles over the next five years by 25 percent. General Motors responded that no matter how much Ford improved fuel efficiency, G.M.'s vehicles would do even better.

headline: New AOL Software Leaked
abstract: August 18, 2000

headline: Polo Ralph Lauren Sues Jordache Over Sport Emblem
abstract: Polo Ralph Lauren sues Jordache, which manufactures women's and men's clothing for United States Polo Assn, charging company's use of name 'polo' and symbol of polo player on horse on their clothing infringes its trademark by confusing consumers (M)

headline: The Ear of the Beholder
abstract: Richard Doege letter says economic rationale for digital augmentation of organs is compelling but only traditionale pipe organs give authentic sound (July 27 article)

headline: E-Commerce Report; For online retailers, close-out sales are becoming a reliable and safe source of revenue.
abstract: Online retailers embrace close-out sales as cost-effective way to tell customers about bargains and unload goods quickly; photo (M)

headline: Job Growth Slows, Suggesting Fed May Not Raise Interest Rates
abstract: US companies add fewer jobs than economists anticipated during July, reducing chances that Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its late-August meeting; unemployment rate remains unchanged at 4 percent; private-sector payrolls grow by 138,000, but overall employment falls 108,000; economists welcome possibility of gradual slowing of economy; charts; tables (M)

headline: Two to Preside Over General Assembly
abstract: Namibia, which held presidency of 54th General Assembly, and Finland, which is to preside over 55th General Assembly, will both preside over summit meeting of member nations this week (S)

headline: World Business Briefings
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Two Are Chosen For Creative Posts
abstract: Freelancers Dallas Itzen and Patrick O'Neill are named to share top creative post at New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day (S)

headline: Investing; KPMG Consulting Arm Looks Ready to Fly Solo
abstract: Article profiles KPMG Consulting Inc; firm specializes in 'e-business services' to list of clients spanning business, government and education (M)

headline: ROLLS-ROYCE STOCK PLUNGES
abstract: Shares of Rolls-Royce PLC plummet more than 20 percent after company backs away from promises of double-digit growth next year; reports 93.5 percent decline in first-half net income to 8 million pounds, or $11.8 million, from 123 million pounds a year ago; photo (S)

headline: TELEFONICA PROFIT FALLS
abstract: Spain's Telefonica SA reports net profit for first half of year at 989 million euros ($881 million), 3 percent drop from 1999 period; graph (S)

headline: Firestone's Crisis Is Other Dealers' Opportunity
abstract: Article on windfall for other tire dealerships in light of Firestone recall; 310 Les Schwab Tire Center stores in six Western states have replaced about 125,000 tires since August 9 recall, more than 10 percent of those replaced nationwide; photo; chart (M)

headline: Last-Minute Repair to Engine That Caught Fire on Concorde
abstract: Officials probing crash of Air France Concorde into Gonesse, France, hotel say flight was delayed by last-minute repairs to engine that burst into flames as jet began takeoff; have not yet linked repairs to crash; Air France says ground crews unsuccessfully searched for spare parts for engine and eventually repaired it with parts taken from another Concorde; Elisabeth Senot, who heads probe, says control tower warned captain that engine was on fire; says pilot tried to divert to smaller nearby airport for emergency landing, but was unable to gain altitude; rules out sabotage; workers comb crash site, trying to identify passengers and find debris that can provide clues to cause of crash; map; diagram of engine; photos (M)

headline: Adviser to Some Hollywood Stars Pleads Guilty to Fraud
abstract: Dana C Giacchetto, money manager who headed Cassandra Group investment advisory firm that handled portfolios of some leading Hollywood stars, pleads guilty to stock fraud, Federal District Court, Manhattan, and admits misappropriating some of clients' funds; managed more than $100 million for more than 300 clients (M)

headline: Bridgestone To Register Record Charge
abstract: Bridgestone Corp will record $350 million one-time accounting charge to earnings to cover costs of recall of 6.5 million defective tires by Firestone, its US subsidiary; photo (M)

headline: Heir Apparent Leaves Post at Big Insurer
abstract: Evan Greenberg is leaving as president and chief operating officer of American International Group, where he was heir apparent to his father, Maurice R Greenberg, chairman and chief executive; Maurice Greenberg repeatedly defended Evan as best choice as successor even amid lingering speculation that his eldest son, Jeffrey, might be the better choice; announcement stuns Wall Street and sets off speculation about whether Evan quit or was fired, and whether Greenberg might have be maneuvering to buy Marsh & McLennan Companies as a way of bringing Jeffrey, its chief executive, back into the fold; photos (M)

headline: Europe Begins Proceedings in Its Case Against Microsoft
abstract: BRUSSELS, Aug. 3 -- The European Union added to Microsoft 's legal woes today, opening an antitrust case accusing the company of abusing its market position in operating systems to dominate the market for server software.

headline: Kafr Kila Journal; Ice Cream and Bottle Rockets At Lebanon's Border Parade
abstract: Lebanese are flocking to nation's latest tourist attraction: border area reclaimed from Israel and its proxy militia; vendors have set up shop along border, many selling Hezbollah flags, T-shirts and caps; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    CROATIA: MISSION TO WASHINGTON  The new, democratic leaders of Croatia have been granted the official visit to Washington that the late president, Franjo Tudjman, was never allowed. President Stipe Mesic and Prime Minister Ivica Racan, opposition leaders elected this year, arrive on Monday for meetings with President Clinton and other administration officials. They have moved Croatia away from Mr. Tudjman's strident nationalism and closer to Western aims in the Balkans, but face huge fiscal problems and unemployment.    Steven Erlanger (NYT)    BRITAIN: GOOD NEWS FOR PETS  Fifteen rabies-free islands -- including Australia, Japan and Hawaii -- will be added to the ''pet passport'' program that allows cats and dogs to enter Britain without being quarantined for six months. The program got under way in February, beginning with 22 rabies-free European countries. Each passport certifies the pet has a microchip implant verifying its identity and that it has been vaccinated and tested. Other regions will be considered for inclusion in the program in the near future, including the continental United States.    (AP)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: UAL Says It Expects a Loss, And Its Stock Falls Further  UAL, the parent of United Airlines, said it would report a loss for the quarter that ends today, driving its stock price, which had already fallen 43 percent this year, down another $2, to $42 a share.

headline: Article 2000092193041637192 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Account Review At Verizon Wireless
abstract: Verizon Wireless, joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone AirTouch, places its Northeast local and tactical account into review, in addition to two other regional accounts being reviewed; billings estimated at $50 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph plots rise in gasoline futures prices on August 10; gasoline for September delivery rose 5 percent in New York to 92.64 cents per gallon, biggest gain in 10 weeks

headline: Bumper Crop From the Middle Ground
abstract: Excerpts of conversation with Oppenheimer MidCap senior vice president and manager Bruce Bartlett, who focuses on midcap characteristics and why they are currently doing so well; photo (M)

headline: Frustrated Customers
abstract: Murray Lesser on July 20 article the poor quality of customer service in high-tech retailing

headline: HEICO TO SELL TRILECTRON UNIT TO ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS
abstract: Heico Corp, which provides parts and services to aircraft and aerospace companies, agrees to sell its Trilectron Industries unit to Illinois Tool Works Inc for $52.5 million in cash and assumption of $4.3 million of long-term debt (S)a

headline: Everett Needham Case, 99, Ex-President of Colgate U.
abstract: Everett Needham Case, former president of Colgate University who was also chairman of Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the last 1960's, dies at age 99; photo (M)

headline: Peres Praises China After Visit to Bolster Ties With Ex-Critic
abstract: Prime Min Shimon Peres lavishly praises China as he finishes two-day visit intended to bolster Israel's ties with onetime adversary and shore up global support for continued peace talks; lauds Pres Jiang Zemin's efforts to dissuade Yasir Arafat from early declaration of a Palestinian state (M)

headline: AON, INSURANCE BROKER, BUYING ACTUARIAL SCIENCES
abstract: Aon Corp agrees to buy Actuarial Sciences Associates (S)

headline: FIRST UNION SELLS BRANCHES IN TENNESSEE TO FIRSTAR
abstract: First Union Corp will sell its 41 Tennessee bank branches to Firstar Corp (S)

headline: Singapore Journal; A Fastidious City-State Has an Answer for Crows
abstract: Singapore, concerned that crows can spread illnesses from carrion and waste they eat, relies on affluent gun club volunteers, using government-supplied ammunition, in its efforts to control crow population; crow hunt described; photo (M)

headline: Judge to Be Asked for Major Ruling in Napster Case
abstract: Judge to Be Asked for Major Ruling in Napster Case

headline: Globalization Tops 3-Day U.N. Agenda for World Leaders
abstract: The stormy battle over globalization that brought protests to the streets of Seattle and Washington moves this week to the heart of the world's only truly global organization, the United Nations.

headline: Novartis Sues Abbott Over Drug Patents
abstract: Novartis unit files lawsuit charging Abbott Laboratories with infringing on patents for drug Neoral (cyclospirine), which is used to combat organ rejection in transplant patients (S)

headline: AGILENT AGREES TO BUY DIGITAL TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Agilent Technologies agrees to buy Digital Technology Inc for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: News Organizations Spar for the Rare Concorde Picture
abstract: News organizations competed frenetically to buy photos taken by three amateurs of Concorde airplane in flames just before it crashed; economics of such deals shows little consistency; Japanese businessman has earned $50,000 so far for photo he took from another airplane at Paris airport; photo (M)

headline: LENDERS IN TAX BATTLE
abstract: Group representing Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Sumitomo Bank and other Japanese banks will sue Tokyo metropolitan government or its governors over new tax on lenders, which they say violates principle of fairness in Japanese constitution because tax is aimed only at major banks (S)

headline: Internet Pornographer Reported Target of Fraud Inquiry
abstract: Internet Pornographer Reported Target of Fraud Inquiry

headline: OIL DRILLING PURCHASE
abstract: Canada's Precision Drilling Corp buys rival well-service company CenAlta Energy Services Inc for about 207.9 million Canadian dollars ($140.7 million) in stock to expand in the western part of country (S)

headline: More Web Hits for GOP Than Democrats
abstract: August 24, 2000

headline: BORDERS SAYS IT HAS ENDED ACQUISITION TALKS
abstract: Borders Group, No. 2 US book chain, ends acquisition talks and is exploring other alternatives, including stock buyback (S)

headline: SHAW GROUP WINS THE BIDDING FOR STONE & WEBSTER
abstract: Shaw Group announces its success in bidding for assets of bankrupt Stone & Webster at auction proceeding held under Bankruptcy Code Chapter 11 (S)

headline: Sharon Touches a Nerve, and Jerusalem Explodes
abstract: Ariel Sharon, right-wing Israeli opposition leader, leads group of Israeli legislators onto bitterly contested Temple Mount to assert Jewish claims there, setting off stone-throwing clash that leaves several Palestinians and more than two dozen policemen injured; Sharon entourage is tightly guarded by Israeli security cordon; violence spreads to streets of East Jerusalem and to West Bank town of Ramallah; Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, condemns Sharon's tour as 'dangerous action' against Muslim holy sites; Sharon claims he brought message of peace; photo (M)

headline: Phone Talks Said to Stall, With Strike in Third Day
abstract: Contract negotiations between Verizon Communications and representatives of striking workers take turn for worse on third day of walkout by more than 86,000 employees dimming hopes for quick resolution; photo (M)

headline: China's Migrants Find Europe's Open Back Door: The Balkans
abstract: Balkans have become latest gateway to Western Europe for tens of thousands of immigrants from China, South Asia and Middle Eastern countries like Iran and Iraq; Yugoslavia in particular, which has cultivated strong ties with China, has opened gates to thousands of Chinese intent on reaching Western Europe; its consulates in China freely grant tourist visas to Chinese, and legal passage into Yugoslavia eases way for illegal entry to rest of Europe; Bosnia has its own flow of illegal immigrants from Iran and Iraq and other countries with which Muslim-led government in Sarajevo has maintained strong ties, and Croatia is experiencing staggering increase in human traffic; influx underscores growing alarm among Western diplomats and migration officials that sophisticated and far-reaching network of human traffickers from Asia has switched attention from US and is looking to Europe; traffickers have found troubled and unruly countries of former Yugoslavia, with porous borders and lack of immigration laws and agreements, are ideal gateway to West; map; photos (M)

headline: Article 2000092193567235692 -- No Title
abstract: CIRCUITS

headline: LOS ANGELES DEVELOPER TO BUY LAS VEGAS HILTON
abstract: Park Place Entertainment Corp, world's largest casino company, agrees to sell Las Vegas Hilton to Los Angeles real estate developer Ed Roski Jr for $365 million in cash, receivables and assumed debt; Roski, president and chief executive of Majestic Realty Corp, will assume $31 million in liabilities and Park Place will keep $28 million in debt owed by high-rolling gamblers (S)

headline: Central Banks Move to Rescue An Ailing Euro
abstract: European, American and Japanese central banks, shaken by relentless decline of euro, undertake surprise attempt to fight what they see as threat to world economy; move announced at start of Group of Seven meeting in Prague is first time in two years that central banks have staged coordinated currency intervention, and first time in support of European currency; action is also shift by US Sec Lawrence Summers; photo; banks buy billions of euros with dollars, yen and British pounds, pushing euro's value up to 90 cents from 85 cents; fear is that Europe faces economic shock from sinking currency and soaring price of oil, which is purchased with strong US dollar; euro's decline has eroded support for common currency in Denmark, which is set to vote on issue, and in Britain, where opposition has intensified (M)

headline: RESPITE IN CANADIAN INFLATION
abstract: Canada's annual inflation rate slowed to 2.5 percent in August from 3 percent in June; excluding energy, inflation rate was 1.7 percent in August, up slightly from 1.5 percent in July; graph (S)

headline: French Turn Vandal Into Hero Against U.S.
abstract: Most store owners in Millau, France, fearing that trial of Jose Bove would turn their quiet little town into battleground for forces of anti-globalization, keep their iron gates closed; McDonald's restaurant, which Bove is charged with ransacking last year, is blockaded by two dozen police vehicles; as trial opens, atmosphere seems more like French Woodstock than a Seattle; people set up tents and strum guitars in the streets in support of Bove, sheep farmer who has become something of national hero with his fight against multinational corporations and what he calls industrialization of agriculture; photos; map (L)

headline: AOL and Time Warner Face Criticism at F.C.C. Hearing
abstract: America Online chairman-chief executive Stephen M Case and Gerald M Levin, his Time Warner Inc counterpart, defend proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner against rising tide of criticism that new colossus will be so anticompetitive that it must be reined in by regulators even before its creation, Federal Communications Commission hearing; Case and Levin vow to keep their cable, broadcast and Internet systems open to rivals, and say it would be against their business interests to discriminate against other companies that rely on them; consumer groups, along with Walt Disney Co, NBC and host of Internet service providers and telephone companies, have raised concerns about the deal coming in midst of digital revolution that is slowly blurring lines between telephones, televisions and the Internet; photo (M)

headline: H.M.O. Costs Spur Employers To Shift Plans
abstract: Health insurance premiums are increasing by 10 percent to 30 percent nationwide, suggesting that apart from most restrictive, bare-bones health maintenance organizations, managed care is no longer keeping medical costs down; increases are spurring many companies, which in past encouraged employees to join managed-care plans, to turn away from HMO's toward insurance that does not entail high administrative costs of managed care; corporations, especially smaller companies in low-margin businesses, may force employees to absorb increasing costs, or even stop offering health insurance altogether; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Controversial Education Study
abstract: Anew analysis of recent research into the use of technology in the classroom is being praised by some educators and policymakers, but critics are already questioning its conclusions and its credibility.

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON ALZHEIMER'S DRUG NEARS APPROVAL
abstract: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval (S)

headline: Few Haitians Turn Out for Runoff Election
abstract: Few Haitians vote in runoff election shunned by opposition candidates and international observers; elections were for legislative and local offices not already won by Lavalas bloc, party of former Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide; low turnout follows questionable first-round results on May 21; photo (M)

headline: GERMAN GROWTH QUICKENS
abstract: German economy expands 1.1 percent in three months ending in June, its fastest rate in years; graph (S)

headline: New Chief for Theglobe.com
No More 'Morning-After Pills' At School, French Court Says
abstract: France's highest administrative court reverses a decision that had allowed nurses in high school health centers to hand out 'morning-after pill' to prevent pregnancies; Council of State overrules decision made by education minister last year, saying that official had misunderstood 1967 law, which says that hormonal contraceptives may be distributed only under prescriptions by pharmacies (S)

headline: St. John´s Journal Cruise Ships Descend On Newfound Bonanza
abstract: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland — In the workaday harbor here, normally plied by tugs, tankers and freighters laid up for repairs, Le Levant offered a startling contrast on a recent day: a sleek French cruise ship disgorging 50 affluent American tourists.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of September 10 Private Sector column about choice of Russell Crowe to play leading role in film about John Forbes Nash Jr, which misstated screenwriter Akiva Goldsman's name (S)

headline: A Personal Tailor For Denimed Masses
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on her happy experience buying a pair of jeans through Interactive Custom Clothes Co, whose Web site allows shopper to have jeans cut to his or her exact measurements and to specify details like button color, fabric weight and number of pockets; drawing (M)

headline: No Longer Bulletproof, but Feeling Bullish Again
abstract: Alex Berenson Market Watch column notes stocks rallied on strong second-quarter corporate earnings and indications that economic growth may be slowing, perhaps making further interest-rate increases unnecessary, at least for a while; graph (M)

headline: Ugandan Vote Backs Leader On Keeping His System
abstract: Early results of referendum on Uganda's political future show that more than 80 percent of those voting want to continue with current 'no party' system advocated by nation's president, Yoweri Museveni; but opponents of Museveni declare victory, saying turnout is far too low for him to claim strong mandate (M)

headline: WHAT'S NEXT; I.B.M. Plans a Tough Problem for Blue Gene's Million Processors
abstract: About.com's Webmasters, called guides, gather in Washington to discuss their work; they work as independent contractors, earning a minimum of $500 a months as a fee against advertising revenue; that many guides are not professionals in their fields, simply passionate hobbyists, is considered one of the strengths of About.com; photo (M)

headline: Brewed in China, Envied Abroad; Tsingtao Outsells Intruders Even as It Courts Anheuser
abstract: China's Tsingtao Brewery, once bloated state-run enterprise, has transformed itself into confident world competitor; Tsingtao has managed to stake out dominant position in crowded and chaotic Chinese beer market by learning marketing skills from its foreign rivals and exploiting its home-field advantage; Tsingtao is negotiating to buy three breweries from foreigner owners; Tsingtao's chief Peng Zuo Yi is seeking alliance with Anheuser-Busch, in which companies would distribute each other's beer in China and US; Stephen Burrows, chief executive of Anheuser-Busch International, calls it premature to talk about such a deal, but says Tsingtao has changed markedly--and for the better--in last five years; graph; map; photos (M)

headline: Hijacked Cuban Plane Crashes Off the Florida Keys
abstract: Ahijacked Cuban plane with perhaps 18 people aboard crashed in international waters off the Florida Keys this morning, and Cuba asked for help in searching for survivors, United States officials said.

headline: FRENCH CABLE STAKE SOLD
abstract: New York-based NTL Inc, Britain's No. 1 cable television company, and Morgan Stanley Private Equity will buy France Telecom's 49.9 percent of Noos, France's biggest cable operator, for 1.35 billion euros ($1.2 billion); Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux is majority owner of Noos (S)

headline: BT CELLNET FACES CHARGE
abstract: British telecommunications regulatory agency accuses wireless unit of British Telecommunications, BT Cellnet, of unfair business practices (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WORLD WRESTLING FEDERATION ENTERTAINMENT INC., -- Stamford, Conn., said it intended to list its common shares on the New York Stock Exchange on Oct. 25 under the symbol WWF. The company's shares were first quoted on the Nasdaq stock market after it completed its public offering on Oct. 19, 1999.    1-800-FLOWERS.COM INC., -- Westbury, N.Y., which sells flowers and gifts via telephone and the Web, said it signed a new five-year marketing agreement with America Online, the Internet services company, extending an existing e-commerce partnership.

headline: FOUR GUILTY IN ACCESS-CARD SALES
abstract: Federal authorities report four people pleaded guilty to felony charges of violating laws against unauthorized decryption of satellite programming; seven others are facing charges after 22-month investigation into sale of counterfeit or pirated satellite television access cards (S)

headline: BRAZIL LIABLE IN LOSSES
abstract: Brazil's Supreme Federal Tribunal rules government is liable for about $21 billion in losses some 600,000 employees suffered to type of individual unemployment insurance fund during late 1980's and early 1990's, when series of unsuccessful economic plans threw economy into chaos (S)

headline: SONY SAYS CHIP WILL ADD BATTERY LIFE
abstract: Sony is bringing out new version of its 2.2-pound Vaio C1VN PictureBook Computer using 600-megahertz microprocessor from Transmeta that will roughly double battery life of system, now ranging up to 5.5 hours (S)

headline: Article 2000092293998173533 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Still Inflation-Wary, Fed Lets Rates Stand
abstract: Federal Reserve, reassured by evidence that wage and price increases remain under control despite robust economic growth, votes to leave interest rates unchanged but warns that it might raise rates later in year if inflation creeps up; decision leaves benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks at 6.5 percent; discount rate remains at 6 percent; photo (M)

headline: Germany´s T-Online Buys Spanish Internet Operator
abstract: Germany's T-Online Buys Spanish Internet Operator

headline: Profit Rises 6.2% at Abbott Laboratories
abstract: Abbott Laboratories reports second-quarter profits rose 6.2 percent, to $685 million, on sales of $3.37 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALLSTATE CORP., Northbrook, Ill., the nation's largest publicly held, personal life insurance company, said that its subsidiary, Allstate Life Insurance Co., had agreed to acquire Provident National Assurance Co., a part of UnumProvident Corp., a disability and specialty risk insurance holding company based in Chattanooga, Tenn., for an undisclosed amount.

headline: FRANKLIN RESOURCES UNIT BUYS FUND MANAGER IN CANADA
abstract: Franklin Resources Inc, mutual fund company, buys Bissett & Associates Investmenet Management Ltd of Calgary, Canada, for $95 million to expand in Canada (S)

headline: 'Big Brother' Who?
abstract: Kevin Hanson letter praises July 6 article explaining technology used in CBS's Big Brother program

headline: Intel Recalls Its Speediest Computer Chip Because of Flaw
abstract: Intel Recalls Its Speediest Computer Chip Because of Flaw

headline: Why This Consumer Giant Isn't About to Sell to Consumers
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co is investing in Internet exchanges to make its factories more efficient; it hopes that work of chemists in Health Care Research Center in Mason, Ohio, can be combined with Web site to create products personalized to customer's tastes; photos (special section, E-Commerce) (M)

headline: Rescue of Retail Chain May Threaten Recovery in Japan
abstract: Japan's Financial Reconstruction Commission says government will spend 97 billion yen ($924 million) to help rescue Sogo Co, averting major retail chain bankruptcy but reigniting concerns about Japan's economic future; accord paves way for Sogo's other banks to forgive over 630 billion yen in loans; decision to rescue Sogo and ease pressure on banks to which Sogo owes $16 billion raises questions about where government will draw line on use of public money and its commitment to economic reform; photo (M)

headline: HOTEL MERGER TALKS
abstract: British conglomerate Granada Compass PLC and French hotel company Accor SA have held talks that could lead to sale of Granada Compass's hotel division to Accor (S)

headline: Cheney's Predicament
abstract: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice presidential candidate, will have a hard time ridding himself entirely of an economic interest in Halliburton and still holding onto the money from his options to buy stock in the company. And the problem will likely arise again when executives leave companies for public service.  News analysis, Page C1.

headline: Low-Price, Highly Ambitious Digital Chip
abstract: Foveon Co develops image-sensing computer chip capable of same resolution as Eastman Kodak's new chip, which can to capture digital images with resolution of 4,096 by 4,096 pixels per square inch, but Foveon says its technique could be much less expensive; clarity achieved with Foveon chip could begin to challenge expensive 4-by-5 film cameras made by companies like Hasselblad that are used by professional photographers; Foveon's founder, Carver Mead, a pioneer in chip industry, says he hopes to replace film camera; new technologies would have other applications as well; photo (M)

headline: Hitting Executives Where They Live
abstract: Camp/Arbues of San Francisco opens retro-looking, attention-getting pony give-away print and TV ad campaign for PeerLogic; photo (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Set for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Active Power Inc., Austin, Tex., an initial public offering of 8 million shares. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: I.B.M. TO OFFER JUNO OPTION
abstract: Shares of Juno Online Services surge 24 percent, to $6.125, after company announces promotional agreement with IBM, similar to those between other top Internet service providers and computer makers, that analysts say will probably be expensive for Juno (S)

headline: NORTEL WINS $1 BILLION CONTRACT
abstract: Nortel Networks Inc wins contract extension from Williams Companies to supply as much as $1 billion of fiber optic gear through 2002 (S)

headline: Feeding the 'Energy Eater'; Atlantic Canada's Oil Boom Helps the Northeastern U.S.
abstract: Atlantic coastal area of Canada is emerging as major source of oil and natural gas, with Northeastern US as its primary customer; Hibernia oil field and Sable gas field are already in production; Terra Nova, $200 million, 14-story oil production vessel will move 220 miles east of St John's, Newfoundland, next spring, lock into place over 400-million-barrel pool of oil, and start pumping 100,000 barrels a day, largely for Northeastern US; Nova Scotia has started sending gas south, and that flow could increase greatly in coming years; Atlantic Canada, from Nova Scotia to Labrador, could prove to be next-generation North Sea or Prudhoe Bay; Newfoundland, long Canada's poorest province, stands to reap biggest benefit; of the 11 oil fields larger than 100 million barrels discovered worldwide since 1979, 4 have been off coast of Newfoundland, on Grand Banks; Newfoundland is in midst of 15-year, $10 billion oil investment plan; by 2004, province will be pumping 400,000 barrels a day, same amount as small OPEC producer; map; photos (M)

headline: Survey Lauds Midwestern Schools
abstract: Sparsely populated Midwestern states are challenging the stereotype of the isolated rural school, leading the nation in the use of technology to connect classrooms to the nation and the world, a recent study suggests.

headline: Sharon Interrupts Lawmakers' Recess to Aim Barbs at Barak
abstract: Likud opposition party uses depleted special session of Israeli Parliament to push through resolution aimed at impeding new peace talks with Palestinians, but Prime Min Ehud Barak's government brushes aside move; Sharon photo; flurry of new peace maneuvers are under way, with Jerusalem compromise proposals on table (M)

headline: A Feeble Croatia Is Battling Its Ex-Leaders
abstract: Croatia Pres Stipe Mesic's first seven months in power have been sobering; he has been determined to bring Croatia into European Union, but economy he inherited afetr death of former Pres Franjo Tudjman is in seriously bad shape; he was elected promising an end to corruption and nepotism of Tudjman government, but court system used for years as political tool has not been strong enough or independent enough to prosecute law vigorously; levels of corruption Mesic has uncovered from old government have far outstripped his worst imaginings, running into the billions of dollars; photo (L)

headline: AT&T TO OFFER AD-SUBSIDIZED WEB ACCESS
abstract: AT&T Corp will start advertising-subsidized Internet access service to match free offerings from competitors like NetZero (S)

headline: Calendar of Debt Sales Planned for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a 10-year inflation index note on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.84 percent and a six-month bill was 5.91 percent. The yield on the current issue of the inflation index note was 4.00 percent.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A big online broker failed to file short-sales data, and Nasdaq's regulatory response was tepid.
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers announces E*Trade Securities, large on-line brokerage firm, has been fined $20,000 because it failed to file short-sales reports for 28 months, from June 1996 through September 1998; E*Trade calls failed filings inadvertent and NASD vice president Stephen Luparello agrees (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Movie Studios Seek to Stop DVD Copies
abstract: Lawyers for eight movie studios urge Judge Lewis Kaplan to keep Eric Corley from distributing on his Web site software program that unscrambles encryption on DVD movie discs (M)

headline: Shares Tumble on Phone Company's Weak Earnings Forecast
abstract: Shares pf Verizon, nation's No.1 local phone company, plunge in trading on August 8 on weak earnings forecast; company says it will be unable to meet financial targets; shares drop almost 14 percent, to $42.0625, in sharpest one-day decline since 1987; investors flee as strike by 86,000 unionized employees enters third day; photo (M)

headline: Crime News Web Site to File For Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: APB Online, operator of criminal justice news Web site that recently foundered, plans to file for protection for creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal Bankruptcy Code; last month, ABP Online laid off staff and scrambled to find private investors to inject new capital into debt-ridden company; bankruptcy filing by APBnews.com is designed to provide little more breathing space for site (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen weakens for fourth consecutive day, settling at 107.84; other exchange rates listed (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Health Insurance Premiums Are Increasing 10% to 30%  Health insurance premiums are increasing 10 percent to 30 percent nationwide, according to employers, insurers and regional business groups familiar with rates being paid by dozens of companies. Driven largely by escalating drug costs, the double-digit increase is the third in a row for many companies.    The rising premiums suggest that apart from the most restrictive, bare-bones health maintenance organizations, managed care is no longer keeping medical costs down. The increasing costs come at a time of rising concern about health care costs, particularly drug costs, in Medicare. The increases revive a contentious issue that clouded the early years of the Clinton administration. [Page A1.]

headline: Monsanto Plans to Offer Rights To Its Altered-Rice Technology
abstract: Monsanto Corp says it will make available patent rights to genetically altered rice that could help stave off malnutrition in poor nations; so-called 'golden rice' is rich in beta carotene, a source of Vitamin A (M)

headline: Flower Power, With PowerBooks
abstract: Burning Man, high-tech music and arts festival in Black Rock Desert north of Reno, Nev, attracts about 28,000 people, mostly from California's Silicon Valley and San Francisco (S)

headline: SIEMENS TO SELL EXCHANGEABLE BONDS
abstract: Siemens AG will issue up to $2.4 billion in five-year bonds exchangeable into stock of Infineon, chip-maker in which it holds majority stake (S)

headline: Earnings Surge At BP Amoco
abstract: BP Amoco PLC reports second-quarter 2000 net of $3.61 billion, compared with $1.37 billion in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Sale: Web Address, Unused, Not Cheap
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co puts the Internet address www.flu.com up for sale at $1.4 million; address does not lead to World Wide Web site, and it never has; because virtually all catch Web addresses ending in '.com' have already been claimed, value of such unused names has risen sharply (M)

headline: RELIEF FOR LAIDLAW
abstract: Laidlaw Inc, operator of Greyhound Lines and North America's largest fleet of school buses, says it should be able to satisfy working capital needs with new credit of up to $200 million that it is close to signing with its banking syndicate (S)

headline: Privacy Can Be Elusive In the World of E-Mail
abstract: Answers to readers' questions on e-mail, including how safe and private it is (M)

headline: CANADA'S ECONOMY GROWS
abstract: Canada's gross domestic product rose at 4.7 percent pace in second quarter; exports rose at 8.5 percent annual rate and imports at 10.2 percent rate; consumer spending rose at 3.6 percent yearly rate; gdp graph (S)

headline: BCE and Thomson Form Canadian Media Giant
abstract: Thomson Corp, owner of The Globe and Mail newspaper, and BCE Inc, whose subsidiaries include television and Internet units, form joint venture, that will be 70.1 percent-owned by BCE and 20 percent-owned by Thomson (M)

headline: I.B.M. AND CISCO EXPAND IN IRELAND
abstract: Industrial Development Authority of Ireland wins investment contracts from IBM and Cisco Systems; IBM announces plans to spend $119 million in placing its online business-to-business procurement services near Dublin, while Cisco Systems is reported to have acquired site that would employ 1,500 to make equipment for the Internet (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PROBEX CORP., -- Dallas, a motor oil recycler, agreed to acquire for an undisclosed price almost all the assets of Specialty Environmental Services Inc., a unit of the Houston-based Pennzoil-Quaker State Co. The Specialty unit, based in Shreveport, La., collects used motor oil for Pennzoil-Quaker State, a maker of the two top motor oil brands.    CANON INC., -- Tokyo, the computer hardware company, said that it would list its American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange. To make the change, the company will delist its A.D.R.'s from the Nasdaq composite index on Sept. 13. The company said the New York Stock Exchange had already approved the listing.

headline: Mother, I'm the Boss Now; Internet Executives Hire Their Parents And Traditions Fall
abstract: Internet executives hire their parents and traditions fall; it has become less unusual, among Internet start-up companies, for chief executives to hire their parents; two main causes for this reversal of tradition: typical start-up CEO is 30 years old, and labor shortage in this sector is pronounced; article profiles examples of parents working for their children; photos (M)

headline: Satellite Web Links Let Indian Tribes Take a Technological Jump
abstract: One hundred twenty locations on Navajo, Hopi and Havasupai reservations throughout Arizona, New Mexico and Utah are supplied with new satellite dishes and computer equipment for two-way, high-speed Internet service; one delivery is made by caravan of pack mules down eight miles of trails to the bottom of the Grand Canyon; three-year pilot project is first commercial venture for Starband Communications, which plans to begin selling two-way saatelite Internet service to the general public later in 2000 (M)

headline: RULING AGAINST U.S.
abstract: World Trade Organization strikes down US restrictions on importation of wheat gluten (S)

headline: Fashion's Walk on the Wild Side
abstract: PARIS—  A funny thing has happened to fashion photography. Models of the thin and flawless variety aren't the only scantily clad bodies attracting attention in magazine spreads and the ad campaigns of the hottest fashion labels anymore.

headline: Korean Summit:Bad for Stocks?
abstract: AN ARTICLE in the June 24-25 Money Report concerned the investment prospects of bonds issued by pariah states, focusing in particular on North Korean debt and the impact that the recent Korean summit might have on it. Barton Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co., has been considering another potential impact of the summit meeting on South Korean stocks.

headline: It's a Word World, Or Is It?
abstract: Joel Brinkley article on his allegiance to WordPerfect in a word-processing world in which Microsoft Word's dominance now hovers between 93 percent and 95 percent; notes that Corel Corp, WordPerfect's owner, has had to make its software as compatible as it can with Word in order to survive; notes a few nice WordPerfect features, especially Reveal Codes button; drawing (M)

headline: DoubleClick Reports Narrower-Than-Expected Loss of 3 Cents a Share
Noted Insurance Analyst Moves
abstract: Noted insurance analyst Alice D Schroeder leaves PaineWebber to join Morgan Stanley Dean Witter (M)

headline: Compaq Sells Unit Interest to CMGI
abstract: Compaq Sells Unit Interest to CMGI

headline: Gas Deposits Off Israel and Gaza Opening Vision of Joint Ventures
abstract: Foreign energy companies are drilling deep below seas off Israel and Gaza Strip, discovering gas reserves that could lift Palestinian economy and give Israel its first taste of energy independence; industry experts say Palestinians and Israelis will both profit if they can work together in high-stakes partnership; they need each other for efficient development of offshore reserves, since neither side alone can fully afford billion-dollar investment in pipelines and pumping facilities that is being sketched out; although territorial issues and long-lasting hostilities could easily intrude, both sides are speaking optimistically of potential bonanza; photos; map (M)

headline: WorldCom Said to Be in Talks To Buy Intermedia of Florida
abstract: Worldcom Corp is in advanced talks to acquire Intermedia Communications Inc, telecommunications operator, for almost $3 billion in cash and stock (M)

headline: SBC SELLS LEASE RIGHTS FOR 3,900 TOWERS
abstract: SpectraSite Holdings, which builds, manages and leases wireless communications towers in major cities, will acquire leasing rights for 3,900 towers from SBC Communications for about $1.3 billion (S)

headline: U.N. MEETING ENDS WITH DECLARATION OF COMMON VALUES
abstract: World leaders at United Nations summit meeting seek to mesh developed world's stress on universal democracy, rule of law and human rights with demands by poor nations for better balance in world's economy and more benefits from rise of globalization in setting goals for next millennium; summit, largest gathering of its kind ever, also serves as impromtu forum for examining UN performance; photo (M)

headline: LIMIT REMOVED ON STEEL MAKER SHARES
abstract: South Korean government, hoping to increase declining share price of Pohang Iron and Steel Co, world's largest steel maker, will eliminate 30 percent stock ownership and 3 percent individual share-holding limit in company this month instead of next year; Pohang's share price gains 3.2 percent (S)

headline: Honeywell to Sell Its Brake Product Business
abstract: Questor Partners Fund II, private investment firm, agrees to buy brake-products business of Honeywell International (S)

headline: The Medium Gets The Message; TV's Monoliths Have Learned The Web Is a Fragmented World
abstract: Television's broadcast networks, despite great effort and hundreds of millions of dollars of promotion, are still also-rans on Web; traffic to their various sites badly lags behind big portals like Yahoo, America Online and Microsoft's MSN; Wall Street has all but written off broadcast companies as Internet players; publicly traded shares of NBC Internet and ABC's online cousin Walt Disney Internet Group are down more than two-thirds this year, and CBS has delayed plans to spin off its Internet operations into separate company; photos; chart of stock prices of network Internet spinoffs; chart of visits to network sites (M)

headline: No Prosecution For Netanyahu In Graft Inquiry
abstract: Israel's attorney general, Elyakim Rubinstein, says former Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu will not be prosecuted on corruption charges; condemns Netanyahu for 'improper' conduct but says six-month probe found insufficient evidence to convict Netanyahu or his wife, Sarah, on criminal charges of bribery, fraud and theft; acknowledges that state attorney, Edna Arbel, disagrees with his conclusion not to convict; Netanyahus were suspected of conspiring with contractor in illegal kickback scheme, of stealing gifts to state and of obstructing justice; Netanyahus have denied wrongdoing, claiming persecution by political enemies; it is unclear whether Netanyahu will try to make comeback in politics; photo (M)

headline: Russian Resistance a Key To Delay on Missile Shield
abstract: Senior Clinton Administration and Pentagon officials say that foundation for Pres Clinton's decision not to authorize even initial construction of national missile shield had in fact been laid months before his speech at Georgetown University; say decision had been shaped by events as far back as January, when Russians first made it clear they would not negotiate changes in Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972; administration's calculated plan for making decision about limited missile shield in election year 2000 had begun to unravel evern before it got very far, and it did so largely because of events that were largely out of administration's control (L)

headline: Judge Shelves Plan for Sale Of Online Customer Database
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Carol Kenner sets aside Federal Trade Commission plan limiting ability of online toy retailer Toysmart.com to sell its customer database as part of its liquidation; says in absence of a buyer, commission's action is premature; she takes action 'without prejudice,' meaning that trade commission and others are welcome to renew their concerns and objections once bid and specific terms have been put forward for approval; Toysmart.com had pledged not to sell its customer information to third parties, but its bankruptcy prompted concerns that data would be sold as part of its assets; photo (M)

headline: As Problems Mount, Colombia's President Shuffles His Cabinet
abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia shuffles his cabinet in effort to revive government's sharply declining political and economic fortunes; composition of restructured cabinet pitches government somewhat further to the left (M)

headline: New York Magazine: End of a Beginning
abstract: New York Magazine ends its popular competition, mix of wordplay and puns, with departure of Mary Ann Madden, who has edited contest since she created it in 1968; photo (M)

headline: Convention Events Schedule
abstract: Following are the principal events scheduled for 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. Pacific daylight time Wednesday at the Democratic National Convention:

headline: KOREAN BANK WORKERS PREPARE TO STRIKE
abstract: South Koreans are bracing for impending financial chaos next week as tens of thousands of unionized bank workers support nationwide strike set for July 11; workers are protesting government plans to restructure industry, which calls for consolidation of number of banks; union workers contend plans would lead to major layoffs (S)

headline: U.S. and Top Chinese Officials Try to Smooth Over Differences
abstract: US Defense Sec William S Cohen and Chinese leaders make hopeful pledges of cooperation and friendship at conclusion of two days of high-level meetings in Beijing, despite evidence of deep rifts over important military policies and Chinese suspicions about American intentions; but officials also struggle with potentially explosive disputes, including United States missile defense and continued arms sales to Taiwan, as well as American contention that China recently helped Pakistan develop ballistic missiles; Chinese officials also endure new humiliation of Israel's reneging on deal to sell China an airborne radar system (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: REUNION INDUSTRIES, Pittsburgh, a machine parts and products manufacturing company, is selling its Irish plastics unit, Data Packaging, to an undisclosed Irish corporation for about $13.4 million.

headline: Critics Asking Clinton to Stop Advancing Missile Plan
abstract: Dr Theodore A Postol, a leading critic of national missile defense, says in letter to Pres Clinton that Clinton's advisers have made misleading statements about proposed missile shield and urges creating an independent commission of top scientists to evaluate plan; American Physical Society, Federation of American Scientists and Union of Concerned Scientists jointly announce that they have urged Clinton not to deploy missile defense system, regardless of how its ground-based interceptor performs in coming test; Greenpeace is sending a Dutch icebreaker, Arctic Sunrise, to designated 'hazard zone' near launching site at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to try to stop test; Defense Department issues statement defending integrity of program (M)

headline: $120 Million Stock Deal for Drug Company
abstract: Human Genome Sciences acquires Principia Pharmaceutical for $120 million in stock (S)

headline: As Election Nears, Yugoslavia's Main Rivals Lash Out
abstract: Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, battling for re-election, attacks opposition leaders as tools of NATO, rallies in Montenegro and Belgrade, Serbia; Vojislav Kostunica, main opposition candidate, appears before crowd estimated at 100,000, Belgrade; Milosevic's brief visit to Montenegro is his first in four years; photo (M)

headline: DOUBTS ON BAAN FUTURE
abstract: Dutch software maker Baan says its 1999 earnings will be lower than originally reported and that without financing or takeover it is unlikely to survive as independent company; says company had 1999 net loss of $310 million on revenue of $619 million, not net loss of $289 million on revenue of $634 million, as company reported on Feb 3 (S)

headline: Schwab to Allow Before-Hours Trading
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp will begin letting customers trade stocks before US markets open; will widen its trading window to include 7:45 am to 9:15 am starting Aug 17 (S)

headline: U.S. Spy Sub Said to Record Torpedo Blast Aboard Kursk
abstract: Acoustical tapes made by US nuclear-powered attack submarine Memphis and other vessels contain strong evidence to support leading American theory that onboard explosion, probably misfiring of torpedo, caused sinking of Russian nuclear submarine Kursk in Barents sea with loss of 118 lives; American officials rule out collision with another submarine, as claimed by Russians; say rocket-propelled torpedo being loaded or launched as part of exercise misfired, with its engine and fuel exploding; refuse comment on whereabouts or mission of Memphis and another American submarine that were spying on largest Russian naval exercise in years, when disaster struck Kursk on morning of August 12; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; Network Newscasts Court Hispanic Viewers
abstract: Television networks weigh steps to court growing audience for 6:30 evening newscasts on Spanish-language networks; ABC will offer Spanish-language audio track for its show; NBC and CBS consider similar services (M)

headline: Going OnlineTo See Bus Systems(Not System Buses)
abstract: Going Online To See Bus Systems (Not System Buses)

headline: Case Closed in ´78 Killing
abstract: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 21 — Bulgaria has officially closed an investigation into the killing of the dissident Georgy Markov with a spiked umbrella in London in 1978, saying the case is too old, the Sofia public prosecutor, Nestor Nestorov, said today.

headline: Setting a Goal of Reconciliation, Clinton Plans a November Trip to Hanoi
abstract: White House says Pres Clinton will visit Vietnam after November elections, becoming first president to step onto Vietnamese soil since end of Vienam war, which took 58,000 American lives; trip would complete reconciliation with Communist government that has unfolded over past six years; Clinton plans state visit to Hanoi as well as visit to Ho Chi Minh City; he will most likely talk about using trade as instrument for democratization; praise for upcoming trip comes from Republican and Democratic veterans of Vietnam war, including Sen John McCain, Sen Chuck Hagel and Sen Bob Kerrey (M)

headline: Report Finds Legal Basis For Controversial Net Agency
abstract: Report Finds Legal Basis For Controversial Net Agency

headline: WELLS FARGO AND FIRST SECURITY AGREE TO SELL 37 OFFICES
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co and First Security Corp agree to sell 37b branch offices to win Justice Department approval of Wells Fargo's $2.9 billion purchase of First Security; merger still requires approval by Federal Reserve System's board of governors (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Medallion Media agrees to acquire Out There Media for undisclosed terms (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Robert E. Dewar, 77, Who Led Kmart in 70's Expansion, Dies
abstract: Robert E Dewar, former chairman and chief executive of Kmart Corporation, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: THIRD WAVE TECHNOLOGIES FILES FOR INITIAL STOCK SALE
abstract: Third Wave Technologies Inc, maker of technology that analyzes genes, files with Securities and Exchange Commission for initial public stock sale (S)

headline: Interviews With the Stars, Past and Present
abstract: Interviews With the Stars, Past and Present

headline: Business Travel; Air traffic systems in Europe are also under increased demand, but there are alternatives.
abstract: Air traffic systems in Europe are under increased demand, but there is no sense of crisis as in US because there are alternatives; in Europe, railroads remain vital components of transportation system; high-speed trains traveling at speeds up to 200 miles an hour on new networks of dedicated track have become major competitors to airlines for short-haul business travel market (M)

headline: Lancelot Ware Dies at 85; Mensa Was His Brainchild
abstract: Lancelot Ware, British barrister and Mensa co-founder, dies at age 85 (M)

headline: Bereft Russia Hears Putin's Mea Culpa on Sub Accident
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin moves decisively to contain political impact of the loss of the submarine Kursk, going on national television to say he feels the full sense of guilt and responsibility for the crisis; says measuring out responsibility must wait for a full investigation of what caused the submarine to explode and plunge to Barents Sea floor; suggests that tortuous pace of the military's rescue effort, and his own seeming diffidence at the start, played no role in sailors' deaths because they were doomed from the moment the submarine went down; photo (M)

headline: Europe Reported Ready to Block Time Warner's Deal With EMI
abstract: European antitrust regulators plan to block Time Warner's joint venture with British music conglomerate EMI Group but are much closer to approving Time Warner's $135 billion merger with America Online; object that deal between EMI and Time Warner would reduce number of worldwide music distributors to four from five, and they are pushing for divestitures that companies are loath to offer; photo (M)

headline: Ford and Another Tire Maker Facing New S.U.V. Problems
abstract: Ford Motor Co and Continental AG are preparing to replace Continental tires on 40,000 Lincoln Navigator full-size sport utility vehicles; plan to present information on problems associated with tires to regulators at National Highway Traffic Safety Administration at meeting in Washington, DC; Bridgestone Corp will reshuffle Firestone's management and will increase its line of bank credit (M)

headline: As Peace Plan Falters, Sri Lanka´s War Has No End in Sight
abstract: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 12 — This war-haunted nation's president, blinded in her right eye by a suicide bomber's attack, still talks of peace. But many ordinary Sri Lankans are more convinced than ever that no end to the country's 17-year conflict with the Tamil rebels is near.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline rises on signs that demand from motorists before Labor Day holiday is eroding inventories; in New York, gasoline for September delivery rises 1.15 cents, to $1.0114 a gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: Istanbul Journal; Turkish Brand of Extreme Polo Making Comeback
