abstract: Cirit, an extreme form of polo, is enjoying rebirth in Turkey after long period of decline; lightning-fast sport features horsemen wielding wooden spears, which they hurl at their opponents; sport began as training for the widely feared Ottoman cavalry; photo (Istanbul Journal) (M)

headline: AIRLINE MERGER TALKS EXTENDED
abstract: British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines extend exclusivity period of their merger negotiations (S)

headline: MOOG TO ACQUIRE ELECTRIC MOTOR UNIT OF EATON
abstract: Moog Inc acquires Eaton Corp's electric-motor division, Vickers Electronics Systems (S)

headline: Article 2000092592600765224 -- No Title
abstract: CIRCUITS

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots decline of euro against dollar on August 9 as investors seek better returns outside euro region

headline: China´s Internet World Shrinks As Sohu.com Purchases Rival
abstract: SHANGHAI, Sept. 14 — One of China's leading Internet companies announced the purchase of a smaller rival today, setting the stage for what is expected to be a sweeping consolidation of China's fledgling Internet industry.

headline: Online Service, Record Label to Target Music Listeners
abstract: Online Service, Record Label to Target Music Listeners

headline: Nasdaq, Calm at Last?
abstract: Nasdaq composite index rises and falls by daily average of only 1.03 percent in August, down from 2.51 percent in first seven months of year (S)

headline: Philippine Captors Say American Hostage Is On a Hunger Strike
abstract: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines, Sept. 2 — An American man kidnapped by Muslim rebels in the southern Philippines has gone on a hunger strike, the guerrillas said today.

headline: American Commercial Insurance Sector Appears on the Upswing
abstract: Insurance company stocks rise on earnings gains and indications that long-depressed prices for coverage are beginning to rise (M)

headline: Russia Trying To Get Assets Of Top Critic
abstract: Senior Russian official Vladislav Surkov confirms government-controlled company Gazprom seeks to take over Media-Most from Vladimir Gusinsky, government's most outspoken critic, interview; Media-Most has hired foreign auditors in bid to show that company is worth far more than it owes Gazprom, which argues that it should get all of company; journalists and analysts see government trying to assert control over Russia's three biggest television networks; government has also begun talks with Boris A Berezovsky on his 49 percent stake in biggest network, ORT (M)

headline: Phone Workers Fight for Place In Wireless Era
abstract: Phone Workers Fight for Place In Wireless Era** 85,000 telephone workers on East Coast are threatening walkout in struggle that pits old-line labor against New Economy; Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers are in face-off with Verizon Communications, company formed by merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, largely out of fear that company's widespread use of lower paid, nonunion workers in its fast growing businesses, most notably wireless phones, will endanger wages and benefits of unionized workers; stakes are high since Verizon, with 260,000 employees, has far more workers than any other American telecommunications company and is nation's largest wireless company; almost 80 percent of 120,000 workers in its local telephone division are unionized, compared with mere 46 of 32,000 in its wireless division; likely effects of strike on businesses and households from Maine to Virginia and company's efforts to prepare for it discussed (M)

headline: What do drinking milk and 'Survivor' have in common?
abstract: Four maining survivors of CBS program Survivors will don milk mustaches in specially made print ad appearing Aug 23, day final episode of series is broadcast; winning survivor is to appear alone in full page ad on Aug 24 in USA Today, and in newspapers and some weekly magazines over next week or more; Milk Processor Education Program, which represents milk processors, sponsors campaign with Dairy Management; Bozell New York created ads; photo (M)

headline: Sun Names 2 Agencies To Share Its Work
abstract: Sun Microsystems names advertising agencies J Walter Thompson and Tonic 360 to handle its account, with billings estimated at $100 million; bulk of account had been handled by Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Farmland Industries, Kansas City, Mo., to Bernstein-Rein Advertising, Kansas City, Mo., to handle the consolidated account for Farmland Foods pork products, which had been divided between Bernstein-Rein and several smaller agencies. Spending was estimated at $12 million.

headline: A Croat's Killing Prods Action on War Atrocities
abstract: August killing of Milan Levar, Croatia's most outspoken critic of crimes committed by fellow Croats against minority Serbs, has pushed government to act on his charges; he left letter naming four men he said were most likely to order his death, men he had charged with killing dozens of Serbs in Gospic in 1991 and 1992, and 10 men most likely to carry out killing; those arrested include Gen Tihomir Oreskovic, long acccused by Levar of leading killings; map; photos (M)

headline: China Clerics Deny Reports That Churches Are Bullied
abstract: Leaders of China's official Protestant church defend China's policies on religious freedom, holding record 15 million Chinese now worship in approved churches and that persecution of so-called underground Christians is rare, news conference; charge meddling by hostile foreign evangelists has caused many of reported conflicts between Christians and police; news conference is tied to 50th anniversary celebration of movement that directs Protestant affairs in China (M)h

headline: Southeast Asia Losing Ground In New Economy, Report Says
abstract: Association of Southeast Asian Nations releases report warning that despite level of economic recovery, globalization threatens region's competitiveness as exporter and place to invest; report is usually released after annual meeting in July of ASEAN foreign ministers, but it was withheld by mistake; report omits references to doubts about governments' commitment to economic reform, which were included in earlier versions leaked to local reporters; report is certain to provide grist in debate about effects of globalization; graph (M)

headline: NAPSTER USE QUADRUPLED IN 5 MONTHS
abstract: Media Metrix says number of people using Napster music file-sharing application reached 4.9 million US home users in July, compared with 1.1 million in February; graph (S)

headline: COMVERSE TO BUY EXALINK FOR ABOUT $480 MILLION
abstract: Software maker Comverse Technology Inc agrees to pay about $480 million in stock to acquire Exalink Ltd, Israeli company whose hardware and software connect wireless devices to Internet (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises against dollar on speculation that European Central Bank will buy euros again to support the currency; graph; chart (S)

headline: Two Big Online Toy Sellers to Merge Units
abstract: Toys 'R' Us and Amazon.com will merge online toy-sales units, acknowledging that selling toys on Internet is too hard for each of them alone; Toys 'R' Us will become mainly merchandiser; will pay Amazon to use Internet site and to house merchandise in its warehouses; Amazon will become order processor; Toys 'R' Us chief executive John Eyler and Amazon chief executive Jeff Bezos comment; photo (M)

headline: Patents; Early detection of melanoma lesions with a computerized light, vision and sensor system.
abstract: Dr Marek Elbaum of Electro-Optical Sciences and colleagues patent computerized light, vision and sensor system for early detection of skin cancer melanoma; James Sabatier and Kenneth Gilbert patent method of using lasers and sound signals to find land mines, other buried objects; Patrick Ciniello patents method of using lasers projected across bowling lane to let players win added points by timing roll of their balls to keep pace with moving spots of laser light (M)

headline: Teenager Appears at Hacker Trial
abstract: The person who kicked off a huge legal battle involving Hollywood and the Internet is a skinny, 16-year-old Norwegian computer programmer who, with his serious face, wire-rimmed glasses and almost-there mustache, could maybe pass for 17.

headline: ASIAN CABLE NETWORK
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd says that it is in talks with PT Telekomunikasi Indonesia to build undersea phone cable (S)

headline: SWISS WIRELESS BIDS
abstract: Swiss government authorizes all of the 10 companies seeking to bid for third-generation wireless licenses due to be auctioned on Nov 13 (S)

headline: ONLINE AUCTION DEAL IN DOUBT
abstract: QXL PLC, Europe's largest online auctioneer, reconsiders acquisition of Ricardo.de AG, German rival, citing new information it has received about company (S)

headline: A New Political Landscape Could Brighten for Barak
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak, flying home from Camp David summit without accord with Palestinians, faces murkypolitical future; newspaper poll shows he has been strengthened by talks; his parliamentary faction begins maneuvering to kill bill that calls for elections (M)

headline: ISRAEL DROPS PLAN TO SELL AIR RADAR TO CHINA MILITARY
abstract: Israel announces that it has canceled its sale of a sophisticated $250 million airborne radar system to China, a decision timed for second day of Camp David summit meeting and aimed at improving mood in Congress, where heated opposition to deal has threatened aid to Israelis; move is carefully calibrated by Isreali officials so that they would be better poised to receive increased assistance if any peace accord is reached with Palestinians; Pres Clinton welcomes decision; photo (M)

headline: As Brazil's Market Grows, So Does the Free Access Dispute
abstract: Dozens of Internet access providers in Brazil are competing to find best strategy to lure consumers to the Internet; online sales are expected to double this year and again in 2001; Luis Carlos Boucinhas of Globo.com thinks broadband and wireless access are best for his country; Caio Tulio Costa of Universo Online opposes free access, while Nizan Guanaes of iG says that there is no better options for all of Latin America; photos (special section, E-Commerce) (M)

headline: Business; Heaping Helpings of Nostalgia, a Child's Plate of Profit
abstract: Rewards of operating a diner are often more sentimental than financial; owners often underestimate costs of restoring their buildings and overestimate profit margin on low-cost meals; fast-food and family restaurants chains have lured away many diner customers; the dream and more difficult reality are subject of fourth annual Diner-Rama conference at Seaplane Diner in Providence, RI; photo (M)

headline: Peru's Deep-Rooted Spy System Could Outlast Promised Purge by Fujimori
abstract: Experts and diplomats say Peru's powerful National Intelligence Service has so thoroughly penetrated government and society that complete purge would be hard to carry out even if Pres Alberto K Fujimori intends to keep pledge; hold it can be dismantled only if very corrupt elite that controls blackmail and bribes loses power altogether; Canadian Amb Peter Boehm reportedly says intelligence service head Vladimiro Montesinos is out of job and could well leave Peru; Panama says it rejected request by Peruvian Prime Min Federico Salas to grant Montesino asylum (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DOMINION RESOURCES INC., Richmond, Va., a diversified utility holding company, said its telecommunications unit, Dominion Telecom, agreed to pay $41.1 million to use 6,000 miles of fiber optic lines of the Williams Communications Group, Tulsa, Okla., to expand its network in the northeastern United States.

headline: JDS Who? Fast Growth, Farflung Fold And Worries
abstract: JDS Uniphase's acquisition strategy, culminating with an astounding $41 billion deal to buy SDL, causes some misgivings among money managers, analysts and industry consultants; JDS has acquired nine fiber optic component suppliers since Sept 1999, filling out the gaps in its product line, but as a result of those deals, about half of JDS's 17,000 employees are new to the fold, and operations are spread far and wide; this raises questions about how well each new acquisition is being integrated with rest; photo; table; graph (M)

headline: Indonesian Leader to Cede Daily Duties to His No. 2
abstract: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 9 — Battered by a hostile Parliament for his haphazard management style, President Abdurrahman Wahid said today that he would hand over daily government administration to Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri.

headline: Sony Postpones PlayStation2 European Launch Due to Supply Problems
abstract: Sony Postpones PlayStation2 European Launch Due to Supply Problems

headline: U.N. Reform Group Assesses U.S. Candidates
abstract: Independent United Nations watchdog organization, Campaign for United Nations Reform, says Vice Pres Al Gore would give more unqualified support to UN and be more willing to sign international treaties than Gov George W Bush; group had sent questionnaire to both men; Bush said he would never place American troops under UN command and would not pay United States debts to UN until its bureaucracy was reformed and American dues lowered; Gore said US should pay dues 'in full, on time and without condition' but he declined to endorse International Criminal Court, saying its treaty had significant flaws (M)

headline: Cell Phones and Health
abstract: N M Swerdlow letter comments on research on cancer risks associated with cell phones (July 27 articel)

headline: Mixing Mac and Windows
abstract: Dr Murray David Schane letter on Aug 3 article on Microsoft Corp unit that creates MacIntosh software suggests purchasing program called MacDrive 2000 by MediaFour that reads Mac disks in Windows (S)

headline: VICTOR IN MEXICO PLANS TO OVERHAUL LAW ENFORCEMENT
abstract: Mexico's president-elect, Vicente Fox Quesada, pledges to rebuild country's federal law enforcement system and wipe out corruption that has crippled nation for decades; is likely to use executive powers to create a Ministry of Security and Justice, similar to Federal Bureal of Investigation, that would be responsible for all federal police, significantly reducing powers of Interior Ministry and attorney general; says he will meet with Pres Clinton and both major presidential candidates to press proposal to open US-Mexico border to less restricted flow of immigrants; expounds on measures his new government will take to deal with range of Mexico's most persistent and complex problems, including fight against poverty, efforts to stem flow of drugs and unresolved conflict in Chiapas; photo (M)

headline: A Spending Account in Need of a Cure
abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer Money & Medicine column on stagnation of medical savings accounts, created by Congress in 1997; drawing (M)

headline: More Deaths Are Attributed To Faulty Firestone Tires
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says that since Aug 31 it has received complaints of 15 more deaths attributed to Firestone tires on sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, raising to 103 the number of deaths under review (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for BOB WRIGHT; Going Not for the Gold, But for the Cachet
abstract: Excerpts from telephone interview with NBC president Bob Wright, who predicts 2000 Olympic Games will be unqualified programming success; photo (M)

headline: IRAN LEADER BARS A BILL RESTORING FREEDOM OF PRESS
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme religious leader, quashes cherished goal of Pres Mohammad Khatami and reformists by ordering Parliament to scrap bill aimed at restoring free press; takes exceptional action of circumventing normal institutional checks on legislative power; surprise move stuns reformers who had hoped to use newly won strength in Parliament to revive once vigorous liberal press; proposed law to deregulate press was centerpiece of Khatami's package for new Parliament, and was meant to counter conservative crackdown of last six months, when courts closed nearly every reformist newspaper and jailed editors and intellectuals; photo (M)

headline: Disillusioned, Many Hong Kong Voters Shun Elections
abstract: Hong Kong voters turn out in smaller numbers than expected for legislative election on Sept 10; are disillusioned by leaders and system that still heavily favors vested interests (M)

headline: A Sparse Week for New Credit Offerings
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.69 percent and on a six-month bill, 5.94 percent.

headline: NOVELL PROFIT IS UP, BUT NOT SALES
abstract: Novell Inc says earnings in third quarter ended July 31 were $8.6 million, down 82 percent from $49.3 million in year-earlier period; sales fell 17 percent, to $270 million from $326.8 million; graph (S)

headline: Through Northwest Passage in a Month, Ice-Free
abstract: St Roche II, Royal Canadian Mounted Police vessel traverses treacherous Northwest Passage in month, retracing same route by namesake boat 50 years ago, when voyage took 27 months; traversed all of Canada's Arctic without encountering pack ice; ice-free passage is latest evidence that Arctic ice is melting in summer more extensively than usual in trend that scientists attribute to changing winds and rising temperatures; photos; map (M)

headline: Final Approval on Swiss Holocaust Claims
abstract: Federal Judge Edward R Korman gives final approval to $1.25 billion accord to settle suit by Holocaust survivors against Swiss banks that allegedly hoarded assets deposited in World War II (M)

headline: For Health Insurers, a Surprisingly Strong Pulse
abstract: Excerpts from conversation with stock analyst James A Lane on changes and trends in health care insurance industry; photo (M)

headline: HypoVereinsbank Agrees to Buy Bank Austria
abstract: HypoVereinsbank AG, Germany's second-biggest bank, will buy Bank Austria AG for 7.8 billion euros ($7.3 billion) in stock; deal would create Europe's fourth-largest bank (M)

headline: Lord Runcie, Outspoken Anglican Leader, Is Dead at 78
abstract: Robert Runcie, former archbishop of Canterbury who was considered a reform-minded if provocative churchman with outspoken views, dies at age 78; photos (M)

headline: KLM PROFIT UP 23%
abstract: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines says first-quarter profit rose 23 percent, to 43 million euros ($40 million); graph (S)

headline: IVAX GETS TENTATIVE APPROVAL FOR GENERIC CANCER DRUG
abstract: Ivax Corp receives tentative regulatory approval for its generic equivalent of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co's $1.5-billion-a-year cancer drug Taxol (S)

headline: A GOOD MONTH FOR PHILIPPINE AIRLINES
abstract: Philippine Airlines Inc reports record profit of 392.7 million pesos ($8.99 million) in April; president Avelino Zapanta comments (S)

headline: 50 Years Later, Reunions Bring Joy to Koreans
abstract: One hundred Korean families separated for half century hold emotional reunions under watchful gaze of North Korean minders; heart-wrenching scenes take place after North Korean plane lands in South Korea for first time since 1950; photos; plane carries another 100 people north for similar reunions; North Korean leader Kim Jong Il has said he intends to arrange two more gatherings soon in line with his agreement with South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung to move toward gradual reunification (M)

headline: Rich Nations and Some Oil Producers Call for Price Cuts
abstract: Representatives of rich nations meeting in Prague, Czech Republic, claim breakthrough in battle against high oil prices after persuading several oil-producing countries to join them in calling for cheaper crude; Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Russia and United Arab Emirates join Group of 7 industrialized nations and other members of committee that governs International Monetary Fund in condemning current crude oil prices as harmful (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Correction of Data Shows Slightly Higher Inflation  The government said that a software error caused it to slightly underestimate inflation during the first eight months of the year. Revision of the data means somewhat higher payments for recipients of Social Security and other federal benefits.    And while economists said that the error, one-tenth of a percentage point, was not large enough to significantly alter their view of the nation's economy, it was nonetheless in the direction of faster inflation. [Page C6.]

headline: About the Tables
abstract: New York Times has revised its stock market tables, listing prices in dollar and cents rather than in fractions; change is being made as stock markets move toward quoting prices of stocks and options in decimals, beginning with tests next week (S)

headline: Arafat's Allies Say He Stands Taller at Home for Firmness at Talks
abstract: Palestinian officials say they will presss ahead with plans to declare independent state on Sept 13 in wake of failure of Camp David talks to produce accord; hold Yasir Arafat made all concessions possible from Palestinian side before talks; say firm stance he apparently took at talks will boost his standing among Palestinians; blame Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak for impasse; photo (M)

headline: Schedule of Bond Offerings This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a 37-day cash-management bill.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 6.09 percent; a six-month bill was 6.04 percent.

headline: The No. 2 Executive at Oracle Resigns Abruptly
abstract: Raymond Lane, president and chief operating officer of Oracle Corp, abruptly resigns; departure comes days after company's admission that it orchestrated surveillance campaign against archrival, Microsoft Corp, in effort to prove that company was secretly financing groups lobbying in its defense in federal antitrust lawsuit (S)

headline: Bookseller and Yahoo to Announce Pact
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com and Yahoo agree to provide free Internet access to Barnes & Noble customers; deal will also significant bolster Barnesandnoble.com's exposure on the Web by making it most prominent bookseller on the Web; Barnesandnoble.com replaces Amazon.com, which did not renew its three-year marketing pact with Yahoo; photo (M)

headline: Changes Are Made In Public Relations
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies is reorganizing public relations divisions of its Allied Commuinications Group; technology practices of Weber Public Relations Worldwide will be merged with Shandwick International to form Weber Shandwick Worldwide; Larry Weber, chairman and chief executive at Allied Communications, is named to additional post of chief executive at Weber Shandwick; Scott Meyer becomes chairman and Marijean Lauzier beomes president and chief operating officer; Havas Advertising is acquiring 60 percent stake in Hudson Sandler (S)

headline: FRENCH BUILDERS TO MERGE
abstract: French builder Vinci SA agrees to buy rival Groupe GTM SA for 1.8 billion euros ($1.7 billion) in stock in deal that will create world's largest construction company, with 17 billion euros in annual sales; graph (S)

headline: DEUTSCHE TELEKOM EXPECTS HIGH COSTS
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG, which bid $7.6 billion for a license to offer advance wireless services in Germany, acknowledges that its profits will be depressed this year as a result of costs in its mobile telephone business (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY -- Consumer Borrowing -- May    TUESDAY -- None

headline: British Free 7 Hostage Soldiers in Raid in Sierra Leone
abstract: British troops free six British soldiers and one from Sierra Leone in surprise dawn attack on jungle base of West Side Boys, renegade guerrilla gang in Sierra Leone; 25 members of militia are killed and 18, including leader Foday Kallay, are captured and turned over to Sierra Leone government; British serviceman is killed, another seriously wounded and 11 others suffer light injuries in rescue; hostages were part of team of Army trainers in Sierra Leone helping rebuild country's defense forces; photo (M)

headline: Taking the Bumps Out of International Online Shopping
Other Systems Might Provide a U.S. Missile Shield
abstract: In putting off a decision on a national missile defense on Friday, President Clinton said the earliest such a shield could be put in place was 2006 or 2007. But the president made a decision on just one system. What he did not say, and what the debate over that system has obscured, is that a number of lesser- known antimissile weapons might be candidates for the same job.

headline: America Online Launches Mexico Service
abstract: America Online Launches Mexico Service

headline: Labeling Genetically Altered Food Is Thorny Issue
abstract: Discovery of unapproved variety of genetically engineered corn in brand of store-bought taco shells produced by Kraft Foods prompts new calls for labeling of bioengineered foods and is offering foretaste of some practical difficulties involved in such labeling; has raised questions about reliability of testing, degree to which conventional grains and foods can feasibly be kept separate from those that are genetically modified, and even definition of genetically modified food; issues are already confronting European Union, Australia, Japan and other countries that already require labeling or are moving toward it, with different countries, or even different supermarkets in same country, adopting different standards; in US, where about two-thirds of processed food contains ingrediants from genetically modified crops, US Repr Dennis J Kucinich has seized on discovery made by coalition opposed to bioengineered foods and is sponsoring bills requiring labeling and safety testing of such foods; food industry officials comment; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Antitrust Case Is Sent to Appeals Court  The Supreme Court handed a tactical victory to Microsoft when it summarily rejected the government's plea to immediately hear the appeal of its landmark antitrust case and instead returned the proceeding to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.    The decision gives Microsoft greater breathing room to pursue its appeals, relieves the company of any pressure to return to the bargaining table in the near future and, in the absence of a settlement, could prolong a final court judgment by a year or longer. [Page A1.]

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: CHIP MAKER'S PROFIT RISES
abstract: National Semiconductor reports fiscal first-quarter earnings of $144.2 million, compared with $47.1 million a year earlier; sales rise 33 percent, to $640.8 million; graph (S)

headline: DE BEERS SEEKS INDUSTRIAL DIAMONDS
abstract: De Beers offers to buy Ashton Mining, world's largest supplier of industrial-use diamonds, for $306 million (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: COLLABOREX, Fairfax, Va., named Mike Meyer president and chief operating officer. He had been chief executive at Cap Gemini America.    INTERNET CAPITAL GROUP, Wayne, Pa., named Edward H. West chief financial officer, succeeding David D. Gathman, who is leaving. Mr. West had been chief financial officer at Delta Air Lines.

headline: Perils of Summer Travel /Dos and Don'ts for a Happy Holiday : Scams and Land Mines:Avoiding Headaches (and Worse) in Asia
abstract: CHINA—  Traveling in Asia this summer? Correspondents for the International Herald Tribune and The Washington Post surveyed major tourist destinations and came up with a collection of tips on how best to foil a con artist.

headline: Article 2000091491425981515 -- No Title
abstract: STATE OF THE ART

headline: Beijing Journal; For a While, Crime Paid. Then Came This Exhibit.
abstract: City government of Beijing mounts exhibit on evils of bribery, embezzlement and fraud as part of growing national propaganda campaign that officials hope will scare off potential economic criminals and convince an angry and skeptical population that the authorities are battling corruption; among cautionary exhibits are those on an embezzler sentenced to life in prison and a former legislator now on death row for extorting $5 million; many visitors leave the exhibition dissatisfied, for it fails to acknowledge depth to which corruption has infected Communist Party; photo (M)

headline: NORTEL BUYING EQUIPMENT MAKER
abstract: Nortel Networks agrees to buy Sonoma Systems, privately held maker of high-speed data devices, in stock deal valued at $540 million (S)

headline: Where Blood Is as Thick as Money; The Sculleys Forge New Careers Financing Internet Start-Ups
abstract: John Sculley, former chief executive of Apple Computer, and his brothers Arthur and David run small venture capital firm that finances Internet start-ups; Sculley focuses on start-ups like TechSmart, company founded by entrepreneur Dennis M Lynch, and serves as mentor and friend as well as investor; so far, Sculley Brothers has invested in 26 start-ups; four are either profitable or breaking even; three of five companies they backed that have gone public now trade at rock-bottom prices; graph; photos (M)

headline: Mixing Mac and Windows
abstract: Incomo

headline: GERMAN CONFIDENCE WAVERS
abstract: Surprising drop in Germany's most closely watched economic indicator, IFO Institute's monthly survey of business confidence, raises new doubts about Europe's biggest economy and pushes euro to its lowest level against dollar in three months (S)

headline: Until Now, Safety Wasn't One of the Many Problems
abstract: Crash of Air France Concorde is first for supersonic passenger jet after over 30 years of flying, unusually long stretch for any type of commercial plane; jet, has become high-tech orphan; only 20 were built because airlines other than Air France and British Airways refused to buy them; jet is barred from flying regularly to all but handful of airports because of noise and pollution issues; chronology of plane's few safety incidents (M)

headline: Olympic Events for Chiefs: Sunning and Burger Flipping
abstract: If you're a chief executive attending the Olympics, where do you stay? Forget the local Ritz-Carlton. Get yourself a yacht, or better yet, an entire cruise liner and dock it next to Sydney's landmark Opera House. That's what Louis Gerstner of I.B.M. did. Mr. Gerstner is staying on a giant cruise liner that I.B.M. rented for the Olympics; he will play host to dozens of parties and meetings there. As a major sponsor of the Games, I.B.M. is flying about 2,000 employees and clients to Sydney to show off the technology it developed for the Games.

headline: Ugandan Villagers Avoiding Cult Massacre Site
abstract: Residents of Kanungu, Uganda, are avoiding compound where hundreds of members of religious sect, Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God, were murdered in March; circumstances surrounding deaths still remain mystery; death toll put at 780; map; photo (M)

headline: The New Might of Money Funds
abstract: Average stock fund tracked by Bloomberg has risen 5.1 percent so far this year, compared with average bond fund gain of 4.7 percent, which do not experience jarring ups and downs (S)

headline: IRELAND PILOTS WANT MORE MONEY
abstract: Pilots for Aer Lingus demand pay increases that would make their salaries comparable with pilots in other airlines that belong to One World Alliance, of which Aer Lingus is a member; in case of top-earning pilots, who currently make 87,000 Irish pounds ($95,000) a year, demands call for a near doubling, to more than 180,000 pounds (S)

headline: Linux Companies Rise for After Lab Announced
abstract: Linux Companies Rise for After Lab Announced

headline: La Turballe Journal; Oil Washes Away Tourism From Brittany Beaches
abstract: Tar-like oil from breakup of tanker Erika continues to wash onto beaches at La Turballe and elsewhere in Brittany; towns have been caught in a sort of moral quandary for months about whether to speak up and demand that government do something about pollution or to stay mum and avoid publicizing the problem; only people who have houses in La Turballe or prepaid vacations are returning this summer; some of merchants say their business is off by as much as 50 percent; photo; map (M)

headline: Nigerian Leader Seeks Peacemaking Role
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 4 — Fifteen months after restoring democracy to Africa's most populous nation for the second time in 20 years, President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria said today that he was ready to step into a larger role in mediating an end to his continent's debilitating wars, beginning with Congo.

headline: Daimler to Review Chrysler Accounts
abstract: DaimlerChrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler AG will begin review on advertising accounts with billings estimated at $1.2 billion; assignments, divided between DDBO Detroit and True North Communications, may be consolidated at single shop (M)

headline: Mogadishu Journal; Somali Business Thwarted by Too-Free Enterprise
abstract: Business people of wrecked and lawless Mogadishu, Somalia, are begging for government; cite need for law and order and public infrastructure to protect and boost thriving businesses; map; photo (M)

headline: Land O'Lakes Buys Plant
abstract: Land O'Lakes Inc., a farmer-owned food and agricultural cooperative, said today that it had acquired a California cheese plant from the Beatrice Group unit of ConAgra Inc. to add to its mozzarella and cream-cheese businesses. Financial terms were not disclosed. The 70,000-square-foot plant in Gustine  has 169 employees.    Under terms of the sale, Land O'Lakes, which is based in Arden Hills, Minn., will enter into a co-packaging agreement for cream cheese with Beatrice.

headline: Quarterly Profit Falls 22% at Perot Systems
abstract: Perot Systems Corp, computer services company founded by billionaire Ross Perot, says second-quarter profit fell 22 percent to $13.1 million from year-earlier $16.9 million (S)

headline: Earnings Rise At Brazilian Plane Maker
abstract: Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA reports 35 percent gain in second-quarter earnings on 54 percent surge in sales; company earned 112.9 million reais, or $62.6 million at current exchange rates, compared with 83.6 million reais in year-earlier period; sales rose to 1.2 billion reais, or $665.4 million (M)

headline: Web Sites' Merger Signals Consolidation of China's Internet Industry
abstract: Sohu.com will acquire ChinaRen.com in the first major merger within China's Internet industry; other mergers are under discussion among Chinese Internet companies, which are under-financed and losing money; venture capitalists say consolidation is healthy; photo (M)

headline: Anything for Her Boy
abstract: Amazon.com chairman Jeff Bezos uses his mother's wish list for demonstration at PC Expo in New York, to show how easy it is for friends to order gifts online (M)

headline: Icahn Sells Entire General Motors Stake a Month After Purchase
abstract: Billionaire investor Carl C Icahn has sold his stake in General Motor Corp just one month after purchase; Icahn refuses to disclose when he sold his shares or size of his stake, but says it was less than $15 million (M)

headline: CROSSING BORDERS: The Trade in Humans; Europe Tries to Turn a Tide Of Migrants Chasing Dreams
abstract: Article, Crossing Borders: The Trade in Humans, discusses Western Europe's problems with hordes of migrants who are using new land routes from Asia, opened up by collapse of Soviet Union; photos; map; bodies of 58 Chinese aliens who died in locked container now lie, unclaimed, in Dover, once-quiet English port where illegal immigrants like Iraqi Tara Muhammad roam streets; well-organized criminal groups trading in human freight have emerged to coordinate smuggled passages into European countries that are largely closed to legal immigration; more than 365,000 people applied for asylum within European Union last year, compared with only 30,000 in US, which is considered more difficult to get into; British government, responding to criticism of 'phony' asylum-seekers, has cut back on benefits but applicants like Muhammad are still given enough for basic needs (M)

headline: With the Slowdown Ending, Can the Fed Stay Friendly?
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on whether Federal Reserve will be able to maintain current interest rates now that economic slowdown appears to be ending; says signs that growth is again on rise are still limited, but it increasingly appears that Fed's efforts to apply breaks gently have only slowed down the economy a bit, and that momentum is again accelerating; Bob Prince, research director of Bridgewater Associates, believes if Fed wants to fight inflation in 2001, it will have to raise interest rates much higher by next summer; graph (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: New Image Technology Can Drive Shadows Away
abstract: New technology promises to substantially increase dynamic range, gradations of light and dark still and video digital cameras can capture so that details are not washed out by light or concealed by shadows; advance could banish underexposed and overexposed snapshots and have important implications for video surveillance and systems that use images for measurements; technology is combination of software and hardware modifications developed by Columbia University researchers led by Dr Shree K Nayar; photos (M)

headline: ING Agrees to Buy 2 Aetna Units
abstract: ING Group NV will pay $5 billion in cash and will assume $2.7 billion of outstanding debt for Aetna units Aetna Financial Services and Aetna International (S)

headline: A Maker of A.T.M.'s Finds A Niche in Brazil's Needs
abstract: Procomp Industria Electronica is supplying electronic voting booths for Brazil's first automated election on Oct 1 (M)

headline: Arrest of Banker in Graft Case Poses a Test of Bosnia's Resolve
abstract: Arrest of Alija Delimustafic, prominent banker and former government minister, is being watched by foreign officials as test of Bosnian government's resolve to fight corruption; foreign officials say corruption has reached such levels that powerful vested interests of governing parties are major bars to democracy and development; Delimustafic owned BH Banka, which collapsed in 1998 owing foreign embassies and international organizations $15 million (M)

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Online Financial Dreams That Didn't Come True
abstract: FTC is cracking down on get-rich-quick schemes touted on the Internet; agency received 18,600 consumer complaints of Internet fraud in 1999, up from fewer than 1,000 just two years earlier; accusations of online abuse now account for about one-quarter of all fraud complaints; average online-fraud victim lost $580 in 1999; photo (M)

headline: Multinationals Sign U.N. Pact on Rights and Environment
abstract: Some 50 multinational corporations join 12 labor and watchdog groups at United Nations to sign 'global compact' that commits them to support human rights, eliminate child labor, allow free trade unions and avoid polluting environment wherever they do business; Sec Gen Kofi Annan organized session to spur companies that operate across borders to protect workers and environment in places where governments do not or face erosion of support for open trade and investment (M)

headline: After Joining the Board
abstract: Fund for Stockowners Rights chairman Carl Olson letter decries omission of mention of stock owners in July 23 article on desired qualities for corporate directors

headline: Electronic Signatures Given Legal Standing
abstract: Pres Clinton signs bill making electronic signatures legal (S)

headline: Fox Urges Opening of U.S.-Mexican Border to Build New Partnership
abstract: Interview with Mexico's Pres-elect Vicente Fox, who says he will press US to open border to Mexican workers during upcoming visit to US and will begin dialogue on formation of North American common market; photo (M)

headline: Hard Legacy for Japan Sect Leader's Family
abstract: Downfall of Japanese sect Aum Shinrikyo has made social pariahs out of six children of sect's founder, Shoko Asahara, who is charged with masterminding subway attack that killed 12 people and injured 5,000 others; four young women and two boys, aged six to 22, were once idolized within sect, but now conceal their identities, relocate constantly to escape local protests, and are barred by public schools, most recently in Ryugasaki; photo; map; their guardian is former cult member and licensed teacher who provides home schooling (M)

headline: Tire Deaths Are Linked To Rollovers
abstract: Government data show virtually all recent deaths linked to Firestone tires being recalled occurred when sport utility vehicles, most of them Ford Explorers, rolled over after tires failed; Federal regulators say they received more than 750 complaints about failure of tires, involving 62 deaths (M)

headline: U.S. Officials Say Bank of New York Transfers Involved Money in Russian Tax Cases
abstract: American law-enforcement officials say billions of dollars that moved through Bank of New York involved tax evasion by Russian businesses; say they are prepared to help Moscow if Russia wishes to pursue its own cases; they have determined that muc of wrongdoing--tax fraud and kidnapping--appears to have occurred in Russia; inquiry began as one of biggest money-laundering investigations in United States history; inquiry shows that system for moving funds through Bank of New York was used to transfer money to individuals connected with organized crime in Russia; Bank of New York has not been accused of wrongdoing; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 20 article on online home sales

headline: Out on the Road to Burning Man
abstract: Abby Ellin Personal Business column holds counter-cultural values of annual weeklong Burning Man festival in Nevada desert are seeping into mainstream American culture, or vice versa; photo (M)

headline: Bosnian Woman, Describing War Ordeal, Faints in U.S. Court
abstract: Suit against Radovan Karadzic, former leader of Bosnian Serbs, begins in federal court, Manhattan, with Bosnian Muslim woman fainting on stand as she describes her captivity, rape and torture in 1992 during Balkan conflict; lawyers for Karadzic, believed hiding in Bosnia, contest plaintiffs' rights to sue in United States for offenses allegedly committed abroad; suit, filed in 1993, charges he masterminded campaign of genocide, rape and torture (M)

headline: Patents; From behind the wheel of a cab, an immigrant doctor sees a new way to mend blood vessels.
abstract: Dr Pepi Dakov receives patent for tiny connector that he hopes will eliminate need for delicate end-to-end stitching together of blood vessels; William Mazzei receives patent for helmet that patients can wear to protect them thoughout surgery, with mask to guard face; Andrew Menzin and Myles Kobren receive patent for scalpel that might be more effective in preventing injuries to babies delivered by Caesarean section (M)

headline: In a Shoot-'Em-Up, Three's Company
abstract: Peter Olafson column on John Romero's computer game Daikatana; photos (M)

headline: A New Rival to N.T.T. For Japan's Local Callers
abstract: Japan Telecom, one of Japan's country's largest telecommunications companies, plans to offer local phone service, which would put it into direct competition with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (S)

headline: Judge Keeps Texaco Case
abstract: Federal Judge Jed S Rakoff of Manhattan rejects motion filed by lawyers for Ecuadorean Indians requesting that he withdraw from handling their seven-year-old lawsuit against Texaco Inc which accuses Texaco of polluting Indians' Amazon lands; lawyers had cited judge's attendance at expenses-paid seminar at which former Texaco chairman was speaker (S)

headline: Oil Prices Hit New 10-Year High on Fear of Persian Gulf Strife
abstract: Oil prices surge to their highest levels in decade on fears that rising tensions between Iraq and Kuwait would disrupt flow of crude oil from Persian Gulf at time when petroleum supplies around the world are extremely tight; cost of crude for delivery in October increases 96 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $36.88 a barrel at New York Mercantile Exchange; Iraq accuses Kuwait of authorizing oil projects close to their mutual border that would permit Kuwait to tap oil deposits in Iraq; Saddam Hussein warns that 'the superpowers will fasten their grip on oil-producing countries'; reportedly urges fellow members of OPEC to resist such pressure from US and Europe; US Defense Sec William S Cohen warns Iraq not to take 'any kind of aggressive action' against its neighbors; graph (M)

headline: Digital Economy's Demand for Stable Power Strains Utilities
abstract: Nation's electrical power supply system is straining to provide an uninterrupted flow of power at the very steady rate required by today's computerized economy, and technologies and services that address problem are attracting interest of Wall Street; digital economy is also driving up demand for electricity in areas like the Northeast where capacity is already strained in peak summer months; photos; graphs (M)

headline: BALFOUR BEATTY ACQUIRES INTEGRAL TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Balfour Beatty PLC announces having acquired Integral Technologies Inc for approximately $50 million (S)

headline: BASF PROFITS SURGE
abstract: BASF AG, Europe's biggest chemical company, says second-quarter profit quadrupled from year-earlier period, to $407 million; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas falls on expectations that mild weather will reduce need for fuel to generate electricity for air-conditioning; in New York, natural gas falls 5.5 cents, to $3.66 per million BTU's; graphs; charts (S)

headline: While the public's concern over online privacy seems to be pervasive, nuances -- and contradictions -- abound.
abstract: Tim Race column on public's inconsistency in its demand for online privacy; questions why people technically adept enough to use software programs that let them swap media files over Internet are not more concerned that these services give strangers access to their computer hard drives; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Has Underestimated Flight Delays, According to a Study
abstract: Transportation Department's inspector general reports that Federal Aviation Administration and Transportation Department, which track airline delays, have underestimated amount of time lost by passengers by total of 247 years since 1988; reports that major airlines increased their scheduled flight times on hundreds of routes over last decade in order to improve their ontime statistics; as a result, 130 million minutes of extra travel time was tacked on to airline schedules between 1988 and 1999, even before counting delays, which have soared over corresponding period; report was requested last summer by Sen Richard C Shelby, who is chairman of Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation, after country experienced worst airline delays in history; this summer has turned out to be even worse (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL SPECIALTY PRODUCTS HAS HERCULES STAKE
abstract: International Specialty Products Inc, whose bid to take over Dexter Corp was rebuffed in June, says it has 10 percent stake in Hercules Inc, world's largest producer of paper-making chemicals (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Tries to Revive Mideast Peace Talks
abstract: State Department's special peace envoy, Dennis Ross, opens new talks in Jerusalem with Prime Min Ehud Barak in an effort to break an impasse in negotiations for an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement; early signs are that neither side sees much prospect of breaking the impasse over Jerusalem and other issues that developed at Camp David meeting in July (M)

headline: 2 Plead Guilty in Online Securities Fraud
abstract: Arash Aziz-Golshani of Beverly Hills and Hootan Melamed of Pomona, Calif, plead guilty to criminal charges that they engineered Internet stock-fraud scheme involving shell company, NEI Webworld Inc; both men also face expanded charges in related civil case brought by Securities and Exchange Commission, contending that they engaged in similar frauds involving 11 other companies; SEC says Aziz-Golshani manipulated 11 stocks, reaping about $321,000 in gains, while Melamed made less than $2,000 on trades in JustWebit.com and Foodvision.com (S)

headline: A Long Long Trail Is Awinding, Right Across Canada
abstract: Canada prepares to open Trans Canada Trail, new 10,000-mile network that will link Atlantic, Pacific and Arctic Oceans; building of trail, billed as world's longest recreational trail, has become exercise in nation building as thousands have volunteered for relay teams snaking way across nation with water from three oceans for Sept inauguration, near Ottawa; 250,000 Canadians have donated money for trail; map (M)

headline: Agency Is Created For Health Business
abstract: CommonHealth opens Noesis Healthcare Interactions, a new healthcare ad agency, in Morristown, NJ (S)

headline: GAY FINANCIAL SITE TESTS ADS
abstract: Gfn.com, financial Web site aimed at gay men and lesbians, is testing two commercials this week on cable TV systems in New York City and San Francisco (S)

headline: Fuel Supplies Ease in Britain but Protests Spread on Continent
abstract: Britain struggles to recover from paralyzing fuel blockades after weeklong truckers strike that saw 90 percent of filling stations go dry; rushes to replenish stocks for emergency services and public transportation; says it will be at least two eeks before supplies return to normal for ordinary drivers; rebound is swifter in Belgium, where impact was milder; truckers elsewhere in Europe step up pressure for relief from soaring gasoline and diesel prices (M)

headline: Behind the Music: Organs Go Electronic
abstract: Organs that produce their sounds by sending columns of air through pipes are giving way to those that produce their sounds by means of electronic circuits and loundspeakers, such as the newly overhauled organ in Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan; proponents say increasingly sophisticated sampling techniques of digital technology have virtually erased difference in sound between a true organ pipe and its digital impersonator and that any shortcomings are outweighed by savings in money and space; opponents argue that sounds of ersatz organ pipes is sharply inferior and object to what they see as yet another musical sacrifice on the altar of frugality; traditionalists are not hostile to use of microprocessors to make the job of pulling stops simpler during a pipe organ performance; photos (M)

headline: Documents Show Firestone Knew of Rising Warranty Costs
abstract: Internal documents from Bridgestone/Firestone show that officials of company were briefed as early as February about rising warranty costs for tires that company recalled in August; Repr Billy Tauzin, chairman of House Committee Subcommittee on Consumer Protection, says Firestone's safety officials should have been concerned about warranty information; Firestone executive vice president, John Lampe, says tire maker did not perceived rising claims as problem because number of Firestone tires in use had been increasing as company gained market share (M)

headline: Russian Admiral Acknowledges Explosion Inside Sub
abstract: Adm Vyacheslav Popov acknowledges that a terrible internal explosion devastated nuclear submarine Kursk before it sank; Russian Navy finally docks a rescue vehicle to the spine of the wrecked submarine after many unsuccessful attempts; rescuers find the deck area around a rear escape hatch so deformed that they are unable to make a watertight connection and enter the sub; photo; seismic wave analysis; drawing of hatch (M)

headline: Two Executives Leaving Saatchi
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide chairwoman-chief executive Jennifer Laing and vice chairman Tony Dalton will leave at end of November as part of reorganization in light of Publicis Groupe SA's acquisition of ad agency; Julie Bauer, Keith Bunnell, Mike Burns, Tom Lom, Tim Love, Marie McNeely, Mike Popernick and Tod Seisser are appointed vice presidents and managing partners (S)

headline: Objection to Time Warner-EMI Deal, but Europeans Favor Merger with AOL
abstract: FRANKFURT, Sept. 28 — European antitrust regulators plan to block Time Warner's joint venture with the British music conglomerate EMI Group but are close to approving Time Warner's $135 billion merger with America Online, people close to the talks said today.

headline: MERGER CONCESSIONS
abstract: America Online and Time Warner propose concessions to overcome European antitrust objections to their merger (S)

headline: Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply After a Report on Inventories
abstract: Crude oil prices surged past $30 barrel on commodity markets on August 9 after industry report shows US inventories at their lowest levels since 1976; graph (S)

headline: Indonesian Leader to Cede Daily Duties to His No. 2
abstract: Indonesian Pres Abdurrahman Wahid, battered by hostile Parliament for his haphazard management style, says he will hand over daily government administration to Vice Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri (M)

headline: Sites and Events This Week
abstract: Sites and Events This Week

headline: Frantic Russian Effort To Rescue Crew of Sub
abstract: Russian nuclear submarine Kursk plunges to seabed in Barents Sea during naval exercises, possibly after explosion on board, trapping more than 100 crew members 450 feet below surface; officials say vessel is badly damaged; are unsure how many of crew are alive or how long they can survive; Russian navy begins desperate rescue attempt; says odds of saving crew are slim; says submarine carried no nuclear weapons and that nuclear reactors were turned off, calming fears of possible radioactive contamination; Pres Clinton is briefed about accident and offers US help; American experts say vessel, unlike most Russian submarines, was probably not equipped with pressurized escape chambers that could have carried crew to surface; Russia's loss of at least four nuclear submarines from 1960's through 1989, and crippling of others by reactor malfunctions, fires or other problems recalled; photo; maps (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph plots plunge in palladium futures prices on August 3 amid speculatyion that Russia, world's largest producer, will resume exports to Japan; metal for September delivery fell $63.05, or 7.4 percent, to $792.10 an ounce in New York

headline: APLION INTRODUCES PRODUCTS
abstract: Aplion Networks Inc introduces first entrants in line of products meant to give some computer customers higher priority than others for e-mail and Web surfing (S)

headline: ONE BID FOR PHILIPPINE BANK
abstract: Lucio Tan appears likely to take control of Philippine National Bank three months after Philippine government, eager to refute allegations of cronyism, pushed Tan to sell his stake; after auction for government's 30 percent stake in bank, officials say they will probably approve Tan's bid, as he is only participant in its second attempt to sell shares in six weeks; Tan offers to pay 6.27 billion pesos ($140 million)--or 61 percent above current market value--but will not have to come up with money until July 2002; photo (S)

headline: Book Seeks to Indict Anthropologists Who Studied Brazil Indians
abstract: New book about anthropologists who worked with Yanomami, isolated Indians in Amazon Basin, sets off storm in the profession and threatens to undermine confidence in legitimate practices of anthropology; book, Darkness in El Dorado: How Scientists and Journalists Devastated the Amazon, by Patrick Tierney, presents evidence to show that anthropologists in 1968, supported by former Atomic Energy Commission, inoculated Yanomami with measles vaccine and suggests experiment possibly contributed to epidemic of disease, leading to deaths of 'hundreds, perhaps thousands' of people; Dr Napoleon A Chagnon, professor emeritus of anthropology who was involved in measles project, denies book's allegations, calling them part of vendetta against him by critics; claims no Indians that got vaccine died (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Robert L. Friedman; Mutual European Fund
abstract: Carole Gould Investing with ... column profiles Robert L Friedman, manager of $926.7 million Mutual European Fund, which seeks undervalued European companies; notes fund has returned average 21.6 percent a year for three years through June 30, beating average 14.9 percent for all European stock funds; photo (M)

headline: Gore and Running Mate Hail 'Common Ideals'
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Vice President Al Gore warmly introduced his running mate Tuesday in Tennessee, saying Senator Joseph Lieberman, as the first Jew on a U.S. major-party presidential ticket, offered Americans an opportunity "to tear down a mighty wall of division."

headline: American Is Denied Bail
abstract: Russian officials deny bail to Edmond Pope, 53, American businessman held on espionage charges (S)

headline: Cablevision Systems´ Plan for Offering
abstract: By The Associated Press

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Regulators Warn Of More Firestone Tire Ills  Shares of Firestone's parent company, Bridgestone of Japan, have declined to 1,288 yen as the tire maker struggles with a large recall. It received another blow when federal regulators warned of safety problems in Firestone tires sold as replacements for factory-issued tires on sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton Orders Oil Released From Emergency Reserve  President Clinton ordered the release of 30 million barrels of oil from the nation's emergency reserve over the next month, only a day after Vice President Al Gore injected the issue into the presidential campaign. The move could stall or even reverse the surge in home heating oil and gasoline prices. But analysts said that there were no guarantees that consumers would benefit and that the decision did nothing to address the underlying issue of how to bring energy supply into line with demand over the long run. Administration officials said they acted primarily because inventories of heating oil on the East Coast had fallen to worrisomely low levels, raising the risk of shortages should the winter be particularly cold or long. [Page A1.]

headline: Wurlitzer Will Wire Jukeboxes for the Internet
abstract: Wurlitzer Will Jukeboxes for the Internet

headline: Decision on Defense System May Fall to Next President
abstract: Senior advisers to Pres Clinton say they still expect him to make decision before end of summer on whether to proceed with missile defense system, while acknowledging that recent failure of major test makes it far more likely that his successor will ultimately decide fate of project; comments by national security adviser Samuel R Berger and others noted (M)

headline: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
abstract: ''I still believe we had to give him one last chance. He failed to live up to that. That was his decision.''    MYLES BRAND, Indiana University president, who fired Coach Bob Knight yesterday. [D9]

headline: CNN's Chief of Domestic News Expected to Announce Resignation
abstract: Richard N Kaplan is expected to resign as president of US news-gathering operation of CNN, which is planning a major reorganization of its management in view of declining ratings; there are conflicting reports on whether Kaplan is leaving on his own accord or if he has been asked to leave (M)

headline: Contraptions' Hardest Puzzle: How to Stop
abstract: Peter Olafson assesses Sierra computer game Return of the Incredible Machine: Contraptions; photo (M)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD PLANS TO HIRE 2,500 OVER THREE YEARS
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co, No. 2 computer maker, to hire about 2,500 consultants and technicians over next three years (S)

headline: Mixed Blood Makes Balkan Outcasts
abstract: Ethnically mixed families in Kosovo, Serbia, are under threat both in Kosovo and rest of Serbia and are seeking refuge elsewhere; many have found refuge in Sarajevo, Bosnia, and elsewhere in Balkans; are seeking help from UN high commissioner for refugees to emigrate; photos; map (M)

headline: ARCHSTONE IS BUYING BACK SHARES FROM SECURITY CAPITAL
abstract: Security Capital Group agrees to sell 17.5 million shares of Archstone Communities Trust to Archstone for $400 million in cash and notes, reducing its stake; Archstone is third-largest apartment real estate investment trust (S)

headline: 2 African Nations Said to Break U.N. Diamond Embargo
abstract: American and British officials accuse presidents of Liberia and Burkina Faso of taking personal roles in trading arms for diamonds in violation of UN embargo; say Charles Taylor of Liberia and Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso helped Sierra Leone rebels to continue fighting in civil war; US Amb Richard C Holbrooke accuses Taylor of fueling conflict in Sierra Leone for his own benefit; map (M)

headline: Reality Television Strikes a Stark Note in a New Show
abstract: Court TV will push television's popular reality genre to its limits with a new series, Confessions, which features actual videotaped confessions of murderers, rapists and other offenders; some of the more graphic descriptions of the convicts' crimes will be excised, but much will remain; program will have neither a host nor a narrator, and analysis and interpretation of various cases will be offered on network's Web site; Henry Schleiff, chairman and chief executive, says program is in keeping with Court TV's stated mission: to cover all aspects of criminal justice system; photos (M)

headline: Media Talk; Report on Organic Foods Is Challenged
abstract: ABC rebroadcasts 20/20 segment in which correspondent John Stossel says research for ABC News found neither conventional nor organic produce showed pesticide residues, while organic food seems more likely than conventional food to be contaminated by E coli bacteria, even after being informed by Environmental Working Group that scientists identified as having performed tests say they never tested produce for pesticide residue for ABC; ABC says it sent Organic Trade Association results of pesticide tests; group says it did not get results; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; KAZAKHSTAN OIL FIND IS CONFIRMED
abstract: Okioc, foreign oil consortium, discoveres oil in Caspian Sea offshore of Kazakhstan; photo (S)

headline: STEEL MAKER REPORTS LOSS
abstract: Corus Group PLC, Europe's second-largest steel maker, reports unexpected loss in third quarter, hurt by rise in pound and lower demand for carbon steel; company lost 93 million pounds ($135 million) compared with loss of 96 million pounds in year-earlier quarter at British Steel PLC, predecessor to Corus; photo (S)

headline: A Biotechnology Sprout In Arid Market Ground
abstract: Article on spinoffs and mergers in biotechnology field explores reasons why Eden Bioscience, plant biotechnology company in Bothell, Wash, is going public (M)

headline: Coke, Lauding Its Strategy, Says Results Beat Estimates
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says its second-quarter earnings slightly beat analysts' expectations; net income fell to $926 milion from $942 million a year ago; revenue rose 5 percent, to $5.62 billion from $5.33 billion (M)

headline: Airline to End Some Flights
abstract: Continental Airlines will end flights to Santiago (Chile) and Santa Cruz (Bolivia), citing refusal by Peru to let it pick up passengers for those flights in Lima (S)

headline: HARLAND, CHECK PRINTER, TO BUY SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: John H Harland Co, check printer, acquires Concentrex Inc for about $140 million, including debt; Concentrex makes automation software for lending and customer service operations of about 5,000 banks (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: UNIVERSAL FOODS TO SELL YEAST UNIT FOR $125 MILLION
abstract: Universal Foods Corp will sell yeast division to Lesaffre et Compagnie of France for $125 million in cash (S)

headline: Ivory Coast Votes on Charter Bringing Back Civilian Rule
abstract: Citizens of Ivory Coast vote on new constitution intended to restore civilian rule; proposed constitution, drawn up by military rulers, lays out guidelines for elections beginning in September; map (M)

headline: Alteon Plans to Offer New System for Net
abstract: Alteon Websystems plans to offer new technology that is designed to enable companies conducting electronic commerce to build the efficiency and speed of their transactions; graph (M)

headline: 2 Sides in UAL Dispute Talk to Senator
abstract: James E Goodwin, chairman of United Airlines, and Dick Rubinsky, leader of pilots union meet with Sen Richard Durbin, who is pushing for resolution of labor dispute that has forced thousands of flight cancellations (S)

headline: REPORT DIMS HOPE FOR AIDS THERAPY TO PROTECT BABIES
abstract: United Nations-sponsored study finds that while a simple drug regimen can stop many mothers with HIV from infecting their children during pregnancy and childbirth, the protection does not last for as long as experts had hoped and that the therapy appears to leave children vulnerable to infection from breast milk; finding safe alternatives to breast-feeding is daunting challenge in Africa, where overwhelming majority of women breast-feed their infants for long periods; findings are certain to renew often bitter controversy over breast-feeding (M)

headline: Text of the Declaration
abstract: UNITED NATIONS -- Text of the declaration being adopted by the U.N. General Assembly at the Millennium Summit:

headline: G.M. to Double Stake in Suzuki Motors
abstract: General Motors will spend $653 million to double its stake in Suzuki Motor Corp to increase its share of fast-growing auto market in Asia-Pacific region; GM's chairman, John F Smith Jr, will become first non-Japanese member of Suzuki's board; in Sept 2001, two companies will start building jointly developed small car called YGM-1 at Suzuki's Kosai plant in Shizuoka, Japan (S)

headline: DAIMLERCHRYSLER TO LAY OFF 3,745 AT TRUCK UNIT
abstract: DaimlerChrysler To Lay Off 3,745

headline: Bull Market Multiplier: A Little Revenue Went a Long Way
abstract: Floyd Norris article says bull market increases rewards to be gained from creative accounting; cites case of Unify Corp, whose reported revenue for past fiscal year was overstated; graph (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: CATERPILLAR INC., -- Peoria, Ill., bought out the remaining 50 percent of its joint venture with Dale Elphinstone Property Ltd. of Australia, a producer of mining equipment. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.    TICKETS.COM INC., -- Costa Mesa, Calif., an online ticket provider, said it would cut 220 jobs and reorganize its operations into two business units.

headline: CONEXANT TO ACQUIRE 2 CONCERNS FOR ABOUT $285 MILLION
abstract: Conexant Systems Inc, maker of computer chips for communications equipment, agrees to buy NetPlane Systems for 2.7 million shares, valued at $132 million, and Novanet Semiconductor for 2.4 million shares, valued at $117.5 million; Conexant wants to speed data on optical networks (S)

headline: From Theory to Practice; Capturing Every Moment of That Saturday Soccer Match
abstract: Henry Fountain article on spending a weekend making a short video of a youth soccer match, using Apple iMac DV video editing software; says making a movie is a fine idea in theory, but one that would take time from things he would rather do; photo (M)

headline: A Dwindling Faith In Deregulation; New Ways to Harness Electricity
abstract: Prices have been far more volatile than expected in deregulated electricity markets, at times jumping to extraordinary levels during shortages; deregulation has faltered as surging consumer demand outstrips supply of electricity, and regulators and utilities scramble to cope with successive summers of price volatility and power failures; more than a year ago, wholesale price of electricity charged by power plants in Midwest surged to $6,000 a megawatt-hour, compared with average costs of $21 and $22 for same amount of power; Con Edison customers in New York paid 43 percent more for electricity this June than last year; prices have spiked elsewhere as well; how Pennsylvania successsfully handled deregulation noted; situations in Wisconsin, Chicago, Texas, Southern California and New York discussed; graph; charts; photos (M)

headline: Campaign to Use E-Mail To Promote Youth Vote
abstract: Rock the Vote plans to work with several large media partners to use e-mail messages to encourage voters ages 18 to 24 to vote; media taking part include ABC, Alta Vista, MTV and Sony Corp's Sony.com Web site (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Delays Punitive Duties On European Luxury Goods  President Clinton has delayed punitive duties on European luxury goods, including Scottish cashmere, British shortbread and Italian pecorino cheese, because Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has shown ''unprecedented'' support for the American position on two trade disputes, administration officials said.

headline: NEW WINDOWS VERSION RELEASED
abstract: Microsoft Corp begins selling new Windows operating system for consumers called Windows Millennium Edition, or Windows Me; new operating system replaces Windows 98 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Heating oil falls on report that US supplies rose for a fifth week; in New York, heating oil for October delivery falls 3.61 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $1.0107 a gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph plots decline in July corn futures by nearly 4 percent, to $1.875 per bushel

headline: CHINESE PHONE PROFITS
abstract: China Unicom Ltd says earnings fell 37 percent, to 171 million yuan ($20 million), in first half; photo (S)

headline: Bosnia Defends Its Efforts Against Corruption
abstract: Bosnian government bridles at US report that crime and corruption are blocking success of Dayton peace accord; does not deny problems, but insists that government itself is pursuing investigations of local government corruption and tackling smuggling (M)

headline: Paper Seen as Villain in Abuse Accusations Against Rabbi
abstract: Jewish Week, largest Jewish newspaper in America, is criticized by some of its readers for publishing an article by Gary Rosenblatt, its editor and publisher, extensively documenting accusations that Rabbi Baruch Lanner of Paramus, NJ, abused teenagers in his charge emotionally, sexually and physically and that Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations shielded him for decades; other Jewish newspapers are put in the same sort of bind when they the publish article that might cause dissension or embarrassment within the Jewish community; photos (M)

headline: Suppose Cinderella Doesn't Want to Marry the Prince?
abstract: Fairy tales are retold on Web site in way that allows reader to pick multiple viewpoints for each story (S)

headline: Starbucks in European Venture Deal
abstract: Switzerland's Bon Appetit Group AG forms joint venture with Starbucks Corp to open first Starbucks store in Continental Europe; first store opening is planned for Zurich in 2001; Starbucks wants to add 500 outlets in Europe by 2003 (S)

headline: BARNESANDNOBLE.COM LOSSES WIDEN
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com says its second-quarter loss more than doubled, to $45.4 million, from $22 million a year ago; says spending on new products and services might result in wider-than-expected loss for year (S)

headline: Officials Say Skeptical U.S. Plans to Work With Fujimori
abstract: Top Clinton administration officials say they will work with Pres Alberto K Fujimori while continuing to press for reform in Peru; they perviously criticized Fujimori's re-election and campaign for gross irregularities; critics in Congress and human rights groups say apparent softening of American stance sets troubling precedent; administration officials attribute their shift to several factors: that Peru is best-performing ally in fight against illegal drug trade, that key Latin American governments oppose tougher action against Peru, that Fujimori has ample financial reserves, which would make sanctions less effective, and that leader of Peru's opposition, Alejandro Toledo, is seen as too weak and inexperienced to lead drive to restore democracy in Peru (M)

headline: 15 Are Accused Of Inside Trades
abstract: Susi Belli, former manager of Luxottica Group of Italy, and 14 other people and companies are accused of trading on inside information in company's 1995 acquisition of US Shoe Corp; Securities and Exchange Commission sees more than $1 million in refunds and interest from defendants as well as unspecified fines; Patrick J Rooney, former chairman of brokerage firm Rooney Pace & Co, now defunct, agrees to pay $1 million to settle civil fraud charges (S)

headline: 30-Year Issue In Biggest Fall In Six Weeks
abstract: 30-year Treasury bond has biggest one-day drop in six weeks as stocks rise; yield is 5.72 percent; graph (S)

headline: Rise in Customers and Prices Lifts Cigna's Profits by 11%
abstract: Cigna Corp says second-quarter profit rose 11 percent to $279 million, compared with year earlier $251 million, beating expectations (M)

headline: Russians Point To a Collision In Sub Sinking
abstract: Russian officials say that 'irrefutable data' point to collision as cause of catastrophic damage to hull of Russian submarine Kursk but ship or object involved in collision has not been identified; Russian teams make several more unsuccessful rescue efforts even though there have been no signs of life for two days from the 118 crewmembers who went down with submarine; diagram of submarine (M)

headline: Views of Nature Before Darwin Jumped Into the Debate
abstract: Web site called Romantic Natural History examines the way artists, writers and scientists viewed nature in the century before Charles Darwin; is maintained by Dr Ashton Nichols; photo (S)

headline: NEW LOWER-COST PALM
abstract: Palm Inc releases its fall lineup of new hand-held computers, including its lowest-priced version to date, priced at $149 (S)

headline: Choosing Quick Hits Over the Card Catalog
abstract: Growing number of students prefer chaos of the Internet to do research to drudgery of the library; some educators fear that point-and-click research can lead to lazy student habits and ineffective searches; photo (M)

headline: Dow Declines on Oil Worries; Nasdaq Has Technology Rally
abstract: Nasdaq composite index isup 31.80 points, or 0.8 percent, to 3,897.44; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 8.56 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,451.34, and Dow Jones industrial average falls 101.37 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,687.92; graph; chart (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Market messes happen. And inefficiencies have consequences.
abstract: Jeff Madrick (Economic Scene) examines efficient-market's hypothesis, which in 1970's was article of near-religious faith among economists but is being questioned by many who now say financial markets do not appear all that efficient after all; discusses findings by Harvard Prof Andrei Shleifer in book Inefficient Markets; hypothesis holds financial markets process all new information about securities so efficiently that no one can get consistent advantage over other investors; photo (M)

headline: Bertelsmann to Buy Struggling Online Music Retailer
abstract: Bertelsmann AG will buy CDNow Inc, struggling online music retailer, for $117 million in cash; deal will give Bertelsmann recognized brand in online music sales as it tries to expand its electronic commerce business (M)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD SHARES DROP
abstract: Shares of Hewlett-Packard fall 11 percent after analysts say fiscal third-quarter sales growth in number 2 computer maker's server division fell short of expectations; graph (S)

headline: Castro Says He Will Press Effort to Change U.S. Policy
abstract: Fidel Castro vows to press campaign to change American policy on Cuba, but suggests he does expect immediate success with either of candidates to succeed Pres Clinton; message is read at first rally since return of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez, subject of custody battle between father and Miami relatives; photo of rally protesting US embargo; map (M)

headline: A Gap in Analysts' Coverage
abstract: Paine Webber removes Gap Inc from its highlighted stocks list after shares fall $3.19, to $22.38 and end week at $23.50 (S)

headline: G.I.'s to Be Sent to Train Africans for Sierra Leone
abstract: In a shift of policy, the Clinton administration plans to send hundreds of American soldiers to Nigeria this month to train and equip West African battalions that will then be dispatched to Sierra Leone to bolster beleaguered government troops and United Nations peacekeepers there.    A senior administration official said the United States had ''gone through an agonizing reappraisal'' of its policy toward Sierra Leone, where guerrillas of the Revolutionary United Front -- notorious for chopping off the limbs of civilian victims -- are waging war against government forces and in May kidnapped hundreds of United Nations troops.

headline: KANEB TO BUY SHORE TERMINALS FOR $160 MILLION
abstract: Kaneb Pipe Line Partners LP, transporter of fuels refined from petroleum, agrees to acquire Shore Terminals LLC for $160.75 million in cash and shares of partnership to expand its West Coast terminal business (S)

headline: CGNU FORMS VENTURE
abstract: Britain's CGNU PLC agrees to pay about $900 million to buy 50 percent of two units of Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC: Royal Scottish Assurance PLC and National Westminster Life Assurance Ltd; photo (S)
